PREFACE 
    This Code constitutes a complete recodification of the general and permanent ordinances of the City of Whiting, Indiana. 
    Source materials used in the preparation of the Code were the 1979 Code, as supplemented through Ord. No. 1428, 1990, and ordinances subsequently adopted by the common council. The source of each section is included in the history note appearing in parentheses at the end thereof. The absence of such a note indicates that the section is new and was adopted for the first time with the adoption of the Code. By use of the comparative tables appearing in the back of this Code, the reader can locate any section of the 1979 Code, as supplemented, and any subsequent ordinance included herein. 
    The chapters of the Code have been conveniently arranged in alphabetical order, and the various sections within each chapter have been catchlined to facilitate usage. Notes which tie related sections of the Code together and which refer to relevant state law have been included. A table listing the state law citations and setting forth their location within the Code is included at the back of this Code. 
Chapter and Section Numbering System 
    The chapter and section numbering system used in this Code is the same system used in many state and local government codes. Each section number consists of two parts separated by a dash. The figure before the dash refers to the chapter number, and the figure after the dash refers to the position of the section within the chapter. Thus, the second section of chapter 1 is numbered 1-2, and the first section of chapter 6 is 6-1. Under this system, each section is identified with its chapter, and at the same time new sections can be inserted in their proper place by using the decimal system for amendments. For example, if new material consisting of one section that would logically come between sections 6-1 and 6-2 is desired to be added, such new section would be numbered 6-1.5. New articles and new divisions may be included in the same way or, in the case of articles, may be placed at the end of the chapter embracing the subject, and, in the case of divisions, may be placed at the end of the article embracing the subject. The next successive number shall be assigned to the new article or division. New chapters may be included in the same manner. If the new material is to be included between chapters 12 and 13, it will be designated as chapter 12.5. Care should be taken that the alphabetical arrangement of chapters is maintained when including new chapters. 
Page Numbering System 
    The page numbering system used in this Code is a prefix system. The letters to the left of the colon are an abbreviation which represents a certain portion of the volume. The number to the right of the colon represents the number of the page in that portion. In the case of a chapter of the Code, the number to the left of the colon indicates the number of the chapter. In the case of an appendix to the Code, the letter immediately to the left of the colon indicates the letter of the appendix. The following are typical parts of codes of ordinances, which may or may not appear in this Code at this time, and their corresponding prefixes: 
CODE CD1:1 CODE APPENDIX CDA:1 CODE COMPARATIVE TABLES CCT:1 STATE LAW REFERENCE TABLE SLT:1 CODE INDEX CDi:1  
Index 
    The index has been prepared with the greatest of care. Each particular item has been placed under several headings, some of which are couched in lay phraseology, others in legal terminology, and still others in language generally used by local government officials and employees. There are numerous cross references within the index itself which stand as guideposts to direct the user to the particular item in which the user is interested. 
Looseleaf Supplements 
    A special feature of this publication is the looseleaf system of binding and supplemental servicing of the publication. With this system, the publication will be kept up-to-date. Subsequent amendatory legislation will be properly edited, and the affected page or pages will be reprinted. These new pages will be distributed to holders of copies of the publication, with instructions for the manner of inserting the new pages and deleting the obsolete pages. 
    Keeping this publication up-to-date at all times will depend largely upon the holder of the publication. As revised pages are received, it will then become the responsibility of the holder to have the amendments inserted according to the attached instructions. It is strongly recommended by the publisher that all such amendments be inserted immediately upon receipt to avoid misplacing them and, in addition, that all deleted pages be saved and filed for historical reference purposes. 
Acknowledgments 
    This publication was under the direct supervision of Milton E. Lefkoff, Supervising Editor, of the Municipal Code Corporation, Tallahassee, Florida. Credit is gratefully given to the other members of the publisher's staff for their sincere interest and able assistance throughout the project. 
    The publisher is most grateful to Mr. Donald Gray, City Attorney, Ms. Margaret Drewniak, City Clerk-Treasurer, Honorable Rudy Wunder, Councilperson, and Honorable Bill Ciesar, Jr., Councilperson, for their cooperation and assistance during the progress of the work on this publication. It is hoped that their efforts and those of the publisher have resulted in a Code of Ordinances which will make the active law of the city readily accessible to all citizens and which will be a valuable tool in the day-to-day administration of the city's affairs. 
MUNICIPAL CODE CORPORATION 
Tallahassee, Florida  
ADOPTING ORDINANCE 

ORDINANCE NO. CC 95-1524 
An Ordinance Adopting and Enacting a New Code for the City of Whiting, Indiana; Providing for the Repeal of Certain Ordinances Not Included Therein; Providing a Penalty for the Violation Thereof; Providing for the Manner of Amending Such Code; and Providing When Such Code and This Ordinance Shall Become Effective. 
Be It Ordained by the Common Council of the City of Whiting: 
    Section 1. The Code entitled "Code of Ordinances, City of Whiting, Indiana" published by Municipal Code Corporation consisting of Chapters 1 through 18, each inclusive, is adopted. 
    Section 2. All ordinances of a general and permanent nature enacted on or before December 7, 1994, and not included in the Code or recognized and continued in force by reference therein, are repealed. 
    Section 3. The repeal provided for in section 2 hereof shall not be construed to revive any ordinance or part thereof that has been repealed by a subsequent ordinance that is repealed by this ordinance. 
    Section 4. Unless another penalty is expressly provided, every person convicted of a violation of any provision of the Code or any ordinance, rule or regulation adopted or issued in pursuance thereof, shall be punished by a fine not exceeding $2,500.00. Each act of violation and each day upon which any such violation shall occur shall constitute a separate offense. The penalty provided by this section, unless another penalty is expressly provided shall apply to the amendment of any Code section whether or not such penalty is reenacted in the amendatory ordinance. In addition to the penalty prescribed above, the city may pursue other remedies such as abatement of nuisances, injunctive relief, and revocation of licenses or permits. 
    Section 5. Additions or amendments to the Code when passed in the form as to indicate the intention of the common council to make the same a part of the Code shall be deemed to be incorporated in the Code, so that reference to the Code includes the additions and amendments. 
    Section 6. Ordinances adopted after December 7, 1994 that amend or refer to ordinances that have been codified in the Code, shall be construed as if they amend or refer to like provisions of the Code. 
    Section 7. This ordinance shall become effective April 6, 1995. 
    Passed and adopted by the common council this 21st day of March, 1995. 
/s/ Robert J. Bercik 
      Mayor   (SEAL) 
ATTEST: 
/s/ Margaret Drewniak 
      Clerk-Treasurer   Certificate of Adoption

Chapter 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS 
  

Sec. 1-1. - How Code designated and cited. 
    The ordinances embraced in the following chapters and sections shall constitute and be designated as the Code of Ordinances, City of Whiting, Indiana, and may be so cited. 
State Law reference- Codification of ordinances, IC 36-1-5-1 et seq. 
Sec. 1-2. - Rules of construction and definitions. 
    In the construction of this Code, and of all ordinances, the rules of construction and definitions set out in this section shall be observed, unless such construction would be inconsistent with the manifest intent of the common council. The rules of construction and definitions set out herein shall not be applied to any section of this Code which shall contain any express provisions excluding such construction, or where the subject matter or context of such section may be repugnant thereto. 
    Generally. All general provisions, terms, phrases and expressions contained in this Code shall be liberally construed in order that the true intent and meaning of the common council may be fully carried out. In the interpretation and application of any provisions of this Code, they shall be held to be the minimum requirements adopted for the promotion of the public health, safety, comfort, convenience and general welfare. Where any provision of the Code imposes greater restrictions upon the subject matter than another more general provision imposed by the Code or other law, the provision imposing the greater restriction or regulation shall be deemed to be controlling. 
    City. The word "city" shall mean the City of Whiting, Indiana. 
    Code, this code. The terms "Code" or "this Code" shall mean the Code of Ordinances, City of Whiting, Indiana, as designated in section 1-1. 
    Common council, council. Whenever the term "council" or "common council" is used, it shall be construed to mean the common council of the City of Whiting. 
    Computation of time. The time within which any act provided by law is to be done shall be computed by excluding the first day and including the last. If the last day is Sunday, it shall be excluded and the next day shall be included. 
    Corporate limits, city limits. The term "corporate limits" or "city limits" shall mean the legal boundaries of the City of Whiting, except as otherwise provided by law. 
    County. The words "the county" or "this county" shall mean the County of Lake in the State of Indiana. 
    Delegation of authority. Whenever a provision appears requiring the head of a department or some other city officer to do some act or perform some duty, it shall be construed to authorize the head of the department or other officer to designate, delegate and authorize subordinates to perform the required act or perform the duty unless the terms of the provision or section specify otherwise. 
    Gender. A word importing the masculine gender only shall extend and be applied to females and to firms, partnerships and corporations, as well as to males. 
    IC. The letters "IC" refer to the cited provision of the Indiana Code, as now or hereafter amended. 
    Joint authority. All words giving joint authority to three or more persons or officers shall be construed as giving such authority to a majority of such persons or officers. 
    Jurisdiction. Except as specifically provided otherwise, the provisions of the Code shall be interpreted to apply only within the corporate limits. 
    Law. The word "law" shall mean any applicable statute, ordinance, rule or regulation promulgated by the city, or any agency thereof, the state, or any agency thereof, the United States, or any agency thereof, or any body politic and corporate, or agency thereof. 
    May. The word "may" is permissive. 
    Month. The word "month" shall mean a calendar month. 
    Nontechnical and technical words. Words and phrases shall be construed according to the common and approved usage of the language, but technical words and phrases and such others as may have acquired a peculiar and appropriate meaning in law shall be construed and understood according to such meaning. 
    Number. A word importing the singular number only may extend and be applied to several persons and things as well as to one person or thing, and a word importing the plural may extend to the singular. 
    Oath. The word "oath" shall be construed to include any affirmation in all cases in which, by law, an affirmation may be substituted for an oath, and in such cases the words "swear" and "sworn" shall be equivalent to the words "affirm" and "affirmed." 
    Officers, etc. Whenever any officer, department, board or commission is referred to by title, such as "clerk-treasurer," such reference shall be construed as if followed by the words "of the City of Whiting." 
    Or/and. The word "or" may be read "and" and "and" may be read "or", if the sense requires it. 
    Owner. The word "owner," applied to a building or land, shall include any part owner, joint owner, tenant in common, tenant in partnership, joint tenant, or tenant by the entirety of the whole or of a part of such building or land. 
    Person. The word "person" shall extend and be applied to associations, clubs, societies, organizations, firms, companies, partnerships, bodies politic and corporate, or any other group, as well as to natural persons. 
    Personal property. The term "personal property" includes every species of property except real property, as herein described. 
    Preceding, following. The words "preceding" and "following" mean next before and next after, respectively. 
    Property. The word "property" shall include real and personal property. 
    Public place. The term "public place" shall mean any street or highway, sidewalk, park, cemetery, schoolyard or open space adjacent thereto, and any lake or stream. 
    Quorum. The word "quorum" shall mean a majority of the members of a board, commission or committee holding office, unless otherwise specifically provided in this Code. 
    Real property. The term "real property" shall include lands, tenements and hereditaments. 
    Reasonable time, reasonable notice. In all cases where any provision shall require any act to be done in a "reasonable time" or "reasonable notice" to be given to any person, such reasonable time or notice shall be deemed to mean such time only as may be necessary in the prompt execution of such duty or compliance with such notice. 
    Shall. The word "shall" is mandatory. 
    Sidewalk. The word "sidewalk" shall mean any portion of a street between the curbline and the adjacent property line intended for the use of pedestrians, excluding parkways. 
    Signature, subscription. The word "signature" or "subscription" includes a mark when the person cannot write. 
    State. The words "the state" or "this state" shall be construed to mean the State of Indiana. 
    Street. The word "street" shall be construed to embrace streets, avenues, boulevards, roads, alleys, viaducts and all other public highways in the city. 
    Tenant, occupant. The word "tenant" or "occupant," applied to a building or land, shall include any person holding a written or oral lease or who occupies the whole or a part of such building or land, either alone or with others. 
    Tense. Words used in the past or present tense include the future as well as the past and present. 
    Written, in writing. The term "written" or "in writing" shall be construed to include any representation of words, letters or figures, whether by printing or otherwise. 
    Year. The word "year" shall mean a calendar year. 
Sec. 1-3. - Certain ordinances not affected by Code. 
    Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall affect any ordinance: 
(1)  Promising or guaranteeing the payment of money for the city, or authorizing the issuance of any bonds of the city or any evidence of the city's indebtedness, or any contract or obligation assumed by the city; 
(2)  Granting any right or franchise; 
(3)  Dedicating, naming, establishing, locating, relocating, opening, paving, widening, vacating, etc., any street or public way in the city; 
(4)  Making any appropriation; 
(5)  Establishing or prescribing grades in the city; 
(6)  Providing for local improvements and assessing taxes therefor; 
(7)  Dedicating or accepting any plat or subdivision in the city or otherwise relating to subdivisions; 
(8)  Extending or contracting the boundaries of the city; 
(9)  Prescribing the number, classification benefits or compensation of any city officers or employees, not inconsistent herewith; 
(10)  Accepting gifts and dedications of real estate; 
(11)  Accepting, releasing or abandoning easements; 
(12)  Relating to zoning; 
(13)  Relating to improvement location permits; 
(14)  Establishing or amending a comprehensive plan; 
(15)  Establishing or amending a thoroughfare plan; 
(16)  Relating to taxation, not inconsistent with this Code; 
(17)  Creating a specific fund; 
(18)  Which is temporary, although general in effect; 
(19)  Which is special, although permanent in effect; 
(20)  The purpose of which has been accomplished; 
and all such ordinances are hereby recognized as continuing in full force and effect to the same extent as if set out at length in this Code. Such ordinances are on file in the clerk-treasurer's office. 
Sec. 1-4. - Code does not affect prior offenses, rights, etc. 
(a)  Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall affect any offense or act committed or done, or any penalty or forfeiture incurred, or any contract or right established or accruing, before the effective date of this Code. 
(b)  The adoption of this Code shall not be interpreted as authorizing or permitting any use or the continuance of any use of a structure or premises in violation of any ordinance of the city in effect on the date of adoption of this Code. 
Sec. 1-5. - References and notes. 
    Charter references, cross references, state law references and editor's note in this Code are explanatory only and should not be deemed a part of the text of any section. 
Sec. 1-6. - Catchlines of sections, history notes. 
    The catchlines of the several sections of this Code printed in boldface type are intended as mere catchwords to indicate the contents of the sections and shall not be deemed or taken to be titles of such sections, nor as any part of the sections, nor, unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when any of such sections, including the catchlines, are amended or reenacted. 
    The presence of a history note such as "(Ord. No. 480, § 5, 1-3-83)" at the end of any section of this Code shall denote the derivation of the Code section; in addition, the presence of such a history note, or of one similar to it, shall be a declaration and determination by the common council that the section is a restatement or reenactment of a previously enacted ordinance and that each such section shall be deemed reordained by the passage of this Code. 
Sec. 1-7. - Amendments to Code. 
(a)  All ordinances passed subsequent to this Code which amend, repeal or in any way affect this Code may be numbered in accordance with the numbering system of this Code and printed for inclusion herein, or in the case of repealed chapters, sections and subsections or any part thereof, by subsequent ordinances, such repealed portions may be excluded from the Code by omission from reprinted pages affected thereby and the subsequent ordinances as numbered and printed or omitted, in the case of repeal, shall be prima facie evidence of such subsequent ordinances until such time as this Code and subsequent ordinances numbered or omitted are readopted as a new city Code by the common council. 
(b)  Amendments to any of the provisions of this Code may be made by amending such provisions by specific reference to the section number of this Code in the following language: "That section ____________ of the Code of Ordinances, City of Whiting, Indiana, is hereby amended to read as follows:...." The new provisions shall then be set out in full as desired. 
(c)  If a new section not heretofore existing in the Code is to be added, the following language may be used: "That the Code of Ordinances, City of Whiting, Indiana, is hereby amended by adding a section, to be numbered ____________ , which section reads as follows:...." The new section shall then be set out in full as desired. 
State Law reference- Adoption of ordinances, IC 36-4-6-11 et seq. 
Sec. 1-8. - Supplementation of Code. 
(a)  By contract, or by city personnel, supplements to this Code shall be prepared and printed whenever authorized or directed by the common council. A supplement to the Code shall include all substantive permanent and general parts of ordinances adopted during the period covered by the supplement and all changes made thereby in the Code. The pages of a supplement shall be so numbered that they will fit properly into the Code and will, where necessary, replace pages which have become obsolete or partially obsolete, and the new pages shall be so prepared that, when they have been inserted, the Code will be current through the date of the adoption of the latest ordinance included in the supplement. 
(b)  In the preparation of a supplement to this Code, all portions of the Code which have been repealed shall be excluded from the Code by the omission thereof from reprinted pages. 
(c)  When preparing a supplement to this Code, the codifier (meaning the person, agency or organization authorized to prepare the supplement) may make formal, nonsubstantive changes in ordinances and parts of ordinances included in the supplement, insofar as it is necessary to do so to embody them into a unified Code. For example, the codifier may: 
(1)  Organize the ordinance material into appropriate subdivisions; 
(2)  Provide appropriate catchlines, headings and titles for sections and other subdivisions of the Code printed in the supplement, and make changes in such catchlines, headings and titles; 
(3)  Assign appropriate numbers to sections and other subdivisions to be inserted in the Code and, where necessary to accommodate new material, change existing section or other subdivision numbers; 
(4)  Change the words "this ordinance" or words of the same meaning to "this chapter," "this article," "this division," etc., as the case may be, or to "sections ____________ to ____________ " (inserting section numbers to indicate the sections of the Code which embody the substantive sections of the ordinance incorporated into the Code); and 
(5)  Make other nonsubstantive changes necessary to preserve the original meaning of ordinance sections inserted into the Code; but in no case shall the codifier make any change in the meaning or effect of ordinance material included in the supplement or already embodied in the Code. 
Sec. 1-9. - Effect of repeal of ordinances. 
(a)  When any ordinance repealing a former ordinance, clause or provision shall be itself repealed, such repeal shall not be construed to revive such former ordinance, clause or provision unless it shall be therein so expressly provided. 
(b)  The repeal of an ordinance shall not affect any punishment or penalty incurred before the repeal took effect, nor any suit, prosecution or proceeding pending at the time of the repeal, for an offense committed or cause of action arising under the ordinance repealed. 
Sec. 1-10. - Severability of parts of Code. 
    The sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses and phrases of this Code are severable, and if any phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section of this Code or the application thereof to any person or circumstance shall be declared unconstitutional, invalid or unenforceable by the valid judgment or decree of a court of competent jurisdiction, such unconstitutionality, invalidity or unenforceability shall not affect any of the remaining phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs and sections of this Code or other applications thereof. 
Sec. 1-11. - General penalty. 
    Except as otherwise provided by state law, wherever in this Code, or in any ordinance of the city, or rule or regulation promulgated by an officer or agency thereof under the authority invested by law or ordinance, any act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful of an offense, or the doing of any act is required, or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful or an offense, where no specific penalty is provided therefore, the violation of any such provision of the Code, ordinance, rule or regulation is hereby declared to be an offense and shall be punished by a fine not to exceed $2,500.00 for a first offense and a fine not to exceed $7,500.00 for a second or subsequent offense unless the violation is of an ordinance that regulates traffic or parking. In such cases, the fine may not exceed the sum of $2,500.00. 
    Every day a violation of this Code or any such ordinance, rule or regulation shall continue shall constitute a separate offense. In any prosecution based upon this section, it shall be necessary to allege only the first day with respect to which any forfeiture is assessable, and upon conviction, the offender shall be assessed for that day and each day subsequent thereto with respect to which it is proven and found that the person did commit such violation. 
(Ord. No. CC-2006-1752, § 1, 7-5-06) 
State Law reference- Limitations on penalties, IC 36-1-3-8(8)-(10). 
Sec. 1-12. - Offenses punishable under separate provisions. 
    In all cases where the same offenses may be made punishable or may be created by different clauses or sections of the ordinances of the city, the prosecuting officer or city attorney may elect under which to proceed, but not more than one recovery shall be had against the same person for the same offense. 
Chapter 2 - ADMINISTRATION[1] 
Footnotes:

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 2-1. - Purchasing agent. 
    The mayor may delegate the responsibilities associated with the duties of a purchasing agent to any city department head or staff member. It is intended for this individual to have the same authority of a "municipal purchasing agent" as defined by state statute. 
(Code 1979, § 2.42.010; Ord. No. 1270, § 1, 1982; Ord. No. CC-2004-1678, 5-18-04) 
State Law reference- Acquisition, use and disposition of property, IC 36-1-4-6; city departments, IC 36-4-9-4. 
Sec. 2-2. - City attorney; fees for city court cases. 
    In all actions which may be brought for the violation of any of the ordinances of the city, the city attorney shall be allowed the fees fixed by the council. 
(Code 1979, § 2.16.010) 
State Law reference- Legal counsel, IC 36-4-6-24; appointments by mayor, IC 36-4-9-8. 
Sec. 2-3. - Official bonds. 
    The following named city officials shall be bonded in the following amounts:

(Code 1962, § 7-701; Code 1979, § 2.64.010; Ord. No. 1292, § 1, 1983; Ord. No. 1313, § 1, 1984; Ord. No. CC 94-1523, § 1, 12-20-94; Ord. No. CC-95-1533, § 1, 12-19-95) 
State Law reference- Surety bonds of city officers and employees, IC 5-4-1-5.1, 5-4-1-18; bond of judge of city court, IC 33-10.1-3-1.1. 
Sec. 2-4. - Additional compensation of officials. 
(a)  The compensation in addition to the annual salaries otherwise authorized in this Code may be provided by the common council as provided in existing state statutes and city ordinances where deemed necessary. 
(b)  A monthly stipend as approved by the common council shall be paid to the board of public works members and the board of public works clerk which monies shall be appropriated from the civil city general fund. 
(Code 1962, § 7-601; Code 1979, § 2.68.010; Ord. No. 1418, 1989; Ord. No. CC- 2004-1700, 12-28-04) 
State Law reference- Additional compensation, IC 36-4-7-4. 
Sec. 2-5. - City seal on city-owned vehicles. 
    All vehicles owned by the city, excluding the police chief's vehicle, all police detective vehicles, the fire chief's vehicle and the mayor's vehicle shall bear clear identification indicating they are owned by the city. Such identification shall be affixed on the side doors of the vehicle. At a minimum, the identification shall include the words "City of Whiting, Indiana" printed in two inch letters. Nothing in this section shall prevent the head of the department from affixing permanent or temporary identification markings on an excluded vehicle. 
(Code 1979, § 1.05.020; Ord. No. 1361, § 1(part), 1986; Ord. No. CC-2004-1678, 5-18-04) 
Cross reference- Vehicles and traffic, ch. 17. 
Sec. 2-6. - Copying fee. 
    Every city department that maintains public records and has duplicating equipment shall charge any person requesting a copy of a public record, pursuant to IC 5-14-3-8, a fee of $0.10 per page. 
(Code 1979, § 2.90.010; Ord. No. 1307, § 1, 1984; Ord. No. CC-2001-1603, 3-20-01) 
Sec. 2-7. - Blanket bond authorization. 
    That a blanket bond may be obtained to cover the faithful performance of all employees, commission members, and persons acting on behalf of the city or any department thereof, including the city judge and clerk-treasurer which blanket bond shall be for the amounts designated in section 2-3. 
(Ord. No. CC 94-1523, § 2, 12-20-94) 
Sec. 2-8. - Deferred prosecution program. 
(a)  When any action to enforce an ordinance is brought forth by the city, the city attorney or an attorney appointed by the city attorney prosecution of such city ordinance violations may be deferred as long as the following terms and conditions are met: 
(1)  The defendant in the action agrees to the conditions of a deferral program offered by the attorney for the city; 
(2)  The terms of the agreement are recorded in writing; 
(3)  The agreement must be filed with the city court; 
(b)  The agreement may include any additional provisions deemed appropriate by the attorney for the city, but the provisions set forth under subsection (a)(1) through (3) are the minimal requirements for a differed prosecution agreement. 
(Ord. No. CC-96-1541, §§ 1, 2, 7-16-96; Ord. No. CC-2004-1678, 5-18-04) 
Secs. 2-9-2-30. - Reserved.

DIVISION 2. - COUNCILMANIC DISTRICTS[3] 

Footnotes:

[Sec. 2-41. - Generally.] 
    Pursuant to I.C. 36-4-6-5(j), as amended, the City of Whiting shall be divided into three districts for purposes of conducting elections of city officials, which the council finds to be in compliance with all of the statutory requirements. 
(Ord. No. CC-2012-1884, § 2, 11-20-12) 
Sec. 2-42. - District number one. 
    Councilmanic district number one shall incorporate that portion of the city as defined by the following boundaries: The northwestern most lake boundary of the city, south to the intersection of Ohio Ave. and Atchison Ave.; Atchison Ave. from Ohio Ave. to 119th St. (east, odd numbered side); 119th St. from Atchison Ave. to New York Ave. (north, odd numbered side); New York Ave. from 119th St. to Ohio Ave. (west, even numbered side); Ohio Ave. from New York Ave. to 119th St. (north, odd numbered side); 119th St. from Schrage Ave. to Front St. (north, odd numbered side); Front St. from 119th St. north along the Park road to White Oak Ave. (west side of Front St. and south side of Park Rd.; The intersection of Park Rd. and White Oak Ave. north to the lake boundary (west side). 
(Ord. No. CC-2012-1884, § 2, 11-20-12) 
Sec. 2-43. - District number two. 
    Councilmanic district number two shall incorporate that portion of the city as defined by the following boundaries: 119th St. from Atchison Ave. to New York Ave. (south, even numbered side); New York Ave. from 119th St. to Ohio Ave. (east, odd numbered side); Ohio Ave. from New York Ave. to 119th St. (south, even numbered side); 119th St. from Schrage Ave. to Front St. (south, even numbered side); Front St. from 119th St. north along the Park Road to White Oak Ave. (east side of Front St. and north side of Park Rd.; the intersection of Park Rd. and White Oak Ave. north to the lake boundary (east side); the city lake boundary abutting the far northeast corner of councilmanic district number 1, eastward along the established city boundary to the intersection of Indianapolis Blvd. with the southern most city boundary of the city; Indianapolis Blvd. from the southern most city boundary to the intersection of Indianapolis Blvd. and Schrage Ave. (east, odd numbered side); Schrage Ave. from Indianapolis Blvd. to Steiber St. (east, odd numbered side); Steiber St. from Schrage Ave. to White Oak Ave. (north side); White Oak Ave. from Steiber St. to John St. (east, odd numbered side); John St. from White Oak Ave. to Clark St. (north, odd numbered side); Clark St. from John St. to Indianapolis Blvd. (west side); Indianapolis Blvd. from the Clark St. intersection to 121st St. (west, even numbered side); 121st St. from Indianapolis Blvd. to Atchison Ave. (north, odd numbered side); Atchison Ave. from 121st St. to 119th St. (east, odd numbered side). 
(Ord. No. CC-2012-1884, § 2, 11-20-12)

(Ord. No. CC-2012-1884, § 2, 11-20-12) 
Secs. 2-45-2-55. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - CONDUCT OF MEETINGS 

Sec. 2-56. - Rules. 
    The rules in this division shall be and constitute the rules of order governing the conduct of business and procedure in the common council. 
(Code 1979, § 2.04.010; Ord. No. 1398, § 1, 1989) 
Sec. 2-57. - Time of meeting. 
a.  The Common Council shall hold its first regular meeting in January after its election. 
b.  Subsequent and regular meetings of the Common Council shall be held at 6:30 p.m. on the first and third Tuesdays of each month, except the months of June, July and August, when only one meeting will be required to be held on the first Tuesday of the month. 
c.  If the regular meetings of the Council occur upon a legal holiday, the council shall reschedule or cancel the meeting at its discretion and provide notice thereof pursuant to IC 5-14-1.5-1 et seq. 
d.  In the event that the provisions of IC 36-4-6-7 are further amended, the changes to the state statute shall supersede the provisions of this Ordinance. 
(Ord. No. CC-2007-1786, §§ 1, 2, 12-18-2007) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. CC-2007-1786, § 1, adopted December 18, 2007, repealed § 2-57 in its entirety. Section 2 of said ordinance enacted a new § 2-57 to read as herein set out. Formerly, said section pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Code 1979, § 2.04.020; Ord. No. 1398, § 2, 1989; Ord. No. 1407, § 1, 1989. See the Code Comparative Table-Ordinance Disposition. 
State Law reference- Meetings, IC 36-4-6-7. 
Sec. 2-58. - Order of business. 
    The following shall be the order of business in meetings of the common council: 
(1)  Roll call of councilpersons. 
(2)  Reading, correction and approval of the minutes of the previous meeting. 
(3)  Reading of communications, petitions, memorials and remonstrances. 
(4)  Report of the mayor. 
(5)  Report of standing committees. 
(6)  Report of the city clerk-treasurer. 
(7)  Report of the city attorney. 
(8)  Report of special committees. 
(9)  Unfinished business. 
(10)  Reading of ordinances and resolutions. 
(11)  New business. 
(12)  Open discussion (public). 
(13)  Adjournment. 
(Code 1979, § 2.04.030; Ord. No. 1398, § 3(part), 1989) 
Sec. 2-59. - Rules of procedure. 
(a)  A majority of all the elected members shall constitute a quorum. 
(b)  All citizens, other than the mayor and members of the council, desiring to address the mayor, or the council, collectively or individually, must stand, state their name and address and must be recognized by the mayor before being permitted to speak, and shall be permitted to speak. 
(c)  Written copies of all resolutions and ordinances to be presented for adoption or passage at any meeting of the council must be presented to the mayor, councilpersons, and the clerk-treasurer at least three days in advance of the meeting at which such resolution or ordinance is to be presented for adoption or passage. Receipt of such documents shall be presumed upon showing delivery to the respective residences of each of such persons at least three days in advance of the meeting by one of the following methods: 
(1)  A personal delivery of such documents as shown by a receipt signed by such person or a member of his immediate family acknowledging the reception of such documents. 
(2)  Mailing such documents by either certified mail or registered mail, return receipt requested, to the usual residence of each councilperson with sufficient postage affixed thereon. 
(3)  Personal delivery of such documents by any city officer or official at the usual residence of the councilperson. 
(Code 1979, § 2.04.040; Ord. No. 1398, § 3(part), 1989) 
State Law reference- Quorum, IC 36-4-6-10. 
Sec. 2-60. - Method of voting. 
    The vote upon any motion before the council shall be by "aye" and "no" voice votes, except in the case of a third and final passage of an ordinance, in which case the vote shall be by roll call vote or if an elected member of the council shall request a roll call vote, in which case the vote shall also be by roll call vote. The presiding officer shall have the power to determine the outcome of a voice vote; however, any elected member of the council may challenge that decision and request a roll call vote to verify or overrule the presiding officer's decision. In the event of a tie roll call vote, the presiding officer shall have the power to break the tie vote. 
(Code 1979, § 2.04.050; Ord. No. 1398, § 4, 1989) 
State Law reference- Majority vote and two-thirds vote defined, IC 36-4-6-11. 
Sec. 2-61. - Committees. 
    All duly elected members of the city council shall serve respectively in both capacities as members of the finance and ordinance committees. These committees shall then select a chairman from the membership of their committee. The mayor may select other committees as necessity dictates. Any ordinance referred to committee may be called from committee for action on the council floor by the committee chairman or by a majority vote of the elected members of the common council. 
(Code 1979, § 2.04.060; Ord. No. 1398, § 5, 1989) 
Sec. 2-62. - Resolutions. 
    All resolutions may be passed and adopted upon motion by a majority vote. Such resolutions may be adopted by a title only reading. 
(Code 1979, § 2.04.070; Ord. No. 1398, § 6, 1989) 
Sec. 2-63. - Ordinances. 
(a)  All ordinances shall be passed and adopted in the manner following: 
(1)  Each ordinance shall receive three separate readings by title only prior to its passage. 
(2)  Such ordinance shall be passed from first to second reading by a majority vote of all elected members present. Such ordinance shall be passed from second to third reading and thereby made effective by majority vote of all elected members present. 
(3)  Any council member may request that an ordinance under consideration be read in its entirety as opposed to a title only reading. 
(b)  A two-thirds vote of all the elected members, after unanimous consent of the members present to consider the ordinance, is required to pass an ordinance of the council on the same day or at the same meeting at which it is introduced. This subsection does not apply to a zoning ordinance or amendment to a zoning ordinance that is adopted under IC 36-7. 
(Code 1979, § 2.04.080; Ord. No. 1398, § 7, 1989) 
State Law reference- Passage of ordinance, IC 36-4-6-12 et seq. 
Sec. 2-64. - Presiding officer may limit debate. 
    The presiding officer shall allow meaningful and orderly discussion by any member or citizen and may not arbitrarily place a time limit on that discussion. Debate should be orderly and to the point. The presiding officer shall have the responsibility of conducting the discussions and debates in an orderly manner, and limitations thereon shall be at the discretion of the presiding officer. 
(Code 1979, § 2.04.090; Ord. No. 1398, § 8, 1989) 
State Law reference- Presiding officer, IC 36-4-6-8. 
Sec. 2-65. - Expulsion of members or persons at meetings. 
    The mayor or presiding officer shall maintain order throughout any and all meetings of the common council and shall order the expulsion from the council chamber of any member whom he shall deem disorderly and obstructing the administration of municipal affairs. He shall likewise order the expulsion from the council chamber of any other person who in any manner interferes with the conduct of the business before the common council. 
(Code 1979, § 2.04.100; Ord. No. 1398, § 9, 1989) 
Sec. 2-66. - Reports of committees. 
    All standing council committees shall give reports at regular meetings of the common council. Each committee report shall be given by that committee's chairman or his designated representative. 
(Code 1979, § 2.04.110; Ord. No. 1398, § 10, 1989) 
Sec. 2-67. - City clerk-treasurer report. 
    The city clerk-treasurer shall submit such reports to the common council as may be requested by the common council for its information and advice. 
(Code 1979, § 2.04.120; Ord. No. 1398, § 11, 1989) 
State Law reference- City clerk, IC 36-4-6-9. 
Sec. 2-68. - Ordinances, resolutions filed with city clerk-treasurer. 
    All ordinances and resolutions shall be filed with the city clerk-treasurer in duplicate, the original of which shall not be taken from the office of the clerk-treasurer. 
(Code 1979, § 2.04.130; Ord. No. 1398, § 12, 1989) 
Sec. 2-69. - Misconduct of city official; impeachment. 
    All charges of misconduct against any city official or employee shall be reduced to writing and sworn to by the complainant, who shall file such complaint with the city clerk-treasurer. The clerk-treasurer shall file such complaint with the mayor, who shall appoint a committee to investigate the charges and who shall report back in writing their findings signed by each member of the committee. The report of such committee shall then be read before the common council for its approval or rejection. If the findings of such committee is approved by the common council against an officer or employee of the city, the council shall then proceed to vote on the punishment which it may deem sufficient for the misconduct complained of, but in no event shall the punishment exceed removal from office. Provided, however, that such investigating committee shall give notice to the complainant and to the officer or employee complained of at the time and place, when and where it will meet to hear evidence in the cause. And provided further, that any officer or employee so complained of and against whom the investigating committee shall have found may petition the common council for a hearing before the common council as a whole, which petition shall be granted as a matter of right without any action upon the part of the common council. Thereupon, the common council shall fix a time and place, where and when it will hear the complainant and the officer or employee complained against, and shall at such time and place make its finding and assess the punishment as hereinbefore provided. The finding and punishment assessed by the common council shall be final and conclusive against all officers and employees of the city. 
(Code 1979, § 2.04.140; Ord. No. 1398, § 13, 1989) 
State Law reference- Expulsion of members, IC 36-4-6-6. 
Sec. 2-70. - Manner of roll call votes. 
    Whenever a roll call vote is called for upon any motion, resolution, or ordinance, each member shall, when his name is called on the roll, vote either in the affirmative or negative. If any member of the common council fails, refuses, or abstains on a vote or leaves the council chamber so as to avoid voting on the motion, resolution or ordinance, the clerk-treasurer shall record the vote of such member as being with the majority vote. 
(Code 1979, § 2.04.150; Ord. No. 1398, § 14, 1989) 
Sec. 2-71. - Special council meeting. 
    A special meeting of the common council may be called by the mayor or upon the call of a majority of the elected members of the common council. A record shall be kept of such special meeting, and such record must show a quorum present and must record the events and actions which occur at such special meetings. The record shall be read, approved or corrected and approved as corrected at the next regular meeting of the common council. Items to be considered by the common council at such special meetings should be determined prior to the meeting. However, upon suspension of the rules by the required two-thirds vote, the common council may consider any item at such special meetings. 
(Code 1979, § 2.04.160; Ord. No. 1398, § 15, 1989) 
State Law reference- Meetings, IC 36-4-6-7. 
Sec. 2-72. - Robert's Rules of Order adopted. 
    Part One of Robert's Rules of Order, such as is not in conflict with any of the rules in this division, is hereby made a part hereof and shall govern the deliberations of the common council. 
(Code 1979, § 2.04.170; Ord. No. 1398, § 16, 1989) 
Sec. 2-73. - Attendance at meetings. 
    It shall be the duty of the police chief, the fire chief, the parks superintendent, the city clerk-treasurer, the street commissioner, the water department superintendent, the city engineer or engineer administrator, the building commissioner, the administrative aide, the community development director and the city attorney or their respective representatives to be present at each regular meeting of the common council. The police chief, the fire chief, the water superintendent and the building commissioner shall submit a written report for their respective offices on a monthly basis. 
(Code 1979, § 2.04.180; Ord. No. 1398, § 17, 1989; Ord. No. CC-2004-1678, 5-18-04) 
Sec. 2-74. - Council member to introduce ordinances. 
    Ordinances shall be introduced only by members of the council then present, except such ordinances as may be presented to the council upon written recommendation of some committee of the council. 
(Code 1979, § 2.04.190; Ord. No. 1398, § 18, 1989) 
Sec. 2-75. - Tabling of ordinances and resolutions. 
    Any member upon motion affirmed by a majority of members present may table an ordinance or resolution from further consideration. Once tabled, an ordinance or resolution can only be brought up for reconsideration by a two-thirds vote of the elected members present. 
(Code 1979, § 2.04.200; Ord. No. 1398, § 19, 1989) 
Sec. 2-76. - Amendment of rules. 
    The rules in this division may be amended or altered or new rules may be adopted by a majority of all the members elected, by ordinance, adopted at any regular meeting of the council. 
(Code 1979, § 2.04.210; Ord. No. 1398, § 20, 1989) 
Sec. 2-77. - Suspension of rules. 
    The rules in this division or any of them may be temporarily suspended at any meeting of the council by a two-thirds vote of the elected members present. 
(Code 1979, § 2.04.220; Ord. No. 1398, § 21, 1989) 
Secs. 2-78, 2-79 - Reserved.

ARTICLE III. - CLERK-TREASURER[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Clerk-treasurer, IC 36-4-10-2. 

Sec. 2-101. - Employees under jurisdiction of clerk-treasurer's office. 
    The clerk-treasurer is authorized to employ and have under the jurisdiction of the office of the clerk-treasurer and the following employees: 
(1)  Chief deputy. 
(2)  Clerk of the city court. 
(3)  Clerk for the city's municipal water department, to be paid out of water department revenues. 
(4)  Clerk to work in the community service center, to be responsible for the receipt of all income, moneys, emoluments, gifts, rents which shall be delivered to the clerk-treasurer for daily deposit, for account of the city as required by state law. 
(5)  Such other full or parttime employees as may be necessary to carry out the duties of the clerk-treasurer out of moneys appropriated from time to time for that purpose by the common council. 
(Ord. No. 1163, § 1, 1975; Code 1979, § 2.08.020) 
Sec. 2-102. - City seal. 
    The device on file in the office of the clerk-treasurer is described as the official city seal and such seal shall be affixed to all instruments or writings of the city as authentication and the clerk of the common council is ordered to have a die cast for the making of such seal. 
(Code 1979, § 1.05.010; Ord. No. 1361, § 1(part), 1986) 
Sec. 2-103. - Publication of ordinances-Clerk-treasurer's duties. 
    The city clerk-treasurer is required to cause all ordinances which by law are required to be published, and also all legal notices necessary to be published for and on behalf of the city, such ordinances to be published at the earliest possible opportunity after their passage and when so published, he shall procure and preserve in his office a copy of the paper publishing the same and shall also conserve the affidavit of the printer or publisher of such paper as proof of publication. When the ordinance is recorded in the ordinance book, he shall note, after the record thereof, the name of the paper in which same was published, the dates on which it was published, and the name of the person making the affidavit. 
(Code 1962, § 28-301; Code 1979, § 1.16.010) 
Sec. 2-104. - Same-Affidavit required. 
    No editor, printer or publisher of any newspaper in which has been published any legal notice, ordinance or other matter required by law to be published by the city shall receive any compensation for any publication until an affidavit of such publication has been properly filed in the city clerk-treasurer's office. 
(Code 1962, § 28-302; Code 1979, § 1.16.020) 
Sec. 2-105. - Claim payments in advance of council allowance. 
(a)  Pursuant to IC 36-4-8-14, the common council authorizes the clerk-treasurer to make claim payments in advance of council allowance for the following kinds of expenses: 
(1)  License or permit fees. 
(2)  Insurance premiums. 
(3)  Utility payments or utility connection charges. 
(4)  Bond or coupon payments. 
(5)  Payroll. 
(6)  State, federal, or county taxes. 
(7)  Lease or rental agreements. 
(8)  Expenses that must be paid because of emergency circumstances. 
(9)  Closing costs associated with the sale or acquisition of real property. 
(b)  Each payment of the expenses listed above must be supported by a fully itemized claim and such paid claim shall be added to the register of claims for review and allowance at the next regular or special meeting of the common council. 
(Ord. No. CC 92-1454, 11-17-92; Ord. No. CC-2011-1863, §§ 1, 2, 12-6-11) 
Secs. 2-106-2-125. - Reserved.

ARTICLE V. - POLICE DEPARTMENT[7] 
Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Editor's note- For statutory provisions on public safety, see IC 36-1-3.5-2 et seq. and 36-8-3-1 et seq. 
Cross reference- Enforcement of noise control program, § 8-133. 
State Law reference- Law enforcement officers, IC 5-2; resisting law enforcement, IC 35-44-3-3; police employment policies, IC 36-8-4-1 et seq.; uniforms and equipment, IC 36-8-4-4; police leaves of absence, IC 36-8-5-1 et seq.; police officers' and firefighters' pension and disability fund, IC 36-8-8-1 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-151. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Board of public safety means the board of public works and safety of the city. 
    Pension board means the board of trustees of the policemen's pension fund of the city. 
(Code 1962, § 14-101; Code 1979, § 2.40.010; Ord. No. CC 92-1457, § 2(2.40.010), 12-29-92) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 2-152. - Organization. 
    The police department shall consist of the following officers and sworn members: 
(1)  One police chief. 
(2)  A patrol division with one captain and such number of sworn officers as shall be provided by the board of public works and safety and the common council. 
(3)  A detective bureau with one captain and such number of sworn officers as shall be provided by the board of public works and safety and the common council. 
(4)  A traffic bureau with one traffic captain and such number of sworn officers as shall be provided by the board of public works and safety and the common council. 
(Code 1962, § 14-102; Ord. No. 1083, § 1, 1965; Ord. No. 1169, § 1, 1976; Code 1979, § 2.40.020; Ord. No. CC 92-1457, § 2(2.40.020), 12-29-92; Ord. No. CC-2003-1656, 12-16-03) 
Sec. 2-153. - Police chief; powers and duties. 
    The chief of the police department shall have the exclusive control and charge of the police department, subject to the rules and regulations and orders of the board of public safety, ordinances of the city and statutes of the state. 
(Code 1962, § 14-103; Code 1979, § 2.40.030; Ord. No. CC 92-1457, § 2(2.40.030), 12-29-92) 
Sec. 2-154. - Detective bureau; supervision and duties. 
(a)  The captain of detectives shall be under the direction and supervision of the chief of police and shall be in charge of the detective bureau. The detective bureau shall supervise all matters pertaining to apprehension of wanted persons, investigation of felonies, missing persons, juvenile investigations, narcotics investigations, and criminal records. 
(b)  Detectives shall be under the supervision of the detective captain and shall perform such duties as may be assigned to them from time to time. 
(Code 1962, § 14-104; Ord. No. 1083, § 2, 1965; Code 1979, § 2.40.040; Ord. No. CC 92-1457, § 2(2.40.040), 12-29-92) 
Sec. 2-155. - Traffic division; supervision and duties. 
(a)  The captain of traffic shall be under the direction and supervision of the chief of police. He shall be in charge of the traffic division and act as the traffic engineer, and shall supervise all matters pertaining to motorcycle patrol, accident prevention control, school patrol, parking regulations, enforcement, and traffic records, and he shall assist all divisions whenever called upon. 
(b)  Each motorcycle officer shall be under the direction of the shift supervisor. They are specially charged with the duty of enforcement of all the laws and ordinances relating to traffic and motor vehicles and such other duties as may be assigned from time to time. Each motorcycle officer shall be held accountable for the motorcycle and equipment assigned to him and shall also keep such equipment in as clean and neat condition as reasonably possible. 
(c)  A patrolman of the traffic division shall come under the direction of the shift supervisor. Each patrolman shall perform such duties as are assigned to him from time to time. 
(Code 1962, § 14-105; Code 1979, § 2.40.050; Ord. No. CC 92-1457, § 2(2.40.050), 12-29-92) 
Sec. 2-156. - Patrol division; supervision and duties. 
(a)  The captain of the patrol division shall be under the direction and supervision of the chief of police and shall be in charge of the patrol division. The patrol division shall handle all matters pertaining to foot patrol, cruiser and radio car patrol and park patrol and shall assist all divisions when called upon. 
(b)  A shift lieutenant shall come under the direction of the shift supervisor and shall be in charge of the shift in the absence of the shift supervisor. 
(c)  A uniform sergeant shall come under the direction of the shift supervisor and shall perform the duties as are assigned from time to time. 
(d)  A uniform corporal shall perform the duties assigned from time to time. 
(e)  A uniform patrolman shall perform the duties assigned from time to time. 
(f)  A probationary patrolman shall perform the duties assigned from time to time. 
(Code 1962, § 14-106; Ord. No. 1083, § 3, 1965; Code 1979, § 2.40.060; Ord. No. CC 92-1457, § 2(2.40.060), 12-29-92) 
Sec. 2-157. - Applicants; qualifications and requirements; probationary period. 
(a)  Citizenship. An applicant for a position of any kind for the police department must be a citizen of the United States of America and an elector of the county in which the applicant resides and who can read and write the English language. An applicant must be a high school graduate or have an equivalent education to be determined by examination designated by the board of public safety. 
(b)  Intelligence quotient. An applicant shall have a minimum intelligence quotient as designated by the board of public safety from time to time. 
(c)  Character; fitness. An applicant for a position of any kind for the police department must meet the following qualifications: 
(1)  The applicant must be at least 21 years of age and not more than 35 years of age. The minimum age requirement shall be interpreted to include those applicants who will attain the minimum age requirement within 60 days subsequent to filing an application and the maximum age requirement shall be interpreted to include those applicants that are not older than the indicated age at the time of the appointment. 
(2)  The applicant must meet the physical and mental requirements of the board of public safety and the pension board. 
(3)  The applicant must be of good moral character. 
(d)  Applications. All applications for the police department shall be executed under oath and in triplicate; one copy of the application shall be submitted to the board of trustees of the police pension fund at the time of the application, one copy shall be submitted to the board of public safety, and one copy shall be retained in the files of the police chief. 
(e)  Probation. Every appointment to the police department shall be for a probationary period of one year. If at any time during the probationary period, the conduct or capacity of the probationer is found not to be satisfactory, which fact shall be determined by the board of public safety, upon the recommendation for discharge by the police chief, the probationer shall, without hearing and without right of appeal, be notified in writing by the board of public safety that the applicant will not receive an appointment as a full-time police officer, whereupon employment shall cease; otherwise retention in service after the expiration of the probationary period shall be equivalent to and shall constitute final appointment as a full-time police officer. 
(Code 1962, § 14-107; Code 1979, § 2.40.070; Ord. No. CC 92-1457, § 2(2.40.070), 12-29-92) 
State Law reference- Residence required, IC 36-8-4-2; probationary appointments, IC 36-8-4-12. 
Sec. 2-158. - Dismissals and suspensions. 
(a)  Policemen who have been appointed as full time police officers to the police department may be discharged or suspended without pay, or demoted or reduced in rank or fined for the reasons provided in this section. 
(b)  Any individual who is a full-time police officer in the city may be disciplined by demotion, dismissal, reprimand, forfeiture, or suspension without pay upon either: 
(1)  Conviction in any court of any crime; or 
(2)  A finding and decision of the board of public safety that the officer has been or is guilty of any one or more of the following: 
a.  Neglect of duty. 
b.  A violation of rules, including but not limited to any rules, regulations and departmental orders adopted by the board of public safety or issued by the chief of police. 
c.  Neglect or disobedience of orders. 
d.  Incapacity. 
e.  Absence without leave. 
f.  Immoral conduct. 
g.  Conduct injurious to the public peace or welfare. 
h.  Conduct unbecoming an officer. 
i.  Any other breach of discipline. 
j.  Drunkenness, use or possession of a controlled substance or use of narcotics while on duty, other than those specifically prescribed by a medical doctor. 
k.  Solicitation or acceptance of a bribe. 
l.  A false statement contained on an application for employment or a false statement made under oath to the board of public safety or the pension board. 
(c)  In addition to the disciplinary powers of the board of public safety, the chief of police may, without a hearing, reprimand or suspend without pay a member of the police department for a maximum of five working days. If the chief reprimands a member in writing or suspends a member, the chief shall within 48 hours notify the board of public safety in writing of the action and the reasons for the action. 
(d)  If the board of public safety takes action to discipline any officer by demotion, dismissal, reprimand, forfeiture, or suspension without pay for the reasons set out in subsection (b)(2), it shall follow the procedure for any such action as outlined in IC 36-8-3-4 and acts amendatory and supplemental thereto. 
(Code 1962, § 14-108; Code 1979, § 2.40.080; Ord. No. CC 92-1457, § 2(2.40.080), 12-29-92) 
Sec. 2-159. - Vacation. 
    Each police officer shall receive vacation time as provided by the collective bargaining agreement with the city. 
(Code 1962, § 14-109; Code 1979, § 2.40.090; Ord. No. CC 92-1457, § 2(2.40.090), 12-29-92) 
Sec. 2-160. - Seniority required for promotion. 
    In order to be eligible for promotion, policemen shall have had not less than the following number of years of continuous active service with the police department for the following positions: 
(1)  Captain, five years. 
(2)  Lieutenant, four years. 
(3)  Sergeant, three years. 
(4)  Corporal, two years. 
(5)  Patrolman, upon completion of probation and appointed by the board of public safety. 
(6)  Probationary patrolman, date of appointment until appointed as a regular patrolman by the board of public safety, which appointment, if given, shall not be later than one year from the date of the original appointment as a probationary patrolman. 
(Code 1962, § 14-110; Ord. No. 1083, § 4, 1965; Code 1979, § 2.40.100; Ord. No. CC 92-1457, § 2(2.40.100), 12-29-92) 
Sec. 2-161. - Police department fees. 
(a)  The department of police is directed to charge a fee for providing a single copy of an accident or any other report in the amount of $10.00. 
(b)  The fee for copies of photos are as follows: 
(1)  5 × 31/2 is $5.00; 
(2)  8 × 10 is $8.00. 
(c)  Fee for copy of a video tape or DVD is $20.00. 
(d)  Fee for a copy of a 911 audio tape or CD is $10.00. 
(e)  The fees collected by the department shall be forwarded to the city clerk-treasurer and deposited in a separate account to be known as the "accident report account." 
(f)  Any ordinance in conflict herewith is repealed. 
[(g)  Additional fees:] 
(1)  Fingerprint fee for non-residents is $10.00. 
(2)  In-house criminal history check for non-resident is $10.00. 
(3)  Resident only salvage VIN check is $25.00. 
(4)  Resident VIN inspection is $5.00. 
(5)  Non-resident VIN inspection is $20.00. 
(6)  Handgun license: Four-year hunting and target is $10.00. 
(7)  Handgun license: Four-year personal protection is $10.00. 
(8)  Lifetime hunting and target, no current license is $50.00. 
(9)  Lifetime hunting and target, with current license is $40.00. 
(10)  Lifetime personal protection, no current license is $50.00. 
(11)  Lifetime personal protection, with current license is $40.00. 
(Code 1979, § 2.40.110; Ord. No. 1260, §§ 1, 2, 1981; Ord. No. CC 92-1457, § 292.40.110, 12-29-92; Ord. No. CC-2011-1868, §§ 1, 2, 12-27-11) 
Secs. 2-162-2-170. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PENSIONS[8] 

Footnotes:

ARTICLE VI. - ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT COMMISSION[9] 

Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
State Law reference- Economic Development and Pollution Control, IC 36-7-12-1 et seq. 

Sec. 2-191. - Creation; composition; control. 
    There is created an economic development commission to be known as the Whiting economic development commission, which shall consist of and be under the control of a board of five members. 
(Ord. No. 1189, § 1, 1977; Code 1979, § 2.52.010) 
Sec. 2-192. - Appointment of members. 
    The members of the economic development commission shall be appointed by the mayor as follows: Three of the members shall be selected by the mayor, one shall be nominated by the county council, and one shall be nominated by the common council of the city. 
(Ord. No. 1189, § 2, 1977; Code 1979, § 2.52.020) 
Sec. 2-193. - Terms of members; vacancy filling. 
(a)  The commissioners shall take office upon their appointment. 
(b)  At the expiration of the respective terms of each of the commissioners, the respective successor shall be selected and nominated, each of which nominees shall be appointed by the mayor within ten days after receiving such nominations, and each succeeding member shall serve for a term of four years. If any person appointed as commissioner fails to qualify within ten days after the mailing to him of the notice of his appointment, or if any member after qualifying dies, resigns, or vacates such office or is removed, a new member shall be chosen and appointed to fill such vacancy in the same manner as provided for the member in respect to whom such vacancy occurs, and the member so chosen and appointed shall serve for the remainder of the vacated term. Commissioners shall hold over after the expiration of their terms until their respective successors have been duly appointed and have qualified. Such commissioners shall receive no salary but shall be entitled to reimbursement for any expenses necessarily incurred in the performance of their duties. 
(Ord. No. 1189, § 3, 1977; Code 1979, § 2.52.030) 
Sec. 2-194. - Residence. 
    No person shall be appointed as a commissioner who is not a resident of the county. If any commissioner ceases to qualify in one of the above categories, his appointment on the board shall thereby terminate and his office shall become vacant. 
(Ord. No. 1189, § 4, 1977; Code 1979, § 2.52.040) 
Sec. 2-195. - Powers and duties. 
    The economic development commission shall have all of the authority, obligations, and duties created in the Municipal Economic Development Act of 1965 (IC 36-7-12), as amended, and shall have the right to exercise all powers set forth therein. 
(Ord. No. 1189, § 5, 1977; Code 1979, § 2.52.050) 
Secs. 2-196-2-215. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - DEPARTMENT OF REDEVELOPMENT 
DIVISION 1. - REDEVELOPMENT COMMISSION 

Sec. 2-216. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    The Act means IC 36-7-14 and IC 36-7-25. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1470, 7-20-93) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 2-217. - Finding. 
    The common council deems it to be in the best interest of the city and its citizens to afford a maximum opportunity for rehabilitation, redevelopment or economic development of areas by private enterprise and the city by establishing a department of redevelopment. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1470, § 1, 7-20-93) 
Sec. 2-218. - Established; commission generally. 
    The common council hereby establishes the department of redevelopment. The department will be controlled by a board of five members known as the Whiting Redevelopment Commission. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1470, § 2, 7-20-93) 
Sec. 2-219. - Taxing district. 
    Pursuant to the Act all of the territory within the corporate boundaries of the city will be a taxing district to be known as the Redevelopment District of Whiting for the purpose of levying and collecting special benefit taxes for redevelopment purposes as provided in the Act. The common council finds and determines that all of the taxable property within this special taxing district will be considered to be benefited by the redevelopment projects and economic development projects carried out under the Act to the extent of the special taxes levied under the Act. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1470, § 3, 7-20-93) 
Sec. 2-220. - Appointment of commission members. 
(a)  The mayor shall appoint three of the five members of the Whiting Redevelopment Commission. 
(b)  The common council shall appoint two of the five members of the Whiting Redevelopment Commission. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1470, § 4, 7-20-93) 
Secs. 2-221-2-226. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - REDEVELOPMENT AUTHORITY 

Sec. 2-227. - Established. 
    The city hereby creates a redevelopment authority under the Act [IC 36-7-14.5] to be known as the Whiting Redevelopment Authority ("authority") as a separate body corporate and politic and as an instrumentality of the city. 
(Ord. No. CC-2015-1949, § 1, 11-4-15) 
Sec. 2-228. - Purpose. 
    The authority is organized for the following purposes: 
(a)  Financing, constructing, and leasing local public improvements to the commission; 
(b)  Financing and constructing additional improvements to local public improvements owned by the authority and leasing them to the commission; 
(c)  Acquiring all or a portion of one or more local public improvements from the commission by purchase or lease and leasing these local public improvements back to the commission, with any additional improvements that may be made to them; 
(d)  Acquiring all or a portion of one or more local public improvements from the commission by purchase or lease to fund or refund indebtedness incurred on account of those local public improvements to enable the commission to make a savings in debt service or lease rental obligations or to obtain relief from covenants that the commission considers to be unduly burdensome; and 
(e)  Any other purposes permitted by the Act, including the issuance of bonds to finance local public improvements. 
(Ord. No. CC-2015-1949, § 2, 11-4-15) 
Sec. 2-229. - Board of directors. 
    The board of directors of the authority shall be composed of three members who are residents of the city and shall be appointed by the mayor for three-year terms from January 1 following their appointment. 
(Ord. No. CC-2015-1949, § 3, 11-4-15) 
Secs. 2-230-2-235. - Reserved.

Sec. 2-237. - Animal control.

(Ord. No. CC-2014-1918, §§ 2, 3, 9-16-14)

(Ord. No. CC-2018-1988, §§ 1,2, 8-7-18)

ARTICLE IX. - DIVISION OF EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT[10] 

Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. CC-2007-1767, §§ 1, 2, adopted April 3, 2007, repealed art. IX, §§ 2-261-2-265, in its entirety. Formerly, said article pertained to the civil defense council. Section 3 of said ordinance, being not specifically amendatory of the Code, has been included as a new art. IX to read as herein set out. 

Sec. 2-261. - Established; director generally; duties; responsibilities; compliance with state law. 
    A new division of the police department titled emergency management is hereby created and established as follows: 
(1)  A new division is added to the police department entitled emergency management. 
(2)  There shall be a director of emergency management, appointed by and serving at the pleasure of the mayor. 
(3)  The director shall serve under the supervision of the chief of police and shall perform duties as assigned by the chief. Said duties may include, but shall not be limited to: 
a.  Control and direct the training efforts of emergency management volunteers. 
b.  Recruit volunteer emergency management workers. 
c.  Assist the police department with issues of crowd and traffic control as assigned by the chief of police or his/her designee. 
d.  Serve as liaison with surrounding emergency management agencies. 
e.  Assume responsibilities designated under the city's disaster plan. 
(4)  The creation, adoption and implementation of a disaster plan by the City of Whiting shall be done by the board of public works and safety under the direction and recommendation of the police chief and fire chief. 
(5)  All interlocal agreements regarding police, fire, emergency management, and mutual aid shall be negotiated by the police or fire chief and approved by the board of public works and safety and the common council, if required by statute. 
(6)  The chief of police shall have the authority, subject to common council approval in the budget and salary ordinances, to compensate members of emergency management who perform duties of park security or special events security but only when and as assigned by the chief of police. 
(7)  The provisions of IC 10-14-3-1 et seq., Emergency Management and Disaster Law shall be complied with in the event a disaster is declared within the city, except as duties and responsibilities are amended by this article. 
(Ord. No. CC-2007-1767, § 3, 4-3-07) 
Secs. 2-262-2-285. - Reserved.

DIVISION 2. - COMPENSATION[12] 

Footnotes:
