State Law reference- Compensation of appointive officers and employees, IC 36-4-7-3. 

Sec. 2-296. - Payment plan. 
    All salaried and hourly employees for the city shall receive payment for their services rendered every two weeks on Friday, for a total of 26 pay periods per year. 
(Code 1962, § 7-401; Code 1979, § 2.72.010; Ord. No. 1344, § 1, 1986) 
Sec. 2-297. - Claims against city; procedure. 
    All claims against the city for labor shall be verified on behalf of such laborers by such officer or officers of the city, ordering or employing such labor or laborers, which claim shall be filed by such officer or officers with the city clerk-treasurer. Thereafter, on the days provided for in section 2-296, the bills and claims committee of the common council shall investigate the merits of the claims and shall allow or disallow the claims on such days and shall report their doings to the common council at its next regular meeting. Thereafter, and immediately upon the allowance of such claims by such bills and claims committee, the city clerk-treasurer shall issue warrants of the city for the payment of such claims, and the city clerk-treasurer shall pay the same to the persons entitled thereto. 
(Code 1962, § 7-402; Code 1979, § 2.72.020) 
Sec. 2-298. - City employees to reside within city. 
    All employees shall reside within the city limits or shall be taxpayers thereof or shall be eligible for an appointive position in accordance with state statutes as amended from time to time. 
(Code 1962, § 7-403; Code 1979, § 2.72.030; Ord. No. 1312, § 2, 1984) 
Secs. 2-299-2-310. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - POLICE AND FIRE COLLECTIVE BARGAINING[13] 

Footnotes: 
--- (13) --- 
Editor's note- This division supersedes Code 1979, §§ 2.84.010-2.84.110; Ord. No. 1288, §§ 1-11, 1983. 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and protection, ch. 7. 
State Law reference- Meetings of governing bodies with employee organizations, IC 5-14-1.5-6.5. 

Sec. 2-311. - Recognition. 
    On the terms and conditions set forth in this division, the city recognizes the Fraternal Order of Police Lodge No. 68 as the exclusive bargaining representative of the city's police employees in the bargaining unit described in this division. On the terms and conditions set forth in this division, the city recognizes the Whiting Firefighters Local No. 969 as the exclusive bargaining representative of the city's firefighters in the bargaining unit described in this division. The respective bargaining units shall select a committee not to exceed three members per bargaining unit for the purpose of carrying out this division. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1463, § 1, 4-20-93) 
Sec. 2-312. - Bargaining unit. 
    The Fraternal Order of Public Lodge No. 68 of the Firefighters Local No. 969 shall be the exclusive bargaining representatives for the police officers and firefighters respectively. The following shall be the excluded classification: Chief, captains and nonsworn personnel (civilian employees). 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1463, § 2, 4-20-93) 
Sec. 2-313. - Issues subject to bargaining. 
(a)  The Fraternal Order of Police Lodge No. 68 and Firefighters Local No. 969 shall represent the employees in the bargaining unit with respect to bargaining on the following subjects only: 
Salary and pay schedules, including shift pay, overtime pay, holiday pay, clothing allowance, vacation schedules and accumulation, layoff procedures, grievance procedures, unscheduled duty pay, and the salary payable at each of the established steps of the step in grade pay, and group medical insurance, provided that the selection of the insurance carriers shall not be a subject of bargaining. 
(b)  With respect to grievance procedures, the city shall not be obligated to bargain about any procedure that would cause or result in the lessening or abrogation of the statutory authority of the board of public works and safety. The board of public works and safety will bargain on those issues that are under its control as set forth by law, and the common council shall likewise bargain on those issues that are under its control as authorized by law. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1463, § 3, 4-20-93) 
Sec. 2-314. - Time schedules. 
(a)  Bargaining between the city and the respective bargaining unit shall begin no later than April 1 of each year and shall end no later than July 1 of the same year. The same schedule shall be followed thereafter so that bargaining on the issues subject to bargaining shall occur in any year with respect to the following calendar year or years. 
(b)  The city by its authorized representatives shall meet with the representatives of the bargaining agent within 30 days after receipt of written notice from the bargaining agent requesting a meeting for collective bargaining purposes. The notices of collective bargaining shall be served upon the appropriate members of the bargaining committee for the city and the city clerk-treasurer. The obligation to bargain in good faith shall include the duty to cause any agreement resulting from such negotiations to be reduced to writing. The respective parties shall meet at least on three occasions after the initial notice to bargain referred to in this section and in section 2-317, and all parties shall bargain in good faith on any and all issues. 
(c)  Nothing in this section shall be interpreted to prevent the parties from entering into an agreement covering a period of more than one calendar year. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1463, § 4, 4-20-93) 
Sec. 2-315. - Representatives. 
    The spokespersons and representatives for the board of public works and safety shall be the mayor and/or two of his designees. The spokespersons for the common council shall be three members selected by the common council. The Fraternal Order of Police Lodge No. 68 and Firefighters Local No. 969 shall select six persons to represent their interest, three being from each bargaining unit. The Fraternal Order of Police Lodge No. 68 and Firefighters Local No. 969 shall have the option of bargaining separate from each other if they so desire. Each of the parties may obtain appropriate legal representation during any collective bargaining procedure. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1463, § 5, 4-20-93) 
Sec. 2-316. - Exclusive mechanism. 
    This division provides the exclusive mechanism by which the city, the Fraternal Order of Police Lodge No. 68 and Firefighters Local No. 969 shall carry out collective bargaining. The city shall not be required to deal directly with the individuals in the bargaining unit in lieu of bargaining collectively. The Fraternal Order of Police Lodge No. 68 and the employees of the bargaining unit shall not attempt to deal directly with any representatives of the city other than those identified in this division. Such an attempt shall be deemed an act of bad faith bargaining. The Whiting Firefighters Local No. 969 and the employees of the bargaining unit shall not attempt to deal directly with any representatives of the city other than those identified in this division. Such an attempt shall be deemed an act of bad faith bargaining. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1463, § 6, 4-20-93) 
Sec. 2-317. - Impasse and advisory mediation. 
(a)  If the bargaining agents and the city are unable within 60 days from and after the date of the first meeting to develop a collective bargaining agreement, either party may declare that an impasse has been reached and request advisory mediation. The Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service shall, within 14 days from the date of request for mediation, promptly assign, as soon as possible, a mediator. If either party refuses to engage in the mediation process then the party that refuses to engage shall bear any cost incurred by the party requesting mediation. If the parties engage in the mediation, all costs shall be shared one-half by the city and one-half by the Fraternal Order of Police Lodge No. 68 and/or Firefighters Local No. 969. The recommendation and action of the mediator shall be advisory only and shall have no binding authority or effect on any of the parties. 
(b)  The parties may mutually agree to any other method of selecting an advisory mediator provided such method is likely to result in the selection of an impartial and knowledgeable mediator. 
(c)  The hearing conducted by the mediator shall be concluded within 20 days from the commencement and within ten days after the conclusion of this meeting. The mediator shall make written findings and conclusions on the issues prescribed, a copy of which is to be mailed or otherwise delivered to the bargaining units and the city. The mediator's decision shall be considered nonbinding unless the bargaining units and the city and common council agree prior to mediation that the decisions in certain areas shall be binding upon the parties. Decisions in regard to annual pay and monetary fringe benefits and hours of employment shall be subject to approval by the common council and in accordance with the requirements of IC 36-8-3-3. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1463, § 7, 4-20-93) 
Sec. 2-318. - Strikes, work stoppages, slowdowns and other changes prohibited. 
(a)  The Fraternal Order of Police Lodge No. 68 and Firefighters Local No. 969 shall not engage in strikes, work stoppages, slowdowns, picketing, increased ticket writing, unusual increase in police activities, harassment, interferences with or departures from the performance of duties as prescribed by the city. The bargaining units shall not engage in, encourage, sanction or defend any such activities against the city. 
(b)  If any of the activities referred to in this section take place, in addition to other appropriate remedies undertaken by the city pursuant to this division, any collective bargaining agreement entered into between the parties pursuant to this division shall be null and void and of no effect; provided, however, that any activity referred to in this section and done by either bargaining agent shall not affect the collective bargaining agreement of the other bargaining agent. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1463, § 8, 4-20-93) 
Sec. 2-319. - General law. 
(a)  This division shall not be deemed in any way to limit or diminish the authority and responsibility of the city to manage and direct the operation and activities of the city, including the police operations and fire department operation and activities, to the full extent authorized or permitted by law. 
(b)  Nothing in this section shall be construed to negate the clear and unambiguous meaning of this division. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1463, § 9, 4-20-93) 
Sec. 2-320. - Other authorization. 
    In order to be effective, collective bargaining agreements made pursuant to this division shall require approval by the board of public works and safety and the common council. The city and the Fraternal Order of Police Lodge No. 68 and Firefighters Local No. 969 shall make every good faith effort to obtain approval of any fiscal funding pursuant to a collective bargaining agreement that shall require the approval of the county tax adjustment board and the state board of tax commissioners. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1463, § 10, 4-20-93) 
Sec. 2-321. - Approval of any agreements. 
    Each collective bargaining agreement reached shall be reduced to writing and shall be approved by the board of public works and safety and the common council together with the Fraternal Order of Police Lodge No. 68 or Firefighters Local No. 969. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1463, § 11, 4-20-93) 
Secs. 2-322-2-335. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - DRUG FREE WORKPLACE 

Sec. 2-336. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Controlled substance means any substance which an individual may or may not see, possess, use, or distribute under the laws of the federal government or the state in which the individual is employed or working. 
    Department director means the department head of the department. 
    Intoxicant means an alcoholic beverage. 
    Otherwise legal but illicitly used substance includes prescription drugs and over-the-counter drugs not being used for their intended purposes. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1485, § 2.34.010(b)-(d), 12-7-93) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 2-337. - Procedures; regulations. 
(a)  Employees are expected to report to work on time and in appropriate mental and physical condition for work. Employees are not to report to work under the influence of intoxicants, illegal drugs, or illicitly used substances and shall not consume, use, or possess intoxicants, illegal drugs, or illicitly used substances at any time during their scheduled workday, on city property, or in any city vehicle (while traveling to or from city property while on duty). The unlawful manufacture, distribution, dispensation, possession, or use of a controlled substance, intoxicant or illicitly used substance on city premises or while conducting city business off premises is absolutely prohibited. Violations of this policy will result in disciplinary action, up to and including termination, and may have legal consequences. 
(b)  If a supervisor has reasonable cause to believe that an employee has reported to work under the influence of intoxicants, illegal drugs, or illicitly used substances, the supervisor, with the approval of the department director, has the right to request that the employee submit to an alcohol or drug screening test at the city's expense. For the purposes of this division, random or routine drug testing shall not be conducted by the city, and testing shall not be conducted in an arbitrary or discriminatory way toward any employee. A supervisor must have reasonable cause for ordering an alcohol or drug screening test and shall document such reasonable cause. The failure of an employee to submit to an alcohol or drug screening test shall be grounds for discipline which may include termination. The results of the alcohol or drug test shall not be used by the city for any purpose other than to determine adherence to city policy, to discipline an employee whenever necessary, and to comply with applicable terms of this division. 
(c)  The city recognizes drug dependency as a major problem. The city also recognizes drug abuse as a potential health, safety and security problem. When it is determined that an employee is suffering from a drug or alcohol abuse problem, reasonable efforts by the city may be made to rehabilitate the employee using available community resources. However, this does not foreclose the right to administer discipline up to and including discharge. Conscientious efforts to seek such help will not jeopardize any employee's job and will not be noted in any personnel record except where action follows a supervisory-initiated referral. The city is committed to assisting employees in this endeavor in any way possible. 
(d)  No employee shall be subject to discipline for the appropriate use of legal nonprescription or prescribed legal drugs for the treatment of illness or injury. However, if the employee knows or should know that use of a nonprescription or prescribed drug does or could impair the employee's ability to operate a city vehicle or equipment, or otherwise perform his job duties, the employee shall share this information with his immediate supervisor. A violation of this section may subject the employee to disciplinary action. 
(e)  Employees must, as a condition of employment, abide by the terms of this division and report any conviction under a criminal drug statute for violations occurring on or off city premises while conducting city business. A report of a conviction must be made within five days after the conviction to the department director. Within ten days of learning of an employee's criminal conviction for illegal drug activity within the workplace, the city will notify the federal government of such conviction. Within 30 days of learning of an employee's criminal conviction for illegal drug activity within the workplace, the city will take appropriate personnel action. (This requirement is mandated by the federally legislated Drug Free Workplace Act of 1988.) 
(f)  A copy of this division shall be provided to each employee. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1485, § 2.34.020, 12-7-93) 
Secs. 2-338-2-350. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XI. - ORDINANCE VIOLATIONS BUREAU 

Sec. 2-351. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of the ordinance from which this article was derived is to establish a violations bureau which will allow duly authorized city personnel to deal in an expeditious manner with minor ordinance violations related to public health, safety or neighborhood maintenance and which will result in compliance with the ordinance(s) by the property or animal owner for little or no cost and in a timely fashion. Further, this chapter will also permit the orderly and efficient enforcement of ordinances applicable to all city parks, athletic complexes and Whihala Beach in order to maintain public health and safety and orderly traffic and parking enforcement. 
(Ord. No. CC-2009-1816, § I, 6-2-2009; Ord. No. CC-2014-1928, § 1, 1-6-15) 
Sec. 2-352. - Establishment. 
(a)  An ordinance violations bureau is hereby established for the City of Whiting pursuant to I.C. 33-36-2-1 et seq. 
(b)  The clerk-treasurer is hereby appointed as the violations clerk pursuant to I.C. 33-36-2-1. 
(c)  Violation notices issued under the ordinances from which this article was derived may be issued by a sworn member of the Whiting Police or Fire Department, the animal control officer/warden, the street commissioner, the building commissioner, the code enforcement officer, any designated parking enforcement officer or any other duly authorized city inspector or designated code enforcement agent or assistant. 
(Ord. No. CC-2009-1816, § II, 6-2-2009; Ord. No. CC-2014-1928, § 2, 1-6-15) 
Sec. 2-353. - Designation of Code provisions subject to the ordinance violations bureau. 
(a)  The following code provisions may be processed through the violations clerk. 
(1)  Animal related provisions: 
a.  WMC section 3.2 Licensing. 
b.  WMC section 3.7 Restraint of animals. 
c.  WMC section 3.13 Rabies control. 
d.  WMC section 3.14 Animal waste. 
(2)  Property maintenance code provisions: 
a.  WMC section 4-193(a)(1)b.1. Refuse, brush, weeds, broken glass, stumps, roots, obnoxious vegetation and growth, filth, garbage, trash, and debris. 
b.  WMC section 4-193(c)(1) Landscaping. 
c.  WMC section 4-193(c)(2) Lawns/weeds. 
d.  WMC section 4-238 Swimming pool maintenance. 
e.  WMC section 8-37 Litter on premises. 
f.  WMC section 8-108 Garbage in receptacles. 
g.  WMC section 8-112 Bagging of garbage. 
h.  WMC Section 8-131 Importing waste. 
i.  WMC Section 11.5-3 Acts of nuisance. 
j.  WMC section 15-4 Snow and ice removal from sidewalks. 
k.  WMC Section 15-127 Duty of owners for front and rear addresses. 
(3)  Park and beach provisions: 
a.  WMC section 13-4 Bicycles. 
b.  WMC section 13-5 Litter. 
c.  WMC section 13-6 Parking. 
d.  WMC section 13-7 Camping. 
e.  WMC section 13-11 Grilling in park or beach. 
(b)  Nothing in the ordinance from which this article was derived prohibits the city inspector or officer from issuing a court citation rather than a violation notice for violators of the designated code provisions if the property or the owner has been issued previous violation notices or the condition of the property warrants court intervention as determined by the officer/inspector issuing the violation notice. 
(Ord. No. CC-2009-1816, § III, 6-2-2009; Ord. No. CC-2014-1928, § 3, 1-6-15; Ord. No. CC-2015-1947, § 1, 10-20-15) 
Sec. 2-354. - Civil penalties. 
(a)  The civil penalty for the first violation notice issued under a code provision designated within the violations bureau ordinance(s) shall be $50.00. 
(b)  The civil penalty for the second violation notice issued under the same code provision shall be $250.00. 
(c)  Subsequent violations may result in the issuance of a court citation. 
(d)  It shall be the responsibility of the duly authorized city officer/inspector who is issuing the violation notice to determine and designate on the violation notice if this is a first, second or subsequent offense. 
(Ord. No. CC-2009-1816, § IV, 6-2-2009; Ord. No. CC-2014-1928, § 4, 1-6-15; Ord. No. CC-2015-1934, §§ 1, 2, 5-19-15) 
Sec. 2-355. - Authority of violations clerk. 
(a)  The violations clerk may accept appearances, waivers of trial and admissions of violations. When an admission is received, the violations clerk may assess and receive from the violator the amount prescribed in section 2-354 of the ordinance from which this article was derived. 
(b)  The violations clerk may accept a denial from the alleged violator and the denial shall be submitted in writing. 
(c)  If the violations clerk receives a written denial, or if an individual fails to satisfy the civil penalty after having entered an admission, or if an individual fails to admit or deny the violation within 30 days of the date of the violation notice, the violations clerk shall report this fact to the official having the responsibility to prosecute ordinance violations in the Whiting city court. 
(d)  Court proceedings shall then be initiated for the alleged violation(s). 
(e)  Funds collect by the violations clerk shall be processed in accordance with Indiana statutes. 
(Ord. No. CC-2009-1816, § V, 6-2-2009) 
Chapter 3 - ANIMALS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Nuisances, § 6-26 et seq.; health and sanitation, ch. 8; health, § 8-108 et seq.; vehicles and traffic, ch. 17. 
State Law reference- Running at large of livestock and poultry, IC 15-2.1-21-8; licensing and taxation of dogs and kennels, IC 15-5-9-1 et seq.; dogs without collar and tag or at large, IC 15-5-9-13; local animal control, IC 36-8-2-6, 36-8-2-13. 

Sec. 3-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Animal means any live, vertebrate creature, domestic or wild. 
    Animal control officer means any person designated by the state, the city, or a humane society as qualified to perform such duties under the law. 
    Animal shelter means any facility operated by a humane society or municipal agency, or its authorized agents, for the purpose of impounding or caring for animals held under the authority of this chapter or state law. 
    Circus means a commercial variety show featuring animal acts for entertainment. 
    Commercial animal establishment means any pet shop, grooming shop, auction, circus, performing animal exhibition or kennel. 
    Enclosure means a structure or fence of at lease six feet in height, forming or causing an enclosure suitable to prevent the entry of young children, and suitable to confine an animal in conjunction with other measures which may be taken by the owner or keeper. Such enclosure shall be securely locked and designed to prevent the animal from escaping the enclosure. 
    Humane society means any organization for the prevention of cruelty to animals incorporated under the laws of this state. 
    Impound means to take into the custody of the animal shelter of the city or an animal shelter of the city's choice. 
    Kennel means an establishment wherein any person engages in the business of boarding, breeding, buying, letting for hire, training for a fee, or selling dogs and cats or a location which continuously harbors or maintains four or more cats or dogs. 
    Licensing authority means the city clerk-treasurer. 
    Livestock or farm animals means all cattle or animals of the bovine species; all horses, mules, burros and asses or animals of the equine species; all swine or animals of the porcine species; and all goats or animals of the caprine species. 
    Owner means any person, partnership, or corporation owning, keeping, or harboring one or more animals; an animal shall be deemed to be harbored if it is fed or sheltered for three consecutive days or more. 
    Performing animal exhibition means any spectacle, display, act, or event other than circuses, in which performing animals are used. 
    Pet means any animal kept for pleasure rather than utility. 
    Pet shop means any person, partnership or corporation, whether operated separately or in connection with another business enterprise, except for a licensed kennel, that buys, sells, or boards any species of animals. 
    Potentially vicious animals means an animal that may reasonable be assumed to pose a threat to public safety as demonstrated by any of the following behaviors: 
(1)  Causing an injury to a person; 
(2)  Without provocation, chasing or menacing a person in an aggressive manner; 
(3)  Running at large and impounded or owners cited by the animal control officer or his/her designee two or more times within any twelve-month period; 
(4)  Acts in a highly aggressive manner within a fenced yard/enclosure and appears to a reasonable person able to jump over or escape. 
    Poultry means any domesticated bird. 
    Public nuisance means any animal or animals which: 
(1)  Molest passersby or passing vehicles. 
(2)  Attack other animals. 
(3)  Trespass on school grounds or park areas and playgrounds. 
(4)  Are repeatedly at large. 
(5)  Damage private or public property. 
(6)  Bark, whine, or howl in an excessive, continuous, or untimely fashion which, by causing frequent or long, continued noises, disturbs the comfort or repose of any persons in the vicinity. 
    Responsible person means a person at least 18 years old who is familiar with any animal and has the size and experience to be able to keep the animal under complete control at all times. 
    Restraint refers to any animal secured by a leash or lead or within the real property limits of its owner. 
    Veterinary hospital means any establishment maintained and operated by a licensed veterinarian for surgery, diagnosis and treatment of diseased and injured animals. 
    Vicious animal means: 
(1)  Any individual animal that when unprovoked afflicts, bites or attacks a human being or other animal on either public or private property; 
(2)  Any individual animal with a known propensity, tendency or disposition to attack without provocation, to cause injury or to otherwise endanger the safety of human beings or domestic animals; 
(3)  Any individual animal which attacks a human being or domestic animal without provocation; 
(4)  Any individual animal which upon three separate occasions is left either unmuzzled, unleashed or unattended by its owner, or a member of the owner's family, and in a vicious or terrorizing manner approaches any person in an apparent attitude of attack upon streets, sidewalks or any public grounds or places. 
(5)  Has been designated as a potentially vicious animal and engages in behavior that poses a threat to public safety as described in the definition of potentially vicious animal of this section. 
    Wild animal means any live monkey (nonhuman primate), raccoon, skunk, fox, poisonous snake, lynx, or any other warmblooded mammal which can normally be found in the wild state. 
(Ord. No. 1168, art. 1, 1976; Code 1979, § 6.04.010; Ord. No. 1382, §§ 1-3, 1988; Ord. No. CC-2004-1679, 5-18-04; Ord. No. CC-2007-1776, §§ I.A, I.B, II, 9-13-07; Ord. No. CC-2011-1848, § I, 5-17-11; Ord. No. CC-2011-1865, § 1, 12-6-11) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 3-2. - Licensing. 
(a)  Any person owning, keeping, harboring or having custody of any animal over three months of age, within this city must obtain a license as provided in this chapter, this provision shall not apply to the keeping of small cage birds or aquatic and amphibian animals kept solely as pets. 
(b)  Reserved. 
(c)  A written application for license shall be made to the clerk-treasurer's office which shall include the name and address of the applicant, a description of the animal, the appropriate fee, and a rabies certificate issued by a licensed veterinarian or anti-rabies clinic. 
(d)  An application for a license must be made within 30 days after obtaining a dog or cat over three months of age, except that this requirement will not apply to a nonresident keeping a dog or cat within the city for no longer than 60 days. 
(e)  License fees shall not be required for Seeing Eye dogs or Governmental Police dogs. 
(f)  Upon acceptance of the license application and fee, the clerk-treasurer's office shall issue a durable tag or identification collar stamped with an identifying number and the year of issuance. Tags should be designed so that they may be conveniently fastened or riveted to the animal's harness or collar. 
(g)  Dogs and cats must wear identification tags or collars at all times when off the premises of the owners. 
(h)  The clerk-treasurer's office shall maintain a record of the identifying numbers of all tags issued and shall make this record available to the public. 
(i)  Applications for licenses must be made between January 1st to and including March 31st each year. Licenses expire December 31st of the year purchased. 
(j)  Applicable fees are located in the fee schedule of the city, 
(k)  No person may use any license for any animal other than the animal for which it was issued. 
(l)  Except as provided below, the number of animal licenses issued per residential lot shall be limited to no more than three licenses in order to comply with the zoning ordinance and the definition of kennel. In locations which are multi-unit residential lots, the resident will be permitted to license one pet per unit. 
    In the event that a residential lot has more than three animals licensed with the city during license year 2011, those animal owners shall be grandfathered and permitted to renew the animal licenses for those particular pets licensed in 2011 under the following conditions: 
(1)  The owner had licensed the pets with the city prior to November 1, 2011; 
(2)  The pet's license maybe renewed annually for the remainder of the pet's natural life; 
(3)  In the event the pet is no longer in the household for any reason, a license may not be obtained for a new or replacement pet if that license brings the household in excess of three animal licenses; 
(4)  The animal warden may recommend to the board of public works and safety that a grandfathered license should not be renewed if the property owner has been cited for more than two violations of animal waste, excessive barking, failure to restrain the animal, violation of the animal care regulation, vicious animals or any other city ordinance violation related to the animals. 
(Ord. No. 1168, art. 2, 1976; Code 1979, § 6.04.020; Ord. No. 1309, 1984; Ord. No. 1368, §§ 1-3, 1987; Ord. No. 1382, §§ 4, 5, 1988; Ord. No. CC-2004-1679, 5-18-04; Ord. No. CC-2007-1776, § VI, 9-13-07; Ord. No. CC-2011-1865, § 2, 12-6-11) 
Sec. 3-3. - Disposition of funds. 
    Fees and fines paid to the licensing authority shall be deposited in the general fund. 
(Code 1979, § 6.04.010) 
Sec. 3-4. - Commercial animal establishments. 
(a)  No person shall operate a commercial animal establishment or animal shelter without first obtaining a license in compliance with this section. 
(b)  The clerk-treasurer's office shall promulgate regulations for the issuance of licenses in this chapter; such regulations shall include requirements for the humane care of all animals and for compliance with the provisions of this chapter and other applicable laws. Such regulations maybe amended from time to time as deemed desirable for public health and welfare and for the protection of animals. 
(c)  Upon a showing by an applicant for a license that he or she is willing and able to comply with the regulations stipulated a permit shall be issued upon payment of the applicable fee, after inspection by the animal control officer and the building commissioner. 
(d)  Applications for licenses must be made between January 1st to and including March 31st each year. Licenses expire December 31st of the year purchased. 
(e)  Applicable fees are located in the fee schedule of the City. 
(Ord. No. 1168, art. 3, 1976; Code 1979, § 6.04.030; Ord. No. CC-2004-1679, 5-18-04) 
Sec. 3-5. - License revocation for commercial establishments. 
(a)  The clerk-treasurer's office may revoke any license if the person holding the license fails or refuses to comply with any provisions this chapter or any law governing the protections and keeping of animals. 
(b)  If the applicant has withheld or falsified any information on the application, a license shall be revoked. 
(c)  Any person whose license is revoked shall humanely dispose of all animals kept by such person immediately, under supervision of the animal control officer. No part of the license fee may be refunded. 
(d)  No person who has been convicted of cruelty to animals shall be issued a license to operate a commercial animal establishment. 
(e)  Any person having been denied a license may not reapply for a period of 30 days. 
(Ord. No. 1168, art. 4, 1976; Code 1979, § 6.04.040; Ord. No. CC-2004-1679, 5-18-04) 
Sec. 3-6. - Authority of animal control officer. 
(a)  The animal control officer is under the direct authority and subject to the rules and regulations and orders of the board of public works and safety, ordinances of the city, statutes of the state, and the chief of police and shall report to and accept orders from the chief of police. 
(b)  The animal control officer shall be equipped with the necessary tools to fulfill his position, but the tools will not include a handgun, shotgun or ballistic armament of any nature. 
(c)  A properly trained animal control officer or city police officer shall be permitted to use any tranquilizing equipment for the purpose of safely subduing or transporting an animal. 
(d)  The code enforcement officer, his or her designee, or any other duly authorized city inspector or enforcement officer shall also be authorized to carry out the duties, responsibilities and rights of enforcement of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1168, art. 5, 1976; Code 1979, § 6.04.050; Ord. No. 1382, § 6, 1988; Ord. No. CC-2004-1679, 5-18-04; Ord. No. CC-2007-1776, § VII, 9-13-07; Ord. No. CC-2011-1848, § II, 5-17-11; Ord. No. CC-2015-1937, § I, 6-16-15) 
Sec. 3-7. - Restraint of animals. 
(a)  Unrestrained dogs and nuisance animals shall be taken by the police, animal control officers, or humane officers and impounded in an animal shelter, and there confined in a humane manner. 
(b)  All dogs shall be kept under restraint. 
(c)  All owners shall exercise proper care and control of their animals to prevent them from becoming a public nuisance. 
(d)  Every female dog or cat in season shall be confined in a building or secure enclosure in such a manner that such female dog or cat cannot come into contact with another animal except for planned breeding. 
(e)  It is unlawful for any animal to make, continue, or cause to be made or continued any loud barking, whines, or howls in an excessive, continuous or untimely fashion which by causing frequent or long-continued noise shall disturb the comfort or repose of any persons in the vicinity. 
(Ord. No. 1168, art. 6, 1976; Code 1979, § 6.04.060; Ord. No. 1382, § 7, 1988; Ord. No. CC-2007-1776, § VIII, 9-13-07) 
Sec. 3-8. - Impoundment and violation notice. 
(a)  Unrestrained dogs and nuisance animals shall be taken by the police, animal control officers, or humane officers and impounded in an animal shelter and there confined in a humane manner. 
(b)  Impounded dogs and cats shall be kept for not less than three working days, excluding Saturdays, Sundays, and Holidays. 
(c)  If, by a license tag or other means, the owner of the impounded animal can be identified, the animal control officer shall immediately upon impoundment notify the owner by telephone or by mail. 
(d)  Applicable fees are located in the fee schedule of the city. 
(e)  Any animal not reclaimed by its owner within the legal impoundment period shall become the property of the local government authority or humane society and shall be placed for adoption in a suitable home or humanely euthanized. 
(f)  The owner of an impounded animal may also be proceeded against for violation of this chapter. 
(g)  The animal control officer shall notify the clerk-treasurer's office of any license that has three or more violations or citations issued in a 12-month period. 
    All other impoundment and violation notice shall remain as listed in section 3-8. 
(h)  The licensing authority or animal control officer shall review automatically all licenses issued to animal owners against whom three or more ordinance violations have been assessed in a 12-month period. 
(Ord. No. 1168, art. 7, 1976; Code 1979, § 6.04.070; Ord. No. CC-2004-1679, 5-18-04) 
Sec. 3-9. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. CC-2011-1848, § III, adopted May 17, 2011, repealed § 3-9, which pertained to unattended animals and derived from Ord. No. CC 93-1496, § 10.05.240, adopted Jan. 4, 1994. 
Sec. 3-10. - Animal care regulations. 
(a)  All owners must provide their animals with sufficient good and wholesome food and water, proper shelter and protection from the weather, veterinary care when needed to prevent suffering, and with humane care and treatment. 
(b)  No person shall beat, cruelly ill treat, torment, overload, overwork, or otherwise abuse an animal, or cause, instigate or permit any dogfight, cockfight, or other combat between animals or between animals and humans. 
(c)  No person shall abandon any animal. 
(d)  No person shall crop a dog's ears, except when a licensed veterinarian issues a signed certificate that the operation is necessary for the dog's health and comfort, and in no event shall any person except a licensed veterinarian perform such an operation. 
(e)  Any person who, as the operator of a motor vehicle, strikes a domestic animal shall stop at once and render such assistance as may be possible and shall immediately report such injury or death to the animal's owner. If the owner cannot be ascertained and located, such operator shall at once report the accident to the appropriate law enforcement agency or to the local humane society. 
(f)  No person shall expose any known poisonous substance, whether mixed with food or not, so that the same shall be liable to be eaten by any animal; provided, that it shall not be unlawful for a person to expose on his own property common rat poison mixed only with vegetable substances. 
(Ord. No. 1168, art. 8, 1976; Code 1979, § 6.04.080) 
Sec. 3-11. - Keeping wild animals. 
    No person shall keep or permit to be kept on his/her premises any wild animal as defined in section 3-1. This section shall not be construed to apply to performing animal exhibitions or to circuses. 
(Ord. No. 1168, art. 9, 1976; Code 1979, § 6.04.090; Ord. No. CC-2007-1776, § IX, 9-13-07) 
Sec. 3-11.5. - Keeping livestock or farm animals. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to have, keep, possess, own, maintain, shelter or harbor any livestock, poultry or other farm-type animals, including but not limited to horse, mule, cattle, bison, swine, hogs, pigs, pot-bellied pigs, sheep, llama, alpaca, goat, wolf, wolf hybrid, coy dog, geese, ducks, chickens, turkeys, ostriches, emus, or any miniature version thereof, within the municipal limits of the City of Whiting. 
(Ord. No. CC-2011-1848, § V, 5-17-11) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. CC-2011-1848, § V, adopted May 17, 2011, added provisions that were not specifically amendatory. At the editor's discretion, these provisions have been included as § 3-11.5. 
Sec. 3-12. - Performing animal exhibitions. 
(a)  No performing animal exhibition or circus shall be permitted in which animals are induced or encouraged to perform through the use of chemical, mechanical, electrical or manual devices in a manner which will cause or is likely to cause physical injury or suffering. 
(b)  All equipment used on a performing animal shall fit properly and be in good working condition. 
(Ord. No. 1168, art. 10, 1976; Code 1979, § 6.04.100) 
Sec. 3-13. - Rabies control. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person to own or harbor a dog or cat over the age of three months without a valid rabies vaccination administered by a licensed, accredited veterinarian. 
(b)  Persons bringing dogs or cats into the city shall have readily available, as proof of vaccination, a valid rabies certificate signed by a licensed veterinarian or issued by an approved governmental agency. Animals which do not qualify shall either be immediately removed from the city or be vaccinated by a licensed veterinarian, and the owner shall be liable for the expenses incurred. 
(c)  Any animal, having a valid rabies vaccination, which bites a person shall be quarantined on the premises of its owner under supervision of the animal control officer for a period of time specified by the animal control officer. The animal shall be securely confined and kept from contact with any other animal during quarantine. 
(d)  If there is no proof of adequate immunization, the animal control officer shall require special confinement and order the animal surrendered to an animal shelter or veterinarian hospital, and such confinement shall be at the owner's expense. 
(e)  In the case of any stray animal or in the case or where ownership is not know, quarantine shall be in a shelter designated by the animal control officer, and the animal may be redeemed upon payment of all fines, expenses and fees. 
(f)  No person shall knowingly allow an animal confined under quarantine to escape, sell, give away, or dispose of such animal before the expiration of the quarantine period. 
(g)  Animals shall be released from quarantines in an animal shelter or veterinary hospital only after a written certificate from a qualified licensed veterinarian is presented to the animal control officer stating that the animal is free of rabies. 
    All other rabies control shall remain as listed in section 3-13. 
(Ord. No. 1168, art. 11, 1976; Code 1979, § 6.04.110; Ord. No. CC-97-1550, 2-4-97; Ord. No. CC-2004-1679, 5-18-04) 
Cross reference- Health and sanitation, ch. 8. 
Sec. 3-14. - Animal waste. 
    The owner of every animal shall be responsible for the removal of any excreta deposited by his animal on public walks, alleys, recreation areas or private property. All animal waste must be bagged and placed inside a trash receptacle for proper disposal. 
(Ord. No. 1168, art. 12, 1976; Code 1979, § 6.04.120; Ord. No. CC-2004-1679, 5-18-04; Ord. No. CC-2015-1941, § 1, 9-1-15) 
Sec. 3-15. - Enforcement authorized. 
(a)  The civil provisions of this chapter shall be enforced by the animal control officer or his/her designee, the code enforcement officer or his/her designee, any duly authorized city inspector or enforcement officer and the police department. 
(b)  The criminal provisions shall only be enforced by the police department. 
(c)  It is unlawful for any person to interfere with the animal control officer or his/her designee, the code enforcement officer or his/her designee, any city inspector or enforcement officer, or a police officer while in the performance of their duties in the enforcement of this chapter. 
(d)  The animal control officer or his/her designee, the code enforcement officer or his/her designee, any duly authorized city inspector or enforcement officer, or police officer, while engaged in the enforcement of this chapter, shall have the authority to protect his/herself or other persons from bodily harm or property damage to the extent of humanely destroying the problem animal. 
(Ord. No. 1168, art. 14, 1976; Code 1979, § 6.04.130; Ord. No. CC-2011-1848, § IV, 5-17-11; Ord. No. CC-2015-1937, § II, 6-16-15) 
Sec. 3-16. - Animals found running at large; penalty. 
    When animals are found running at large and their ownership is known to the animal control officer or the police department, such animals need not be impounded. The animal control officer, after one warning has been given to the owner, may issue a citation. 
(Ord. No. 1168, art. 15(2), 1976; Ord. No. 1221, 1978; Code 1979, § 6.04.135; Ord. No. CC-2004-1679, 5-18-04) 
Sec. 3-17. - Animals as prizes prohibited. 
    No person shall give away any live animal, fish, reptile or bird as a prize for, or as an inducement to enter, any contest, game or other competition, or as an inducement to enter a place of amusement, or promise or offer vertebrates as an incentive to enter into any business agreement whereby the offer was for the purpose of attracting trade. 
(Code 1979, § 6.04.141; Ord. No. 1368, § 4, 1987) 
Sec. 3-18. - Dogs in city parks. 
    It shall be unlawful to allow any dog in any park owned by the city. The park department shall post appropriate signs warning all persons of this prohibition. This prohibition shall not apply to the following: 
(1)  Police dogs; 
(2)  Seeing-eye dogs; 
(3)  Other trained service dogs which provide assistance to individuals with disabilities; 
(4)  Dogs under restraint, in the following areas: 
a.  The Whiting Lakefront Park boardwalk and adjacent bicycle path, including park entrance sidewalks to the boardwalk and adjacent bicycle path and excluding areas north of the boardwalk such as the gazebo, the pier, the formal garden and grassy areas, and all areas south of the park road; 
b.  The Whiting Lakefront Trail which is the bicycle path that spans from New York Avenue to Whiting Lakefront Park as well as the Front Street spur; 
c.  Whihala public beach during the closed/off-season as designated by the park authority. 
(Ord. No. CC-2009-1818, §§ 1, 2, 7-21-09; Ord. No. CC-2015-1941, §§ 2, 3, 9-1-15) 
Cross reference- Parks and recreation, ch. 13. 
Sec. 3-19. - Vicious and potentially vicious animals. 
(a)  Applicability. Along with all other provisions of this chapter, this section shall also apply to vicious animals and potentially vicious animals as defined in section 3-1. 
(b)  Determination of a potential vicious animal: 
(1)  After an investigation which must be initiated within three days after the situation becomes known to the animal control officer or his/her designee, the animal control officer or his/her designee is authorized to make a determination whether an animal is potentially vicious based upon the faction listed in the definition of a potentially vicious animal in writing by certified mail or hand delivery with signature of that status within five days after the completion of the investigation. 
(2)  Following written notice to the owner, if the animal control officer or his/her designee has probably cause to believe that an animal is a potentially vicious animal and may pose a threat to public safety, said officer or designee may issue an order to impound and/or quarantine said animal pending disposition of the case or until the owner has fulfilled the requirements contained herein. The owner of the animal may be liable to the city for the costs and expenses of keeping the animal. 
(3)  Upon notice, the owner may, within seven calendar days after a determination that an animal is a potentially vicious animal, appeal the determination to the board of public works and safety. Said appeal shall be in writing. The board shall conduct a hearing into the matter at its next regularly scheduled meeting. The board may affirm the determination, modify the determination or reverse the determination. A decision by the board reversing the determination shall not affect the animal control officer or his/her designee's right to later declare an animal to be a potentially vicious animal or a vicious animal, or to determine that the animal poses a threat to public safety, for the animal's subsequent behavior. 
(c)  Determination of a vicious animal. 
(1)  After an investigation which must be initiated within three days after the situation becomes known to the animal control officer, the officer or his/her designee is authorized to make a determination whether an animal is vicious based on the factors listed above and shall notify the owner of the animal in writing by certified mail or hand delivery with signature of that status within five days after completing the investigation. 
(2)  Following notice to the owner, if the officer or his/her designee has probably cause and believes the animal to be a vicious animal and that the animal poses an imminent threat to public safety, said officer or designee may issue an order for the immediate impoundment and/or quarantine of said animal pending disposition of the case or until the animal owner has fulfilled the requirements contained herein. The owner of the animal shall be liable to the city for the costs and expenses of keeping the animal if the animal is determined to be a vicious animal. 
(3)  The owner may, within seven calendar days after a determination that an animal is a vicious animal, appeal the determination to the board of public works and safety. 
(4)  Said appeal shall be in writing. The board shall conduct a hearing into the matter at its next regularly scheduled meeting. The board may affirm the determination, modify the determination or reverse the determination. A decision by the board reversing the determination shall not affect the animal control officer or his/her designee's right to later declare an animal to be a potentially vicious animal or a vicious animal, or to determine that the animal poses a threat to public safety, for the animal's subsequent behavior. 
(d)  Exceptions. No animal shall be declared a vicious or potentially vicious animal if: 
(1)  The animal was used by a law enforcement official for legitimate law enforcement purposes; 
(2)  The threat, injury or damage was sustained by a person: 
a.  who was committing, at the time, a willful trespass or other tort upon the premises lawfully occupied by the owner of the animal; 
b.  who was provoking, tormenting, abusing, or assaulting the animal or who can be shown to have repeatedly, in the past, provoked, tormented, abused or assaulted the animal; or 
c.  who was committing or attempting to commit a crime; or 
(3)  The animal was: 
a.  responding to pain or injury, or was protecting itself or its offspring; or 
b.  Protecting or defending a human being within the immediate vicinity of the animal from an attack or assault. 
(e)  Consequences of a vicious or potential vicious animal determination. 
(1)  If the animal control officer or his/her designee determines that an animal is a potentially vicious animal under subsection (b) above, the owner shall comply with all of the provisions of this section and any other special security or care requirements said officer or designee may establish. 
(2)  If the animal control officer or his/her designee determines that an animal is a vicious animal under subsection (c), the owner shall comply with all of the provisions of this section and any other special security or care requirements said officer or designee may establish. 
(3)  The animal control officer or his/her designee may require impoundment and/or quarantine of the animal until the owner of the animal has satisfied all the requirements of the certificate or registration holding permit. The requirements must be met within 30 days. If, after 30 days, the owner has not satisfied all the requirements of the holding permit, the animal may be humanely destroyed on the 31st day. 
(f)  Vicious animal and potentially vicious animal registration and handling requirements. 
(1)  The animal control officer or his/her designee shall issue a certificate of registration to the owner of a potentially vicious animal if the owner establishes to the satisfaction of said officer or designee, all of the following: 
a.  The owner of the potentially vicious animal is 21 years of age or older; 
b.  A valid animal license has been issued by the City of Whiting; 
c.  The owner has proof of current rabies vaccination; 
d.  The owner has a proper enclosure to prevent the entry of any person or animal and the escape of said potentially vicious animal as described in subsection (a); 
e.  The owner has paid the annual fee pursuant to the City of Whiting Fee Schedule in addition to regular licensing fees, to register the potentially vicious animal; 
f.  The potentially vicious animal has been spayed or neutered; 
g.  The potentially vicious animal has been implanted with a microchip containing owner identification information and said information is registered with the city; 
h.  The owner shall enter the animal in a socialization behavior program approved by the city. 
(2)  The animal control officer or his/her designee shall issue a certificate of registration to the owner of a vicious animal if the owner, in addition to satisfying the requirements for registration of a potentially vicious animal pursuant to paragraph (1) above, establishes to the satisfaction of said officer or his/her designee all of the following: 
a.  The owner of the vicious animal has written permission of the property owner or homeowner's association, if applicable, where the vicious animal will be kept; 
b.  The owner will maintain the vicious animal exclusively on the owner's property except for medical treatment or examination; and 
c.  The owner of the vicious animal has posted on the premises a clearly visible written warning sign that there is a vicious animal on the property with a conspicuous warning symbol that informs children of the presence of a vicious animal. The sign shall be very visible from the public roadway or 50 feet, whichever is less. 
(3)  The officer of his/her designee may order the immediate impoundment or humane destruction of a vicious animal if the owner fails to abide by the conditions for registration or confinement or handling of a vicious animal. 
(4)  If any animal previously determined to be a potentially vicious animal has not exhibited any of the behaviors specified in subsection (a)(1)a. within the 36 months since the date of the potentially vicious animal determination, then that animal is eligible for a review of the determination with the potential for lifting the requirements of this section; provided, however, that that same animal may again be declared a vicious or potentially vicious animal if it again exhibits any of the specified behaviors. 
(g)  Vicious or potentially vicious animal owner responsibility. It shall be unlawful to: 
(1)  Keep an animal determined to be vicious or potentially vicious without a valid certificate of registration issued under subsection (f); 
(2)  Permit a potentially vicious animal to be outside a proper enclosure unless the potentially vicious animal is under the control of a responsible person as defined in subsection (a)(1)b., muzzled, and restrained by a lead not exceeding four feet in length. The muzzle shall be made in a manner that will not cause injury to the animal or interfere with its vision or respiration but shall prevent it from biting any human being or animal; 
(3)  Fail to maintain a vicious animal exclusively on the owner's property as required except for medical treatment or examination. When removed from the owner's property for said reason, the vicious animal shall be caged or under the control of a responsible person as defined herein, muzzled and restrained with a lead not exceeding four feet in length. The muzzle shall be made in a manner that will not cause injury to the animal or interfere with its vision or respiration but shall prevent it from biting any human being or animal; 
(4)  Fail to notify the animal control officer or the police department immediately upon escape if a vicious or potentially vicious animal is on the loose, is unconfined, or has attacked a human being, within five calendar days if the animal has died or within 24 hours if the animal has been sold or has been given away. If the vicious or potentially vicious animal has been sold or given away, the owner shall provide the animal control officer or his/her designee with the name, address, and telephone number of the new owner; 
(5)  Fail to surrender a vicious or potentially vicious animal to the animal control officer or his/her designee for safe confinement pending a disposition of the case when there is a reason to believe that the vicious or potentially vicious animal poses an imminent threat to public safety; or 
(6)  Fail to comply with any special security or care requirements for a vicious or potentially vicious animal which the officer or his/her designee may have established pursuant to the finding that the animal was potentially vicious or vicious. 
(Ord. No. CC-2007-1776, § III, 9-13-07) 
Sec. 3-20. - Feeding of non-domesticated animals prohibited. 
    No person shall feed or put out food stuff of any kind for any non-domesticated animal within the Whiting city limits. 
    Non-domesticated animal includes, but is not limited to, any animal which meets the definition of wild animal in W.M.C. § 3-1, seagulls, pigeons, squirrels, geese, ducks, and other waterfowl. 
    This prohibition does not apply to the feeding of family pets or to bird feeders placed on private property. 
    This section shall be enforced by any duly authorized police officer of the city and/or animal control officer. 
(Ord. No. CC-2005-1724, §§ 1-4, 7-19-05) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. CC-2005-1724, §§ 1-4, adopted July 19, 2005, was not specifically amendatory of the Code and has been included as § 3-20 at the discretion of the editor. 
Sec. 3-21. - Penalty. 
(a)  Any individual found in violation of this chapter shall be issued a citation from the animal control officer. The citation shall list the date, time, location and amount of the violation. The amount of each violation shall be prescribed in the fee schedule of the City of Whiting. 
(b)  The owner may elect to pay the amount of the violation or appear in City Court. The penalty shall be paid to the clerk-treasurer's office. 
    If the violation is for a second or subsequent offense within a twelve-month period, the animal control officer may designate on the ticket that the alleged violator must appear in court rather than pay the violation. 
(c)  If the violation has not been paid to the clerk-treasurer's office within five days of the issuance of the citation, the individual may be issued a court date and prosecuted in accordance with chapter 1, section 1-11 in the Code of Ordinances, City of Whiting, Indiana. 
(Ord. No. CC-2004-1679, 5-18-04; Ord. No. CC-2007-1776, §§ IV, V, 9-13-07) 
Editor's note- Formerly § 3-19. 
Chapter 4 - BUILDINGS AND BUILDING REGULATIONS[1] 
Footnotes:

Cross reference- Cable communications, ch. 5; fire prevention and protection, ch. 7; health and sanitation, ch. 8; housing, ch. 9; inspections under housing code, § 9-29; dancehalls, § 10-436 et seq.; mobile homes, ch. 11; community building in mobile home park, § 11-12; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 15; zoning, ch. 18; zoning of manufactured housing, § 18-356 et seq.; improvement location permit, § 18-532. 
State Law reference- Fire safety, building and equipment laws, IC 22-12 et seq.; fire prevention and building safety commission, IC 22-12-2-1 et seq.; fire and building services department, IC 22-12-5-1 et seq.; building inspection and regulations, IC 36-7-2-3 et seq.; enforcement of building standards, IC 36-7-9-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 4-1. - Building commissioner-Office created. 
    Pursuant to the home rule powers granted to the city in IC 36-1-3, there is hereby created in the city the office of building commissioner. The person chosen to fill such office shall be appointed by the mayor, subject to removal at the mayor's pleasure. In all matters relating to the duties of his office, the building commissioner shall be under the direction, supervision and control of the mayor except when otherwise expressly stipulated in this Code or by state statute. 
(Code 1962, § 4-206; Code 1979, § 2.24.010; Ord. No. CC 90-1421, § 2, 3-20-90) 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 
Sec. 4-2. - Same-Oath. 
    Before the building commissioner enters upon his duties, he shall take and subscribe an oath of office to be administered by the mayor. An official certificate of appointment along with the oath of office shall be filed with the city clerk-treasurer. 
(Code 1962, § 4-207; Code 1979, § 2.24.020; Ord. No. CC 90-1421, § 2, 3-20-90) 
Sec. 4-3. - Same-Salary. 
    The fixing of the salary of the building commissioner shall be done on a yearly basis by the common council. 
(Ord. No. CC 90-1421, § 2(2.24.030), 3-20-90) 
Sec. 4-4. - Building department-Established; supervised by building commissioner. 
    A building department is hereby established as a separate department of municipal government of the city. The building department shall be supervised by the duly qualified building commissioner appointed pursuant to this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1193(part), 1977; Code 1979, § 2.28.010; Ord. No. CC 90-1421, § 3, 3-20-90) 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 
Sec. 4-5. - Same-Operation; purpose. 
    The building department shall operate the same as any other department of city government with the necessary budget, office and transportation essential to provide the inspections and inspectors that are necessary to determine that all new and existing residential, commercial, and industrial construction within the city limits meet the requirements of the authorized building, electrical, mechanical, and plumbing codes promulgated into law by the state and adopted by ordinance by the common council. 
(Ord. No. 1193(part), 1977; Code 1979, § 2.28.020; Ord. No. CC 90-1421, § 3, 3-20-90) 
Sec. 4-6. - Certificate of occupancy-Required prior to furnishing of gas, electric or water service. 
    Prior to furnishing gas/electric or water service to any dwelling unit in the city, the public utility and the city water utility, respectively, shall require that the owner of such unit has complied with the City of Whiting Building Code as described in article II of this chapter. Evidence of compliance shall be by certificate of occupancy issued by the building department. 
(Ord. No. 1191, § 1, 1977; Code 1979, § 15.20.010; Ord. No. CC-2003-1648, 10-7-03) 
Cross reference- Utilities, ch. 16. 
Sec. 4-7. - Same-Applicability. 
    The provisions of section 4-6 shall apply to all dwelling units in the city, both new and existing. 
(Ord. No. 1191, § 2, 1977; Code 1979, § 15.20.020) 
Secs. 4-8-4-35. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - BUILDING CODE[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. CC-2003-1640, adopted Aug. 5, 2003, repealed art. II, §§ 4-36-4-54, in its entirety. Sections 1-22 of said ordinance have been included as a new article II to read as herein set out. Former art. II pertained to similar subject matter as enacted by Code 1979; as amended. See the Code Comparative Table for a detailed analysis of inclusion. 
Cross reference- Housing, ch. 9. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERAL REQUIREMENTS 

Sec. 4-36. - Title. 
    This ordinance and all material included herein by reference shall be known as the "Building Code of the City of Whiting, Indiana. 
(Ord. No. CC-2003-1640, § 1, 8-5-03) 
Sec. 4-37. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this article is to protect the life, public safety, health and general welfare of the citizens of the City of Whiting, Indiana, and shall be construed in such a manner to effectuate this purpose. 
(Ord. No. CC-2003-1640, § 2, 8-5-03) 
Sec. 4-38. - Definitions. 
    Unless otherwise clearly indicated by its context, the words and terms defined in this section shall have the specified meanings. 
    "Building commissioner", as used in this article, includes individuals employed by the building department that are authorized to represent the building commissioner. 
    "Class 1 structure", pursuant to IC 22-12-1-4, has the following definition: 
(a)  "Class 1 structure" means any part of the following: 
(1)  A building or structure that is intended to be or is occupied or otherwise used in any part by any of the following: 
(A)  The public. 
(B)  Three or more tenants. 
(C)  One or more persons who act as the employees of another. 
(2)  A site improvement affecting access by persons with physical disabilities to a building or structure described in subdivision (1). 
(3)  Any class of buildings or structures that the commission determines by rules to affect a building or structure described in subdivision (1), except buildings or structures described in subsections (c) through (e). 
(b)  Subsection (a)(1) includes a structure that contains three or more condominium units (as defined in IC 32-25-2-9) or other units that: 
(1)  Are intended to be or are used or leased by the owner of the unit; and 
(2)  Are not completely separated from each other by an unimproved space. 
(c)  Subsection (a)(1) does not include a building or structure that: 
(1)  Is intended to be or is used only for an agricultural purpose on the land where it is located; and 
(2)  Is not used for retail trade or is a stand used for retail sales of farm produce for eight or less consecutive months in a calendar year. 
(d)  Subsection (a)(1) does not include a Class 2 structure. 
(e)  Subsection (a)(1) does not include a vehicular bridge. 
(f)  Pursuant to IC 22-12-1-24, structure includes swimming pool. 
    "Class 2 structure", pursuant to IC 22-12-1-5, has the following definition: 
(a)  "Class 2 structure" means any part of the following: 
(1)  A building or structure that is intended to contain or contains only one dwelling unit or two dwelling units unless any part of the building or structure is regularly used as a Class 1 structure. 
(2)  An outbuilding for a structure described in subdivision (1), such as a garage, barn, or family swimming pool, unless any part of the outbuilding is regularly used as a Class 1 structure. 
(b)  Subsection (a) does not include a vehicular bridge. 
(c)  Pursuant to IC 22-12-1-24, structure includes swimming pool. 
    "Construction", pursuant to IC 22-12-1-7, means any of the following: 
(a)  Fabrication of any part of an industrialized building system or mobile structure for use at another site. 
(b)  Erection or assembly of any part of a Class 1 or Class 2 structure at the site where it will be used. 
(c)  Installation of any part of the permanent heating, ventilating, air conditioning, electrical, plumbing, sanitary, emergency detection, emergency communication, or fire or explosion suppression systems for a Class 1 or Class 2 structure at the site where it will be used. 
(d)  Work undertaken to alter, remodel, rehabilitate, or add to any part of a Class 1 or Class 2 structure. 
(e)  Work undertaken to relocate any part of a Class 1 or Class 2 structure, except a mobile structure. 
    "Industrialized building system", pursuant to IC 22-12-1-14, means any part of a building or other structure that is in whole or in substantial part fabricated in an off-site manufacturing facility for installation or assembly at the building site as part of a Class 1 structure, a Class 2 structure, or another building or structure. However, the term does not include a mobile structure or a system that is capable of inspection at the building site. 
    "Manufactured home", pursuant to IC 22-12-1-16, has the meaning set forth in 42 U.S.C. 5402 as it existed on January 1, 1984. This definition is as follows: "Manufactured home" means a structure, transportable in one or more sections, which, in the traveling mode, is eight body feet or more in width or forty body feet or more in length, or, when erected on site, is three hundred twenty or more square feet, and which is built on a permanent chassis and designed to be used as a dwelling with or without a permanent foundation when connected to the required utilities, and includes the plumbing, heating, air-conditioning, and electrical systems contained therein; except that such term shall include any structure which meets all the requirements of this paragraph except the size requirements and with respect to which the manufacturer voluntarily files a certification required by the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development and complies with the standards established under this 42 U.S.C. 5402. 
    "Mobile structure", pursuant to IC 22-12-1-17, has the following definition: 
(a)  "Mobile structure", means any part of a fabricated unit that is designed to be: 
(1)  Towed on its own chassis; and 
(2)  Connected to utilities for year-round occupancy or use as a Class 1 structure, a Class 2 structure, or another structure. 
(b)  The term includes the following: 
(1)  Two or more components that can be retracted for towing purposes and subsequently expanded for additional capacity. 
(2)  Two or more units that are separately towable but designed to be joined into one integral unit. 
    "Person", pursuant to IC 22-12-1-18, means an individual, corporation, limited liability company, partnership, unincorporated association, or governmental entity. 
    "Structure" means both Class 1 and Class 2 structures, unless specifically stated otherwise. 
    "Vehicular bridge", pursuant to IC 22-12-1-26, means any bridge that is neither: 
(a)  A pedestrian walkway; nor 
(b)  A passageway for light vehicles; suspended between two or more parts of a building or between two or more buildings. 
(Ord. No. CC-2003-1640, § 3, 8-5-03) 
Sec. 4-39. - Scope. 
(a)  All construction shall be accomplished in compliance with the provisions of this Building Ordinance. 
(b)  Pursuant to IC 22-13-2-6, this Building Ordinance shall not apply to industrialized building systems or mobile structures certified under IC 22-15-4; however, the provisions of this Building Ordinance and the rules promulgated by the fire prevention and building safety commission do apply to any construction related to an industrialized building system or mobile structure not certified under IC 22-15-4. 
(c)  Pursuant to IC 22-13-2-9, this Building Ordinance is not applicable to regulated amusement devices, regulated boilers, regulated pressure vessels, or regulated lifting devices. 
(Ord. No. CC-2003-1640, § 4, 8-5-03) 
Sec. 4-40. - Authority. 
    The building commissioner is hereby authorized and directed to administer and enforce the following: 
(1)  All of the provisions of this Building Ordinance. 
(2)  Variances granted in accordance with IC 22-13-2-11. 
(3)  Orders issued under IC 22-12-7. 
(Ord. No. CC-2003-1640, § 5, 8-5-03) 
Sec. 4-41. - Severability. 
    Should any provision (section, clause, phrase, word, or any other portion) of this article be declared by a court of competent jurisdiction to be invalid for any reason, the remaining provisions shall not be affected, if and only if such remaining provisions can, without the invalid provision or provisions be given the effect intended in adopting this ordinance. To this end, the provisions of this article are severable. 
(Ord. No. CC-2003-1640, § 6, 8-5-03) 
Sec. 4-42. - Effect of adoption on prior ordinance. 
    The expressed or implied repeal of amendment by this article of any other ordinance or part of any other ordinance does not affect any rights or liabilities accrued, penalties incurred, or proceedings begun prior to the effective date of this article. These rights, liabilities, and other proceedings are continued and penalties shall be imposed and enforced under the repealed or amended ordinance as if this article had not been adopted. 
(Ord. No. CC-2003-1640, § 7, 8-5-03) 
Secs. 4-43-4-46. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - BUILDING PERMITS 

Sec. 4-47. - Building permit required. 
    Construction is prohibited unless in conformity with a valid building permit obtained from the building commissioner prior to commencement of construction. Permits shall be required for the alteration, repair or construction of any building or structure when the cost exceeds $250.00. 
(Ord. No. CC-2003-1640, § 8, 8-5-03) 
Sec. 4-48. - Application for building permit. 
(a)  Any person required to have a building permit shall submit a complete application to the building commissioner. 
(b)  This application shall be submitted on a form prepared by the building commissioner, and may contain the following: 
(1)  Information that the building commissioner determines to be necessary to locate and contact the applicant. 
(2)  A clear and understandable copy of detailed plans and specifications drawn to scale which indicate in a precise manner the nature and location of all work to be accomplished. 
(3)  A plot plan drawn to scale. This plot plan shall reflect the location of the structure in relation to existing property lines and show streets, curbs and sidewalks and proposed changes or additions to such streets, curbs and sidewalks. 
(4)  If required by Indiana law or any rule of the fire prevention and building safety commission, a copy of a design release for the work to be done that has been issued by the state building commissioner and the state fire marshal pursuant to IC 22-15-3. 
(5)  Any additional information that the building commissioner finds to be necessary to determine that the construction will conform to all applicable building laws and will not violate any other applicable ordinances or laws. 
(6)  The fee shall be $17.50 for work costing between $250.00 and $1,000.00 of estimated worth. For work costing over $1,000.00, the fee shall be $7.50 for each $1,000.00 of estimated worth or part thereof, and shall be added to the original charge of $17.50. 
(c)  Application for a building permit shall be made by the person entitled to obtain the permit or by an employee or agent of that person. The building commissioner may require that such an employee or agent provide written authority to apply for a permit. 
(Ord. No. CC-2003-1640, § 9, 8-5-03; Ord. No. CC-2009-1811, § 4(e), 2-3-09; Ord. No. CC-2011-1868, § 4, 12-27-11) 
Sec. 4-49. - Issuance of building permit. 
    The building commissioner shall issue a building permit to a person after the person has submitted a complete application, including any applicable fee, provided that the proposed construction will conform to all applicable building laws and will not violate any other applicable ordinances or laws. 
(Ord. No. CC-2003-1640, § 10, 8-5-03) 
Sec. 4-50. - Certificate of occupancy. 
    No certificate of occupancy for any building or structure shall be issued unless such building or structure was constructed in compliance with the provisions of this Building Ordinance. It shall be unlawful to occupy any such building or structure unless a full, partial, or temporary certificate of occupancy has been issued by the building commissioner. 
(Ord. No. CC-2003-1640, § 11, 8-5-03) 
Sec. 4-51. - Fees. 
    Any fees applicable to building permits, inspections, or reinspection are prescribed in the fee schedule of the city. 
    In the event the building commissioner discovers a contractor or subcontractor doing work in the City of Whiting without having first obtained the necessary permit(s), the building commissioner shall be authorized to triple the permit fee. This shall be in addition to any other remedy permitted by this chapter. 
(Ord. No. CC-2004-1668, 3-16-04; Ord. No. CC-2005-1704, § 4, 3-1-05; Ord. No. CC-2009-1811, § 4(d), 2-3-09) 
Sec. 4-52. - Inspections. 
    After the issuance of any building permit under this article, the building commissioner shall make, or cause to be made, such inspections of the work being done under such permit as are necessary to ensure full compliance with the provisions of this article. 
    In the course of such inspections the building commissioner may charge additional fees for the following: 
(1)  An inspection that must take place outside of normal business hours at a time that is mutually agreed to by the building commissioner and the permit holder on the work being done. 
(2)  A re-inspection that must take place because of non-compliance by the permit holder on the work being done. 
(3)  A permit holder that does not meet with the building commissioner at a pre-arranged time for inspection. The building commissioner shall wait 15 minutes past the designated time, if the permit holder fails to arrive at a designated location during the allotted time, a fee may be assessed. 
(4)  If the building commissioner investigates a complaint regarding work being done without a permit or with an improper permit, the building commissioner may assess fees against the individual or contractor found in violation of the building ordinance. 
All fees described in this section are prescribed in the fee schedule of the city. 
(Ord. No. CC-2004-1668, 3-16-04) 
Sec. 4-53. - Additional requirement for application. 
    Whenever a building permit application is received for a multi-family structure, as part of the submission, the applicant shall be required to submit a plan describing how the solid waste for the occupants of such structure will be managed, including reduction, reuse and recycling steps taken to reduce the waste stream, which plan shall be subject to approval as provided under this article. 
(Ord. No. CC-2005-1711, § 1, 4-19-05) 
DIVISION 3. - INVESTIGATIONS AND INSPECTIONS OF CONSTRUCTION ACTIVITIES 

Sec. 4-54. - General authority to make inspections and investigations. 
(a)  All construction shall be subject to periodic inspections by the building commissioner irrespective of whether a building permit has been or is required to be obtained. 
(b)  The building commissioner may at any reasonable time go in, upon, around or about the premises where any structure subject to the provisions of this Building Ordinance or to the rules of the fire prevention and building safety commission is located for the purposes of inspection and investigation of such structure. Such inspection and investigation may be made before and/or after construction on the project is completed for the purposes of determining whether the structure meets building standards and procedures, and ascertaining whether the construction and procedures have been accomplished in a manner consistent with this Building Ordinance and the rules of the fire prevention and building safety commission. 
(Ord. No. CC-2003-1640, § 12, 8-5-03) 
Sec. 4-55. - Inspections by fire department. 
    The building commissioner and the fire department shall work cooperatively to conduct inspections and investigations to promote compliance with fire safety laws (The fire department has independent authority to conduct inspections and take enforcement actions under IC 36-8-17). The fee established for an investigation by the building or fire department is $50.00. 
(Ord. No. CC-2003-1640, § 13, 8-5-03; Ord. No. CC-2009-1811, § 4(c), 2-3-09) 
Secs. 4-56-4-59. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - ENFORCEMENT AND PENALTIES 

Sec. 4-60. - Withhold issuance of permits. 
(a)  Whenever a person which is either an applicant for a building permit or an obtainer of a building permit owes fees (including checks returned for insufficient funds, permit fees owed, or inspection fees owed) to the building commissioner the building commissioner may withhold the issuance of subsequently requested permits until such time that the debt is satisfied.
