(b)  Whenever a person applies for a building permit for a structure that is not being used or constructed in conformance with applicable provisions of an applicable zoning ordinance or other ordinance relating to land use, the building commissioner is authorized to withhold the issuance of requested permits until such time that the property is brought into conformance with applicable ordinances. 
(Ord. No. CC-2003-1640, § 14, 8-5-03) 
Sec. 4-61. - Permit revocation. 
    The building commissioner may revoke a building permit when any of the following are applicable: 
(1)  The application, plans or supporting documents contain a false statement or misrepresentation as to a material fact. 
(2)  The application, plans or supporting documents reflect a lack of compliance with building standards and procedures. 
(3)  There is failure to comply with the building ordinance. 
(4)  The structure for which the building permit has been issued is not being used or constructed in conformance with an applicable zoning ordinance or other ordinance relating to land use. 
(Ord. No. CC-2003-1640, § 15, 8-5-03) 
Sec. 4-62. - Stop-work order. 
(a)  The building commissioner may issue an order requiring suspension of the pertinent construction (stop-work order) in accordance with this section. 
(b)  The stop work order shall: 
(1)  Be in writing. 
(2)  State with specificity the construction to which it is applicable and the reason for its issuance. 
(3)  Be posted on the property in a conspicuous place. 
(4)  If practicable, be given to: 
a.  The person doing the construction; and 
b.  To the owner of the property or the owner's agent. 
(5)  The stop-work order shall state the conditions under which construction may be resumed. 
(c)  The building commissioner may issue a stop-work order if: 
(1)  Construction is proceeding in an unsafe manner, including, but not limited to, in violation of any standard set forth in this Building Ordinance or any state law pertaining to safety during construction. 
(2)  Construction is occurring in violation of this Building Ordinance or in such a manner that if construction is allowed to proceed, there is a reasonable probability that it will substantially difficult to correct the violation. 
(3)  Construction for which a building permit is required is proceeding without a building permit being in force. 
(d)  The issuance of a stop-work order shall in no way limit the operation of penalties provided elsewhere in this Building Ordinance. 
(Ord. No. CC-2003-1640, § 16, 8-5-03) 
Sec. 4-63. - Civil action. 
    Pursuant to IC 36-1-6-4, the city may initiate a civil action in a court of competent jurisdiction to restrain any person from violating a provision of this Building Ordinance. 
(Ord. No. CC-2003-1640, § 17, 8-5-03) 
Sec. 4-64. - Monetary penalty. 
    If any person shall violate any of the provisions of this article, or shall do any act prohibited herein, or shall fail to perform any duty lawfully enjoined, within the time prescribed by the building commissioner, or shall fail, neglect or refuse to obey any lawful order given by the building commissioner in connection with the provisions of this article, for each such violation, failure or refusal, such person shall be punished as provided in Section 1-11 - General Penalty in the Code of Ordinances of the City of Whiting, Indiana. 
(Ord. No. CC-2003-1640, § 18, 8-5-03) 
Sec. 4-65. - Right of appeal. 
    Any person aggrieved by an order issued under this Building Ordinance shall have the right to petition for review of any order of the building commissioner. Such a person may file a petition using either, or both, of the following procedures: 
1.  Appeal to the Fire Prevention and Building Safety Commission. 
(a)  A person aggrieved by an order issued under this Building Ordinance may submit a petition for review to the fire prevention and building safety commission, in accordance with IC 22-13-2-7. 
(b)  The commission may modify or reverse any order that covers a subject governed by IC 22-12, IC 22-13, IC 22-14, IC 22-15, a fire safety, or a building rule. 
(c)  The fire prevention and building safety commission must review orders that concern a Class 2 structure if the person aggrieved by the order petitions for review under IC 4-21.5-3-7 within 30 days after the issuance of the order. 
(d)  The fire prevention and building safety commission may review all other orders issued under this Building Ordinance that cover a subject governed by IC 22-12, IC 22-13, IC 22-14, IC 22-15, a fire safety rule, or a building rule. 
(e)  The review of an order by the fire prevention and building safety commission does not suspend the running of the time period under any statute in which a person must petition a court for judicial review of the order. 
2.  Appeal to the board of public works & safety. Any person aggrieved by an order issued under this Building Ordinance shall have the right to petition the Board of Public Works and Safety of the City of Whiting, Indiana for review of any order of the building commissioner. 
(Ord. No. CC-2003-1640, § 19, 8-5-03) 
Secs. 4-66, 4-67. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 5. - MINIMUM CONSTRUCTION STANDARDS 

Sec. 4-68. - Adoption of rules by reference. 
(a)  Pursuant to IC 22-13-2-3(b), the rules of the Indiana Fire Prevention and Building Safety Commission as set out in the following Articles of Title 675 of the Indiana Administrative Code are hereby incorporated by reference in this Code and shall include any later amendments to those rules. 
(1)  Article 13 - Building Codes 
a.  Fire and Building Safety Standards. 
b.  Indiana Building Code. 
(2)  Article 14-Indiana Residential Code 
(3)  Article 16-Indiana Plumbing Code 
(4)  Article 17-Indiana Electrical Code 
(5)  Article 18-Indiana Mechanical Code 
(6)  Article 19-Indiana Energy Conservation Code 
(7)  Article 20-Indiana Swimming Pool Code 
(8)  Article 22-Indiana Fire Code 
(9)  Article 25-Indiana Fuel Gas Code. 
(b)  Two copies of the above building rules incorporated by reference are on file in the office of the clerk for the legislative body for public inspection as required by IC 36-1-5-4. 
(c)  The building commissioner and the fire prevention and building safety commission may grant a variance to the fire safety laws and building laws adopted in this Building Ordinance. Pursuant to IC 22-13-2-7(b), a variance granted by the building commissioner is not effective until it has been approved by fire prevention and building safety commission. 
(Ord. No. CC-2003-1640, § 20, 8-5-03; Ord. No. CC-2004-1667, 3-2-04) 
Sec. 4-69. - Lifting devices located within a private residence. 
(a)  Pursuant to IC 22-12-1-22(b)(12), lifting devices, such as elevators and wheelchair lifts, located within a private residence are not regulated lifting devices. Therefore, the following standards applicable to lifting devices located within a private residence are incorporated by reference: 
(1)  Part 5.3, Private Residence Elevators, ANSI/ASME A17.1-2000, Safety Code for Elevators and Escalators published by the American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Three Park Avenue, New York, New York, 10016. 
(2)  Part 5.4, Private Residence Inclined Elevators, ANSI/ASME A17.1-2000, Safety Code for Elevators and Escalators published by the American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Three Park Avenue, New York, New York, 10016. 
(3)  Section 5, Private Residence Vertical Platform Lifts, ASME A18.1a, 2001 (Addenda to ASME 18.1-1999), Safety Standard for Platform and Stairway Chair Lifts, published by the American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Three Park Avenue, New York, New York 10016. 
(4)  Section 6, Private Residence Inclined Platform Lifts, ASME A18.1a, 2001 (Addenda to ASME 18.1-1999), Safety Standard for Platform and Stairway Chair Lifts, published by the American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Three Park Avenue, New York, New York 10016. 
(5)  Section 7, Private Inclined Stairway Lifts, ASME A18.1a, 2001 (Addenda to ASME 18.1-1999), Safety Standard for Platform and Stairway Chair Lifts, published by the American Society of Mechanical Engineers, Three Park Avenue, New York, New York 10016. 
(b)  Two (2) copies of the above lifting device standards incorporated by reference are on file in the office of the clerk for the legislative body for public inspection as required by IC 36-1-5-4. 
(Ord. No. CC-2003-1640, § 21, 8-5-03) 
Secs. 4-70-4-72. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 6. - EFFECTIVE DATE 

Sec. 4-73. - Effective date. 
    This Building Ordinance shall be in full force and effect beginning on the date on which both of the following have occurred: 
1.  The City Council has adopted this ordinance. 
2.  The Fire Prevention and Building Safety Commission has approved of this ordinance as required by IC 22-13-2-5. 
(Authentication of enactment according to local style). 
Approved this 3rd day of Feb., 2003, by the Fire Prevention and Building Safety Commission of the State of Indiana. 
____________ 
Chair of Commission 
(Ord. No. CC-2003-1640, § 22, 8-5-03) 
Secs. 4-74, 4-75. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - CONTRACTOR LICENSE[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Unified license bond for contractors, IC 22-11-3.1-1 et seq. 

Sec. 4-76. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Board means the board of public works and safety of the city. 
    Contractor means any natural person who, for compensation, undertakes to, or submits bids to, or does himself, or has done by others, construction, repair, alteration, remodeling, addition to, subtraction from, and improvement of structures and buildings, moves, wrecks, or demolishes any structure, and/or manages all or any of the above items, and who is responsible for all contracting within the entire project. "Contractor" also means any person except a licensed architect or registered professional engineer who, in any capacity other than as the employee of another for wages as the sole compensation, undertakes to construct, alter, repair, move, wreck or demolish any structure. The term includes a subcontractor or specialty contractor but does not include a person who furnishes materials or supplies. 
    Designee means the building commissioner of the city. 
    License means a certificate issued by the board or its designee, established pursuant to this article, which confers upon the holder the privilege to perform as a contractor. 
    Maintenance person means a person who is employed on a permanent basis to keep the premises of a business establishment in good repair. 
    Person means a natural person, partner, partnership, limited partnership, or any form of unincorporated enterprise, owned by two or more persons, and as applied to "corporation," in addition to the corporation, includes the officers, directors, and employees thereof. 
    Specialty contractor means, in addition to the foregoing definition of "contractor," one who specializes in a particular branch of the building construction industry and who shall be licensed and limited to such specific field of work (practice). 
(Code 1979, § 5.60.020; Ord. No. 1327, § 1(part), 1985) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 4-77. - Purpose. 
    The purpose, intent and policy of the common council is to safeguard the health, safety and public welfare of the citizens, the business of building construction and the persons engaged therein as defined in section 4-76. 
(Code 1979, § 5.60.010; Ord. No. 1327, § 1(part), 1985) 
Sec. 4-78. - Board and designee-Generally. 
    The board of public works and safety shall have general charge and responsibility of administering this article, and such administrative responsibility is hereby delegated to the board's designee, the building commissioner. 
(Code 1979, § 5.60.030; Ord. No. 1327, § 1(part), 1985) 
Sec. 4-79. - Same-Duties and policies. 
    It shall be the duty and policy of the board or its designee to: 
(1)  Prescribe the form of license and issue same, provided that all such licenses, while in force, shall be under the supervision and control of the board by and through its designee, the building commissioner. 
(2)  Issue licenses as contractors and specialty contractors to any person who qualifies and complies with the provisions of this article and pays the required license fee. 
It shall be the responsibility of the board or its designee to adopt and promulgate rules and regulations for the conduct of its business consistent with the guidelines and provisions of this article and do all things necessary to effect the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1979, § 5.60.040; Ord. No. 1327, § 1(part), 1985) 
Sec. 4-80. - License application. 
(a)  Who may be licensed. Except as otherwise provided in this article, any person over the age of 18 years, and any corporation which satisfies the further requirements of this article, shall be licensed by the board or its designee. 
(b)  Application generally. Persons seeking to be licensed as a contractor or specialty contractor shall file a written application on a form to be provided by the board or its designee, which shall contain such information as the board or its designee deems necessary to determine the qualifications and competency of the application. 
(c)  Managers, etc., to apply. The application, if filed on behalf of a firm, copartnership, association or corporation, also shall contain the name of the person who actively will manage the business and be licensed. Where a license is issued, authority to transact business thereunder as a contractor or specialty contractor shall be limited to one person (officer) of such business to be designated in the application and named in the license. Each other person or employee of such business desiring to act as a contractor or specialty contractor in connection with the business of the firm, copartnership or corporation shall be required to take out a separate license. 
(d)  Signing application; recommendations. All applications shall be signed by the applicant or its duly authorized officer and shall be accompanied by a recommendation as to the character and honesty of the applicant from two citizens of this county who are not related to the applicant, or in the case of a corporation, its officer, and who shall be owners of real estate in the county where the applicant proposes to actively engage in the contracting business. 
(e)  Investigation. Upon the filing of an application, the board or its designee may investigate the statements contained therein and, if any statements are found to be untrue, may refuse to examine or license the applicant. 
(f)  Examination-When required. Except as hereinafter provided, all individual applicants for a license as a contractor or a specialty contractor shall submit to and pass an oral and written examination conducted by the board or its designee. The contents of the examination herein required shall be developed by the designee of the board and he shall, for each license category, test the current levels of skills required of persons to be licensed in said category. 
(g)  Same-Notice. Upon receipt of application and proof of fee payment as prescribed in this article, it shall be the duty of the board or its designee to set a date and notify the applicant in writing at least five days before such examination. 
(h)  Reexamination. Any applicant who fails to qualify for a license as a contractor or specialty contractor may be reexamined at the next succeeding date for examination. But in any event, any applicant who fails to qualify for the examination on two successive attempts shall be ineligible for reexamination for one year subsequent to the date of his last examination. 
(i)  Bond. Before a license is issued by the board or its designee to any applicant, the board or its designee shall require the applicant to file a bond with the county recorder's office in the amount required by law. The bond shall be issued by a surety authorized to do business in the state and be conditioned upon the faithful observance of the ordinances and laws of the county and the state relating to contracting and all rules and regulations promulgated thereunder. The bond shall be in conformance with IC 22-11-3.1-2. 
(j)  Forfeiture of bond. Whenever any contractor's license issued under the provisions of this article is revoked by the board or its designee, the board or its designee shall deliver the bond of the offending licensee to the city attorney, who shall institute proceedings to forfeit the bond. 
(k)  Renewal of license generally. Every license issued under the provisions of this article shall expire at the end of each calendar year (December 31) and shall be renewed annually upon payment of the required renewal fees as a matter of right, if the applicant for renewal has not violated, during the preceding license period, any of the provisions of this article or the rules and regulations promulgated pursuant hereto. 
(l)  Application for renewal generally. Applications for renewal shall be filed with the board or its designee, on a form provided therefor, no later than 60 days prior to the expiration date of the licensee's current license. The application shall be accompanied by the required renewal fee. The board or its designee, upon the receipt of the application for renewal and the required renewal fee, shall issue the license in the category the applicant has previously held, provided that he had not violated any of the provisions of this article or the rules and regulations promulgated pursuant hereto. 
(m)  Violations by licensee. Upon receipt of an application for renewal from an applicant who, during the preceding licensed period, has violated any of the provisions of this article or any rules promulgated by the board or its designee, the board or its designee shall make such investigation as it deems necessary to determine the fitness of the applicant for renewal of his license. If the board or its designee determines after the investigation that a question exists as to whether the application under consideration should be renewed, they or he shall so advise the applicant and he shall thereafter, within 30 days, show cause to the board or its designee why his license should be renewed. If after hearing the board or its designee determines that the license should not be renewed, they or he shall notify the applicant, and the applicant thereafter may seek remedies under the laws of the state. 
(n)  Extension of license. No license shall be renewed during any period a licensee is under citation by the board or its designee for violation of any of the provisions of this article or any rules promulgated by the board or its designee; however, the board or its designee, in their or his discretion, may temporarily extend the applicant's current license for a period or periods of time not to exceed 30 days, or until the act complained of shall be heard by the board or its designee, and during any period of appeal provided for by this article. 
(o)  Fees-Amounts. The fees to be charged by and paid to the board's designee by licensees for all licenses and renewals thereof shall be as follows: 
(1)  A fee of $15.00 shall accompany any application for examination as a contractor. 
(2)  An additional fee of $100.00 shall be required for the initial issuance of the license upon successful passage of the examination. 
(3)  A fee of $50.00 shall be paid to the board or its designee for every annual renewal of a license. 
(4)  If a contractor begins work without a valid contractor's license, regardless of whether it is a new license or a renewal, the building commissioner is authorized to charge double the license fee so the initial contractor's license would be $200.00 and a renewal for the contractor's license would be $100.00. 
(p)  Same-Disposition. All fees assessed by the board and collected by the board's designee shall be paid into the office of the city clerk-treasurer and shall be credited to the city's general fund. 
(q)  Revocation or suspension of license. If a licensee shall have been convicted in this state or any other state of obtaining money under false pretenses, extortion, forgery, embezzlement, or criminal conspiracy to defraud, or other like offenses, and a duly certified or exemplified copy of the record in the proceeding is filed with the board or its designee, the board or its designee shall revoke the license issued to the licensee. In the event of the revocation or suspension of the license issued to any member of a copartnership, association, or corporation or an employee thereof, the license issued to the other copartner, member, or members of the firm, association or corporation shall be revoked unless, within the time fixed by the board or its designee, where a copartnership or association, the connection of the member or employee whose license has been suspended (or revoked) shall be severed and his interest in the copartnership or association, or his employment thereby in the case of an employee, shall be terminated, and his share in its activities brought to an end, or where a corporation, the offending officer or employee shall be discharged and shall have no further participation in the corporation activities. 
(r)  License required. It is unlawful for any person to engage in business or to do work as a contractor or subcontractor without have first obtained a license to do so in the manner provided in this chapter. Violations of this provision are subject to the penalty provisions of Whiting Municipal Code Section 1-11. 
(Code 1979, § 5.60.050; Ord. No. 1327, § 1(part), 1985; Ord. No. CC-2005-1704, § 1, 3-1-05; Ord. No. CC-2009-1811, § 4(a), 2-3-09; Ord. No. CC-2009-1823, § 1, 10-20-09; Ord. No. CC-2011-1868, § 4, 12-27-11) 
Sec. 4-81. - Violations and enforcement procedures. 
    The board or its designee may, upon their own motion, and shall, upon the verified complaint in writing of any person setting forth specifically the wrongful act or acts complained of, investigate any action or business transaction of any licensee and shall have the power to suspend or revoke a license issued by the board or its designee under the provisions of this article, if after due proceedings, as herein provided, it shall find the holder to have been guilty of the performance or attempt to perform any of the following prohibited acts or conduct: 
(1)  Willful or deliberate disregard of the applicable construction codes and ordinances of the city or any rules promulgated pursuant thereto. 
(2)  Aiding or abetting any unlicensed person to evade the provisions of this article or rules and regulations promulgated pursuant hereto. 
(3)  Knowingly combining or conspiring with unlicensed persons with the intent to evade the provisions of this article or the rules and regulations promulgated pursuant hereto. 
(4)  Acting in the capacity of a contractor under any license issued hereunder except in the name of the licensee as set forth on the issued license. 
(5)  Diversion of funds or property received from prosecution or completion of a specified construction project or operation, where as a result of the diversion, the contractor is or will be unable to complete or fulfill the terms of his obligation to contract. 
(6)  In the case of a contractor being adjudicated a bankrupt, or the making by a contractor of a composition with creditors or the appointment of a receiver for the licensee's business. 
(7)  Paying compensation in money or other valuable consideration to any person other than a licensed contractor for rendering services or doing any act required by this chapter to be performed by a licensed contractor holding a license. 
(8)  No violation of any provision of this article by an agent or employee of any licensed contractor shall be grounds for the suspension or revocation of the license of the employer. For the purpose of the preceding sentence, a course of dealing shown to have been consistently followed by an employee shall constitute prima facie evidence of knowledge on the part of the employer. 
(9)  Any person aggrieved by any action by the board or its designee in suspending, revoking, or failing to renew a license may seek judicial review thereof. 
(10)  The record of the board or its designee, or a duly certified copy thereof, shall be admissible in any proceeding at law or in equity in any court of competent jurisdiction in this or any other state in which the applicant or licensee charged or under investigation is a party, and where the issues involved in the proceedings are pertinent to the inquiry before the board or its designee, and the verdict or judgment of the court in any action at law or the decree of the court in any proceeding in equity shall be prima facie evidence of the facts at issue in the proceedings and necessarily adjudicated therein. 
(11)  The verdict in any prosecution in a court of record of this or any state in which the applicant licensee charged shall have been the defendant shall be conclusive as to the facts charged and at issue in such prosecution. 
(12)  After the revocation of any license, no new license shall be issued to the same licensee within a period of at least one year subsequent to the date of the revocation. 
(13)  Whenever a new license is issued by the board or its designee to any person whose license has been previously revoked, the issuance shall be treated as an initial issuance and the applicant shall be required to pay the fees, and in the case of contractors, shall be required to submit to the examination required of all other initial applicants. 
(14)  Any person who acts as a contractor without first obtaining a license from the board or its designee, as provided herein, or any person who continues to act as a contractor after his license has been suspended or revoked, shall be deemed to have violated this article. 
(15)  Any person who fails to renew his license and continues to act as a contractor after the same has expired shall be deemed to have violated this article. 
(Code 1979, § 5.60.060; Ord. No. 1327, § 1(part), 1985) 
Sec. 4-82. - Exceptions, exclusions. 
    This article does not apply to: 
(1)  An authorized employee of the United States, the state, the county, or any political subdivision thereof, so long as the employee does not hold himself out for hire and is acting within the scope of his employment. 
(2)  Public utilities, where construction, maintenance, and development work is performed by their own forces and incidental to their business. 
(3)  The owner-occupant of a dwelling of a two or less family residential unit when said owner-occupant is installing, altering, or repairing such residential unit. 
(4)  Any construction, alteration, improvement, or repair of improvements located on any site and project where state and federal law supersedes this article. 
(5)  Any individual who is employed or acts as a maintenance person at his place of employment. 
(Code 1979, § 5.60.070; Ord. No. 1327, § 1(part), 1985) 
Sec. 4-83. - Enforcement of building codes; inspections. 
    Nothing in this article shall limit the power of the city to regulate the quality and character of work performed by contractors through the enforcement of building codes and inspections. The building commissioner may impose fees for inspection and reinspection as required to enforce this article. Applicable fees are prescribed in the fee schedule of the city. 
(Code 1979, § 5.60.080; Ord. No. 1327, § 1(part), 1985; Ord. No. CC-2004-1668, 3-16-04) 
Sec. 4-84. - Renewal. 
    Any person actively engaged in the contracting business for a period of one year prior to or on the effective date of the ordinance codified in this article shall be issued a license without the requirement of taking an examination if such person makes application to the board or its designee and furnishes adequate proof of his entitlement to be licensed in the category in which he makes application, and pays the fees required by this article. 
(Code 1979, § 5.60.090; Ord. No. 1327, § 1(part), 1985) 
Sec. 4-85. - Legal proceedings. 
    Where in any proceeding before the board or its designee, any contractor or witness fails or refuses to attend a request issued by the board or its designee, or appearing, refuses to testify or refuses to provide any information or data, the production of which is called for by the board or its designee, such failure or refusal shall institute legal action to be taken by the board or its designee and shall be enforced by any court of this state. 
(Code 1979, § 5.60.100; Ord. No. 1327, § 1(part), 1985) 
Sec. 4-86. - Authorization for rules. 
    The board or its designee is authorized and empowered to adopt, fix, and establish all rules and regulations necessary for the proper administration of the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1979, § 5.60.110; Ord. No. 1327, § 1(part), 1985) 
Sec. 4-87. - Insurance. 
    Liability insurance shall be required with the combined limits specified in IC 34-13-3-4 from each applicant. A certificate or copy of the insurance policy shall be filed with the board or its designee by the licensed general contractor, specialty contractor or subcontractors as provided in this article. All applicants shall also be required to provide either a certificate or Worker's Compensation insurance coverage or Indiana Form WCE-1, a Worker's Compensation Clearance Certificate Application. 
(Code 1979, § 5.60.130; Ord. No. 1327, § 1(part), 1985; Ord. No. CC-99-1584, 11-16-99; Ord. No. CC-2005-1704, § 2, 3-1-05) 
Sec. 4-88. - Stop work orders. 
    In the event the building commissioner discovers a contractor or subcontractor doing work in the City of Whiting without having first obtained both the applicable license and permit(s), the building commissioner shall have the authority to issue a stop work order until such time as the applicable license and/or permit(s) are obtained. In addition, the building commissioner has the authority to issue a citation for the Whiting City Court for any violations of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. CC-2005-1704, § 3, 3-1-05) 
Sec. 4-89. - Validity of license. 
    In accordance with I.C. 22-11-3.1-4, a license issued by the city is valid until the contractor to whom the license was issued fails to perform any work under that license for a period of five years. At such time, the city may require an initial license fee be paid rather than a renewal fee. Any licensed contractor shall be required to pay the renewal fee for every year in order to do work in the city. 
(Ord. No. CC-2009-1823, § 3, 10-20-09) 
Secs. 4-90-4-110. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - ELECTRICITY[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Cross reference- Cable communications, ch. 5. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 4-111. - Title. 
    This article shall be known as the Whiting Electrical Code. 
(Code 1962, § 8-101; Code 1979, § 5.24.010) 
Sec. 4-112. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Chief electrical inspector means the department head of the electrical inspection department. 
    Electrical commission means the electrical commission described in division 2. 
    Electrical contractor means any person engaged in the business of, or holding himself out to the public as, engaged in the business of installing, altering, repairing or contracting to install or repair wires, conductors, motors, conduit, conduit fittings, wire supports, raceways, electrical signs and erections, devices, appliances, or equipment for the transmission or use of electrical current. 
    Electrical inspection department means the city-operated department created for the purpose of administering this article. 
    Electrical work means any work of installing, maintaining, altering, or repairing any electrical wiring, including conduit, conduit fittings, raceways, sign erections, motors, devices, and appliances for the transmission or use of electric current. 
    Examining board means a board which will conduct examinations for other than license holders. 
    License holder means the individual who has passed the required examination and who has been issued a license. 
(Code 1962, § 8-102(part); Code 1979, § 5.24.020) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 4-113. - Applicability. 
    The provisions of this article do not apply to radio, television, or telegraph apparatus, nor do they apply to the wiring, apparatus, or equipment installed for or by public utilities, including common carriers, which are under the jurisdiction of the state public service commission for use in their operations as public utilities; nor shall such provisions apply to manufacturers of electric apparatus in conducting tests of apparatus of their own manufacture. A public service utility shall not install its customers' light or power service outlet, their distribution center, or their switches or their meter boxes, in or on their property, but the public service utility may install and connect its services, meters, and metering equipment on the customers' premises; however, in no event shall the service be energized until approval is given by the electrical inspection department. 
(Code 1962, § 8-102(part); Code 1979, § 5.24.030) 
Sec. 4-114. - Electrical inspection department-Established; headed by chief electrical inspector. 
(a)  There is created and constituted the office of electrical inspector, in this article called the electrical inspection department. The mayor shall appoint a competent person to be known as chief electrical inspector and such assistants as may be necessary to enforce this article. The chief electrical inspector shall be a practical electrician well versed in all types of electrical construction work, with not less than five years of electrical experience, and he shall have continuously resided in the city for at least five years immediately prior to his appointment. 
(b)  The chief electrical inspector and his assistants shall be required to give surety bonds in the sum of $8,500.00. The cost of the bond shall be paid by the city. 
(c)  The city shall appropriate money sufficient to operate the electrical inspection department. 
(Code 1962, § 8-104; Code 1979, § 2.32.010) 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 
Sec. 4-115. - Same-Powers and duties. 
(a)  The electrical inspection department shall have immediate supervision of all electrical work according to the rules established by the electrical commission and ordinances of the city. 
(b)  The electrical inspection department shall issue permits for installation and alteration of electrical work where application for such permit shall be made in accordance with the rules and regulations applicable thereto; provided, however, that no permit shall be issued for installing or altering electrical work unless the person applying for such permit is licensed, except that no owner of property desiring to do his own electrical work in his own property shall be required to be licensed. 
(c)  The electrical inspection department shall inspect all electrical installations authorized by any permit to assure compliance with provisions of this article or amendments thereto, approving or condemning the work in whole or in part as the condition requires. 
(d)  The electrical inspection department shall maintain an official record of all persons lawfully entitled to carry on or engage in the business of electrical work in the city. 
(e)  The electrical inspection department shall require the owner, lessee or their representative to submit specifications, drawings, descriptions, and/or diagrams necessary to show clearly the character, kind and extent of electrical work covered for an installation. If found to be in conformity with the requirements of this article and all other laws or ordinances, the electrical inspector shall endorse it in writing or stamp plans and specifications, "Approved." 
(f)  The chief electrical inspector or the electrical inspectors shall have the power to enter any building or premises in order to examine the electrical work in such building or premises, and it shall be unlawful for any person to interfere with them in the performance of their duties. 
(g)  No electrical work of any kind including conduit and raceways shall be concealed or enclosed until it has been inspected by the electrical inspection department. No electrical services shall be supplied to any building or premises until the electrical work in such building or premises has been inspected and approved by the electrical inspection department. 
(h)  Whenever, in the opinion of the chief electrical inspector, it is necessary to call upon the police department for aid and assistance in carrying out or enforcing any of the provisions of this article, governing the inspection of electrical work, he shall have the authority to do so, and it shall be the duty of the police department, when called upon by the chief electrical inspector, to act according to the instructions of and to perform such duties as may be required by such chief electrical inspector in order to enforce or put into effect the provisions of this article. 
(i)  The electrical inspection department shall charge for its service in accordance with the schedule of permits and fees adopted by the city council, except as otherwise provided in this article. 
(j)  All electrical construction and installations, all materials, devices, appliances and equipment installed or used in connection with electrical work and the operation of all electrical apparatus within the city, relative to the construction, repair or maintenance of places of employment, public buildings, tenant homes and other buildings, including private residences and outbuildings in connection therewith, buildings used for agricultural purposes and temporary buildings or additions used for construction purposes, only, shall conform to the rules of the state fire marshal, the rules and regulations of the city, the electrical commission, and the electrical inspection department thereof, and the rules and regulations of the state fire prevention and building safety commission, approved and promulgated for the construction, repair or maintenance of public buildings and tenant homes. Two copies of the rules and regulations of the commission have been filed in the office of the city clerk-treasurer for public inspection and are adopted, approved, and made a part of this article as fully as though every word, clause, phrase, sentence, section and part thereof has been set out herein. 
(Code 1962, § 8-105; Code 1979, § 2.32.020) 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and protection, ch. 7. 
State Law reference- Fire safety, building and equipment laws, IC 22-12 et seq.; state fire marshal, IC 22-14-2-1 et seq. 
Secs. 4-116-4-125. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - ELECTRICAL COMMISSION[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 

Sec. 4-126. - Established. 
    There is established a commission which shall be known as the electrical commission of the city. The commission shall have five members consisting of the chief electrical inspector and four other members appointed by the mayor and approved by the board of public works and safety. 
(Code 1962, § 8-103(a)(part); Code 1979, § 2.56.010; Ord. No. CC-2004-1663, 2-17-04) 
Sec. 4-127. - Powers and duties. 
    The electrical commission shall have the following powers and duties in the licensing and regulating of electrical contractors, their license holder and the issuing of homeowner's permits. It shall be the duty of the commission to formulate and recommend safe and practical standards and specifications, using as a minimum the requirements of the National Electric Code, 2002; as amended from time to time, for the installation and alteration of electrical work designed to meet the necessities and conditions that prevail in the city, to recommend reasonable rules and regulations, providing penalty for violation thereof, and governing the issuance of permits by the electrical inspection department. The standards and specifications, rules and regulations governing the issuance of permits shall become effective upon the passage of an ordinance adopting the same by the common council. All fees are established in the fee schedule for the city, and shall be paid to the office of the clerk-treasurer. The electrical commission shall examine all applicants for an electrical license. The commission shall have the authority to revoke licenses or to suspend permit privileges for cause. 
(Code 1962, § 8-103(a)(part); Code 1979, § 2.56.020; Ord. No. CC-2004-1663, 2-17-04) 
Sec. 4-128. - Special meetings to formulate future actions. 
    Upon the appointment of the electrical commission, the chief electrical inspector shall notify all members of the commission of a special meeting to formulate its actions in the future and to elect a member of the commission to act as chairman. 
(Code 1962, § 8-103(b); Code 1979, § 2.56.030; Ord. No. CC-2004-1663, 2-17-04) 
Sec. 4-129. - Quorum. 
    Three members of the electrical commission shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of any business. A majority vote of the members present shall be sufficient to take official action on any matter. 
(Code 1962, § 8-103(c); Code 1979, § 2.56.040) 
Sec. 4-130. - Meetings to hear appeal; fees required. 
    The chief electrical inspector may call a meeting of the electrical commission for special causes. At any time the commission meets to hear an appellant, the appellant shall pay a fee as prescribed in the city fee schedule, payable to the clerk-treasurer. A fee shall also apply to those applicants taking an examination to do electrical work under this division; as prescribed in the fee schedule of the city, payable to the clerk-treasurer. 
(Code 1962, § 8-103(d); Code 1979, § 2.56.050; Ord. No. CC-2004-1663, 2-17-04) 
Sec. 4-131. - Recordkeeping of official proceedings and license holders. 
    The chief electrical inspector or his designate shall keep a full and correct record of the official proceedings of the commission. The city clerk-treasurer of other designated official shall keep an up-to-date record specifying names and addresses of all license holders with the city. 
(Code 1962, § 8-103(e); Code 1979, § 2.56.060; Ord. No. CC-2004-1663, 2-17-04) 
Sec. 4-132. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. CC-2004-1663, adopted Feb. 17, 2004, repealed § 4-132 in its entirety. Formerly, said section pertained to compensation of members as enacted by Code 1962, § 8-103(f); as amended. 
Secs. 4-133-4-145. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - ELECTRICIANS[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference- Local business regulations, IC 36-8-2-10. 

Sec. 4-146. - License-Examination of applicants. 
(a)  In order to safeguard persons and buildings and their contents from hazards arising from the use of electricity, any person desiring to operate an electrical contractor business or work as a licensed electrician in the city, shall be required to pass an examination administered by the electrical commission as to his or her ability and qualifications in the installation of electrical work. 
(b)  The applicant for an electrical license shall be notified in writing of the date of his or her examination at least five days before such date. Such examinations shall be held, as the electrical commission deems necessary. The electrical commission shall, by its rules and regulations, establish the type and manner of determining the result of such examination, which all applicants shall meet to entitle them to a license. The fee payable for such examination is provided in the fee schedule for the city. 
(c)  Any applicant failing to qualify, shall not be eligible to file an application for examination again for a period of three months from the date on which he or she failed his examination, and no other person of the same firm, partnership or corporation or an individual applicant shall be entitled to an examination before the expiration of the three-month period. 
(Code 1962, § 8-106; Code 1979, § 5.24.040; Ord. No. CC-2004-1663, 2-17-04) 
Sec. 4-147. - Same-Issuance. 
    Upon compliance with all requirements of this article, the clerk-treasurer shall issue a license for each successful applicant, the license shall be displayed in compliance with the general licensing provisions of this article. 
(Code 1962, § 8-111; Code 1979, § 5.24.050; Ord. No. CC-2004-1663, 2-17-04) 
Sec. 4-148. - Same-Fees. 
    Before a license is issued under this article, the appropriation fee shall be paid to the clerk-treasurer as specified in the city fee schedule. 
(Code 1962, § 8-109; Code 1979, § 5.24.060; Ord. No. 1395, § 1, 1989; Ord. No. CC-2004-1663, 2-17-04; Ord. No. CC-2009-1823, § 2, 10-20-09) 
Sec. 4-149. - Bond and insurance requirements. 
    Any applicant, having qualified as a holder of an electrical license, shall file with the clerk-treasurer, proper proof of indemnity bond and insurance specified in the city's application for contractor's license. 
(Code 1962, § 8-107; Code 1979, § 5.24.070; Ord. No. 1395, § 2, 1989; Ord. No. CC-2004-1663, 2-17-04) 
Sec. 4-150. - Transfer of license. 
    No license or renewal thereof, granted under the provisions of this article, shall be assignable or transferable, and every such license or renewal thereof shall specify the name of the person to whom the same was issued, as well as the name of the electrical contractor represented by the licensed holder. 
(Code 1962, § 8-112; Code 1979, § 5.24.080) 
Sec. 4-151. - Renewal of license. 
    Any license holder under this article who allows the same to lapse shall not be entitled to renew the same without re-examination, paying the amount prescribed in the city fee schedule for a new license. 
    All applications for renewal must be certified in writing each year by the chief electrical inspector before they can be issued. In applying for a renewal license, the old license shall be presented, together with the bond required in the bond and insurance requirements and a receipt showing payment in full for fee due at the time of application for the renewal license. 
(Code 1962, § 8-110; Code 1979, § 5.24.090; Ord. No. CC-2004-1663, 2-17-04) 
Sec. 4-152. - Special requirements for license holders; license revocation upon violation. 
    All persons licensed under this article shall perform their work in a proper manner. No license holder shall allow his name to be used by any other person, directly or indirectly, either to obtain permits or to do any electrical work under his license. For violation of these requirements, revocation of the license may be ordered. 
(Code 1962, § 8-113; Code 1979, § 5.24.100) 
Sec. 4-153. - Suit of license holder. 
(a)  All electrical work within the city requires a permit. If a permit has not been obtained, and work is in progress or has been completed, the matter may be sent to the city court through the chief electrical inspector. All work performed must be inspected and approved by the chief electrical inspector or designate before the closing of walls or ceilings and upon completion of the work done. 
(b)  If the business association between the license holder and the electrical contractor terminates, the license holder shall immediately notify the city, and the right of the electrical contractor to do business in the city shall terminate immediately. The contractor may apply for his own individual license to the electrical commission. 
(c)  The license holder may authorize a new person to be his applicant, and upon notice to the commission, the commission may call a special meeting for the purpose of examining the applicant. If the applicant fails the examination, then upon the request of the license holder, the commission will appoint an acting bond supervisor acceptable to the license holder for a temporary period not to exceed six months from the date of original termination. If the license holder's authorized applicant does not pass the license examination by the expiration of the six-month period, the license shall be permanently terminated. 
(Code 1962, § 8-108; Code 1979, § 5.24.110; Ord. No. CC-2004-1663, 2-17-04) 
Sec. 4-154. - Homeowner permit. 
    Any owner of property in the city may apply for a homeowner's permit to do electrical work on his own property. A separate test by the electrical commission shall be given to the homeowner. Upon passage of this test a permit may be issued to the homeowner. This permit is intended for work done on owner-occupied single-family homes. Work done on rental properties must be accomplished by a licensed individual or firm with the city. The fees for the homeowner permit and test are prescribed in the fee schedule of the city. 
(Code 1962, § 8-114; Code 1979, § 5.24.120; Ord. No. CC-2004-1663, 2-17-04) 
Sec. 4-155. - Permit fees. 
    Refer to city fee schedule for applicable permit fees. 
(Code 1962, § 8-115; Code 1979, § 5.24.130; Ord. No. CC-2004-1663, 2-17-04) 
Secs. 4-156-4-175. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - PROPERTY MAINTENANCE[7] 
Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Cross reference- Housing, ch. 9. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 4-176. - Improper maintenance generally. 
(a)  Any owner, tenant or resident who fails to maintain a house, building, structure or real estate shall be in violation of this Code if the lack of maintenance results in any of the following: 
(1)  Structural deterioration rendering the house, building or structure unsafe. 
(2)  Unsafe or unhealthy condition of public utilities used in connection with the house, building or structure. 
(3)  The existence of any condition conductive to the propagation of illness or disease. 
(4)  A gross and notorious state of general disrepair or dilapidation, or an imminent hazard to the public health, safety, and welfare, such that a blight on the neighborhood exists causing economic devaluation of surrounding properties. 
(b)  The failure to properly maintain a house, building, structure or real estate, as the same set forth in subsection (a) of this section, shall be deemed a public nuisance. An owner, tenant or resident found responsible for such violation shall be subject to a fine not to exceed $2,500.00; each day of violation shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(c)  The building commissioner shall be empowered to maintain an action in court for the abatement of the nuisance and the recovery of all costs and expenses of the action, including reasonable attorney fees. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1464, § 3, 5-4-93) 
Secs. 4-177-4-190. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PROPERTY MAINTENANCE CODE 

Sec. 4-191. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Accessory structure means a structure on the same lot with, and of a nature customarily incidental and subordinate to, the principal use or structure, not including temporary buildings for construction purposes. Such accessory uses or structures generally include but are not limited to: garages, sheds, storage buildings, carports, garden houses, playhouses, or greenhouses. 
    Building commissioner means the building commissioner of the city or his duly appointed agent. 
    Deterioration means the degeneration in the condition of a building or part thereof, characterized by holes, breaks, rot, crumbling, peeling, rusting or other evidence of physical decay or neglect, lack of maintenance or excessive use. 
    Exposed to public view refers to any premises or any part thereof, or any building or any part thereof, which may be lawfully viewed by the public. 
    Exterior of the premises means open space on the premises outside of any building thereon. 
    Extermination means the control and elimination of insects, rodents and vermin or other pests on the premises which constitute a health hazard. 
    Foundation means that portion of the building or structure generally below ground which supports the upper portions of the building or structure. 
    Garbage means putrescible animal and vegetable waste resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking and consumption of food. 
    Habitable rooms means rooms used or designed for use by one or more persons for living or sleeping or cooking and eating, but not including bathrooms, water closet compartments, laundries, serving and storage pantries. Corridors, foyers, vestibules, cellars, heater rooms, boiler rooms, utility rooms, and other rooms or spaces that are not used frequently or for an extended period of time or that have less than 50 square feet of superficial floor area shall not be considered habitable rooms. 
    Infestation means the longterm or extended presence of insects, rodents, vermin or other pests on the premises which constitute a health hazard. 
    Mixed occupancy means any building containing one or more dwelling units or rooming units and also having a portion thereof containing a permitted nonresidential use. 
    Nuisance means: 
(1)  Residential and nonresidential properties which by lack of maintenance and because of progressive deterioration have the effect of creating blighted areas: 
a.  A "blighted area" may be either improved or vacant property within the territorial limits of the city. 
b.  In evaluating whether a particular property is blighted, the presence of one or more of the following factors can be used to support the conclusion that the particular property in question is blighted property. However, the factors should be viewed in totality of all the facts and circumstances as they relate to the property in question and must be present to such an extent that a reasonable person would conclude that public intervention is appropriate or necessary. Those factors supporting conclusion of "blight" include: 
1.  Age. 
2.  Dilapidation. 
3.  Obsolescence. 
4.  Illegal use of individual structures. 
5.  Presence of structures below minimum code standards. 
6.  Excessive vacancies. 
7.  Overcrowding of structures and community facilities. 
8.  Lack of ventilation, light, or sanitary facilities. 
9.  Inadequate utilities. 
10.  Excessive land coverage. 
11.  Deleterious land use or layout. 
12.  Depreciation of physical maintenance. 
(2)  Any attractive nuisance which may prove detrimental to the health or safety of children whether in a building, on the premises of a building or upon an unoccupied lot. This includes, but is not limited to: buildings under construction, abandoned construction in progress sites, abandoned wells, shafts, basements, excavations, abandoned refrigerators, motor vehicles, any structurally unsound fences or structures, lumber, garbage or refuse, fences, debris, or vegetation such as poison ivy, poison oak, or poison sumac which may prove hazardous to the public. 
(3)  Fire hazards. 
    Operator means any person who has charge, care or control of a dwelling or premises, or a part thereof, whether with or without the knowledge and consent of the owner. 
    Owner means any person who, alone or jointly or severally with others, shall have legal or equitable title to any premises, with or without accompanying, actual possession thereof; or shall have charge, care or control of any dwelling unit, as owner or as executor, executrix, administrator, administratrix, trustee, receiver, or guardian of the estate, or as a mortgagee in possession regardless of how such possession was obtained. Any person who is a lessee subletting or reassigning any part or all of any dwelling or dwelling unit shall be deemed to be a co-owner with the lessor and shall have joint responsibility over the portion of the premises sublet or assigned by said lessee. 
    Parties in interest means all individuals, associations, and corporations who have interest of record in a building and any who are in actual possession thereof. 
    Premises means a lot, plot or parcel of land including the buildings, structures and/or secondary structures thereon. 
    Public authority means any person who is in charge of any department or branch of the government of the city, the county or the state relating to health, fire, building regulations or other activities concerning buildings and structures in the city. 
    Refuse means all putrescible and nonputrescible solid waste (except body wastes), including but not limited to: garbage, rubbish, ashes, street cleaning, dead animals, abandoned automobiles and solid market and industrial wastes. 
    Rubbish means nonputrescible solid wastes consisting of both combustible and noncombustible wastes such as paper, wrapping, cigarettes, cardboard, tin cans, yard clippings, leaves, wood, glass, bedding, crockery, or similar materials. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1506, § 1, 3-15-94) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 4-192. - Application of division. 
(a)  Every residential, nonresidential or mixed occupancy building and the land on which it is situated, used or intended to be used for dwelling, commercial, business or industrial occupancy, shall comply with the provisions of this division, whether or not such building is under construction or has been constructed, altered or repaired before or after the enactment of this division, and irrespective of any permits or licenses which shall have been issued for the use or occupancy of the building or premises, for the construction or repair of the building, or for the installation or repair of equipment or facilities prior to the effective date of Ordinance No. CC 93-1506. 
(b)  In any case where the provisions of this division impose a higher standard than set forth in any other ordinance provision of the city or statute of the state, then the standards set forth herein shall prevail, but if the provisions of this division impose a lower standard than any other ordinance provision of the city or statute of the state, then the higher standard contained in any other such ordinance provision or law shall prevail. 
(c)  No license or permit or other certification of compliance with this division shall constitute a defense against any violation of any other ordinance provision of the city applicable to any structure or premises, nor shall any provisions herein relieve any owner, operator or occupant from complying with any such other provision, nor any official of the city from enforcing any such other provision. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1506, § 2, 3-15-94) 
Sec. 4-193. - Duties and responsibilities of owners and operators. 
(a)  Maintenance of premises. 
(1)  Free of hazards and unsanitary conditions. 
a.  The exterior of the premises and all structures thereon shall be kept free of all nuisances, and any hazards to the safety of the occupant(s), pedestrians and other persons utilizing the premises, and free of unsanitary conditions. Any of the foregoing shall be promptly removed and abated by the owner or operator. 
b.  It shall be the duty of the owner or operator to keep the premises free of hazards which include but are not limited to the following: 
1.  Refuse. Brush, weeds, broken glass, stumps, roots, obnoxious vegetation and growth, filth, garbage, trash, and debris. 
2.  Natural growth. Dead and dying trees and limbs or other natural growth which, by reason of rotting or deteriorating conditions or storm damage, constitute a hazard to persons in the vicinity thereof. Trees shall be kept properly pruned and trimmed to prevent such conditions. Topping shall not be an acceptable form of trimming. Existing ordinances of the city dealing with trees, their maintenance, removal and all other aspects of their care shall apply for purposes of this division. 
3.  Ground surface hazards or unsanitary conditions. Holes, excavations, breaks, projections, obstructions, icy conditions, uncleared snow, and excretion of pets and other animals on paths, walks, driveways, parking lots and parking areas, and other parts of the premises which are accessible to holes and excavations shall be filled, repaired, or kept clear of all ground surface hazards. 
4.  Recurring accumulations of stormwater. Adequate stormwater runoff drains shall be provided and maintained to eliminate any recurrent or excessive accumulation of stormwater on the premises. 
5.  Areas of infestation and its source. 
6.  Foundation deterioration. 
(2)  Foundations. 
a.  Foundations shall be kept structurally sound and shall be free of critical and major defects. Foundation walls shall: 
1.  Support the loads placed on them without indications of settlement, bulge or buckle. 
2.  Prevent the entrance of water or excess moisture into the basement or crawl spaces. Cracks or holes in the wall or rotting of the wall which prevent the proper function of the foundation are considered faults for purposes of this division. Individual footings under exterior or interior columns should support the loads placed on them without indications of differential settlement. 
b.  Examples of critical and major foundation defects include: 
1.  Settlement to a degree that structural components supported by the foundation are detrimentally affected. Large cracks, sagging walls, out-of-plumb corners, vertical separations of cracking, and sloping floors are often indicators of a settling foundation. 
2.  Extreme crumbling, failure of mortar joints or other deterioration such as that caused by heaving or buckling that would require replacement of the foundation. 
3.  Lack of adequate foundation support in a permanent building. 
4.  Other than concrete or masonry foundation in a permanent structure. 
5.  Foundation wall thickness less than that of wall supported. 
6.  Crack penetrating encompasses the entire thickness of foundation wall and extending from its top to base; cracks of this nature will be visible from both exterior and interior. 
7.  Multiple or numerous cracks not penetrating entire thickness of the foundation wall. 
8.  Foundation wall not extending above grade. 
9.  Flaking or deteriorating mortar over large areas of a stone foundation wall. 
10.  Excessive leakage or seepage through the foundation wall. 
11.  Numerous holes and loose material over large area of foundation wall. 
12.  Failure of the bearing capacity of the soil through erosion; insufficient original loadbearing capacity. 
(3)  Loadbearing walls. 
a.  The loadbearing walls and columns which support the structural loads between the floor and roof systems shall provide such support without bulging or buckling and shall be kept free of critical and major defects. Loadbearing walls shall provide such support without indications of settlement, bulging, or buckling and be maintained in a manner which will protect the surface from deterioration caused by the elements and should prevent the entrance of moisture and cold air into the building; for example, in the foundation, cracks or holes in the wall, rotting of wall members, or leaks which prevent the proper functioning of this component are faults. 
b.  There are two types of loadbearing walls, exterior masonry and exterior frame, each of which has several defects peculiar to it: 
1.  Exterior masonry wall. The same general types of failure and deteriorations as are observed in foundations. In many instances the exterior wall exhibits diagonal cracking in addition to vertical and horizontal cracking. Such cracks generally are not confined to mortar joints themselves but tend to pass through the primary wall material as well as through the lintels over openings in the wall. Lack of watertightness or inadequate ventilation can cause rotting of sills, toeplates, etc. An additional item of deterioration in masonry materials and concrete is the extensive chipping, flaking, crumbling, and erosion of primary exterior wall material. Such deterioration in the exterior wall will lead to deterioration of the core of the wall which may result in failure of the wall if not corrected. 
2.  Exterior frame wall. In wood walls, lack of corner bracing, disposal or ridged sheathing, or firestops, as well as the separation of joints or crushing of the ends of framing members can cause failure of the wall. The entrance of moisture can cause rot which in turn can lead to failure of the wall. For example, rotting of toeplates, sills, studs, bracing, etc. 
3.  Examples of critical and major loadbearing wall defects include: 
i.  Walls which are severely out of plumb. 
ii.  Severe sagging over a large area. 
iii.  Numerous cracks penetrating entire thickness of the wall and extending from floor to ceiling. 
iv.  Failure to support structural loads between floor and roof systems. 
v.  Extensive fire damage creating hazardous conditions. 
vi.  Numerous cracks not penetrating entire thickness of wall. 
vii.  Deteriorating material over large areas. Large holes, loose or missing material over large area. 
viii.  Sagging of a limited area. 
ix.  Fire damage affecting basic structural elements (e.g., studs, columns, etc.) over a large area. 
x.  Termite infestation over large areas. 
xi.  Improper size or spacing of basic supporting members. 
(4)  Chimneys and all flue and vent attachments thereto. 
a.  Chimneys and all flue and vent attachments thereto shall be maintained structurally sound, free from defects, and so maintained as to capably perform at all times the functions for which they were designed. Chimneys, flues, gas vents or other draft-producing equipment shall provide for uninterrupted passage for smoke or combustible gases to the outside. 
b.  Examples of defects include: 
1.  Substantial leaning or out of plumb. 
2.  Combustible material in direct contact with or in dangerous proximity to chimney. 
3.  Loose or missing material, missing cap, or broken flue lining over extensive area. 
4.  Cracks and holes over extensive area. 
5.  Chimney should extend above the highest point of the roof (approximate two to three feet minimum). 
6.  Spalling, open joints, or other unsafe or hazardous conditions over most of the vertical length. 
7.  Tilting, leaning, or other footing failure. 
(5)  Exterior porches, landings, balconies, stairs and fire escapes. 
a.  Exterior porches, landings, balconies, stairs and fire escapes shall be provided with banisters or railings properly designed and maintained to minimize the hazard of falling, and the same shall be kept structurally sound, in good repair, and free from defects. 
b.  Examples of defects include: 
1.  Deterioration over an extensive area. 
2.  Loose or missing material over an extensive area. 
3.  Cracks and holes over an extensive area. 
4.  Extreme weakness due to fire damage or wear. 
5.  Lack of adequate support. 
6.  Sagging of treads or stringers. 
7.  Inadequate headroom. Headroom should be continuously clear six foot eight inch main, six foot four inch service. 
8.  Improper tread and riser size (treads and risers should be consistent all the way upstairs). 
9.  Improper construction, improper size members or lack of footage under posts. 
(6)  Appearance of buildings, secondary structures or the exterior of premises. Buildings, secondary structures, exterior of the premises, areas exposed to public view and the condition of all buildings and structures shall be maintained so that their appearance shall not constitute a blighting factor for adjoining property. 
(7)  Roof structure. 
a.  The roof structure is that system which supports the roof loads (e.g., snow loads) of the building. Also included in the system are the structural members represented by the roof trusses, rafters, and ceiling joists where rafter and joist become part of the roof truss. 
b.  The roof structure as a system should be capable of supporting the required roof loads without indication of sag or deflection. A crack, warp, or buckle in any member of the structural system are faults or defects. Also holes, leaks, corrosion, or rotting of structural members of the system are faults. Critical joints between the exterior wall and the roof system should be protected by flashing material to prevent the entrance of water. 
c.  Examples of roof faults and defects include: 
1.  Deflection caused by rotting of wood joist. 
2.  Roof joist deflection to such an extent that critical sagging of the ridge pole or beam occurs. 
3.  Critical deflection of or bulging observed in exterior masonry and frame walls caused by excessive roof structure deflection. 
4.  Pronounced sagging at gutter line. 
5.  Severe deterioration of shingles, sheathing, or rafters over most of roof area. 
6.  Severely weakened or missing material over large portion of roof area due to weather or fire damage. 
7.  Excessive spacing of rafters and joist, lack of bracing, undersized members in relation to span, crushed, broken or rotting rafters or joist ends. 
8.  Rotted, broken or missing material over a widespread area of the roof deck. 
9.  Rafters which are insufficiently secured to a deck. 
10.  Excessive sagging caused by an inadequate thickness of decking in relation to span. 
11.  Lack of support in the roof deck. 
12.  Loose or missing roof material over large area. 
13.  Deteriorated shingles with evidence of leakage on interior. 
14.  Improper size and spacing of support members. 
15.  Vegetation growth on roof (deterioration). 
16.  Infestation. 
17.  Rafter, plate, joist or ridge beam sagging, broken, bowed or otherwise unable to support roof loads over a limited area. 
18.  Lack of weatherproofing of roof deck. 
(8)  Floor structure. 
a.  The floor structure is composed of a system of braces and bearing surfaces (flooring) required to support the floor loads of a building and to provide a surface for circulation within the individual rooms. The floor structure should be capable of supporting floor loads without indications of sag or deflection. The floor structure should provide bracing and act as a structural tie which keeps the walls in their vertical plane. In addition, the joist of the floor structure should provide the necessary support for the finished surface of the ceilings in the room below. Any cracking, warping or buckling of any member of the floor structure is a fault. Rotting or corrosion of any member of the floor structure shall also be considered a fault. 
b.  Examples of floor defects include: 
1.  Deflection causing buckling of interior walls. 
2.  Crushing at the ends of wood joists causing serious deflection of exterior walls. 
3.  Extreme weakness of floor. 
4.  Pronounced sagging or sloping of the floor. 
5.  Severely weakened or missing floor joists resulting from fire damage. 
6.  Pronounced sagging or sloping of the floor. 
7.  Severely weakened or missing floor joists resulting from fire damage. 
8.  Bowing, sagging, inadequate bracing, insufficient dimensions of members in relation to span and excessive spacing of joist or other members of the floor, joist, sills and headers system. 
9.  Severely worn floor over large area. 
10.  Loose or missing material over large area. 
11.  Cracks or holes over large areas. 
12.  Improper size and spacing of supporting members. 
13.  Lack of bridging. 
14.  Infestation and damage by destructive insects, i.e., carpenter ants or termites, affecting a significant area. 
15.  Damage from rotting over an extensive area due to lack of ventilation or water seepage. 
16.  Missing material over a widespread portion of the component. 
17.  Ceilings improperly secured to studs or joists. 
18.  Excessive sagging, bulging or bowing of ceilings, which may also be indicative of defects or faults in structural members. 
19.  Plaster defects in the ceiling over an extensive area, including water damage, cracked material, and broken, missing or loose lath. 
(9)  Exterior curtain walls. 
a.  Exterior curtain walls are those walls which are not part of a building's structural supporting system. Exterior curtain walls do not support the floors or the roof; but rather, their primary function is to enclose the building, protect the structure from deterioration due to the elements and prevent the entrance of moisture or seasonal cold air or hot air. Exterior curtain walls are often the sections between columns or piers separated by floors on multistory buildings. Exterior curtain walls shall be kept free of any defects. 
b.  Examples of exterior curtain wall defects include: 
1.  Deterioration of parapets or coping over an extensive area. 
2.  Corrosion of large areas of metal exterior curtain wall. 
3.  Failure of curtain wall glass and framing. 
4.  Extensive cracks, buckling, or spalling of concrete, masonry, or ceramic exterior curtain walls. 
5.  Hairline cracks over a small area. 
6.  Deterioration or weathering over a limited area. 
7.  Small holes or loose or missing material over a confined area. 
8.  Minor weather or fire damage. 
9.  Minor sagging of windows within exterior curtain wall sections. 
(10)  Nonbearing walls and ceiling interior walls and partitions. 
a.  Nonbearing walls and ceiling interior walls and partitions are generally provided to separate space within a building into separate functional areas. Such structural components should be free of dry rot, cracks, bulges, buckles, or holes. Nonbearing walls and ceiling interior walls and partitions should also provide a suitable base surface for decorative finish. Nonbearing walls and ceiling interior walls and partitions shall be kept free of any defects. 
b.  Examples of nonbearing wall and ceiling interior wall and partition defects include: 
1.  Walls or partitions out of plumb. 
2.  Bowing or bulging of an entire wall. 
3.  Extreme deterioration affecting major structural members over an extensive area. 
4.  Numerous cracks penetrating entire thickness of wall or partition material. 
5.  Severe sagging. 
6.  Loose or missing material over substantial area. 
7.  Cracks or holes over an extensive area. 
8.  Improper size and spacing of members. 
9.  Fire damage affecting structural elements over large area. 
10.  Evidence of infestation. 
11.  Deterioration over large area. 
12.  Evidence of extensive leakage or seepage. 
13.  Bowing due to lack or failure of toeplates or headers. 
14.  Broken or missing material over a widespread portion of the building. 
15.  Inadequate lintels over openings. 
16.  Inadequate spacing, sizing, or doubling at opening of stud. 
17.  Insufficiently dimensioned or otherwise unsuitable material which is green, split, checked or cracked, warped, swelled, or excessive spacing between studs used for framing or supporting required loads. 
(11)  Interior stairs. 
a.  Interior stair systems must provide safe access between different floor levels. They should be capable of supporting loads without indications of sag or deflection. Excessive sloping; broken treads or risers; and cracks, warping, or buckling of the supporting structure shall be considered defects. Interior stairs shall be kept free of all defects. 
b.  Examples of interior stair defects include: 
1.  Deterioration over an extensive area. 
2.  Loose or missing material over an extensive area. 
3.  Cracks and holes over an extensive area. 
4.  Extreme weakness due to fire damage or wear. 
5.  Lack of adequate support. 
6.  Sagging of treads or stringers. 
7.  Inadequate headroom. Headroom should be continuously clear six feet eight inches for main and six feet four inches for service. 
8.  Improper tread and riser size (treads and risers should be consistent all the way upstairs). 
9.  Springing or inadequately sized or spaced stringers. 
10.  Wood stair platforms or treads that are rotted through or otherwise unsafe. 
11.  Whole interior stair system unstable because of deterioration of stair supports, especially the stringers. 
(12)  Window and window units. 
a.  Windows are necessary to provide required natural light and ventilation in any room or space. Window units, including sashes, frames, sills, jambs, weights or springs, glazing and hardware, must be intact, operate properly and must be sufficiently tight to keep out drafts and elements of weather. Windows and window units shall be kept free of defects. 
b.  Examples of window and window unit defects include: 
1.  Extreme deterioration of lintels, sash, sills or frame elements. 
2.  Loose or missing material to an extensive degree. 
3.  Pronounced sagging of lintels, sills, and sash or any combination. 
4.  Multiple cracks or broken window panes. 
(13)  Door and door units. 
a.  Doors should provide openings adequate in size to admit persons or property to a building and to all rooms and spaces within a building. 
b.  Examples of door and door unit defects include: 
1.  Openings which are out of plumb. 
2.  Extreme deterioration. 
3.  Improper fit of door to the door unit. 
4.  Loose or missing material to an extensive degree. 
(b)  Storage of commercial and industrial materials. There shall not be stored or used at a location exposed to public view equipment or materials relating to commercial or industrial use unless permitted under chapter 18 of this Code. 
(c)  Landscaping/lawns/weeds. 
(1)  Landscaping. 
a.  Premises with landscaping, hedges and bushes shall be kept trimmed and from becoming overgrown and unsightly where exposed to public view where the same constitute a blighting factor to adjoining property(ies). 
(2)  Lawns/weeds. 
a.  Allowing in excess of six inches. 
1.  It is unlawful for any person to permit, suffer or allow any lawns, thistles, weeds, brush or undergrowth or other vegetation of any kind whatsoever to be, remain or grow to a height above six inches from the ground upon any lots, parcels or tracts of land within the city. 
2.  It shall be the duty of any person owning, leasing or controlling any such lots, tracts or parcels of land within the city to cause the undergrowth to be removed therefrom before the undergrowth reaches the heights of six inches; provided that this provision shall not apply to trees, flowers or cultivated plants. 
b.  Notice to remove to be given by the building department. 
1.  Whenever it comes to the notice of the building department that any lot, parcel or tract of land within the city is in violation of this article, it shall be the duty of the building department to notify the landowner of the property by registered letter at the landowner's last known address. 
2.  The building department may also serve notice of the violation by attaching to any structure on the lot, parcel or tract, a statement of the violation. In such cases, the building department shall also notify the landowner by registered letter, of the violation and of the notice attached to the structure on the lot, parcel or tract. 
3.  The landowner shall have three days to remove the vegetation upon receipt of the building department's registered letter. 
c.  Repeat offenders. 
1.  Anyone committing a second offence of this section within the same calendar year, will receive a citation including a $25.00 fine, along with the three day notice to remove the growth. 
d.  Action by the building department on failure to act.
