(6)  If not built by a contractor, an insurance policy and bond may be required. 
(e)  Fee. Prior to the issuance of a permit, a fee in the amount established in the city fee schedule ordinance for building permits shall be paid to the city. 
(Ord. No. CC-2007-1780, § 4, 10-16-07) 
Sec. 4-385. - Maximum height of fences; location of structural members; construction and maintenance. 
    In addition to all other provisions and restrictions of this division, the following items shall be applicable unless otherwise approved by the board of zoning appeals: 
(1)  Except as otherwise provided in this section, no fence shall be erected which stands over six feet in height. An allowance of up to six inches shall be permitted for decorative post tops in excess of the maximum height provision. Fence height shall be measured from grade and shall follow grade along its length, although a variation of seven inches shall be allowed to compensate for minor grade changes. 
(2)  Structural members must be on the interior of the fence itself. The finished side of the fence shall face outward. 
(3)  All fences shall be constructed in a sound and sturdy manner, according to standard construction practices, and shall be maintained in a good state of repair, including the replacement of defective parts, painting and other acts required for maintenance. 
(4)  Rear and side yard fences may not extend past the front main building line, excluding front porches and steps. 
(Ord. No. CC-2007-1780, § 5, 10-16-07) 
Sec. 4-386. - Fences in residential districts. 
    The following provisions shall apply to fences in zoning districts R-SF (single-family detached); R-MD (medium density residential); and R-HD (high density residential): 
(1)  Front yards. 
a.  Front yard fences. 
1.  The general rule is that front yard fences are prohibited in any area zoned residential other than as a landscape amenity. 
2.  Special exception may be made to the general rule to permit front yard fences by making application to the Board of Zoning Appeals. 
3.  The board shall review the application, the reasons cited for the special exception, and may grant, deny or defer to the plan commission the special exception on a case-by-case basis in accordance with the provisions of the Unified Zoning and Subdivision Control Ordinance of the City of Whiting. 
b.  Landscape amenities in front yards. 
1.  Fences in the front yard may only be located as landscape amenities, in an aggregate length of no greater than eight feet, with a maximum of four feet in any one direction. Fences in the front yard shall not be installed so as to result in the creation of enclosed areas within the fence, visibility problems or hazards to pedestrians. 
2.  Only fences that are of an open construction, such as split rail and picket fences, may be installed as landscape amenities. Chain link fences and other woven or fabric types are prohibited. 
3.  Landscape amenity fences shall be limited to a maximum height of 36 inches above the established grade of the lots. 
4.  An allowance of up to six inches shall be permitted for decorative post tops in excess of the maximum height provision. 
c.  Hedge fences. A hedge fence or planting not exceeding three feet in height above the grade of the adjacent sidewalk or ground may be located in the front yard with no minimum setback, subject to the sight triangle requirement provisions. 
d.  Front yard railings. 
1.  A railing to provide for safe use of steps shall be allowed so long as its construction shall be the minimum necessary for safe use and it shall span only the immediate area of the steps involved. 
2.  Railings necessary to the construction and use of a wheelchair access ramp shall be allowed as part of a design for the ramp and as approved by the building commissioner. 
e.  Landscape accessories. Landscape accessories such as timbers, borders, edging and fences of a variety of materials not exceeding 24 inches in height may be used as needed so long as they are used to separate, highlight or otherwise delineate areas for trees, shrubbery, evergreens and flower beds, or the combination, thereof, from the lawn area. 
f.  Landscape major features. A maximum of two major features of a landscape program, such as windmills, trellises, wagon wheels, milk cans, etc., used to set a theme to the landscaping shall be allowed with each program, limited to a height of six feet and a base width of five feet. The installation of a flagpole shall be allowed in excess of the two allowed major features. 
g.  Structures in parkway. No fences, wall, railings or other structures shall be permitted in the parkway area except for borders to a maximum height of six inches to enclose tree bases, unless permitted by the board of public works and safety. 
h.  Exceptions. 
1.  Exceptions from height restrictions. The height restrictions of this section shall not apply to the following uses: a post light; a mailbox as required by the U.S. Postal Service; or a nameplate/address sign attached to or suspended from a post and arm. 
2.  Residential lots adjacent to non-residential use. A residential lot adjacent to a commercial or other nonresidential use zoned property shall be allowed to construct a fence at the property line adjacent to such property forward of the building setback line. 
3.  Holiday decorations. Holiday decorations erected on a temporary basis to celebrate recognized, broadly accepted holidays shall be exempt from the provisions of this section. 
(2)  Fences on corner lots. 
a.  For purposes of this subsection, the word "front" shall apply to the building setback line on the street side of the lot of shortest dimension, irrespective of the orientation of the residence. 
b.  Where the zoning administrator determines that allowing a fence on the side yard of a corner lot facing the street would hamper traffic visibility, endanger public health or safety, or be detrimental to the aesthetic qualities or property values of neighboring properties, the zoning administrator may require that the side yard facing the street shall be treated as an additional front yard, and all regulations for fences forward of the front yard setback line shall apply. The decision of the zoning administrator to apply the front yard regulations to the side yard may be appealed to the board of zoning appeals. 
(3)  Fences in rear yards. 
a.  Fences not greater than six feet in height shall be permitted on or within the rear property lines of a lot in any residential district. 
b.  No rear yard fence shall be quipped with barbed wire or its equivalent or have any electrical conducting wires attached to it. 
(4)  Miscellaneous provisions. 
a.  All existing nonconforming fences, railings, walls, landscape accessories and other features in existence prior to the effective date of this ordinance may remain in use until: 
1.  Removed or replaced by a legal use. 
2.  The fence, etc., falls into disrepair and/or becomes a public hazard or nuisance. 
3.  A building permit is issued to modify or improve the exterior of the principal structure on the property. 
b.  All fences and landscaping improvements must be constructed in compliance with the following site triangle provisions: 
Landscaping improvements and fences in excess of 30 inches in height are not to be located within ten feet of the sight triangle of an intersecting street, alley or driveway as measured from the right-of-way and along the property line. 
(Ord. No. CC-2007-1780, § 6, 10-16-07) 
Sec. 4-387. - Fences in commercial and manufacturing districts. 
    The following provisions shall apply to fences in areas zoned C-DB downtown business; C-BB boulevard business; I-LIM low impact manufacturing and I-HIM high impact manufacturing. 
(1)  Fence required. The fence set out in this section shall be mandatory for commercial or manufacturing developments. Construction of a fence to a height of eight feet shall be permitted on commercial or manufacturing property abutting a residential district. In all other respects except as listed below, fences in commercial or manufacturing districts shall conform to the requirements of fences in residential districts, including the permit requirements. 
(2)  Height restrictions. 
a.  Fences in a manufacturing district shall conform to the requirements of residential districts, except that such fences may be constructed to a maximum height of eight feet. 
b.  Wherever a commercial or manufacturing district abuts a residential property, a fence eight feet in height shall be erected along the district boundary unless: 
1.  The district boundary is separated from the residential property by a street. 
2.  The district boundary is located on a side lot line, in which case the required fence shall be limited in height to three and one-half feet from the point at which the side lot line intersects the front building line of the abutting residential property to the front property line. 
(3)  Material restrictions. Whenever a commercial or manufacturing district abuts a residential property, all fences constructed to a height of eight feet pursuant to this section shall be made of a solid material, without gaps or spaces, to reduce noise transmission. If a wood fence is constructed, it shall present a solid face. Each fence shall be water-resistant treated. Fences which serve as sound barriers or for purposes of sound proofing may be constructed in excess of the eight-foot height restriction, subject to the approval of the board of public works and safety. 
(Ord. No. CC-2007-1780, § 7, 10-16-07) 
Sec. 4-388. - Other types of fences. 
(a)  Swimming pool fences. These types of fences shall be regulated by Whiting Municipal Code Section 4-235. 
(b)  Wall fences. 
(1)  Fences made of materials other than wood, wire, mesh or plastic mesh, such as masonry or concrete block, shall be built upon a foundation with a minimum depth of three and one-half feet. 
(2)  Wall fences shall be restricted by the side yard requirements of the district. 
(Ord. No. CC-2007-1780, § 8, 10-16-07) 
Sec. 4-389. - Prohibited fences. 
(a)  No fence in a residential or commercial district shall be equipped with barbed wire or its equivalent or have any electrical conducting wire attached to it. 
(b)  No fence in a manufacturing district shall have any electrical conducting wires attached to it. 
(Ord. No. CC-2007-1780, § 9, 10-16-07) 
Chapter 5 - CABLE COMMUNICATIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 4; electricity, § 4-111 et seq.; fire prevention and protection, ch. 7; licenses and business regulations, ch. 10; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 15; utilities, ch. 16; zoning, ch. 18. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 5-1-5-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CABLE TELEVISION 

Sec. 5-26. - Authority. 
(a)  The common council does hereby adopt the rules and regulations set forth by the Federal Communications Commission pursuant to section 623(b) of the Cable Television Consumer Protection and Competition Act of 1992 (47 USC 543(b)) for the review of the basic service tier of cable television services and equipment necessary for the provisions of such service tier. 
(b)  For the purposes of this article, the basic service tier of cable television services means a separately available service tier to which subscription is required for access to any other tier of service, including as a minimum, but not limited to, all signals of domestic television broadcast stations provided to any subscriber (except a signal secondarily transmitted by satellite carrier beyond the local service area of such station, regardless of how such signal is ultimately received by the cable system), any public, education, and governmental programming required by the franchise to be carried on the basic tier, and any additional video programming signals or service added to the basic tier by the cable operator. Equipment necessary to provide the basic tier of service means those items of associated equipment necessary for the reception of basic cable service by a subscriber, including, but not limited to, converter boxes, remote control units, additional outlets, and installations. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1510, § 1, 2-15-94) 
Sec. 5-27. - Rate regulation process. 
(a)  The city shall provide the grantee of the cable television franchise, the public and interested parties an opportunity to be heard at a public hearing before the common council, upon 14 days' written notice to the grantee of the cable television franchise of the time and place of the public hearing, provided further that the notice shall indicate that the purpose of the public hearing is to receive the views of the grantee and interested persons on issues pertaining to regulation of the basic tier of cable television services and equipment necessary to provide the basic tier of service; and provided further that notice of the public hearing shall be published in a local newspaper of general circulation at least ten days before the date of this hearing, and provided further, that an agenda for the public hearing shall be posted in three public places at least seven days prior to the public hearing. 
(b)  Upon the adoption of Ordinance No. CC 94-1510 and the certification of the city by the Federal Communications Commission, the city shall immediately notify the cable operator by certified mail, return receipt requested, that the city intends to regulate subscriber rates charged for the basic service tier and associated equipment as authorized by the Cable Television Consumer Protection and Competition Act of 1992. Upon receipt of the notice by the city, the cable operator shall, within 30 days, file with the city its current rates for the basic service tier and associated equipment along with any additional documentation justifying the reasonableness of its rates. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1510, § 2, 2-15-94) 
Sec. 5-28. - Review of rates. 
(a)  The city shall establish that the period for review of rates of the basic service tier of cable television services and the equipment necessary to provide the basic tier of services shall be 30 days from the submission by the grantee of the cable television franchise of Federal Communications Commission form 393. If the common council takes no action within 30 days from the date the cable operator files its basic cable rates with the city, the proposed rates will continue in effect. 
(b)  If additional time for review of the Federal Communications Commission form 393 submitted by grantee is necessary, the common council or its designee shall issue a brief written order prior to the end of the 30-day review period, with a copy of the order to be sent by certified United States mail to the grantee, providing for an additional 90-day period for review of rates of the basic service tier and the equipment necessary to provide the basic tier of service. During the extended review period and before taking action on the proposed rate, the common council shall hold at least one public hearing in which interested citizens may express their views and record objections. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1510, § 3, 2-15-94) 
Sec. 5-29. - Review of rates extension. 
(a)  The city shall establish that the period for review of the basic service tier of cable television services and the equipment necessary to provide the basic tier of services shall be 90 days from the submission by the grantee of information and forms prescribed by the Federal Communications Commission for a showing of cost-of-service, as defined by the Federal Communications Commission. 
(b)  If the additional time for review of the cost-of-service showing submitted by the grantee is necessary, the common council or its designee shall issue a brief written order prior to the end of the 90-day review period with a copy of the order to be sent by certified United States mail to the grantee, providing for an additional 150-day period for review of rates of the basic service tier and the equipment necessary to provide the basic tier of service. During the extended review period and before taking action on the proposed rate, the common council shall hold at least one public hearing in which interested citizens may express their views and record objections. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1510, § 4, 2-15-94) 
Sec. 5-30. - Rate regulation resolution. 
(a)  Upon completion of its review of the proposed rates for the basic service tier of cable television services and the equipment necessary to provide the basic tier of service, the common council shall adopt its decision by formal resolution. The resolution shall indicate the reasons for the decision. Upon passage of the resolution, the common council shall publish the resolution in pamphlet form. 
(b)  If the cable operator's proposed rates exceed the reasonable rate standard as established by the FCC in its rules and regulations attached to Ordinance No. CC 94-1510, the common council may order the rates reduced by rollbacks or refunds to subscribers, in the manner so prescribed by the FCC. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1510, § 5, 2-15-94) 
Sec. 5-31. - Disclosure of proprietary interests. 
    In considering information provided by the grantee as part of review of the rates for the basic service tier of cable television services and the equipment necessary to provide the basic tier of service, the common council shall not disclose to the public the content of any records, forms, reports, calculations, or other documents which the grantee has indicated as being of a proprietary interest or constituting a trade secret in nature. The executive officer or mayor of the city shall retain the right to determine the validity of the grantee's claim of proprietary interest or trade secrecy in accordance with the provisions of the Indiana Open Records Act. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1510, § 6, 2-15-94) 
Sec. 5-32. - Authority to execute. 
    The executive officer or the mayor of the city, or his designee, is authorized to execute on behalf of the city and file with the FCC such certification forms or other instruments as are now or may hereafter be required by the FCC rate regulations in order to enable the city to regulate basic service rates and charges. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1510, § 7, 2-15-94) 
Sec. 5-33. - Subscriber refunds. 
    The city may order the cable operator to refund to subscribers a portion of previously paid rates under the following circumstances: 
(1)  A portion of the previously paid rates has been determined to be in excess of the permitted basic cable service tier charge or above the actual cost of equipment; or 
(2)  The cable operator has failed to comply with a valid rate order issued by the city. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1510, § 8, 2-15-94) 
Sec. 5-34. - Violation of terms. 
    Failure by the cable operator to comply with the terms and conditions established by this article, including the attachment to Ordinance No. CC 94-1510, shall constitute a violation of this Code. The penalties for such violation are subject to the conditions of section 1-11. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1510, § 9, 2-15-94)

Chapter 7 - FIRE PREVENTION AND PROTECTION[1] 
Footnotes:

Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2; personnel, § 2-286 et seq.; collective bargaining, § 2-311 et seq.; buildings and building regulations, ch. 4; powers and duties of electrical inspection department, § 4-115; cable communications, ch. 5; environment, ch. 6; health and sanitation, ch. 8; housing, ch. 9; dancehalls, § 10-436 et seq.; mobile homes, ch. 11; utilities, ch. 16; vehicles and traffic, ch. 17.

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 7-1-7-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - FIRE DEPARTMENT[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 
State Law reference- Uniforms and equipment, IC 36-8-4-4. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Prior history: Code 1962, §§ 9-102 through 9-114 and Ord. No. 1088. 

Sec. 7-26. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Board of public works means the board of public works and safety of the city. 
    Pension board means the board of trustees of the firefighters' pension fund of the city. 
(Code 1962, § 9-101; Code 1979, § 2.36.010) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 7-27. - Organization. 
(a)  The fire department shall consist of the following officers and members: 
(1)  One chief. 
(2)  One captain for each shift. 
(3)  Such number of fire department lieutenants, drivers, pipemen, advanced emergency medical technicians, emergency medical technicians (EMTs), and probationary fire pipemen as the mayor, board of public works and safety and common council shall specify. 
(b)  The fire department shall be divided into three 24-hour shifts with a captain in charge of each shift. 
(Code 1979, § 2.36.020; Ord. No. 1420, § 1, 1989) 
Sec. 7-28. - Fire chief; powers and duties. 
    The chief of the fire department shall have the exclusive control and charge of the fire department, subject to the rules, regulations and orders of the board of public works and safety, ordinances of the city, and statutes of the state. The chief's orders shall have the force and effect of rules of the department. He shall have the following specific powers and duties. He shall: 
(1)  See that all fires are extinguished with the least possible damage of life and property. 
(2)  Make official report of his actions and of officers and members under his command as may be provided by law or the rules of his department. 
(3)  Enforce the rules and regulations of the fire department, fire department merit commission, the board of public works and safety, the ordinances of the city and the statutes of the state relating to the fire department. 
(4)  Have the power and it shall be his duty to demolish buildings and parts of buildings which, in his judgment, may cause further damage to life and property or which, in his judgment, may be necessary to demolish in order to prevent the spread of fire or additional destruction caused by fire. 
(5)  Examine the condition of the equipment, buildings and other property belonging to the fire department and shall be entitled to make recommendations to the common council for appropriations of money for the purchase of additional equipment as well as funds for the replacement or repair of existing equipment. 
(6)  Maintain a personnel record of every person appointed to the fire department, which shall be open for inspection by the individual firefighter and those officials involved in an official disciplinary proceeding against the firefighter. The record shall contain a copy of each person's application for employment in the fire department, recommendations, correspondence and other matter relating to the firefighter's job performance. 
(7)  The fire inspection department shall charge for its services in accordance with the schedule of permits and fees adopted by the city council, except as otherwise provided in this article. 
(8)  Said fees may be assessed in addition to any other fees, fines, or costs which may be assessed as a result of the order to correct violations. 
(Code 1979, § 2.36.030; Ord. No. 1420, § 2, 1989; Ord. No. CC-2005-1722, 7-19-05) 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 
Sec. 7-29. - Captains; powers and duties. 
    There shall be a captain who shall be in charge of each shift of the fire force. In the absence of the chief, the captain shall assume the powers and duties of the fire chief. Each captain shall have the following additional powers and duties. He shall: 
(1)  Report to the fire chief in writing of the incapacity, neglect of duty, disobedience of orders, or violations of any rules, regulations or orders by any member of the fire department which may occur or come to his attention. 
(2)  Have the power to suspend from duty any member of his shift who is intoxicated or willfully refuses to obey orders or where the interest of the fire department would suffer by the fireman remaining on active duty. 
It shall be his duty in his respective shift to preserve order and discipline in compliance with the rules and regulations of the department and orders of the fire chief and to see that the equipment committed to his care is in good order and repair for immediate use at all times, and to see that the buildings, furniture and fixtures are kept neat and clean. 
(Code 1979, § 2.36.040; Ord. No. 1420, § 3, 1989) 
Sec. 7-30. - Lieutenants; powers and duties. 
    A lieutenant shall be second in command of each shift and in the absence of the captain shall assume the powers and duties of the captain. He shall be in charge of the piece of fire equipment assigned to him in a fire or emergency call and shall see that such equipment is kept in good order and repair. 
(Code 1979, § 2.36.050; Ord. No. 1420, § 4, 1989) 
Sec. 7-31. - Fire department drivers; powers and duties. 
    Fire department drivers shall drive their assigned vehicle to the scene of fires or emergency calls and assist in the care of the vehicle and perform such other duties as the chief or captain who in charge at the scene may require. 
(Code 1979, § 2.36.060; Ord. No. 1420, § 5, 1989) 
Sec. 7-32. - Fire pipeman; powers and duties. 
    A fire pipeman shall perform duties and powers as are assigned to him by his superior officers. 
(Code 1979, § 2.36.070; Ord. No. 1420, § 6, 1989) 
Sec. 7-33. - Probationary firefighters. 
(a)  The position of probationary firefighter is hereby created. The probationary firefighter shall have such powers and duties as are assigned to him by his superior officers. 
(b)  Every appointment to the fire department shall be for a probationary period of one year. If, at any time during the probationary period, the conduct or capacity of the probationer is found not to be satisfactory, which fact shall be determined by the board of public works, upon the recommendation for discharge by the fire chief, the probationer shall, without hearing and without right of appeal, be notified in writing by the board of public works that he will not receive a permanent appointment, whereupon his employment shall cease; otherwise his retention in service after the expiration of the probationary period shall be equivalent to and shall constitute his final and permanent appointment. 
(Code 1962, § 14-107; Code 1979, § 2.36.080; Ord. No. 1420, § 7, 1989) 
State Law reference- Probationary appointments, IC 36-8-4-12. 
Sec. 7-34. - Applicants; procedures for hiring and appointment of firefighters; residence. 
(a)  All procedures regarding the application process, screening, testing and eventual hiring of firefighters for the fire department shall be determined by the fire department merit commission. 
(b)  An applicant for a position of any kind in the fire department must reside within 15 miles of the corporate boundaries of the city; must have adequate means of transportation into the city; and must maintain in his residence telephone service with the city. As a member of the fire department he must reside within the corporate boundaries of the city until he has served for five years. 
(Code 1979, § 2.36.100; Ord. No. 1420, § 8, 1989) 
State Law reference- Residence required, IC 36-8-4-2. 
Sec. 7-35. - Dismissals and suspensions. 
    All suspensions and disciplinary hearings of firefighters shall be conducted in accordance with existing state statutes and the procedures established by the fire department merit commission. 
(Code 1979, § 2.36.110; Ord. No. 1420, § 9, 1989) 
Sec. 7-36. - Firefighters' hours of duty. 
    All working days of firefighters shall commence at 8:00 a.m. The fire force shall be on a three-shift system with each firefighters working a period of 24 consecutive hours and then being off duty not less than 48 consecutive hours except in cases of emergency when firefighters shall be subject to call at any time or in those cases where a firefighter has been authorized to work overtime. Overtime shall be authorized by the chief or captain in charge of the shift. 
(Code 1979, § 2.36.120; Ord. No. 1420, § 10, 1989) 
Sec. 7-37. - Benefits. 
    All benefits, vacations and other entitlements to firefighters shall be determined by the collective bargaining procedure in effect between the city and the union representing the firefighters of the city. The collective bargaining process shall ultimately result in a written contract between the city and members of the fire department. Such contract shall clearly specify all benefits and entitlements available to the members of the fire department. 
(Code 1979, § 2.36.130; Ord. No. 1420, § 11, 1989) 
Sec. 7-38. - Pension fund; created; administrative authority. 
    There is created a firefighters' pension fund, and a board of trustees is established to administer the same. 
(Code 1962, § 9-401; Code 1979, § 2.76.010) 
State Law reference- 1977 police officers' and firefighters' pension and disability fund, IC 36-8-8-1 et seq. 
Sec. 7-39. - Dispersal of persons obstructing operations of fire department authorized. 
    Whenever the chief of the fire department, or any officer or member thereof finds the entrances, exits, aisles, fire escapes, stairs, passageways, doors, windows, etc., of any theater, moving picture house or any hall where the public is accustomed to congregate, crowded or obstructed with people in such manner as to be liable to interfere with the operations of the fire department or egress of the occupants thereof in case of fire he shall order the same to be dispersed or the situation remedied and such order shall forthwith be complied with by the owner or occupant of such premises or building. 
(Code 1962, § 9-203; Code 1979, § 15.12.040) 
Secs. 7-40-7-50. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - MERIT SYSTEM 

Sec. 7-51. - Established; purpose. 
    Pursuant to IC 36-8-3.5-1, a fire department merit system is established. This merit system is expressly established for the purpose of promulgating rules and regulations for hiring, promoting and disciplining members of the fire department as governed by IC 36-8-3.5. 
(Code 1979, § 2.38.010; Ord. No. 1392, § 1, 1988) 
Sec. 7-52. - Merit commission-Created; powers and duties; appointment of members. 
    Pursuant to IC 36-8-3.5, a merit commission consisting of three members is created to act as governing body for the fire department merit system. This commission shall have all the rights, powers and duties as specifically set forth in IC 36-8-3.5. The commission members shall be appointed as follows: 
(1)  One person appointed by the mayor. 
(2)  One person appointed by the common council. 
(3)  One person elected by the active members of the department; however such person cannot be an active member of the fire department. 
(Code 1979, § 2.38.020; Ord. No. 1392, § 2, 1988) 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 
Sec. 7-53. - Same-Membership; term of office; filling of vacancies; tenure. 
    Pursuant to IC 36-8-3.5-7, the common council does hereby expressly adopt the rules and regulations regarding commission members' terms of office, procedures for filling vacancies and tenure requirements. 
(Code 1979, § 2.38.030; Ord. No. 1392, § 3, 1988) 
Sec. 7-54. - State and statutes adopted. 
    The common council does hereby expressly adopt the following portions of IC 36-8-3.5: 
(1)  Rules governing the commission, transaction of business, selection of officers, records, and budgets. IC 36-8-3.5-9. 
(2)  Rules; adoption; notice and hearing. IC 36-8-3.5-10. 
(3)  Department members: tenure; chief, appointment and qualifications. IC 36-8-3.5-11. 
(4)  Department members; appointments; qualifications; application; examination. IC 36-8-3.5-12. 
(5)  Promotions; rules; requisites; eligibility list. IC 36-8-3.5-13. 
(6)  Promotions; competitive examinations; procedures. IC 36-8-3.5-14. 
(7)  Performance ratings; rules; appeal. IC 36-8-3.5-15. 
(8)  Promotions; certification of eligible members; probation; procedures. IC 36-8-3.5-16. 
(9)  Disciplinary actions; grounds, hearing; notice; requisites; procedures; appeal. IC 36-8-3.5-17. 
(10)  Appeal to court; suspension or dismissal; precedence. IC 36-8-3.5-18. 
(11)  Summary disciplinary actions; reprimand or suspension. IC 36-8-3.5-19. 
(12)  Retirement age. IC 36-8-3.5-20. 
(Code 1979, § 2.38.040; Ord. No. 1392, § 4, 1988) 
Sec. 7-55. - Prior system. 
    The common council does hereby expressly state that under the merit system, all members of the fire department will be entitled to the same ranks and pay grades held under the prior system (i.e., civil service) until such time as the member is promoted, retired or some other change occurs in strict accordance with the procedures as established in the merit system. 
(Code 1979, § 2.38.060; Ord. No. 1392, § 6, 1988) 
Secs. 7-56-7-75. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - FIRE PREVENTION DIVISION[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- This division supersedes Code 1962, § 9-201(part); Code 1979, §§ 15.12.010-15.12.030. 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 

Sec. 7-76. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Board of public works means the board of public works and safety of the city. 
    Occupants means the residents of a multifamily dwelling. 
    Owner means the legal owner of a commercial building or private residence. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1483, § 15.12.010(4)-(6), 12-7-93) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 7-77. - Creation. 
    There is hereby created in the fire department a fire prevention division, supervised by a fire hazard inspector. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1483, § 15.12.020, 12-7-93) 
Sec. 7-78. - Appointment of fire hazard inspector. 
    For purposes of enforcing the provisions of this division, the fire hazard inspector shall be the fire chief and/or his designee. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1483, § 15.12.030, 12-7-93) 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 
Sec. 7-79. - Duties. 
    The fire prevention division, under the supervision of the fire hazard inspector, shall enforce all laws and ordinances covering the following: 
(1)  Inspection of potential fire hazards. 
(2)  Abatement of existing fire hazards. 
(3)  Investigation of the cause, origin and circumstances of fires. 
(4)  Control and use of explosives and flammables. 
(5)  Regulation of the maintenance of fire escapes. 
(6)  Regulation of the maintenance of automatic and other private fire alarm systems, and fire extinguishing equipment. 
(7)  Control of the means and adequacy of exits in case of fire, from factories, schools, churches, halls, theaters, and all other places in which numbers of persons work, meet, live or congregate. 
(8)  Education fire prevention programs. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1483, § 15.12.040, 12-7-93) 
Sec. 7-80. - Right to enter for inspection. 
    The fire hazard inspector shall have the right and authority to enter any building, structure, or premises within the corporate limits of the city for the express purpose of making inspections or investigations at all reasonable hours; provided that except in cases of emergency, the right and authority conferred by this section shall not apply to the entry of a private residence unless written notice is served on the occupant thereof. Such written notice shall contain a statement of the time that inspection will be made and shall also contain a statement of the purpose of such investigation. Inspections of private residences may be performed at the request of the owner or occupants. Involuntary inspections (i.e., inspections not otherwise requested by the owner/occupant of private residences) may only occur upon the presentation of an inspection warrant obtained from the local court. The local court shall issue the inspection warrant subject to the following conditions: 
(1)  The fire hazard inspector seeking the warrant must establish that the premises to be inspected are part of an inspection program created pursuant to this division and that the building or premises in question are naturally part of the inspection program or that there exists some other probable cause for believing that a condition, object, activity, or circumstance legally justifies a search or inspection of the building or premises in question. 
(2)  An affidavit establishing one of the grounds described in section 7-79(1) as a reason meriting the inspection above must be signed under oath or affirmation by the affiant. 
(3)  The court must examine the affiant under oath or affirmation to verify the accuracy of the affidavit. 
(4)  The inspection warrant is valid, which will only occur if it: 
a.  Is signed by the judge of the court and bears the date and hour of its issuance above that signature, with a notation that the warrant is valid for only 48 hours after its issuance. 
b.  Describes (either directly or by reference to the affidavit) the building where the inspection is to occur so that the executor of the warrant and owner or the possessor of the building can reasonably determine what property the warrant authorizes an inspection of. 
c.  Indicates the conditions, objects, activities, or circumstances that the inspection is intended to check or reveal. 
d.  Is attached to the affidavit required to be made in order to obtain the warrant. 
(5)  A warrant issued under this section is valid for only 48 hours after its issuance, must be personally served upon the owner or possessor of the building, and must be returned within 72 hours. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1483, § 15.12.050, 12-7-93) 
Sec. 7-81. - Scope of inspection authorized. 
    The inspection and examination authorized by this division shall be for the purpose of reporting and correcting the following hazards pertaining to buildings and their occupants: 
(1)  Disrepair. 
(2)  Age and dilapidated condition. 
(3)  Faulty or unapproved construction. 
(4)  Inadequate fire alarm protection. 
(5)  Inadequate fire extinguishing equipment. 
(6)  Materials and buildings especially susceptible to fire. 
(7)  Conditions endangering other property or occupants. 
(8)  Any other fire hazards dangerous to life or property. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1483, § 15.12.060, 12-7-93) 
Sec. 7-82. - Required inspections. 
(a)  Generally. It shall be the duty of the fire hazard inspector, in addition to the inspections required below, to inspect as often as he shall find necessary to the enforcement of this division all buildings and premises in the city. 
(b)  Buildings and premises. The fire hazard inspector shall inspect all commercial buildings and premises not less than one time per year. 
(c)  Place of public assembly. The fire hazard inspector shall inspect all places of public assembly not less than one time per year. 
(d)  Places housing dangerous materials. The fire hazard inspector shall inspect, not less than one time per year, all hazardous manufacturing processes, storages or installations of gases, chemicals, oils, explosives, and flammable materials. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1483, § 15.12.070, 12-7-93) 
Sec. 7-83. - Order to correct violations. 
(a)  When and where served. Where violations of this division or of any other laws or ordinance provisions relating to fire hazards are found by the fire hazard inspector, he shall serve a written order to correct the violation upon the owner, operator, occupant or other person responsible for the violation. 
(b)  Method of service. The order required herein shall be served in one of the following ways: 
(1)  By making personal delivery of the order to the person responsible. 
(2)  By leaving the order with some person of suitable age and discretion upon the premises in violation. 
(3)  By affixing a copy of the order to the door at the entrance of the premises in violation. 
(4)  By mailing a copy of the order to the last known address of the owner of the premises by registered mail. 
(5)  By publishing a copy of the order in a newspaper of general circulation within the city once a week for two consecutive weeks. 
(c)  Time for compliance. The order required in this section shall set forth a time limit for compliance, dependent upon the hazard and danger created by the violation. In cases of extreme danger to persons or property, the fire hazard inspector shall have the authority to require compliance immediately upon service of the order. 
(d)  Appeal from order. A person to whom an order under this section is directed shall have the right to appeal the order to the board of public works. Upon receipt of a request to review an order, which may be made in writing, the board of public works shall review the fire hazard inspector's order at its next regularly scheduled meeting, and unless the order is revoked or modified, it shall remain in full force and be obeyed by the person to whom directed. No person to whom an order is directed shall fail to comply with such order within five days after an appeal has been reviewed and a final decision has been issued by the board of public works. Except for judicial relief, the decision of the board of public works shall be the final decision on behalf of the city. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1483, § 15.12.080, 12-7-93) 
Sec. 7-84. - Failure to comply. 
    Any person to whom an order is directed who fails to comply within the specified time shall be liable to penalty as provided in section 1-11. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1483, § 15.12.090, 12-7-93) 
Sec. 7-85. - Action upon failure to comply. 
    When a person to whom an order is directed under this division shall fail to comply within the specified time, the fire hazard inspector shall have the authority to contract with others for the removal of such materials and charge the cost thereof to the person to whom the order is directed. The person removing material under a contract made hereunder shall be authorized to enter the premises to remove such material. If the cost of removal is not paid within 15 days after receipt of a statement from the fire hazard inspector, such cost shall be levied by an action filed by the city attorney against the property upon which the fire hazard exists. The levying of such assessment shall not affect the liability of the person to whom the order is directed. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1483, § 15.12.100, 12-7-93) 
Sec. 7-86. - Investigation of fires. 
    The fire hazard inspector shall investigate promptly the cause, origin, and circumstance of every fire occurring in the city in which property has been destroyed or damaged. If it appears to the officer making investigation that such fire is of suspicious origin, he shall then take immediate charge of the physical evidence and notify the proper authorities designated by law to make the investigation of such matters and shall further cooperate with them in the collection of the evidence and in the prosecution of the case. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1483, § 15.12.110, 12-7-93) 
Sec. 7-87. - Record of fires. 
    The fire hazard inspector shall keep a record of all fires and of all the facts concerning the same, including statistics as to the extent of such fires and the damage caused thereby, and whether such losses were covered by insurance, and if so, in what amount. All such records shall be public. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1483, § 15.12.120, 12-7-93) 
Sec. 7-88. - Report on activity. 
    The chief of the fire department shall submit a report on the activities of the fire prevention division to the mayor and members of the common council quarterly. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1483, § 15.12.130, 12-7-93) 
Sec. 7-89. - Permits generally. 
(a)  Issuance generally. The fire hazard inspector is hereby authorized and empowered to issue any written permit required by this division and to attach or prescribe conditions or limitations in the issuance thereof. 
(b)  Inspection prior to issuance. Before issuing a permit the fire hazard inspector shall inspect and approve the receptacles, vehicles, buildings, appliances, installations, equipment or storage places to be used. 
(c)  Application. All applications for permits required by this division shall be made to the fire hazard inspector in such form and detail as he shall prescribe. 
(d)  Record. It shall be the responsibility of the fire hazard inspector to maintain all records associated with the issuance of any permit pursuant to this division. 
(e)  Period. Every permit granted by the fire hazard inspector shall be for such period as the inspector shall determine. Permits: 
(1)  Shall not be transferable. 
(2)  Must at all times be kept on the premises designated therein. 
(3)  Shall at all times be subject to inspection by the fire hazard inspector and any officer of the fire or police department. 
(f)  Revocation. The fire hazard inspector shall revoke any permit issued under this section when he finds that: 
(1)  The permit is being used by any person other than the person to whom it was issued; 
(2)  The conditions or limitations set forth in the permit have been violated; 
(3)  Violations set forth in any written notice served upon a permittee by the fire hazard inspector have not been corrected within the time required by the notice; or 
(4)  The permit is being used for any premises or location other than that for which it was issued. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1483, § 15.12.140, 12-7-93) 
Sec. 7-90. - Required number of permits. 
    One permit only shall be required for retail establishments dealing in, or manufacturing plants using, two or more flammable, combustible or explosive materials, or keeping the same in the establishment at any one time. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1483, § 15.12.150, 12-7-93) 
Sec. 7-91. - Permits enumerated. 
    Permits are required by this division for: 
(1)  Flammable liquids: storage, handling and transportation. 
(2)  Liquefied petroleum gases: handling, transportation and storage. 
(3)  Explosives: use, storage, sale and transportation. 
(4)  Mechanical refrigeration systems: installation and operation. 
(5)  Pyrotechnic (fireworks) displays. 
(6)  Acetylene generators: installation and operation. 
(7)  Carbide storage. 
(8)  Public garages: repair and storage. 
(9)  Tank trucks, tank trailers, tank truck semitrailers: operation. 
(10)  Paint spray booths: installation and operation. 
(11)  Small arms ammunition: storage and sale. 
(12)  Nitrocellulose film: storage. 
(13)  Pyroxylin plastic: storage and handling of in excess of 200 pounds. 
(14)  Tire retreading and rebuilding plants. 
(15)  Installation of hot plates, ranges, boilers, grease hoods and vents other than residential. 
(16)  Any retail establishment. 
(17)  Occupancy of multifamily dwellings. 
(18)  Reoccupancy of private multifamily residences and retail establishments immediately following a fire. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1483, § 15.12.160, 12-7-93) 
Sec. 7-92. - Fire drills. 
    The fire hazard inspector shall require the officials of public, private and parochial schools, and other educational institutions to have one fire drill every quarter and to keep all doors and exits unlocked during school hours. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1483, § 15.12.170, 12-7-93) 
Sec. 7-93. - Hazardous practices. 
    No person shall engage in any of the following hazardous practices unless a permit has been issued by the fire hazard inspector: 
(1)  Bonfires. 
(2)  Use of flammable decorations. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1483, § 15.12.180, 12-7-93) 
Sec. 7-94. - Penalty. 
    Any person who shall violate any of the provisions of this Division or fails to comply with any order made thereunder, or who shall build in violation of any detailed statement of specifications or plans submitted and approve thereunder, or any certificate or permit issued thereunder, and from which no appeal has been taken, or who shall fail to comply with an order as affirmed or modified by the Chief of the Whiting Fire Department or the board of public works and safety or by court of competent jurisdiction, within the time fixed herein, shall severally for each and every violation and non-compliance respectively, be guilty of a violation and shall be fined not less than $100.00 nor more than $2,500.00 for each offense and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1483, § 15.12.190, 12-7-93; Ord. No. CC-2002-1633, 9-17-02) 
Secs. 7-95-7-100. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - SMOKE DETECTORS 

Sec. 7-101. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall apply, unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning. 
    Mobile home rental. Any mobile home or trailer occupied by or offered for occupancy to an individual as a residence on a rental basis. 
    Rental dwelling unit. Any building that contains living quarters for rent or lease for occupancy and shall include hotels, motels, boarding houses, sleeping room houses, buildings of mixed occupancy having any residential units, nursing homes, convalescent homes, licensed half-way houses, or lodging homes. 
    Sleeping area. The area of a unit in which bedrooms or sleeping rooms are located. Bedrooms or sleeping rooms separated by another use area such as a kitchen or living room are separate "sleeping areas", but bedrooms or sleeping rooms separated by a bathroom are not separate "sleeping areas". 
    Smoke detector. A device which detects particles or products of combustion other than heat, approved by Underwriters Laboratories, Inc. or Factory Mutual. The "smoke detector" device shall be equipped with a test button. The "smoke detector" device may be either battery powered with a minimum nine volt or it may be powered by a 110 volt alternating current. 
(Ord. No. CC-2002-1633, 9-17-02) 
Sec. 7-102. - Smoke detectors required. 
    All rental dwelling units and all mobile home rentals shall be equipped with smoke detectors. 
(Ord. No. CC-2002-1633, 9-17-02) 
Sec. 7-103. - Location; installation. 
(a)  Smoke detectors shall be mounted on the ceiling or wall at a point centrally located in the corridor or area giving access to the rooms used for sleeping purposes. Where a common hallway is used, smoke detectors shall be spaced not more than 15 feet apart in the hallway or as otherwise provided by the authorities with jurisdiction, i.e., building commissioner or fire department. All smoke detectors shall be located either on the ceiling or on a wall not less than four nor more than 12 inches from the ceiling, and within 15 feet of all rooms used for sleeping purposes. No detector shall be recessed into the ceiling. 
(b)  If a smoke detector is A.C. powered, it must be directly attached to a junction box not controlled by any switch other than the main power supply. The installation of A.C. powered detectors shall conform to all electrical standards adopted by the city. A smoke detector required under this chapter shall be installed according to the directions and specifications of the manufacturer, but if in conflict with any city electrical standard, the city electrical standard shall take precedence. 
(Ord. No. CC-2002-1633, 9-17-02) 
Sec. 7-104. - Maintenance. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to tamper with or remove any smoke detector except when it is necessary for maintenance or inspection purposes. Any smoke detector removed for repair or replacement shall be re-installed or replaced so that it is in place during normal sleeping hours. At every change of tenant in every multiple family dwelling unit or mobile home rental, smoke detectors shall be tested to see that they are in operable condition. 
(Ord. No. CC-2002-1633, 9-17-02) 
Sec. 7-105. - Duties of property owner and tenant. 
    Every owner of any rental dwelling unit or mobile home rental shall be responsible for a) the installation and repair of all smoke detectors as herein provided, and b) the installation, repair, and maintenance of all smoke detectors in common areas. Every tenant of any rental dwelling unit shall be responsible for the maintenance and testing of such smoke detectors in the unit such tenant occupies. Testing shall be conducted by the occupant at least one time every six months. The occupant shall notify the manager, rental agent or owner immediately if the smoke detector is in need of repair or replacement. This requirement applies to smoke detectors required by any state or federal law as well as by this chapter, unless excused by other applicable state or federal law. 
(Ord. No. CC-2002-1633, 9-17-02) 
Sec. 7-106. - Enforcement of provisions. 
    The building department and the fire department of the city shall be authorized to make such inspections and require such certification as they deem necessary and appropriate in order to enforce the terms of this ordinance. Certification may not be required more frequently than annually. Inspections may be made more frequently than annually as the respective departments deem necessary. 
(Ord. No. CC-2002-1633, 9-17-02) 
Sec. 7-107. - Authority to seek injunctive relief. 
    In addition to pursuing in Whiting City Court the penalty provisions enumerated in Section 7-94 of Chapter 7, the Chief of the Whiting Fire Department may also bring an action in the name of the city in the Lake Circuit Court or any of the Lake Superior Courts (Civil Division) for mandatory or prohibitory injunctive relief in the enforcement of the provisions of this subchapter, including the securing of compliance with any other order of the chief of the fire department, and any such action for injunctive relief may have joined with it an action to recover the penalties listed in section 7-94. 
(Ord. No. CC-2002-1633, 9-17-02) 
Secs. 7-108-7-120. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - FIRE PREVENTION GENERALLY 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 7-121. - Burning. 
    It is unlawful and shall be deemed disorderly conduct for any person to kindle or cause to be kindled any fire for the purpose of burning shavings or any other combustible matter, rubbish and paper in any highway, street, alley or upon any plot within the corporate limits of the city. 
(Code 1962, § 17-510; Code 1979, § 8.04.010) 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 15. 
Secs. 7-122-7-140. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - USE, IGNITION OR DISCHARGE OF FIREWORKS[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. CC-2008-1788, § I, adopted February 19, 2008, repealed Ch. 7, Art. III, Div. 2A-F, §§ 7-141-7-144 in its entirety. Section II of said ordinance enacted new provisions to read as herein set out. Formerly, said division was entitled Fireworks; Explosives and derived from Code 1962, § 17-101-17-105; Code 1979, §§ 8.12.010-8.12.040. 
State Law reference- Fireworks, IC 22-11-14-1 et seq.; fire safety rules, IC 22-13-3-1 et seq.; regulated explosives, IC 22-14-4-1 et seq. 

Sec. 7-141. - Scope. 
    This division shall regulate the use, ignition or discharge of fireworks within the City of Whiting. 
(Ord. No. CC-2008-1788, § 2A, 2-19-2008) 
Sec. 7-142. - Definitions. 
    [The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:] 
    Consumer firework is a small firework that is designated primarily to produce visible or audible effects by combustions and that is required to comply with the constructions, chemical compositions, and labeling regulations promulgated by the United States Consumer Product Safety Commission under 16 CFR 1507. The term also includes some small devices designated to produce an audible effect, such as whistling devices, ground devices containing fifty (50) milligrams or less of explosive composition, and aerial devices containing one hundred thirty (130) milligrams or less of explosive composition. Propelling and expelling charges consisting of a mixture of charcoal sulfur and potassium nitrate are not considered to be designed to produce an audible effect. Consumer fireworks include: 
a)  aerial devices, which include, but are not limited to, sky rockets, missile type rockets, helicopter or aerial spinners, roman candles, mines and shells; 
b)  ground audible devices, which include, but are not limited to, firecrackers, salutes and chasers; and 
c)  firework devices containing combinations of the effects described in numbers (1) and (2). 
d)  Consumer fireworks do not include the following fireworks as referenced in Indiana Code 22-11-14-8(a): 
1)  Dipped sticks or wire sparklers. However, the total pyrotechnic composition may not exceed one hundred (100) grams per item, and devices containing chlorate or perchlorate salts may not exceed five (5) grams per item; 
2)  Cylindrical fountains; 
3)  Cone fountains; 
4)  Illuminating torches; 
5)  Wheels; 
6)  Ground spinners; 
7)  Flitter sparklers; 
8)  Snakes or glow worms; 
9)  Smoke devices; 
10)  Trick noisemakers that include party poppers, booby traps, snapper trick matches, cigarette loads and auto burglar alarms. 
2.  Firework is any composition or device designed for the purpose of producing a visible or audible effect by combustions, deflagration or detonation. Fireworks consist of both common fireworks and special fireworks, including Consumer Fireworks. The following items are excluded from the definition of fireworks: 
a)  model rockets; 
b)  toy pistol caps; 
c)  emergency signal flares; 
d)  matches; 
e)  fixed ammunition for firearms; 
f)  ammunition components intended for use in firearms, muzzle loading cannon or small arms; 
g)  shells, cartridges and primers for use in firearms, muzzle loading cannons or small arms; 
h)  indoor pyrotechnics special effects material; 
i)  M-80s, cherry bombs, silver salutes and any device banned by the federal government. 
(Ord. No. CC-208-1788, § 2B, 2-19-2008) 
Sec. 7-143. - Regulation of use of consumer fireworks. 
(a)  No person within the City of Whiting may use, ignite, or discharge or permit to be used, ignited or discharged, any type of Consumer Fireworks on any other day or time other than the following: 
(1)  June 29, June 30, July 1, July 2, July 3, July 5, July 6, July 7, July 8 and July 9 between the hours of 5:00 p.m. and two (2) hours after sunset; 
(2)  Memorial Day, July 4 th , Labor Day and Veterans Day between the hours of 10:00 a.m. and 12:00 midnight; and 
(3)  Between the hours of 10:00 a.m. on December 31 and 1:00 a.m. on January 1. 
(b)  No person may use, ignite or discharge or permit to be used, ignited or discharged, any Consumer Fireworks, as such use is permitted in paragraph (a) above, within the City of Whiting in or on any park, playground, school property, church property or parking lot without the express written consent of the owner. 
(c)  No person may use, ignite or discharge or permit to be used, ignited or discharged, any Consumer Fireworks, as such use is permitted in paragraph (a) above, within the City of Whiting upon any public street, alley or sidewalk without the prior written consent of the City of Whiting Board of Public Works and Safety. 
(Ord. No. CC-2008-1788, § 2C, 2-19-2008) 
Sec. 7-144. - Regulation of use of fireworks. 
    No person within the City of Whiting may use, ignite or discharge or permit to be used, ignited or discharged, any Fireworks other than Consumer Fireworks except in accordance with Indiana Code 22-11-14-2. 
(Ord. No. CC-2008-1788, § 2D, 2-19-2008) 
Sec. 7-145. - Enforcement. 
    This division may be enforced by any duly authorized City Inspector, including but not limited to, sworn fire department personnel, sworn police department personnel and members of the Emergency Management Branch of the Police Department. 
(Ord. No. CC-2008-1788, § 2E, 2-19-2008) 
Sec. 7-146. - Penalty provision. 
    Violations of this division shall be subject to the general penalty provisions of Whiting Municipal Code Section 1-11. 
(Ord. No. CC-2008-1788, § 2F, 2-19-2008) 
Chapter 7.5 - FLOODS 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 7.5-1-7.5-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - FLOOD HAZARD AREAS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. CC-2016-1953, arts. 1-8, adopted Feb. 16, 2016, repealed the former Art. II, §§ 7.5-26-7.5-33, and enacted a new Art. II as set out herein. The former article pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. CC-2011-1857, §§ 1-8, adopted Sept. 20, 2011. 

Sec. 7.5-26. - Statutory authorization, findings of fact, purpose, and objectives. 
(a)  Statutory authorization. The Indiana Legislature has in IC 36-7-4 and IC 14-28-4 granted the power to local government units to control land use within their jurisdictions. Therefore, the Common Council of the City of Whiting does hereby adopt the following floodplain management regulations. 
(b)  Findings of fact. 
(1)  The flood hazard areas of the City of Whiting are subject to periodic inundation which results in loss of life and property, health and safety hazards, disruption of commerce and governmental services, extraordinary public expenditures for flood protection and relief, and impairment of the tax base, all of which adversely affect the public health, safety, and general welfare. 
(2)  These flood losses are caused by the cumulative effect of obstructions in floodplains causing increases in flood heights and velocities, and by the occupancy in flood hazard areas by uses vulnerable to floods or hazardous to other lands which are inadequately elevated, inadequately flood-proofed, or otherwise unprotected from flood damages. 
(c)  Statement of purpose. It is the purpose of this article to promote the public health, safety, and general welfare and to minimize public and private losses due to flood conditions in specific areas by provisions designed to: 
(1)  Restrict or prohibit uses which are dangerous to health, safety, and property due to water or erosion hazards, which result in damaging increases in erosion or in flood heights or velocities. 
(2)  Require that uses vulnerable to floods, including facilities which serve such uses, be protected against flood damage at the time of initial construction. 
(3)  Control the alteration of natural floodplains, stream channels, and natural protective barriers which are involved in the accommodation of flood waters. 
(4)  Control filling, grading, dredging, and other development which may increase erosion or flood damage. 
(5)  Prevent or regulate the construction of flood barriers which will unnaturally divert floodwaters or which may increase flood hazards to other lands. 
(6)  Make federal flood insurance available for structures and their contents in the city by fulfilling the requirements of the National Flood Insurance Program. 
(d)  Objectives. The objectives of this article are: 
(1)  To protect human life and health. 
(2)  To minimize expenditure of public money for costly flood control projects. 
(3)  To minimize the need for rescue and relief efforts associated with flooding and generally undertaken at the expense of the general public. 
(4)  To minimize prolonged business interruptions. 
(5)  To minimize damage to public facilities and utilities such as water and gas mains, electric, telephone, and sewer lines, streets, and bridges located in floodplains. 
(6)  To help maintain a stable tax base by providing for the sound use and development of flood prone areas in such a manner as to minimize flood blight areas. 
(Ord. No. CC-2016-1953, art. 1, 2-16-16) 
Sec. 7.5-27. - Definitions. 
    Unless specifically defined below, words or phrases used in this article shall be interpreted so as to give them the meaning they have in common usage and to give this article its most reasonable application. 
    A zone means portions of the SFHA in which the principal source of flooding is runoff from rainfall, snowmelt, or a combination of both. In A zones, floodwaters may move slowly or rapidly, but waves are usually not a significant threat to buildings. These areas are labeled as Zone A, Zone AE, Zones A1-A30, Zone AO, Zone AH, Zone AR and Zone A99 on a FIRM. The definitions are presented below: 
Zone A: Areas subject to inundation by the one-percent annual chance flood event. Because detailed hydraulic analyses have not been performed, no base flood elevation or depths are shown. 
Zone AE and A1-A30: Areas subject to inundation by the one-percent annual chance flood event determined by detailed methods. Base flood elevations are shown within these zones. (Zone AE is on new and revised maps in place of Zones A1-A30.) 
Zone AO: Areas subject to inundation by one-percent annual chance shallow flooding (usually sheet flow on sloping terrain) where average depths are between one and three feet. Average flood depths derived from detailed hydraulic analyses are shown within this zone. 
Zone AH: Areas subject to inundation by one-percent annual chance shallow flooding (usually areas of ponding) where average depths are between one and three feet. Average flood depths derived from detailed hydraulic analyses are shown within this zone. 
Zone AR: Areas that result from the decertification of a previously accredited flood protection system that is determined to be in the process of being restored to provide base flood protection. 
Zone A99: Areas subject to inundation by the one-percent annual chance flood event, but which will ultimately be protected upon completion of an under-construction federal flood protection system. These are areas of special flood hazard where enough progress has been made on the construction of a protection system, such as dikes, dams, and levees, to consider it complete for insurance rating purposes. Zone A99 may only be used when the flood protection system has reached specified statutory progress toward completion. No base flood elevations or depths are shown. 
    Accessory structure (appurtenant structure) means a structure with a floor area 400 square feet or less that is located on the same parcel of property as the principal structure and the use of which is incidental to the use of the principal structure. Accessory structures should constitute a minimal initial investment, may not be used for human habitation, and be designed to have minimal flood damage potential. Examples of accessory structures are detached garages, carports, storage sheds, pole barns, and hay sheds. 
    Addition (to an existing structure) means any walled and roofed expansion to the perimeter of a structure in which the addition is connected by a common load-bearing wall other than a firewall. Any walled and roofed addition, which is connected by a firewall or is separated by independent perimeter load-bearing walls, is new construction. 
    Appeal means a request for a review of the floodplain administrator's interpretation of any provision of this article. 
    Area of shallow flooding means a designated AO or AH Zone on the community's flood insurance rate map (FIRM) with base flood depths from one to three feet where a clearly defined channel does not exist, where the path of flooding is unpredictable and indeterminate, and where velocity flow may be evident. Such flooding is characterized by ponding or sheet flow. 
    Base flood means the flood having a one-percent chance of being equaled or exceeded in any given year. 
    Base flood elevation (BFE) means the elevation of the one-percent annual chance flood. 
    Basement means that portion of a structure having its floor sub-grade (below ground level) on all sides. 
    Boundary river means the part of the Ohio River that forms the boundary between Kentucky and Indiana. 
    Boundary river floodway means the floodway of a boundary river. 
    Building. See "Structure." 
    Community means a political entity that has the authority to adopt and enforce floodplain ordinances for the area under its jurisdiction. 
    Community rating system (CRS) means a program developed by the Federal Insurance Administration to provide incentives for those communities in the regular program that have gone beyond the minimum floodplain management requirements to develop extra measures to provide protection from flooding. 
    Critical facility means a facility for which even a slight chance of flooding might be too great. Critical facilities include, but are not limited to, schools, nursing homes, hospitals, police, fire, and emergency response installations, installations which produce, use or store hazardous materials or hazardous waste. 
    D Zone means unstudied areas where flood hazards are undetermined, but flooding is possible. Flood insurance is available in participating communities but is not required by regulation in this zone. 
    Development means any man-made change to improved or unimproved real estate including but not limited to: 
(1)  Construction, reconstruction, or placement of a structure or any addition to a structure; 
(2)  Installing a manufactured home on a site, preparing a site for a manufactured home or installing a recreational vehicle on a site for more than 180 days; 
(3)  Installing utilities, erection of walls and fences, construction of roads, or similar projects; 
(4)  Construction of flood control structures such as levees, dikes, dams, channel improvements, etc.; 
(5)  Mining, dredging, filling, grading, excavation, or drilling operations; 
(6)  Construction and/or reconstruction of bridges or culverts; 
(7)  Storage of materials; or 
(8)  Any other activity that might change the direction, height, or velocity of flood or surface waters. 
"Development" does not include activities such as the maintenance of existing structures and facilities such as painting, re-roofing; resurfacing roads; or gardening, plowing, and similar agricultural practices that do not involve filling, grading, excavation, or the construction of permanent structures. 
    Elevated structure means a non-basement structure built to have the lowest floor elevated above the ground level by means of fill, solid foundation perimeter walls, filled stem wall foundations (also called chain walls), pilings, or columns (posts and piers). 
    Elevation certificate means a certified statement that verifies a structure's elevation information. 
    Emergency program means the first phase under which a community participates in the NFIP. It is intended to provide a first layer amount of insurance at subsidized rates on all insurable structures in that community before the effective date of the initial FIRM. 
    Existing manufactured home park or subdivision means a manufactured home park or subdivision for which the construction of facilities for servicing the lots on which the manufactured homes are to be affixed (including, at a minimum, the installation of utilities, the construction of streets, and either final site grading or the pouring of concrete pads) is completed before the effective date of the community's first floodplain ordinance. 
    Expansion to an existing manufactured home park or subdivision means the preparation of additional sites by the construction of facilities for servicing the lots on which the manufactured homes are to be affixed (including the installation of utilities, the construction of streets, and either final site grading or the pouring of concrete pads). 
    FEMA means the Federal Emergency Management Agency. 
    Flood means a general and temporary condition of partial or complete inundation of normally dry land areas from the overflow, the unusual and rapid accumulation, or the runoff of surface waters from any source. 
    Flood boundary and floodway map (FBFM) means an official map on which the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) or Federal Insurance Administration (FIA) has delineated the areas of flood hazards and regulatory floodway. 
    Flood insurance rate map (FIRM) means an official map of a community, on which FEMA has delineated both the areas of special flood hazard and the risk premium zones applicable to the community. 
    Flood insurance study (FIS) means the official hydraulic and hydrologic report provided by FEMA. The report contains flood profiles, as well as the FIRM, FBFM (where applicable), and the water surface elevation of the base flood. 
    Flood prone area means any land area acknowledged by a community as being susceptible to inundation by water from any source. (See "Flood.") 
    Flood protection grade (FPG) means the elevation of the regulatory flood plus two feet at any given location in the SFHA. (See "Freeboard.") 
    Floodplain means the channel proper and the areas adjoining any wetland, lake, or watercourse which have been or hereafter may be covered by the regulatory flood. The floodplain includes both the floodway and the fringe districts. 
    Floodplain management means the operation of an overall program of corrective and preventive measures for reducing flood damage and preserving and enhancing, where possible, natural resources in the floodplain, including but not limited to emergency preparedness plans, flood control works, floodplain management regulations, and open space plans. 
    Floodplain management regulations means this article and other zoning ordinances, subdivision regulations, building codes, health regulations, special purpose ordinances, and other applications of police power which control development in flood-prone areas. This term describes federal, state, or local regulations in any combination thereof, which provide standards for preventing and reducing flood loss and damage. Floodplain management regulations are also referred to as floodplain regulations, floodplain ordinance, flood damage prevention ordinance, and floodplain management requirements. 
    Floodproofing (dry floodproofing) means a method of protecting a structure that ensures that the structure, together with attendant utilities and sanitary facilities, is watertight to the floodproofed design elevation with walls that are substantially impermeable to the passage of water. All structural components of these walls are capable of resisting hydrostatic and hydrodynamic flood forces, including the effects of buoyancy, and anticipated debris impact forces. 
    Floodproofing certificate means a form used to certify compliance for non-residential structures as an alternative to elevating structures to or above the FPG. This certification must be by a registered professional engineer or architect. 
    Floodway is the channel of a river or stream and those portions of the floodplains adjoining the channel which are reasonably required to efficiently carry and discharge the peak flood flow of the regulatory flood of any river or stream. 
    Freeboard means a factor of safety, usually expressed in feet above the BFE, which is applied for the purposes of floodplain management. It is used to compensate for the many unknown factors that could contribute to flood heights greater than those calculated for the base flood. 
    Fringe means those portions of the floodplain lying outside the floodway. 
    Hardship (as related to variances of this article) means the exceptional hardship that would result from a failure to grant the requested variance. The Whiting Common Council requires that the variance is exceptional, unusual, and peculiar to the property involved. Mere economic or financial hardship alone is not exceptional. Inconvenience, aesthetic considerations, physical handicaps, personal preferences, or the disapproval of one's neighbors likewise cannot, as a rule, qualify as an exceptional hardship. All of these problems can be resolved through other means without granting a variance, even if the alternative is more expensive, or requires the property owner to build elsewhere or put the parcel to a different use than originally intended. 
    Highest adjacent grade means the highest natural elevation of the ground surface, prior to the start of construction, next to the proposed walls of a structure. 
    Historic structures means any structures individually listed on the National Register of Historic Places or the Indiana State Register of Historic Sites and Structures. 
    Increased cost of compliance (ICC) means the cost to repair a substantially damaged structure that exceeds the minimal repair cost and that is required to bring a substantially damaged structure into compliance with the local flood damage prevention ordinance. Acceptable mitigation measures are elevation, relocation, demolition, or any combination thereof. All renewal and new business flood insurance policies with effective dates on or after June 1, 1997, will include ICC coverage. 
    Letter of final determination (LFD) means a letter issued by FEMA during the mapping update process which establishes final elevations and provides the new flood map and flood study to the community. The LFD initiates the six-month adoption period. The community must adopt or amend its floodplain management regulations during this six-month period unless the community has previously incorporated an automatic adoption clause. 
    Letter of map change (LOMC) is a general term used to refer to the several types of revisions and amendments to FEMA maps that can be accomplished by letter. They include letter of map amendment (LOMA), letter of map revision (LOMR), and letter of map revision based on fill (LOMR-F). The definitions are presented below: 
Letter of map amendment (LOMA) means an amendment by letter to the currently effective FEMA map that establishes that a property is not located in a SFHA through the submittal of property specific elevation data. A LOMA is only issued by FEMA. 
Letter of map revision (LOMR) means an official revision to the currently effective FEMA map. It is issued by FEMA and changes flood zones, delineations, and elevations. 
Letter of map revision based on fill (LOMR-F) means an official revision by letter to an effective NFIP map. A LOMR-F provides FEMA's determination concerning whether a structure or parcel has been elevated on fill above the BFE and excluded from the SFHA. 
    Lowest adjacent grade means the lowest elevation, after completion of construction, of the ground, sidewalk, patio, deck support, or basement entryway immediately next to the structure. 
    Lowest floor means the lowest elevation described among the following: 
(1)  The top of the lowest level of the structure. 
(2)  The top of the basement floor. 
(3)  The top of the garage floor, if the garage is the lowest level of the structure. 
(4)  The top of the first floor of a structure elevated on pilings or pillars. 
(5)  The top of the floor level of any enclosure, other than a basement, below an elevated structure where the walls of the enclosure provide any resistance to the flow of flood waters unless: 
a.  The walls are designed to automatically equalize the hydrostatic flood forces on the walls by allowing for the entry and exit of flood waters by providing a minimum of two openings (in addition to doorways and windows) in a minimum of two exterior walls; if a structure has more than one enclosed area, each shall have openings on exterior walls;
