    It is lawful for persons to install and maintain benches located upon public property for the accommodation of persons awaiting public bus transportation and others, and to place advertising matter and signs upon such benches, subject to the regulations, limitations and qualifications of this article. The city council reserves the power to make all reasonable regulations for carrying out the provisions of this article and the issuing of all permits or licenses. 
(Code 1962, § 6-201; Code 1979, § 5.04.020) 
Sec. 10-78. - Permit-Required; application. 
    No bench shall be installed or maintained under this article without a permit obtained as provided in this article. No more than one permit shall be allowed for any single location. An applicant for a permit under this article shall submit his written application to the city clerk-treasurer, giving the location of the proposed bench or benches and such other information as the city council requires in this article or may from time to time require. 
(Code 1962, § 6-202; Code 1979, § 5.04.030) 
Sec. 10-79. - Same-Fee. 
    Each application for a permit under this article shall be accompanied by a fee of $1.00 for each bench where the permit is to be issued after July 1 in any year, and a fee of $2.00 where the permit is to be issued before July 1 in any year, and thereafter a fee of $2.00 shall be paid annually for each bench. 
(Code 1962, § 6-203; Code 1979, § 5.04.040) 
Sec. 10-80. - Same-Denial or cancellation. 
    The application for a permit for any bench shall be denied or the permit cancelled under any of the following circumstances: 
(1)  If the city council at any time finds that the maintenance of a bench at the granted or proposed location would tend to obstruct passage along a public way or to create a hazard to persons traveling thereon. 
(2)  If the city council at any time finds that the maintenance of a bench at the granted or proposed location would not promote the convenience of the traveling public or allow free and customary use of any street, alley or sidewalk. 
(3)  If at the proposed location the distance from the face of the curb to the property line is less than eight feet, unless the city council finds that to maintain a bench at such location is in the interest of the convenience of the traveling public. 
(Code 1962, § 6-204; Code 1979, § 5.04.050) 
Sec. 10-81. - Maintenance responsibility; removal by city. 
    By acceptance of a permit under this article, the licensee agrees to be bound by all the provisions of this article, agrees to inspect each bench periodically and to maintain the bench or benches in safe, clean and sightly condition, and to post and maintain public liability insurance as required in section 10-83. The city council reserves the right to order the removal of any such bench at any time when in its opinion the interest of the public will be best served by the removal of the bench. If any such bench is ordered removed by the city council and the same is not done within 30 days of the mailing of written notice to so remove any such bench to the licensee, the city council may revoke the permit and take whatever action is deemed necessary for the removal of the bench without any liability on the part of the members of the city council individually or the city council as a whole. 
(Code 1962, § 6-205; Code 1979, § 5.04.060) 
Sec. 10-82. - Specifications. 
    All benches installed by permission of this article shall conform rigidly to the following specifications: 
(1)  No bench shall be more than seven feet in length, nor more than 25 inches in depth, nor more than 42 inches in height and six inches thick. The benches shall be of uniform painting and construction, the ends and legs thereof to be made of concrete and the seats and backs thereof to be made of hardwood or plywood and shall be constructed in a workmanlike manner. 
(2)  No advertising placed on the benches shall contain words that might tend to cause traffic confusion such as "stop," "damage," "drive-in," or other such words. 
(Code 1962, § 6-206; Code 1979, § 5.04.070) 
Sec. 10-83. - Liability insurance required. 
    Before proceeding to install any bench or benches, the licensee under this article shall furnish to and file with the city clerk-treasurer and at all times keep in effect a policy of insurance in some company approved by the city council naming the licensee and the city as assured, which shall be in such form and with conditions as to protect the city against all claims for death or injury resulting from the installation or maintenance of such benches, and to pay all damages which may be recovered against the city as a result of any such suit or suits. Such policy shall be conditioned to pay all damages not exceeding the sum of $100,000.00 for the death of or injury to any one person and with a total limit of liability for death or injury of not less than $200,000.00, and $5,000.00 for property damage. If at any time by reason of judgments obtained the city feels itself insecure against further claims, additional insurance shall be furnished so that at all times the city shall be protected against such losses to the extent of $100,000.00. 
(Code 1962, § 6-207; Code 1979, § 5.04.080) 
Secs. 10-84-10-105. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - AMUSEMENT DEVICES[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference- Amusement devices, IC 22-15-7-1 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 10-106. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Amusement device means any amusement machine or device operated by means of the insertion of a coin, token, or similar object, for the purpose of amusement or skill and for the playing of which a fee is charged. The term shall also include any pool table (regardless of whether such table requires the insertion of coin or token in order to operate), any game using computer technology and a type of video display, and all other games, operations, or transactions similar thereto under whatever name that may be indicated, whether or not the element of skill for such manipulation of special equipment predominates over chance, luck, or fortuity. The term does not include vending machines in which are not incorporated gaming or amusement features, nor does the term include any coin-operated mechanical musical devices. 
    Business means any person, firm, club, corporation, or other business entity doing business in the city. 
    Business arcade license means the license required to operate a game arcade business. 
    Fire chief means the chief of the fire department. 
    Game arcade means any place where three or more amusement devices are displayed for use by the public, whether or not another business is conducted on the premises. 
    Game license means the license required to operate an amusement device. 
    Police chief means the chief of police of the police department. 
    Proprietor means any individual, firm, club, or corporation or any other business entity operating a game arcade. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1503, § 1A-D, F, I, L, M, 12-7-93) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 10-107. - Persons under 16; school hours; posting notice. 
    The person in charge of any game arcade, and the person in charge of the area of any other establishment where games are available for use by the public, shall not permit any person under 16 years of age to remain in the arcade or area where the games are available, on school days during the hours when school is in session. The person in charge shall not use force to enforce this requirement, but the truant officer may be called. A person under 16 who normally attends a private school or a school sponsored by a religious organization in lieu of the public school may be in an arcade or in the area where games are kept at times when the private school or school sponsored by the religious organization is not in session. Each licensee under this article shall display a sign with substantially the following wording, or with other wording giving substantially the same meaning: 
NOTICE 
If you are under 16 years of age, you will not be allowed to remain in this arcade on school days during the hours when school is in session. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1503, § 11, 12-7-93) 
Sec. 10-108. - Coins and tokens. 
    In devices requiring coins for operation, only United States coins shall be used. The management of any establishment may sell tokens or provide machines to sell tokens, to be used in games instead of coins. No person shall defraud any business by using any foreign coin, counterfeit coin or unauthorized token to obtain the use of a game without paying for it. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1503, § 13, 12-7-93) 
Sec. 10-109. - Nuisance; injunction. 
    Any violation of this article is hereby declared to be a nuisance. In addition to any other relief provided by this article, the city may apply to a court of competent jurisdiction for an injunction to prohibit the continuation of any violation of this article. Such application for relief may include seeking a temporary restraining order, temporary injunction or permanent injunction. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1503, § 14, 12-7-93) 
Sec. 10-110. - Gambling devices prohibited. 
    Nothing in this article shall be construed as to authorize, permit, or license any gambling devices of any kind, nature, or description whatsoever. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1503, § 15, 12-7-93) 
Sec. 10-111. - Prohibition near church or school. 
    No person shall place or keep any amusement device or devices for use, or permit such placement, maintenance, or use, within 200 feet of a school or church. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1503, § 16, 12-7-93) 
Sec. 10-112. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating any provision of this article shall be fined not less than $25.00 nor more than $2,500.00 for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1503, § 17, 12-7-93) 
Secs. 10-113-10-130. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSES 

Sec. 10-131. - Required for games; fees. 
(a)  Any business having an amusement device or devices open for business shall obtain a game license for each amusement device. 
(b)  The annual fee for such game license shall be $50.00 for each amusement device except for pool tables, which shall be $50.00 per table, except in the instance in which no charge is assessed for the use of the pool table in which case no game license is required. 
(c)  No additional license need be obtained when a different machine is substituted for a machine on the premises, without increasing the total number of machines offered for use on the premises. 
(d)  The license fees required by this section shall be payable annually in advance, provided that where application is made after the expiration of any portion of any license year, a license may be issued for the remainder thereof upon payment of a proportionate part of the annual fee. In no case shall any portion of the license fee be refunded to the licensee. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1503, § 2, 12-7-93; Ord. No. CC-2009-1811, § 2, 2-3-09) 
Sec. 10-132. - Required for arcades; fees. 
(a)  No proprietor shall operate a game arcade without having a valid business arcade license for such business. 
(b)  The annual fee for such business arcade license shall be $50.00. 
(c)  The license fee required by this section shall be payable annually in advance, provided that where application is made after the expiration of any portion of any license year, a license may be issued for the remainder thereof upon payment of a proportionate part of the annual fee. In no case shall any portion of the license fee be refunded to the licensee. 
(d)  Any business that is already licensed as some other business shall also be required to obtain a business arcade license if three or more amusement devices are displayed for use by the public on the premises of the business. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1503, § 3, 12-7-93) 
Sec. 10-133. - Investigation and processing fee. 
    In addition to the annual fee required by the terms of this article, each applicant for a new business arcade license or game license shall pay a one-time nonrefundable investigation fee of $35.00. No investigation fee shall be required for renewals. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1503, § 4, 12-7-93) 
Sec. 10-134. - Applications. 
(a)  Applications for business arcade licenses and game licenses shall be filed with the clerk-treasurer on forms to be furnished by the clerk-treasurer. Such applications shall contain enough information to enable city employees and officials to process the application and make the necessary investigation and shall contain the following specific information: 
(1)  The name and address of the applicant. 
a.  If the applicant is a partnership, the name and address of each partner shall be given. 
b.  If the applicant is a corporation, the name and address of the chief executive officer of the corporation, and of the president, vice president, secretary and treasurer of the corporation, shall also be furnished. 
c.  If a post office box is used as a mailing address, the individual's or firm's residence or business address shall be provided as well. 
(2)  The address and room or store number of the location where the games are to be placed. 
(3)  The number of games to be placed along with a complete description of the amusement device or devices including but not limited to the trade name, the name of the manufacturer, model number, serial number, and any other identification number or feature or designation by which the amusement device or devices may be readily identifiable. 
(4)  The name to be used for the business. If the games are to be located on the same premises as a restaurant, convenience store or other business, the name of the business shall also be provided. 
(5)  Whether the applicant is the owner, renter, or lessee of the premises where the amusement device or devices shall be kept, possessed, operated, used, played, or maintained; if the applicant is not the owner, then the name and address of the owner shall be given. 
(6)  Whether or not the applicant or any other person or persons who shall be connected or associated with the keeping, possession, operation, maintaining or placing of the amusement device or devices have ever been convicted for the violation of any gambling laws or any dangerous drug-related offenses. 
(7)  Any other information as may be requested on the application form. 
(b)  Applications for business arcade licenses and game licenses shall be filed with the clerk-treasurer no later than the last day of the third month of continuous operation of the business filing the application. Failure to file an application within this three-month designated time span will result in an additional $25.00 being assessed at the time of application approval and issuance. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1503, § 5, 12-7-93; Ord. No. CC 93-1513, § 4(5), 4-19-94) 
Sec. 10-135. - Procedure. 
    Upon receipt of an application for an arcade license or a game license, the clerk-treasurer shall provide a copy of the application and refer the matter to the police chief for an investigation of the character of the individuals whose names and addresses are required to be furnished by section 10-134. The clerk-treasurer shall also furnish a copy of the application to the building commissioner to determine whether the proposed business will violate any provision of the zoning code or the building code of the city and to the fire chief to determine if all fire safety requirements have been met. The application, together with the reports of the police chief and fire chief along with the building commissioner's report and any other city department report associated with the applicant, shall be returned to the clerk-treasurer, who shall forward all such information to the board of public works and safety for action at its next regularly scheduled meeting. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1503, § 6, 12-7-93) 
Sec. 10-136. - Requirements for business arcade license. 
    The following regulations shall apply to issuance of business arcade licenses: 
(1)  No business arcade license shall be issued to any individual who has been convicted of a felony crime. No license shall be issued to any partnership unless each of the partners is of good moral character. No license shall be issued to any corporation unless the chief executive officer, president, vice-president, secretary, and treasurer of the corporation are of good moral character. 
(2)  No business arcade license shall be issued for any business in any premises that do not comply with the applicable provisions of the building, zoning or fire codes of the city. 
(3)  No business arcade license shall be issued for any business that does not comply with this article or any other ordinance provisions of the city and with all applicable state laws. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1503, § 7, 12-7-93) 
Sec. 10-137. - Issuance; notice; appeals. 
(a)  Based upon a review of a completed application and all investigation results associated with the application and only upon finding that an applicant for a business arcade license and/or game license has complied with the requirements of this article, all other city ordinance provisions and applicable state laws, the board of public works and safety shall authorize the clerk-treasurer to issue the applicable license. 
(b)  Applicants shall be promptly notified by the clerk-treasurer's office of the issuance or decision refusing a license. The board of public works and safety shall give reasons in writing for any license refusals. 
(c)  Any applicant aggrieved by a decision issuing or refusing to issue a license may appeal the board of public works and safety's decision to the city council by filing a written notice of appeal within one week of the board's decision. The notice of appeal need not be in any particular form, but it must identify the decision from which the appeal is being taken. Such appeal shall be heard by the city council at its next regularly scheduled meeting upon receiving an appeal request. The city council action shall be final, except for the right of any party to file an action in court. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1503, § 8, 12-7-93) 
Sec. 10-138. - Renewal. 
    Any license issued under this article shall be renewed upon the filing of an application for renewal and the payment of the annual fee, if the business complies with all applicable laws and ordinances and if there are no grounds for revocation of the arcade business license. No investigation fee shall be charged in connection with a renewal. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1503, § 9, 12-7-93) 
Sec. 10-139. - Available for inspection. 
(a)  Each current business arcade license or game license issued under this article shall be kept at the business premises available for inspection by appropriate authorities of the city. 
(b)  Each licensee shall display the license so issued for each amusement device in a conspicuous place in or on such location or place where it may be readily observed by anyone using the licensed amusement device. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1503, § 10, 12-7-93) 
Sec. 10-140. - Cancellation of license. 
    The board of public works and safety shall have the right to cancel the license, effective upon notice to the licensee, of any licensee that repeatedly violates the terms of this article. Such cancellation may be appealed to the city council pursuant to the procedures as set forth in section 10-137. Any licensee that has had any license canceled under this article shall not be eligible to apply for any other license under this article for a period of six months. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1503, § 12, 12-7-93) 
Secs. 10-141-10-165. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - AMUSEMENTS[4] 
Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- References to auctions have been deleted from this article because of the adoption of article VI of this chapter. References to peddlers have been deleted because of the adoption of article XVI of this chapter. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 10-166-10-185. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 10-186. - Required. 
    It is unlawful for any person to exhibit to public view for gain any circuses, equestrian exhibition, menagerie or other exhibition, or to operate any merry-go-round without first having obtained a license to do so as provided in this article. It is unlawful for any such person, having such license provided for in this article, to refuse to show or exhibit the same for public inspection when requested to do so by any of the police officers of the city or any other officer, agent or employee of the city. 
(Code 1962, § 5-101; Code 1979, § 5.08.010) 
Sec. 10-187. - Issuance; signing and sealing by clerk-treasurer. 
    The license provided for in this article shall be granted to any person upon the payment of the fee specifically prescribed in section 10-189 to the city clerk-treasurer. Upon the production by such person of the receipt issued to such person of the license for which payment has been made, such license shall be signed by the city clerk-treasurer and shall be sealed with the corporate seal of the city. 
(Code 1962, § 5-102; Code 1979, § 5.08.020) 
Sec. 10-188. - Assignable only to licensee; payment of fee required. 
    No license issued pursuant to the provisions of this article shall be assignable to inure to the benefit of any other than the person to whom such license is originally issued. No such license shall be issued until the applicant has first paid to the city clerk-treasurer the fee provided in section 10-189; any license issued without such payment shall be absolutely void. 
(Code 1962, § 5-103; Code 1979, § 5.08.030) 
Sec. 10-189. - Fees designated. 
    The rates for a license under this article, in the case and for the purpose set forth in this section, are fixed and established as follows: 
(1)  Merry-go-rounds, the sum of $2.00 per day, $10.00 per week and $500.00 per year. 
(2)  Each day that any circus, menagerie, equestrian or other performance may be given or exhibited, the sum of $25.00. 
(3)  Each and every other show and exhibition or performance of any kind whatsoever, for gain, except moving pictures or vaudeville performance, the sum of $5.00 per day, $25.00 per week, and $1,200.00 per year; provided, that the foregoing rate shall not apply to what is usually known as a street carnival or carnival, the license fee for which shall be $100.00 per day, $600.00 per week, or $2,400.00 per month. Before a license shall be issued for the conducting of any such carnival, show, circus or menagerie within the corporate limits of the city, the person desiring to conduct such carnival shall first obtain a permit from the mayor, and it shall be optional with the mayor whether or not he issues such permit. 
(4)  For each fakir, street corner lecturer, or performer, the sum of $100.00 per day, $500.00 per week, and $2,000.00 per year. 
(Code 1962, § 5-104; Code 1979, § 5.08.040) 
Secs. 10-190-10-225. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - AUCTIONS, AUCTIONEERS 

Sec. 10-226. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Auctioneer means any person who shall by public outcry sell or offer to sell to the highest bidder any real or personal property, or any person who conducts an auction sale in the city, where any and all persons who choose to do so are permitted to attend and offer bids, or any person who shall advertise as a public auctioneer, or in any manner hold himself out as such, or who shall receive fees or a commission for services as such. 
    Charitable organization includes any benevolent, philanthropic, or patriotic partnership, association, or corporation or one purporting to be such. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1476, § 5.09.10(a), (d), 9-7-93) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 10-227. - Exemptions. 
(a)  The provisions of this article shall not apply to auction sales conducted solely for charitable purposes. No auction sale shall be deemed to be a sale for charitable purposes unless more than 75 percent of the gross proceeds of the sale are donated to a charity or religious organization. 
(b)  The provisions of this article shall not apply to auction sales conducted by any public officer in the performance of his duty as a public officer pursuant to any law of the state or the United States of America. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1476, § 5.09.50, 9-7-93) 
Sec. 10-228. - Auction houses; license fees; fire inspection; indemnity bond. 
(a)  Every person conducting, managing, carrying on an auction sale in an auction house or place of business where goods, wares, merchandise or personal property of any kind are regularly sold or dispersed for value by public auction shall pay in advance a license fee at the rate of $500.00 per year, payable quarterly, semiannually, or annually, the period to be dependent on the portion of the year remaining or the effective date of the license. The city clerk-treasurer shall collect the license fee and shall maintain on file in the clerk-treasurer's office a record of the license. The record shall contain the name, address, and phone number of the auction house along with the name, address and phone number of the owner/operator of the auction house. 
(b)  Every person conducting, managing, or carrying on an auction sale in an auction house or place of business where goods, wares, merchandise or personal property of any kind are regularly sold or dispersed for value by public auction shall, at the time of license application, present to the city clerk-treasurer official certification from the fire department that the auction house or place of business has been inspected by a member of the fire department and has satisfied all fire safety regulations of the fire department, other ordinance provisions of the city and existing statutes of the state. 
(c)  Each applicant for a license to conduct an auction house which sells or deals in personal property or proposes to accept any personal property on consignment for sale shall post with the city clerk-treasurer, prior to the issuance of such license, a cash or security bond in the sum of $5,000.00 in a form approved by the city attorney protecting the city and the public in the event of any fraud, breach of warranty, or sale of stolen property. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1476, §§ 5.08.20, 5.08.30, 9-7-93) 
Sec. 10-229. - Occasional auction sales; auctioneer and licenses fees. 
(a)  Occasional auctions shall mean a sale of property by public outcry to the highest bidder not as part of the regular business of an auction house. Such sales in the city shall be conducted only by a person or persons licensed pursuant to this article. Each applicant for a license shall pay the sum of $50.00 to the city clerk-treasurer at the time of the original application and shall provide his name, address and phone number. The license fee shall be retained by the city as compensation for making an investigation of the auctioneer. The license of the auctioneer may be renewed annually upon the payment of a licensee fee of $50.00. 
(b)  Any person holding or conducting an auction sale of real or personal property except in an auction house shall pay to the clerk-treasurer a fee of $50.00 per day for each day or portion of any day that such auction sale is held; provided, that in the case of the closing of a business or the liquidation of the stocks of a business which business has been operating in the city for a period of time in excess of one year, auction sales may be held in connection therewith in the place of business for not to exceed three consecutive business days upon the payment of the license fee of $50.00. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1476, § 5.09.40, 9-7-93) 
Sec. 10-230. - Warranties. 
    Every auctioneer and person selling goods, wares, or merchandise at auction in the city shall be deemed to warrant that all representations made in the course of such sale are true and correct, and that the purchase price of any article purchased will be returned to any purchaser upon proof satisfactory to the local court that any false or misleading statement or representation has been made concerning the auction sale by the auctioneer or by any person managing or carrying on the auction sale. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1476, § 5.09.60, 9-7-93) 
Sec. 10-231. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating any provision of this article shall be fined not less than $100.00 and not more than $2,500.00. A separate offense shall be deemed to be committed on each day during on or which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1476, § 5.09.70, 9-7-93) 
Secs. 10-232-10-255. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - AUTOMOBILE SALVAGE YARDS 

Sec. 10-256. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Automobile salvage yard means any lot or place which is exposed to the weather, upon which five or more motor vehicles of any kind, incapable of being operated, are placed. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1478, § 5.40.10(a), 9-7-93) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 10-257. - Permit required. 
    No person shall maintain or operate an automobile salvage yard without first having obtained a permit therefor. Application for a permit shall be made to the city clerk-treasurer and shall contain the name, address, phone number and emergency phone number of the applicant and the location of the premises where the business is to be carried on. A fee of $50.00 shall be charged. Such fee may be prorated for months during the year in which such business is not in operation. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1478, § 5.40.140, 9-7-93) 
Sec. 10-258. - Fences. 
(a)  Required. An automobile salvage yard operating within the city shall be entirely enclosed by a fence not less than six feet, preferably eight feet in height, which shall be kept neatly painted and in good repair at all times, and shall be constructed of materials so as to exclude such yard from public view. 
(b)  Advertisements. The fence enclosing an automobile salvage yard within the city shall not be used for bill postings or other advertising purposes, except that a space not larger than six feet by 12 feet may be used to identify the business of the owner thereof. Where such yard fronts on more than one street, the use of space for advertisement permitted in this subsection shall extend to each street on which the yard abuts. 
(c)  Height of contents of yard. The contents of an automobile salvage yard within the city shall not be placed or deposited to a height greater than the height of the fence surrounding it. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1478, §§ 5.40.20-5.40.40, 9-7-93) 
Sec. 10-259. - Time for demolishing and wrecking cars. 
    Work in connection with the demolishing or wrecking of cars shall be permitted only on weekdays between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. except in the case of an emergency delivery of a vehicle involved in an accident. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1478, § 5.40.50, 9-7-93) 
Sec. 10-260. - Open fire. 
    No open fire for the burning of rubbish, trash, automobiles, or any parts thereof, or other waste matters, shall be permitted. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1478, § 5.40.60, 9-7-93) 
Sec. 10-261. - Rubbish and waste matter. 
    An automobile salvage yard, shall, as far as practicable, be kept clean and clear of all rubbish and waste matter. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1478, § 5.40.70, 9-7-93) 
Sec. 10-262. - Rodent control. 
    The owner and/or operator of an automobile salvage yard is hereby required to keep the premises free and clear from all rodents. It is the owner/operator's responsibility to make provisions for effective pest control. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1478, § 5.40.80, 9-7-93) 
Sec. 10-263. - Gasoline to be drained from vehicles. 
    All tanks and engines shall be kept thoroughly drained of gasoline. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1478, § 5.40.90, 9-7-93) 
Sec. 10-264. - Police officers to have access for inspection. 
    All automobile salvage yards, together with the books required by this article, shall be at all times during regular business hours open for inspection to all officers of the police department. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1478, § 5.40.100, 9-7-93) 
Sec. 10-265. - Records. 
    Any person maintaining or operating an automobile salvage yard shall keep at his place of business a book in which a record shall be kept of the day and time of day of each transaction, the name, residence, and description of all persons delivering or purchasing any vehicles, parts, or accessories, the make, state license number, motor number, body number and style, together with any other information concerning the property as may be necessary to prove ownership or identity of such vehicles or of such automobile parts or accessories purchased. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1478, § 5.40.110, 9-7-93) 
Sec. 10-266. - Buying, selling vehicles or parts without identification marks; notice to police. 
    It is hereby deemed a violation of this article for any automobile salvage yard owner/operator to knowingly sell, dispose, or have in his possession any motor vehicle, part, or accessory from which the manufacturer's serial number or any other number or identification mark has been removed, defaced, covered, altered, or destroyed for the purpose of concealing or misrepresenting the identity of the vehicle, part or accessory. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1478, § 5.40.120, 9-7-93) 
Sec. 10-267. - Sales to minors. 
    No licensee under this article shall purchase any auto or auto part or any article whatever from any minor without the written consent of the minor's parent or guardian. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1478, § 5.40.130, 9-7-93) 
Sec. 10-268. - Fire extinguishers; fire inspection. 
    Each automobile salvage yard shall have on hand at least one fire extinguisher of a type recommended by the fire department, to extinguish gasoline fires and fires in automobiles. Such fire extinguisher shall be in plain sight in an easily accessible location and shall be kept charged. Each automobile salvage yard shall undergo semiyearly fire inspections by an official of the fire department. Official certification that the premises have successfully satisfied all fire department regulations, other ordinance provisions of the city and existing statutes of the state must be presented to the clerk-treasurer at the time that application for permit is filed with the clerk-treasurer. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1478, § 5.40.150, 9-7-93) 
Sec. 10-269. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating any provision of this article shall be fined not less than $100.00 and not more than $2,500.00. A separate offense shall be deemed to be committed on each day during or on which a violation shall continue. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1478, § 5.40.160, 9-7-93) 
Secs. 10-270-10-300. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - BUSES[5] 
Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference- Motor carriers, IC 8-2.1-17 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 10-301. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Bus means every motor vehicle designed for carrying passengers for hire and used for the transportation of persons; and every motor vehicle other than a taxicab, designed and used for the transportation of persons for compensation. 
    Bus loading zone means a place adjacent to a curb reserved for the exclusive use of vehicles during the loading or unloading of passengers. 
    Motor vehicle means every vehicle which is self-propelled but not operated upon rails or tracks. 
(Code 1962, § 6-101; Code 1979, § 5.12.010) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 10-302. - Approval of routes. 
    No motorbus for hire service shall be operated on the public streets of the city until the operator thereof: 
(1)  Furnishes to, and files with, the board of public works and safety a certified copy of specific routes upon the public streets of the city which have been approved by some unit of government duly authorized by law to fix such routes within the city; or 
(2)  Applies for and obtains from the board of public works and safety express permission to operate over specific routes within or through the city. 
(Code 1962, § 6-105; Code 1979, § 5.12.080) 
Sec. 10-303. - Deviation from authorized routes prohibited. 
    It is unlawful for any motorbus to deviate from the route or routes, as certified to, or permitted by, the board of public works and safety, as provided in section 10-302, and to travel upon any public street or part thereof, not within the legally prescribed route. However, in cases of extreme emergency, the carrier may deviate from such route. 
(Code 1962, § 6-106; Code 1979, § 5.12.090) 
Sec. 10-304. - Maximum passenger capacity; determination; certificate required. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person, for hire, to operate any motorbus upon the public streets in the city without first having the vehicle inspected by the chief of police or his duly appointed representative for the purpose of determining and fixing the maximum passenger capacity of each vehicle. The chief, in determining and fixing the maximum capacity of each vehicle, shall allot a seat for each passenger and shall also determine and fix the maximum number of passengers who may stand while the motor vehicle is in motion. After the chief has inspected the vehicle, he shall cause a certificate of safety and capacity to be issued by the city, showing the approval as to safety and the maximum capacity; this certificate shall be placed in the front part of the interior of the bus and shall be displayed at all times the vehicle is in operation within the city. 
(b)  It is unlawful for any person operating a motorbus or common carrier service to permit such motorbus to carry passengers in this city in excess of the maximum capacity stated in the certificate. 
(Code 1962, § 6-107; Code 1979, § 5.12.100) 
Sec. 10-305. - Bus loading zones. 
    All buses shall stop at the curb for the purpose of permitting passengers to enter or leave the vehicle. The board of public works and safety shall, upon request of lawful operators of motor carriers of persons for hire, select bus loading zones along the public streets in which other parking shall be prohibited. The board shall cause the loading zones to be appropriately marked. Bus loading zones shall be used for temporary stopping of buses for permitting passengers to board or leave the buses. No motorbus or common carrier of persons for hire shall use or occupy any portion of a public street as a bus loading zone, unless the loading zone has been first fixed or approved by the board of public works and safety or other proper authority, appropriately marked and specific permission for this use has been given to the operators of the motorbus or common carrier for passengers for hire. 
(Code 1962, § 6-108; Code 1979, § 5.12.110) 
Sec. 10-306. - Route indicators on buses required. 
    Every motorbus which receives and discharges passengers for hire within the city shall be equipped with legible indicators at both the front and rear of the motorbus, showing the destination or route number of the bus. The indications shall be so constructed and maintained that the route or destination shall be clearly legible and visible, at all times, for a distance of at least 100 feet from the bus. 
(Code 1962, § 6-109; Code 1979, § 5.12.120) 
Sec. 10-307. - New or additional drivers; notification of and approval by clerk-treasurer required. 
    It shall be the duty of any person to whom a bus license is issued, if any driver or operator leaves the service of the owner, or if a new or additional driver or operator is employed, to advise the city clerk-treasurer of such change and to submit the same information concerning such driver or operator as is in this article required in the original application. No such new or additional driver or operator shall drive or be permitted by the licensee to drive a bus until he has been approved by the city clerk-treasurer. 
(Code 1962, § 6-102(part); Code 1979, § 5.12.050) 
Secs. 10-308-10-320. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 10-321. - Required; application. 
    It is unlawful for any person to operate a bus within the city without first having obtained a license therefor from the clerk-treasurer. Applications for the license for buses shall be made, under oath, by the owner upon blank forms to be provided by the clerk-treasurer, and such applications shall state the name, age, residence, length of residence in the state, address and place of business of the person applying for such license, together with the name of the person or persons who will drive or operate such bus, and also a description of the vehicle to be operated including the motive power, model, motor and chassis numbers, seating capacity, make, license number and ownership, a statement of the experience in driving motor vehicles of the person or persons who will drive or operate such buses. 
(Code 1962, § 6-102(part); Code 1979, § 5.12.030) 
Sec. 10-322. - Conditions of issuance. 
(a)  No bus license as defined in this article shall be issued unless the common council, after a hearing, shall by resolution declare that the public convenience and necessity require the proposed bus service for which application for license is made. 
(b)  In determining whether public convenience and necessity require the licensing of such buses for which application may be made, the common council shall take into consideration whether the demands of public convenience and necessity require such proposed bus service within the city; the financial responsibility of the applicant; the number, kind, and type of equipment; the schedule of rates proposed to be charged; the color scheme to be used by the applicant; the increased traffic congestion and demand for increased parking spaces on the streets of the city which may result, and whether the safe use of the streets by the public, both vehicular and pedestrian, will be preserved by the granting of such license, and such other relevant facts as the common council may deem advisable or necessary. 
(Code 1962, § 6-102(part); Code 1979, § 5.12.020) 
Sec. 10-323. - When issuance prohibited. 
    It shall be the duty of the clerk-treasurer before issuing a license under this article to satisfy himself as to the truth of the statements made in the application. No such license shall be issued where the statements are found to be false, nor shall a license be issued to the owner, driver or operator of any bus who is under the age of 21 years, or who is found to be blind in either eye, or who has suffered the loss of either hand or foot, or who has serious impairment of the use of mind or body, or who has been convicted of operating motor vehicles while under the influence of intoxicating liquors, or who has been convicted two or more times of any violation of the motor speed laws or who is unable to intelligently speak and read the English language. 
(Code 1962, § 6-102(part); Code 1979, § 5.12.040) 
State Law reference- Minimum age for commercial driver's license for transportation of persons, IC 9-1-13-6. 
Sec. 10-324. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. CC-2011-1868, § 7, adopted Dec. 27, 2011, repealed § 10-324, which pertained to [bus] fees and derived from Code 1962, § 6-103; Code 1979, § 5.12.060. 
Sec. 10-325. - Plates. 
(a)  License plates shall be issued by the city clerk-treasurer and shall be displayed upon each vehicle under this article licensed in a prominent, conspicuous place. All license plates shall be numbered and a record containing the name of the licensee, the name and type of the vehicle, its capacity and the number shall be kept by the clerk-treasurer. 
(b)  It is unlawful to place a city license plate upon any vehicle not licensed, or to place a license plate upon any vehicle other than the one for which it was issued. It is unlawful to place any counterfeit plate upon a vehicle. It is unlawful to remove any license plate without the consent of the owner. 
(Code 1962, § 6-104; Code 1979, § 5.12.070) 
Secs. 10-326-10-345. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - CHARITABLE SOLICITATIONS[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference- Charitable solicitations, IC 36-8-2-11. 

Sec. 10-346. - Permit required. 
    Any person desiring to solicit aid, contributions or donations of any nature whatsoever, for charitable purposes, within the corporate limits of the city shall first produce a written permit to do so from either the mayor or chief of police. 
(Code 1962, § 5-201; Code 1979, § 5.16.010) 
Sec. 10-347. - Soliciting without permit prohibited. 
    It is unlawful for any person to solicit for charitable purposes within the corporate limits of the city, as set forth in section 10-346, without first securing a permit as required in section 10-346. 
(Code 1962, § 5-202; Code 1979, § 5.16.020) 
Secs. 10-348-10-370. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - CHILDREN'S CARE CENTERS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 10-371. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Board of public works means the board of public works and safety of the city. 
    Children's day care center means any nursery, person, association, corporation, institution, or agency which provides care and supervision for three or more children under 18 years of age in lieu of care and supervision ordinarily provided by parents in their own homes with or without charge. 
    Fire hazard inspector means the fire hazard inspector of the fire department of the city. 
    Health officer means a duly authorized health official from the county department of health. 
    Preschool means any person, association, corporation, institution or agency that advertises itself to be a preschool and that provides care and educational facilities for children under seven years of age with or without charge for less than four hours. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1486, § 5.15.010(A), (B), (E), (G), (H), 12-7-93) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 10-372. - Exemption. 
    Nothing in this article shall apply to care given to children in the homes of parents, legal guardians, grandparents, brothers, sisters, uncles or aunts or as part of the program of an education institution regulated by the boards of education of this state or as part of the program of a parochial educational institution. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1486, § 5.15.010(C), 12-7-93) 
Sec. 10-373. - Approval required for new or altered facilities. 
    Any applicant or licensee proposing to build new buildings or facilities for, or to make any major alterations of, a preschool or day care center shall submit plans and specifications for such buildings, facilities or alterations to the building department. The same shall be built or made in compliance with all ordinances of the city. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1486, § 5.15.100, 12-7-93) 
Sec. 10-374. - Inspection by health department. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of the health officer, or his authorized representative, to visit and inspect all hourly care centers, preschools, and day care centers for the purpose of determining the sanitary conditions therein and to determine whether the same are being conducted in compliance with this article and all applicable statutes and ordinances. 
(b)  The findings of such inspections shall be recorded, in duplicate, by the person making the inspection, one copy of which will be conspicuously posted and maintained by the licensee on an inside wall of the establishment, and the other copy shall be filed with the clerk-treasurer. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1486, § 5.15.110, 12-7-93) 
Sec. 10-375. - Right of entry. 
    The health officer, fire hazard inspector or their authorized representatives shall have the right to enter all locations regulated by this article at any reasonable time for the purpose of making necessary inspections and investigations. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1486, § 5.15.120, 12-7-93) 
Sec. 10-376. - Food storage. 
    All perishable foods shall be stored so as to be kept clean and free from contamination. All utensils and equipment shall be stored so as to be kept clean and protected from contamination. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1486, § 5.15.130, 12-7-93; Ord. No. CC 93-1513, § 1(5.15.130), 4-19-94) 
Sec. 10-377. - Bedding; laundry. 
    Bedding and clothing shall be clean and sanitized and laundry properly stored, not in the food service area. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1486, § 5.15.140, 12-7-93) 
Sec. 10-378. - Safety requirements. 
    Safety rails or guards shall be placed wherever there is an unprotected drop from a stair, hall or porch. Medicine shall be kept in a locked cupboard. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1486, § 5.15.150, 12-7-93) 
Sec. 10-379. - Employee requirements. 
    All employees shall be clean and shall wear clean clothing and shall have a current food handler's card. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1486, § 5.15.160, 12-7-93) 
Sec. 10-380. - Recreation area. 
    Inside recreation areas shall be kept neat and clean. If an outside recreation area is utilized, such area shall also be kept neat and clean and free from trash and other hazards. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1486, § 5.15.170, 12-7-93; Ord. No. CC 93-1513, § 1(5.15.170), 4-19-94) 
Sec. 10-381. - Administration. 
    A qualified operator or a qualified assistant shall be present in children's day care centers and preschools whenever children are present. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1486, § 5.15.180, 12-7-93) 
Sec. 10-382. - Records. 
    There shall be kept on file at the children's care center an up-to-date record of the name, address and phone number of the family doctor and the person to be notified in case of emergency for each child attending the care center. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1486, § 5.15.190, 12-7-93; Ord. No. CC 93-1513, § 1(5.15.190), 4-19-94) 
Sec. 10-383. - Buildings. 
    Floors shall be of easily cleanable construction in all premises used for children's day care centers or preschools, smooth and in good repair. Walls and ceilings shall be smooth, kept in good repair and clean. Outer windows and doors shall be effectively screened and other doors shall be self-closing. Toilet facilities must comply with the plumbing code and be adequate and convenient, ventilated to the outside, with no direct openings to the kitchen. Individual towels or paper towels shall be available for each child. Artificial or natural light shall be adequate, all rooms shall be ventilated and there shall be an adequate heating plant available in good working order. Safe hot and cold water is to be available under pressure. Liquid wastes shall be disposed of as provided by ordinance. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1486, § 5.15.200, 12-7-93) 
Sec. 10-384. - Utensils and equipment. 
    All utensils, dishes, glassware and cooking equipment shall be easily cleanable and in good repair. All utensils, dishes and similar equipment shall be washed, rinsed and kept free of garbage. All garbage shall be stored in proper containers not accessible by any child attending the children's day care center. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1486, § 5.15.210, 12-7-93; Ord. No. CC 93-1513, § 1(5.15.210), 4-19-94) 
Sec. 10-385. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating any provision of this article shall be fined not less than $100.00 and not more than $2,500.00 for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1486, § 5.15.220, 12-7-93) 
Secs. 10-386-10-405. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 10-406. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct, operate, carry on or maintain a children's day care center or a preschool without first obtaining a license from the clerk-treasurer to do so. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1486, § 5.15.020, 12-7-93) 
Sec. 10-407. - Application. 
(a)  Every person desiring to obtain a preschool or children's day care center license shall make an application therefor to the clerk-treasurer. The application shall include such information as the clerk-treasurer may prescribe, including a description of the center and services, and a statement of the personnel and programs that are to be used therefor. 
(b)  The application shall contain the following paragraph: 
"By making the application, the undersigned agrees that the fire inspector and a health officer, or any inspector working for the health department, may enter the licensed premises to make inspections at any time the premises are open for business." 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1486, § 5.15.030, 12-7-93) 
Sec. 10-408. - Fees. 
    The license fee for a preschool or children's day care center shall be $50.00 per year. Such fee shall be prorated if the license shall cover a period of less than one year. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1486, § 5.15.040, 12-7-93) 
Sec. 10-409. - Inspection. 
    Upon receipt of the application, the fire hazard inspector and county health officer, or their authorized representative, shall make an inspection of the premises to be used as a children's day care center. If the premises are found to be in compliance with all city ordinances and existing state statutes, a license shall be issued to conduct such business. If the premises upon such inspection are found not in satisfactory compliance with the ordinances or statutes, no license shall be issued. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1486, § 5.15.050, 12-7-93) 
Sec. 10-410. - Duration. 
    The license provided for in this article shall run from the original date of approval to December 31 of the year in which it is approved. All renewals shall run for a 12-month period starting January 1 and ending December 31 of each year, unless sooner revoked. In the case of renewals, a license must be obtained prior to March 31. Failure to obtain a renewal license prior to March 31 will result in an additional $25.00 assessed to the cost of obtaining a renewal license. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1486, § 5.15.060, 12-7-93; Ord. No. CC 93-1513, § 1(5.15.060), 4-19-94) 
Sec. 10-411. - Suspension; revocation. 
    The license issued under this article may be suspended or revoked by the county health officer, fire hazard inspector or their authorized representatives upon the violation by the holder of any of the terms of this article. Except as herein provided, the suspension or revocation of the license shall take effect 30 days after written notice to the licensee advising of the contemplated suspension or revocation and setting forth the reasons for such action. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1486, § 5.15.070, 12-7-93) 
Sec. 10-412. - Hearing. 
    At any time before the suspension or revocation date, a licensee may request a hearing on the proposed suspension or revocation before the board of public works, which shall pass finally upon the matter of such suspension or revocation at its next regularly scheduled meeting after receipt of a written request for a hearing filed by the licensee. The notice to the licensee, referred to in this division, shall advise him of the right to such hearing. Except for judicial relief, the decision of the board of public works shall be the final decision on behalf of the city. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1486, § 5.15.080, 12-7-93) 
Sec. 10-413. - Emergency. 
    When in the opinion of the health officer, fire hazard inspector or their representatives, there exists an emergency which may endanger the public health or safety, the health officer, fire hazard inspector or their authorized representatives are empowered to declare an emergency and immediately suspend any or all such licenses as may be required, without a hearing or prior notice. Any licensee may request a hearing with the board of public works on such emergency suspension, but the suspension shall remain in effect until the hearing which shall be held within ten days of receipt of request for hearing. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1486, § 5.15.090, 12-7-93) 
Secs. 10-414-10-435. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XI. - DANCEHALLS[7] 
Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 4; fire prevention and protection, ch. 7. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 10-436. - Special policeman to be on duty. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of any person owning, leasing or operating a dancehall or dancing pavilion to have a person vested with police powers on duty at each entrance and exit of such building to maintain peace and order. Such person shall be on duty during the entire time any entertainment is being presented and shall be furnished at the expense of the licensee. Such person shall be subject to the approval of the chief of police and the board of public works and safety. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of the licensee to present an application to the chief of police for the person who is to be placed on duty as provided in subsection (a). The chief of police, upon receiving such application, shall investigate the qualifications of such person and, if found suitable, make recommendation to the board of public works and safety. Upon receiving such recommendation, the board of public works and safety shall appoint such person as a special policeman. 
(c)  It is unlawful for any person to open a dancehall or dancing pavilion or receive admission until a duly qualified officer, as provided above in this section, shall be on duty at such dancehall or dancing pavilion. 
(Code 1979, § 5.20.070; Ord. No. 1136, § 7, 1971) 
Sec. 10-437. - City health officer authorized to inspect premises. 
    In addition to any other requirement of state law or county ordinances, the city health officer is authorized and empowered to make inspections of the premises licensed under this article from time to time to determine if provision has been made for sanitary facilities in the premises and that same are maintained in compliance with health codes. 
(Code 1979, § 5.20.090; Ord. No. 1136, § 9, 1971) 
Sec. 10-438. - Noise abatement. 
    There is specifically prohibited the using, operating or permitting to be played, used, or operated of any radio receiving set, musical instrument, phonograph, loudspeaker, sound amplifier, or other machine or device for the producing or reproducing of sound which is cast upon the public streets for the purpose of commercial advertising or attracting the attention of the public to any building or structure. 
(Code 1979, § 5.20.100; Ord. No. 1136, § 10, 1971) 
Secs. 10-439-10-465. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 10-466. - Required; fee. 
    It is unlawful for any person to own, operate or manage a dancehall or a dancing pavilion for public dancing within the corporate limits of the city without having first obtained a license from the city clerk-treasurer after approval for the granting of such permit by the board of public works and safety. The license fee for dancehalls and dancing pavilions shall be $100.00 per year, payable in advance. 
(Code 1979, § 5.20.010; Ord. No. 1136, § 1, 1971) 
Sec. 10-467. - Application; contents. 
    Any person who desires to operate a place of entertainment as described in section 10-466 shall file an application for a license to do so with the clerk-treasurer, who shall deliver a copy of such application to the building commissioner and to the board of public works and safety. This application shall be on a form prepared under authorization of the board of public works and safety and contain the following information: 
(1)  The location and character of the entertainment sought to be licensed. 
(2)  The type of building and a full description of the apparatus to be used therein. 
(3)  A floor plan of the room showing the seating capacity and the number of entrances and exits. 
(4)  The provisions made for ventilation and prevention and extinguishing of fires. 
(5)  The hours between which entertainment is proposed to be conducted. 
(6)  Such other information as may be required by the board of public works and safety or the chief of the fire department. 
(Code 1979, § 5.20.020; Ord. No. 1136, § 2, 1971) 
Sec. 10-468. - Issuance following inspection of premises. 
(a)  Upon filing of the application provided for in section 10-467, the board of public works and safety shall direct the building commissioner to inspect the premises where such entertainment is proposed to be carried on and shall also notify the chief of the fire department of the filing of the application. It shall thereafter be the duty of the chief of the fire department to make a personal inspection of the premises. Both the building commissioner and the chief of the fire department are charged with the duty of seeing that such place of entertainment complies in all respects to the laws of the state and all ordinances of the city and that proper precautions have been taken by the proprietor or operator thereof to protect persons and property from fire and other dangers. If in the judgment of the building commissioner and the chief of the fire department the place of entertainment complies with the abovementioned laws and ordinances and is a safe and proper place to be licensed for the character of entertainment sought to be carried on therein, they shall certify such fact to the board of public works and safety, which will thereupon have the authority to determine whether the applicant shall be entitled to the issuance of a license and, if the applicant has complied with all of the requirements of the state and ordinances of the city, shall authorize the city clerk-treasurer to issue a license to conduct such place of entertainment for a period of one year upon payment of the application fee. 
(b)  The board of public works and safety shall authorize the issuance of such license to such applicant authorizing him to conduct and carry on the class and type of entertainment specified in such license at the place described and for the period of time for which such license is issued; provided, that the following requirements are met: 
(1)  Approval of application with respect to compliance with the provisions of this article and all other existing ordinances affecting such dancehalls or dancing pavilions. 
(2)  There is nothing obscene, illegal or dangerous in the character of the entertainment to be offered. 
(3)  The person applying for such license is of good moral character. 
(4)  Payment of the license fee is made to the office of the city clerk-treasurer. 
(Code 1979, §§ 5.20.030, 5.20.040; Ord. No. 1136, §§ 3, 4, 1971) 
Sec. 10-469. - Posting required. 
    Upon receiving his license to operate a place of amusement as described in this article, the holder thereof shall post such license in a conspicuous place within his place of amusement where it may be seen at any time by persons attending such entertainment. 
(Code 1979, § 5.20.050; Ord. No. 1136, § 5, 1971) 
Sec. 10-470. - Nontransferability. 
    The license provided for in this article shall be nontransferable and it is unlawful for any person who is the holder of such license to transfer or assign such license to any other person. 
(Code 1979, § 5.20.060; Ord. No. 1136, § 6, 1971) 
Sec. 10-471. - Enforcement of article; license revocation; report of violations. 
(a)  The building commissioner and the chief of the fire department are charged with the duty and vested with the authority to visit any place of entertainment, licensed as provided for in this article, to inspect the premises and the apparatus, scenery and other paraphernalia therein, and to report promptly in writing to the board of public works and safety if in their judgment any such place is not equipped, operated and conducted according to law, as contemplated by this article and the statutes of the state, whereupon the board of public works and safety may revoke the license of such place of entertainment. 
(b)  It shall be the further duty of the building commissioner and the chief of the fire department to report promptly to the city attorney any violation of the provisions of this article or of the statutes of the state. The city attorney shall thereupon prosecute the violation of this article or any other ordinances of the city and bring to the attention of the prosecuting attorney the fact of the violation of the statutes of the state. 
(Code 1979, § 5.20.080; Ord. No. 1136, § 8, 1971) 
Secs. 10-472-10-500. - Reserved.

Footnotes:

Formerly, said article pertained to direct sellers as enacted by Ord. No. CC-93-1477, adopted Sept. 7, 1993. The users attention is directed to Art. XXI of this chapter.

ARTICLE XIII. - FLEA MARKETS 

Sec. 10-556. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Flea market means a market, indoors or out-of-doors, where new or used items are sold from individual locations, with each location being operated independently from the other locations. Items sold include but are not limited to used household items, antiques, rare items, curios (unusual objects), decorations, used books and used magazines. A single business selling the items described in this definition shall also constitute a flea market for purposes of this article. 
    Flea market seller means a person selling items or offering items for sale at a flea market. 
    Market means a place where goods are sold to the public. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1479, § 5.33.010(a)-(c), 9-7-93) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 10-557. - License required. 
    No person shall operate a single flea market business or the business of renting space or allocating space to flea market sellers without first obtaining a license. Applications for licenses shall be made to the clerk-treasurer on forms to be provided by the clerk-treasurer. Only one license shall be required for each flea market, and, where applicable, individual flea market sellers shall not be required to obtain a license under this section. The fee for such license shall be $50.00 per year. The fee may be prorated for those years in which the flea market was not operating for the entire year. Prior to issuance of any license, the applicant shall also submit to the clerk-treasurer official certification from the fire department that any premises to be used for purposes of a flea market have successfully satisfied all existing fire regulations of the fire department, other ordinances of the city, and existing statutes of the state. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1479, § 5.55.020, 9-7-93) 
Sec. 10-558. - Records to be kept by licensee. 
    In the case of a flea market involving more than one flea market seller, each person required by this article to obtain a license shall keep accurate records of the names and addresses of each flea market seller, together with a brief description of the type or types of merchandise offered for sale by that seller. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1479, § 5.33.030, 9-7-93) 
Sec. 10-559. - More than one market. 
    Any person renting or allocating space to flea market sellers in more than one place of business shall be required to obtain a license for each place of business, provided that one license shall be adequate for locations that are on the same lot, adjacent lots or lots separated only by an alley. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1479, § 5.33.040, 9-7-93) 
Sec. 10-560. - Unlawful transactions. 
    No person shall sell or offer for sale at any flea market any goods known to be stolen. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1479, § 5.33.050, 9-7-93) 
Sec. 10-561. - Purchases from children. 
    No flea market seller shall purchase any used household item, antique, or used article whatsoever from any person under the age of 18 years, unless such person is accompanied by the person's parent or guardian. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1479, § 5.33.060, 9-7-93) 
Sec. 10-562. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating any provision of this article shall be fined not less than $100.00 nor more than $2,500.00 for each offense. A separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1479, § 5.33.070, 9-7-93) 
Secs. 10-563-10-585. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XIV. - GUN CLUBS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 10-586-10-600. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 

Sec. 10-601. - Issuance authorized. 
    The common council authorizes the mayor to issue to any duly organized gun club a permit for the members thereof to discharge firearms for the purpose of becoming proficient therein, under the terms and conditions of this article. 
(Code 1962, § 17-301; Code 1979, § 5.28.010) 
Sec. 10-602. - Application-Required; contents. 
    Any gun club desiring a permit shall file with the city clerk-treasurer a written application for a permit, which application shall contain a description of the location of the place to which such permit shall apply. 
(Code 1962, § 17-302; Code 1979, § 5.28.020) 
Sec. 10-603. - Same-Consent of landowners required. 
    A written application for a permit under this article shall be accompanied by the written consent of all owners residing on land bordering upon the land upon which the permit shall apply. 
(Code 1962, § 17-303; Code 1979, § 5.28.030) 
Sec. 10-604. - Same-List of club members and officers required. 
    The written application shall be accompanied by the list of the members of the gun club with their respective post office addresses, and a list of its officers, duly certified by its president and secretary. 
(Code 1962, § 17-304; Code 1979, § 5.28.040) 
Sec. 10-605. - Bond. 
    Any gun club receiving a permit shall file with the city clerk-treasurer a bond with freehold sureties in the penal sum of $500.00, conditioned that it will save the city or any person harmless from any loss or damage either directly or indirectly occasioned by the granting of such permit. 
(Code 1962, § 17-305; Code 1979, § 5.28.050) 
Sec. 10-606. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. CC-2011-1868, § 7, adopted Dec. 27, 2011, repealed § 10-606, which pertained to [gun club permit] fee; nontransferability; expiration; revocation and derived from Code 1962, § 17-306; Code 1979, § 5.28.060. 
Secs. 10-607-10-635. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XV. - JUNK DEALERS[9] 
Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
State Law reference- Junkyards, IC 8-23-20-1 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 10-636. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Board of public works means the board of public works and safety for the city. 
    Junk means any metal, paper, rags, rubber tires, building materials, bottles and scrap iron. 
    Junk dealer means a person who buys, sells, exchanges, sorts, or bales scrap iron, metal, paper, rags, rubber tires, building materials and bottles. 
    Junkyard/junk shop means an open or enclosed area where waste or scrap materials are bought, sold, exchanged, sorted, baled, limited to scrap iron and other metal, paper, rags, rubber tires, building materials and bottles. A junkyard does not include an automobile wrecking yard. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1474, § 5.36.010(A)-(D), 9-7-93) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 10-637. - Vehicles. 
    Every vehicle used by a junk dealer in the conduct of his business shall bear thereon in legible characters the name and address of the owner and proprietor thereof. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1474, § 5.32.060, 9-7-93) 
Sec. 10-638. - Stolen goods. 
    Every keeper of a junk shop or junkyard (i.e., a junk dealer) who shall receive or knowingly be in possession of any goods, articles, or things of value which may have been lost or stolen has the responsibility to notify the police department upon the receipt of such goods and shall upon demand from an official of the police department produce such articles for examination by the police department. Any keeper of a junk shop or junkyard found to be dealing in stolen goods on a persistent basis shall immediately forfeit the license and shall cease all operations. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1474, § 5.32.070, 9-7-93) 
Sec. 10-639. - Fire inspection. 
    Every keeper of a junk shop or junkyard (i.e., a junk dealer) shall obtain from the fire department official certification that the junkyard/junk shop property has been duly licensed and satisfies all current fire safety requirements as outlined in regulations of the fire department, other ordinance provisions of the city, and existing statutes of the state. Documentation certifying the fire inspection results must be presented to the clerk-treasurer at the time that application for license under this article is filed. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1474, § 5.32.090, 9-7-93) 
Sec. 10-640. - Buying from or selling to minors prohibited. 
    It is unlawful for any person to buy or sell any junk from or to any minor under the age of 18 years within the city without first procuring the consent of the parent or parents of the minor. 
(Code 1962, § 5-302; Code 1979, § 5.36.050) 
Sec. 10-641. - Penalty. 
    A person operating a junkyard without a properly issued license shall be fined not less than $100.00 and not more than $2,500.00. A separate offense shall be deemed and committed on each day during which a junkyard is operated without a properly issued license. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1474, § 5.32.080, 9-7-93) 
Secs. 10-642-10-665. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 10-666. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to operate or carry on the business of a junk dealer or to keep any junk shop, store or place for the purchase or sale of junk, old iron, brass, copper or junk vehicles, without having first obtained a license as is provided in this article. This section shall not apply to recycling centers. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1474, § 5.32.020, 9-7-93) 
Sec. 10-667. - Applications. 
    Applications for licenses under this article shall be made by filing a request for such license with the city clerk-treasurer's office. Such license applications shall be filed on a yearly basis by any junk dealer wishing to operate within the city. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1474, § 5.32.030, 9-7-93) 
Sec. 10-668. - Approval for junkyard operation. 
(a)  Upon receipt of an application for a junkyard or junk shop license, the clerk-treasurer shall present such application at the next regularly scheduled board of public works and safety meeting which shall schedule a public hearing on the application within 30 days of receipt. 
(b)  The board of public works and safety shall notify the general public of the hearing through publication of the date, time and location of the hearing in a newspaper of general circulation within the city on at least two different publication dates. Publication shall also be by posting in places normally utilized by the clerk-treasurer for publication postings. 
(c)  The board of public works and safety is hereby charged with the duty of inquiring into the suitability of any proposed location and is empowered to require fencing or such other regulations as may be necessary to prevent unsightly conditions. The board of public works shall recommend or deny that such license for the establishment of a junkyard operation be granted based on the results of the hearing held in connection with the license application. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1474, § 5.32.040, 9-7-93) 
Sec. 10-669. - Fee. 
    The fee to be paid for licenses under this article shall be an annual fee of $50.00 for each junk shop or junkyard and an additional fee of $50.00 for each vehicle used in the conduct of such business. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1474, § 5.32.050, 9-7-93) 
Secs. 10-670-10-700. - Reserved.

No. CC 93-1475, adopted Sept. 7, 1993. The users attention is directed to Art. XXI of this chapter.
