(a)  It is a defense to a violation under this article that the child was emancipated by any of the following conditions at the time the child engaged in the prohibited conduct: 
(1)  Under I.C. 31-37-19-27 or I.C. 31-6-4-15.7 (before its repeal); 
(2)  By virtue of having married; or 
(3)  In accordance with the laws of another state or jurisdiction. 
(b)  It is a defense to a violation under this article that the child engaged in the prohibited conduct while: 
(1)  Accompanied by the child's parent, guardian or custodian; 
(2)  Accompanied by an adult specified by the child's parent, guardian or custodian; 
(3)  Participating in, going to, or returning from: 
a.  Lawful employment; 
b.  A school sanction activity; 
c.  A religious event; 
d.  An emergency involving the protection of a person or property from an imminent threat of serious bodily injury or substantial damage; 
e.  An activity involving the exercise of the child's rights protected under the First Amendment of the United States Constitution or Article 1, Section 31 of the State of Indiana, or both, such as freedom of speech and the right of assembly; or 
f.  An activity conducted by a nonprofit or governmental entity that provides recreation, education, training or other care under the supervision of one or more adults; 
(4)  Participating in an activity undertaken at the prior written direction of the child's parent, guardian or custodian; or 
(5)  Engaged in interstate or international travel from a location outside Indiana to another location outside Indiana. 
(Ord. No. CC-2008-1810, § 3(C), (D), 2-17-09) 
Sec. 12-104. - Enforcement by police department; temporary custody. 
    The Whiting Police Department is charged with the responsibility of enforcing this article. A child found to be in violation of this article shall be issued a citation. In addition, a child found in violation of this article shall immediately be taken into the temporary custody of the Whiting Police Department which shall then notify the child's parent, guardian or custodian. Temporary custody of the child shall remain with the police department until the child is surrendered to the child's parent, guardian or custodian or to an adult specified by the child's parent, guardian or custodian or until 5:00 a.m., whichever occurs first. 
(Ord. No. CC-2008-1810, § 3(E), 2-17-09) 
Sec. 12-105. - Penalty. 
    Violations of this article shall be subject to the general penalty provision of Whiting Municipal Code section 1-11. 
(Ord. No. CC-2008-1810, § 3(F), 2-17-09) 
Secs. 12-106-12-125. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - WEAPONS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference- Weapons, IC 35-47-1 et seq. 

Sec. 12-126. - Discharging pellet guns prohibited. 
    It is unlawful for any person to fire or discharge, within the city limits, any airgun, spring gun, or other similar device commonly called a BB gun, which is intended to propel a pellet, bullet, or any similar projectile; provided, however, that nothing in this section shall prevent the use of such weapons in shooting galleries or in any authorized place regulated by the police department. 
(Code 1962, § 17-201; Code 1979, § 9.32.010) 
Sec. 12-127. - Allowing minors to discharge pellet guns prohibited. 
    It is unlawful for the parents, guardian, or other adult person having care and custody of a minor under the age of 21 years to knowingly permit such minor to fire any airgun, spring gun, or other similar device commonly known as and called a BB gun, which is intended to propel a pellet, bullet, or any other similar projectile within the city limits. 
(Code 1962, § 17-202; Code 1979, § 9.32.020) 
Sec. 12-128. - Discharging gun within city prohibited. 
    It is unlawful and shall be deemed disorderly conduct for any person to discharge any gun, pistol or revolver within the corporate limits of the city, except when necessary to protect his person or property. 
(Code 1962, § 17-521; Code 1979, § 9.32.040) 
Secs. 12-129-12-150. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - PROPERTY DAMAGE 

Sec. 12-151. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Business means any individual, corporation, partnership or other entity operating a business for profit within the city. 
    Legal guardian means a person appointed guardian, or given custody of a minor child, by a court. 
    Minor means any person who has not yet reached 18 years of age. 
    Parent includes the lawful mother or father of a minor, whether by birth or adoption. 
    Person means the city, or any individual, firm, partnership, association, corporation, company, government unit, government agency or organization of any kind. 
    Property includes any real estate, including improvements thereon, and tangible personal property. 
    Property damage means: 
(1)  The willful or malicious damaging or defacing, within the corporate limits of the city, of another person's real or personal property, without the other person's consent; or 
(2)  The willful or malicious entry into, or the obtaining control over, any motor vehicle, bicycle, aircraft or watercraft of another person, without the person's consent. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1508, § 9.24.010(A)-(E), (G), (I), 1-18-94) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 12-152. - Prohibition. 
    All acts of property damage are hereby declared to be unlawful including any use of spray paints for defacing purposes. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1508, § 9.24.020, 1-18-94) 
Sec. 12-153. - Prohibition of sale of spray paint to minors. 
    It shall be unlawful for any business to sell spray paint canisters to any minor within the city. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1508, § 9.24.050, 1-18-94) 
Sec. 12-154. - Issuance of complaint. 
    Upon complaint by any member of the police department, the city may make a complaint for the enforcement of this article, brought in the name of the city in the local city court. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1508, § 9.24.060, 1-18-94) 
Sec. 12-155. - Liability of parent or legal guardian of minor offender. 
    The parent or legal guardian of a minor who resides with such parent or legal guardian shall be liable for any fine or condition of restitution imposed by a court upon a minor for violation of this article, if the minor has not paid the fine or made restitution or reparation within the time ordered by the court, and if the parent or legal guardian has been made a party defendant in all enforcement proceedings against the minor for violation of this article and has been served with all citations, summons, complaints, notices or any other documents required to be served on the minor. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1508, § 9.24.080, 1-18-94; Ord. No. CC 93-1513, § 6, 4-19-94) 
Sec. 12-156. - Penalties. 
(a)  Any person found guilty of an act of property damage as defined in section 12-151 or violates the section 12-153 prohibition of sale of spray paint to minors shall be subject to the following penalties: 
(1)  A fine of not less than $100.00 nor more than $2,500.00. 
(2)  A period of conditional discharge not to exceed one year. 
(3)  Court costs. 
(b)  The conditions of a conditional discharge may include that the defendant: 
(1)  Not violate any criminal statute or quasi-criminal ordinance of any jurisdiction; 
(2)  Periodically report or appear in person before the local court or any agency as directed by the court for the purpose of reviewing the defendant's fulfillment of the conditions of the conditional discharge; 
(3)  Make restitution or reparation in an amount not to exceed actual loss or damage to property and pecuniary loss; or 
(4)  Community service for a number of hours not to exceed 500 hours, to be determined by the court based on the facts and circumstances of the particular instance. 
(c)  A separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation of any provision of this article occurs or continues. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1508, § 9.24.070, 1-18-94) 
Secs. 12-157-12-180. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - LOITERING 

Sec. 12-181. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Loitering means remaining idle in essentially one location and shall include the concept of spending time idly; to be dilatory; to linger; to stay; to delay; to stand around and shall also include the colloquial expression "hanging around." 
    Public place means any place to which the general public has access and a right to resort for business, entertainment, or other lawful purpose, but does not necessarily mean a place devoted solely for uses of the public. It shall also include the front or immediate area of any store, shop, restaurant, tavern or other place of business and also public grounds areas or parks. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1466, § A, 6-22-93) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 12-182. - Police order to disperse. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to loiter, loaf, wander, stand or remain idle either alone and/or in consort with others in a public place in such a manner so as to: 
(1)  Obstruct any public street, public highway, public sidewalk, or any other public place or building by hindering or impeding or tending to hinder or impede the free and uninterrupted passage of vehicles, traffic or pedestrians. 
(2)  Commit in or upon any public street, public highway, public sidewalk or any other public place or building any act or thing which is an obstruction or interference to the free and uninterrupted use of property or with any business lawfully conducted by anyone in or upon or facing or fronting on any such public street, public highway, public sidewalk or any other public place or building, all of which prevents the free and uninterrupted ingress, egress, and regress, therein, thereon and thereto. 
(b)  When any person causes or commits any of the conditions enumerated in subsection (a) of this section, a police officer or any law enforcement officer shall order that person to stop causing or committing such conditions and to move on or disperse. A person who fails or refuses to obey such orders shall be guilty of a violation of this article. 
(Code 1962, § 17-527; Code 1979, § 9.20.010; Ord. No. CC 93-1466, § A, 6-22-93) 
Sec. 12-183. - Penalty. 
    Any person who violates any of the provisions of this article shall be subject to a fine not exceeding $2,500.00 and/or community service not to exceed 500 hours. Any such violation shall constitute a separate offense on each successive day continued. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1466, § A, 6-22-93) 
Secs. 12-184-12-190. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - TRESPASSING 

Sec. 12-191. - Definitions. 
    For purposes of this article, the following words shall have the meanings ascribed to them as follows: 
    Business shall mean any individual, corporation, partnership or other entity operating a business for profit within the city. 
    Business parking lot means any privately owned parking lot providing free parking during business hours adjacent to any store, office building, commercial building or industrial building, for the convenience of employees and customers or patrons. 
    City shall mean the City of Whiting, Lake County, Indiana. 
    Minor means any person who has not yet reached the age of 18. 
    Person shall mean the city, or any individual, firm, partnership, association, corporation or company, government unit, government agency or organization of any kind. 
    Premises shall include any private or business real estate, including improvements thereon located within the city. 
(Ord. No. CC 95-1525, 3-21-95) 
Sec. 12-192. - Prohibition of trespasses. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to commit a trespass within this municipality upon either public or private property. 
(Ord. No. CC 95-1525, 3-21-95) 
Sec. 12-193. - Specifically enumerated trespasses. 
    Without constituting any limitation upon the provisions of section 12-192 of this article, any of the following acts by any person shall be deemed included among those that constitute trespasses in violation of the provisions of section 12-192 of this article: 
(1)  An entry upon the premises, or any part thereof, of another, including any public property in violation of a notice posted or exhibited at the main entrance to such premises or at any point of approach or entry or in violation of any notice, warning or protest given orally or in writing, by any owner or occupant thereof. 
(2)  The pursuit of a course of conduct or action incidental to the making of an entry upon the land of another in violation of a notice posted or exhibited at the main entrance to such premises or at any point of approach or entry, or in violation of any notice, warning or protest given orally or in writing by any owner or occupant thereof. 
(3)  A failure or refusal to depart from the premises of another in case of being requested, either orally or in writing by any owner or occupant thereof. 
(4)  An entry into or upon any vehicle or water craft made without the consent thereof, or a failure or refusal to leave any such vehicle water craft after being requested to leave by the person having such right. 
(5)  Entrance or remaining on parking lots by minors during prohibited hours. 
a.  It shall be unlawful for any minor to enter upon or remain within any parking lot, unless accompanied by a parent, guardian or responsible adult who is using such facility for its lawful purpose of vehicular parking. 
b.  The prohibition set out in this section of this ordinance shall be in effect at any business parking lot at any time that staying or entering the lot is prohibited by the owner, as shown by a sign at the parking lot. No person shall place or leave any vehicle on any business parking lot at any such time. 
c.  The prohibition set out in this section of this article shall be in effect at any business parking lot where the owner or person lawfully in charge has posted a sign or signs clearly stating the prohibition. Signs must be placed so that they can be seen either at all entrances to the lot or at prominent locations. Signs should contain substantially the following language: 
NO PARKING OR TRESPASSING BETWEEN 10:00 P.M. AND 6:00 A.M. 
d.  The owner or person in charge of any parking lot may grant temporary permission to use the lot during any specified hours when parking or trespassing is normally prohibited, by posting temporary signs or posters to that effect. The owner or person in charge shall notify the police department of any such temporary permission. 
(Ord. No. CC 95-1525, 3-21-95) 
Sec. 12-194. - Issuance of complaint. 
    Upon complaint by any member of the city police department, the city may make a complaint for the enforcement of this article, brought in the name of the city in the local city court. 
(Ord. No. CC 95-1525, 3-21-95) 
Sec. 12-195. - Severance clause. 
    If any section, paragraph, clause or provision of this article shall be held invalid, the invalidity thereof shall not affect any of the other provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. CC 95-1525, 3-21-95) 
Sec. 12-196. - Penalties. 
(a)  Any person found guilty of an act of trespass as defined in this article shall be subject to the following penalties. 
(1)  A fine not less than $100.00 nor more than $2,500.00. 
(2)  A period of conditional discharge not to exceed one year; 
(3)  Court costs; and/or 
(4)  Community service not to exceed 500 hours. 
(b)  A separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation of any provision of this article occurs or continues. 
(Ord. No. CC 95-1525, 3-21-95) 
Sec. 12-197. - Liability of parent or legal guardian of minor offender. 
    The parent or legal guardian of a minor who resides with such parent or legal guardian shall be liable for any fine or penalty imposed by a court upon a minor for violation of this article, if such minor has not paid such fine or satisfied the court imposed penalty for violation of this article within the time ordered by the court, provided that such parent or legal guardian has been made a party defendant and has been served with all citations, summons, complaints, notices and other documents required to be serviced on the minor in all enforcement proceedings against the minor for violation of this article. 
(Ord. No. CC 95-1525, 3-21-95) 
Secs. 12-198-12-210. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - REAL ESTATE USED FOR ILLEGAL PURPOSES[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. CC-2003-1653, §§ 1-9, adopted Dec. 2, 2003, was not specifically amendatory of the Code and has been included as art. VIII, §§ 12-211-12-219 at the editor's discretion. 

Sec. 12-211. - Owners responsibilities. 
    No owner of real estate in the City of Whiting shall knowingly allow that real estate to be used as a site for any use or sale of illicit narcotics or controlled dangerous substances, gambling, gang activity or prostitution after having received written notice pursuant to I.C. 36-7-9-25, from the Police Department of the City of Whiting, that a present occupant or tenant of that property has been using or selling illicit narcotics or controlled dangerous substances, or allowing the using or selling of illicit narcotics or controlled dangerous substances at that property, or has been engaging in or allowing gambling, gang activity or prostitution, or has otherwise been engaging in or allowed activity constituting a nuisance pursuant to I.C. 34-19-1-1. A legal or equitable owner of such real estate is deemed to have knowledge of such activity upon receipt of notice set forth herein. For the purposes of this article, an owner of real estate is defined as any person who, alone, or jointly or severally with others shall have legal or equitable title to any dwelling or dwelling unit. Notice is deemed to be given to the owner, upon receipt of notice as indicated above, by the owner or record pursuant to the records and files of the Office of the Lake County Assessor's and/or Treasurer's Office. 
(Ord. No. CC-2003-1653, § 1, 12-2-03) 
Sec. 12-212. - Report of illegal activity to be filed with police department. 
(a)  A complaint or report of suspected illegal activities constituting the use or sale of narcotics or controlled substances, or gambling, gang activity, prostitution, or conduct constituting a nuisance pursuant to I.C.34-19-1-1, by tenants, occupants, and/or their visitors, guests or invites as observed by the lessor, third persons such as other tenants of the property, or persons residing or working in the vicinity of the property, or city officials, and/or representatives of agencies and/or departments of the City of Whiting shall be submitted to the Office of the Chief of Police of the City of Whiting and each such report or complaint shall be individually logged in that office. 
(b)  Upon receipt of any report or complaint of such suspected illegal activities on real estate premises, a determination shall be made by the Whiting Police Department whether to conduct an investigation. 
(c)  Upon completion of investigation by the Whiting Police Department Detective Bureau revealing that such suspected illegal activity is taking place at a particular premise, a warning letter shall be sent by the Whiting Police Department Detective Bureau to the owner of the real estate and a copy to the tenant/occupant whose premise is the subject of the investigation, by certified mail, return receipt requested, informing the owner of the investigation revealing the suspected illegal activity and the fact that there is an ongoing investigation. The warning letter shall inform the owner of his/her choice to take action to abate such suspected illegal activity and of the intent of the Whiting Police Department, if its ongoing investigation indicates such suspected illegal activity has not ceased, to take further legal action. 
(d)  Once a search warrant has been obtained to search the real estate premises for narcotics or controlled substances, or, for any other evidence related to such suspected illegal activity, a second letter shall be sent to the owner of the real estate by certified mail, return receipt requested, and shall inform the owner that such warrant was served, that the investigation at the premises is continuing, and that legal proceedings may be commenced pursuant to this article. Such letter shall inform the owner of his/her choice to take some form of remedial action. A copy of the letter shall be sent to the chief of police, the city attorney's office and to the tenant/occupant of the premises for which a search warrant is obtained. 
(e)  Upon receipt of a copy of the second letter, the city attorney's office may proceed under I.C. 34-19-1-2(b) to abate or enjoin any suspected illegal activity as defined herein constituting a nuisance as defined in I.C. 34-19-1-1 and/or to advise the police department detective bureau to issue a notice pursuant to this article. The notice shall advise that legal proceedings may be instituted against the owner of real estate pursuant to this article and shall also inform the owner of his/her choice to commence eviction proceedings. 
(Ord. No. CC-2003-1653, § 2, 12-2-03) 
Sec. 12-213. - Criteria. 
    The criteria for establishing conviction for a violation will be determined by the appropriate judicial authority based upon the totality of the circumstances present, including, but not limited to the fact that the owner has received notices of suspected illegal activity of this article. 
(Ord. No. CC-2003-1653, § 3, 12-2-03) 
Sec. 12-214. - Eviction proceedings as a defense. 
    No person shall be charged with the violation of this article if such person: 
(1)  Has instituted eviction proceedings within 30 days of receipt of the first or the second notice of criminal activities against the tenant whose suspected criminal activities would otherwise give rise to potential liability under this article; and, 
(2)  Has completed the eviction proceedings within 30 days of commencement of the proceedings. 
(3)  If any eviction proceedings are not completed within 30 days by reason of court ordered delays in such proceedings, the person charged with a violation of this article must, nonetheless, move forward expeditiously with any such eviction proceeding. 
(Ord. No. CC-2003-1653, § 4, 12-2-03) 
Sec. 12-215. - Multiple unit dwellings. 
    In the case of a multiple unit dwelling, the only person(s) necessary to name in an eviction proceeding is the tenant/occupant occupying the actual unit involved with the suspected illegal activity described herein. 
(Ord. No. CC-2003-1653, § 5, 12-2-03) 
Sec. 12-216. - Filing of criminal charges. 
    Charging an owner of real estate with a violation of this article shall be an adjunct to, and not substitution for, any criminal charges filed as a result of investigation by the police department against occupants or tenants of that owner's real estate premises for use or sale of illicit drugs or controlled dangerous substances, gambling, prostitution or conduct constituting a nuisance pursuant to I.C. 34-19-1-1. 
(Ord. No. CC-2003-1653, § 6, 12-2-03) 
Sec. 12-217. - Assistance by chief of police. 
    The chief of police shall use reasonable efforts to train, educate and assist owners of real estate in avoiding placing tenants or occupants in their real estate who are known violators of illegal activities enumerated herein. 
(Ord. No. CC-2003-1653, § 7, 12-2-03) 
Sec. 12-218. - Limited indemnification of owners of real estate. 
    The City of Whiting shall provide a limited indemnification to an owner of real estate located in the City of Whiting, subject to the following conditions: 
(1)  That the owner of real estate shall have received the written notice required under this article from the Police Department of the City of Whiting advising that a present occupant or tenant of the property of that owner of real estate has been using or selling illicit narcotics or controlled dangerous substances or allowing the using or selling of illicit narcotics or controlled dangerous substances at that property, or who has been engaging in or allowing gambling or prostitution or has otherwise been engaging in or allowing activity constituting a nuisance pursuant to I.C. 34-19-1-1. 
(2)  That the owner of real estate has instituted eviction proceedings with 30 days of receipt of notice of suspected illegal activities in accordance with this article against a tenant whose suspected criminal activities would otherwise give rise to potential liability under this article. 
(3)  That the owner of real estate shall give no less than 30 days notice to the city attorney, by certified mail, return receipt requested, of the trial date for any eviction proceedings and a list containing the names and addresses of all witnesses the owner of real estate intends to call at the hearing. 
(4)  That the city attorney, upon receipt of the notice and list of witnesses shall have the right to provide the owner of real estate with the names and address of additional other witnesses including but not limited to witnesses from the Whiting Police Department whose presence shall be required at the hearing of the eviction proceedings. 
(5)  All witnesses listed by either the owner of real estate and/or the city attorney's office shall be subpoenaed by the owner of real estate in proper and legal fashion, and be allowed to testify. 
(6)  The tenant involved as a defendant in the eviction proceedings shall prevail on the merits, not by reason of procedural irregularities but by sole reason that a court finds after trial that the illegal activity alleged in the notice the owner of real estate has received pursuant to this article, did not, in fact, take place. 
(7)  The tenant institutes legal proceedings against the owner of real estate in the form of a counter claim or separate action and obtains a judgment for damages against the owner of real estate by reason of the tenant having prevailed on the merits in accordance with paragraph (6) above. 
(8)  The owner of real estate completes whatever steps he/she chooses to undertake to seek review of the judgment by motion to correct errors and/or appeal. 
(9)  The limited indemnification by the City of Whiting shall be restricted solely to those damages assessed by judgment against the owner of real estate as set out aforesaid but shall not, in any event, include any attorneys' fees incurred by the owner of real estate in connection with the enforcement of any of the terms of this article; but will include either the reasonable attorney's fees incurred in the defense of legal proceedings brought by a tenant pursuant to this section, paragraph (7) above, regardless of the outcome of the proceedings, or the provision of the legal services by the City of Whiting, at the city's option. 
(Ord. No. CC-2003-1653, § 8, 12-2-03) 
Sec. 12-219. - List to be kept by police department. 
    The police department shall keep a list of the names and addresses of all tenants/occupants to whom copies of letters sent pursuant to this article, and shall make the names available to members of the public requesting same in reference to potential renters of the real estate in the city. 
(Ord. No. CC-2003-1653, § 9, 12-2-03) 
Sec. 12-220. - Penalty. 
    Anyone violating any provision of this article shall, upon conviction thereof, be fined in a sum up to $2,500.00 and costs of prosecution. Each day a violation of this article continues constitutes a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. CC-2003-1653, § 10, 12-2-03) 
Secs. 12-221-12-230. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - STREET GANG ACTIVITY[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. CC-2003-1654, §§ 1-7, adopted Dec. 2, 2003, was not specifically amendatory of the Code and has been included as art. IX, §§ 12-231-12-237 at the editor's discretion. 

Sec. 12-231. - Assemblies. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for two or more persons to assemble, except at a public meeting of the citizens, on any of the sidewalks, street corners, street crossings, alleys, or in any doorway or passage of any public building of this city to the obstruction of the same so as to hinder, delay, or annoy any persons passing in, upon, or along the same or the owners or occupants or property adjacent thereto or for any person so assembled to make offensive personal remarks upon any passerby. 
(b)  No attempt shall be made to hinder or interfere with the flow of vehicular traffic. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for an individual to knowingly permit any assembly for the purpose of committing any unlawful act of breach of peace, or any riot, offense or disorderly conduct in or upon any premises owned, or occupied by him or under his control. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any individuals to interrupt or disturb any lawful assembly of people by making any loud or unusual noise, or by rude or indecent behavior or by profane, obscene or improper discourse or conduct. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful for any person to be involved in mob action. Said mob action is defined as follows: 
(1)  The use of force or violence disturbing the public peace by two or more persons acting together without authority of law; or 
(2)  The assembly of two or more persons to do an unlawful act; or 
(3)  The assembly of two or more persons without authority of law, for the purpose of doing violence to the person or property of anyone supposed to have been guilty of a violation of the law, or for the purpose of exercising correctional powers or regulative powers over any person by violence. 
(Ord. No. CC-2003-1654, § 1, 12-2-03) 
Sec. 12-232. - Curfew. 
(a)  Refer to Ordinance No. CC-2003-1651 adopted November 4, 2003. This article was adopted to comply with Indiana Code 31-37-3-1, et seq. as amended from time to time. 
(Ord. No. CC-2003-1654, § 2, 12-2-03) 
Sec. 12-233. - Criminal gang activity prohibited. 
(a)  In shall be unlawful for any person in the city to engage in "criminal gang activity". For purposes of this section a "street gang" or "gang" is defined as: 
Any ongoing organization, association in fact or group of three or more persons, whether formally or informally organized, or any sub-group or affiliated group thereof, having as one of its activities the commission of criminal or illegal acts or violations of municipal ordinances, and whose members individually or collectively engage in or have engaged in a pattern of criminal activity, illegal acts or ordinance violations, and which group frequently, though not necessarily, claims one or more particular geographical territories or turfs exclusively as its realm of influence and operations. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person within the city of knowingly use, display or wear colors, emblems or insignia on or about their person in public for the purpose of promoting any street gang activity. Evidence of the commission of such offenses may be seized by police officers. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person within the city to knowingly do or make any act, utterance, gesture, or display for the purpose of communicating membership of, affiliation with, association with, support of identification with, sympathy toward or affront or insult toward any street gang or that the subject act, utterance, gesture, or display is used and recognized as communicative of street gang membership, affiliation, association, support, identification, sympathy or affront. 
(Ord. No. CC-2003-1654, § 3, 12-2-03) 
Sec. 12-234. - Parental responsibility. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for a parent or guardian of an unemancipated minor residing with such parent or legal guardian to knowingly permit said minor to commit any violation of a city ordinance. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any custodial parent, legal guardian or other person who has a child in his or her custody or control under the age of 18, to knowingly permit said child to visit a place of prostitution or associate with known thieves, burglars, felons, narcotic addicts, or other persons of ill repute to commit an unlawful act. 
(Ord. No. CC-2003-1654, § 4, 12-2-03) 
Sec. 12-235. - Persons responsible for unlawful activities on their premises. 
    It shall be unlawful for any persons who are the owners or occupants of any premises to allow, initiate or maintain any gathering on that premises in which tenants, invitees, visitors or trespassers engage in any unlawful activity. Unlawful activity shall include but not be limited to, violations of any sections of this article. 
(Ord. No. CC-2003-1654, § 5, 12-2-03) 
Sec. 12-236. - Telecommunications devices. 
(a)  Unlawful transfer of telecommunications device to a minor: A person commits the unlawful transfer of a telecommunication device to a person under 18 years of age when he gives, sells or otherwise transfers possession of a telecommunications device to a person under 18 years of age with the intent that the device be used for unlawful purposes or as a means of communication between gang and gang member. 
(b)  Seizure: Any telecommunications device possessed by a person under 18 years of age, which is used in the commission of an unlawful act, or which is used as a means of communication between gangs and gang members, or which constitutes evidence of the commission of such offenses, may be seized by police officers. 
(Ord. No. CC-2003-1654, § 6, 12-2-03) 
Sec. 12-237. - Penalty. 
(a)  Any person found in violation of this article shall be fined not more that $2,500.00 for each separate offense. 
(b)  Restitution by the violator may also be made with respect to any property damaged, destroyed, or defaced in any way. 
(Ord. No. CC-2003-1654, § 7, 12-2-03) 
Secs. 12-238-12-250. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - NOISE[7] 
Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 2004-1690 renumbered ch. 8, art. V, §§ 8-131-8-140 as ch. 12, art. X, §§ 12-251-12-260 to read as herein set out. 
State Law reference- Noise regulations and standards, IC 13-7-8-1, 36-8-2-8. 

DIVISION 1. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 12-251. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Ambient noise level means the sound pressure level of all the encompassing noise associated with a given environment, being usually a composite of sounds from many sources, excluding the source under consideration. 
    Chief means the chief of police or his duly authorized representative. 
    Emergency vehicle means a motor vehicle used to respond to a public tragedy or to protect persons or property from imminent danger. 
    Emergency work means work made necessary to restore property to a safe condition following a public tragedy, work to restore public utilities, or work required to protect persons or property from an imminent exposure to danger. 
    Motor vehicle means any vehicle, such as, but not limited to, passenger cars, trucks, truck-trailers, semitrailers, campers, motorcycles, minibikes, go-carts, snowmobiles, dune buggies, amphibious craft on land, or racing vehicles, which are propelled or drawn by mechanical power. 
    Muffler means a device for diminishing or lessening the sound of escaping gases of an internal combustion engine. 
    Noise means any sound which is unwanted or which causes or tends to cause an adverse psychological or physiological effect on human beings. 
    Noise control board means and shall be composed of the entire board of public works and safety. The purpose of such board is to review exceptions and permits to this article. Members shall serve without pay. 
    Person means any individual, association, partnership, or corporation, and includes any officer, employee, department, agency or instrumentality of the United States, a state or any political subdivision of that state. 
    Powered model vehicles means any powered vehicles, either airborne, waterborne, or landborne, which are designed not to carry persons or property such as, but not limited to, model airplanes, boats, cars, and rockets, and which can be propelled by mechanical means. 
    Property boundary means an imaginary line exterior to any enclosed structure, at the ground surface, which separates the real property owned by one person from that owned by another person, and its vertical extension. 
    Public right-of-way and public space means any street, avenue, boulevard, highway, alley, or public space which is owned or controlled by a public governmental entity. 
(Ord. No. CC-97-1538, 5-21-96; Ord. No. CC-97-1552, 4-15-97; Ord. No. 2004-1690, 11-3-04) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Note- Formerly § 8-131. 
Sec. 12-252. - Agencies. 
(a)  The noise control program required by this article shall be administered by the police department. 
(b)  All departments of city government shall, to the fullest extent consistent with their authorities under other ordinances administered by them, carry out their program in such a manner as to further the policy of this article and shall cooperate to enforce the noise regulations of this article. 
(c)  All departments engaged in any activities which result or may result in the emission of noise shall comply with federal and state laws and regulations as well as the provisions of this article, respecting the control and abatement of noise to the same extent that any person is subject to such laws and regulations. 
(Ord. No. CC-97-1538, 5-21-96; Ord. No. CC-97-1552, 4-15-97; Ord. No. 2004-1690, 11-3-04) 
Cross reference- Police department, § 2-151 et seq. 
Note- Formerly § 8-132. 
Sec. 12-253. - Authority and duties of police department. 
    In order to implement the purposes of this article, the police department shall have the power to, but shall not be required to: 
(1)  Studies. Conduct, or cause to be conducted, studies, research, and monitoring related to noise. 
(2)  Education. Conduct programs of public education regarding the causes and effects of noise but not giving specific advice for its abatement, and to encourage the participation of public interest groups in related public information efforts. 
(3)  Project reviews. Review projects subject to review by any other department for compliance with the intent and provisions of this article. This power shall include the review of all licensing applications where noise may be an important factor. 
(4)  Inspections. For reasonable cause and upon presentation of proper credentials, enter any building, property, premises, or place with the owner's, occupant's, or tenant's approval to inspect any noise for the purpose of ascertaining compliance or noncompliance with any provision of this article. 
(5)  Duties of law enforcement officers. The police chief may: 
a.  Develop measurement methods and standards which will further the purposes of this article. 
b.  Develop a truck route map of the city for the purpose of reducing truck noise. 
c.  Develop long-term objectives for achieving quiet in the city and develop a means for implementation of these objectives into the long-range planning process. 
(Ord. No. CC-97-1538, 5-21-96; Ord. No. CC-97-1552, 4-15-97; Ord. No. 2004-1690, 11-3-04) 
Note- Formerly § 8-133. 
Sec. 12-254. - Prohibited noises. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person to make, continue, create, assist in creating; permit, continue or permit the continuance of any unreasonable loud, disturbing or unnecessary noise within the limits of the city. 
(b)  The following acts, among others, are declared to be loud, disturbing, or excessive in violation of this article: 
(1)  The sounding of any horn or signaling device on any motor vehicle on any public right-of-way, except as a danger warning signal or as provided in the vehicle code of the state, or the sounding of any such device for any unnecessary and unreasonable period of time, at any place. 
(2)  Operating or permitting the use or operation of any radio receiving set, musical instrument, amplifier, television, phonograph, drum or other device for the production or reproduction of sound, in such a manner as to annoy and/or disturb the quiet, comfort of persons, or operating any such device in such a manner as to be plainly audible across property boundaries, or through partitions common to two parties within any dwelling, hotel or other type of residence. 
(3)  Owning, keeping, possessing, or harboring any animal which, by frequent or habitual noisemaking, causes a noise in such a manner as to annoy and/or disturb; the provision of this section shall also apply to all private or public facilities, including any animal pounds which hold or treat animals. 
(4)  Repairing, rebuilding, modifying or testing any motor vehicle, off-road vehicle or motorboat in or near a residential area, in such a manner as to cause a noise in such a manner as to annoy and disturb the quiet. 
(5)  Operating or permitting the operation of powered motor vehicles between the hours of 8:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. the following morning, in such a manner as to annoy and disturb the peace and quiet of the neighborhood. 
(6)  Operating or permitting the operation of any motor vehicle which can compact and/or collect refuse between the hours of 7:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. the following day in a residential district or directly adjacent to a residential district, except in emergencies by city vehicles. 
(7)  Operating or permitting the operation of the motor of any motor vehicle whose manufacturer's gross weight is in excess of 10,000 pounds, or any attached auxiliary equipment for a period longer than ten minutes in any hour while such vehicle is stationary on public or private property and is not within a completely enclosed structure; this section shall not apply to buses and taxis operated for transportation, bus/taxi turnabouts, terminals, lots and storage yards; and vehicles operating in industrial zones. 
(8)  Using or causing the use of any device that creates a vibration which in such a manner as to annoy and disturb an individual beyond the property boundary of the source on private property. 
(9)  Discharging into the open air the exhaust of any stationary internal combustion engine or motor vehicle except through a muffler or other device which will effectively prevent loud or explosive noises therefrom. 
(c)  Any person who modifies or changes the exhaust muffler, intake muffler or any other noise abatement device of a motor vehicle in such a manner that the noise emitted by the motor vehicle is increased above that emitted by the vehicle as originally manufactured can be found in violation of this article. 
(Ord. No. CC-97-1538, 5-21-96; Ord. No. CC-97-1552, 4-15-97; Ord. No. 2004-1690, 11-3-04) 
Note- Formerly § 8-134. 
Sec. 12-255. - Making noise with mechanical devices for advertising purposes. 
    Any person who makes or causes, permits or allows to be made any noise of any kind by means of any whistle, rattle, bell, gun, clapper, hammer, drum, horn or similar mechanical device at any time for the purpose of advertising any goods, wares or merchandise or of attracting the attention or inviting the patronage of any person to do any business whatsoever anywhere in the city shall be guilty of disorderly conduct. 
(Ord. No. CC-97-1538, 5-21-96; Ord. No. CC-97-1552, 4-15-97; Ord. No. 2004-1690, 11-3-04) 
Note- Formerly § 8-135. 
Sec. 12-256. - Exceptions; permits. 
(a)  Emergency exception. Noise caused in the performance of emergency work for the immediate safety, health, or welfare of the community or individuals of the community, or to restore property to a safe condition following a public tragedy, and noise emanated by safety devices, shall not be subject to the provisions of this article. Nothing in this section shall be construed to permit law enforcement, ambulance, fire, or other emergency personnel to make excessive noise in the performance of their duties when such noise is clearly unnecessary. Noises emanating from church bells, organs or carillons is exempt from the terms of this article. Noises emanating from any approved municipal or school related activity is exempt from the terms of this article. 
(b)  Permit issuance. The noise control board is authorized to grant special exceptions from the requirements of this article, as it determines are necessary and appropriate to protect public health, safety, and welfare from the noise emanating therefrom. This section shall in no way affect the duty to obtain any other permit or license required by law for such activities. 
(c)  Exceptions for time to comply. Upon good cause shown by the owner of any noise source, the noise control board shall have the power to grant an exception from the operation of this article in order to allow sufficient time for installation of needed control equipment, facilities, or modifications to achieve compliance not to exceed 30 days; provided, that such exception may be renewed for an additional period if satisfactory progress toward compliance is shown. Any person seeking an exception shall file a petition with the noise control board. The noise control board shall promptly give written notice of such petition to any person who has, in writing, requested notice of such exception petitions, and shall publish notice of such petition in a newspaper of general circulation within this city. If the noise control board, in its discretion, concludes that a hearing would be advisable, or if any person files a written request for a hearing or a written objection to the grant of such exception within ten days of the notice provided in this section, a hearing shall be held on the petition. A written transcript shall be kept of any such hearing. In granting or denying any exception, the noise control board shall file and publish a written order stating the facts and reasons leading to its decision. All costs arising out of that hearing shall be the responsibility of the applicant. 
(Ord. No. CC-97-1538, 5-21-96; Ord. No. CC-97-1552, 4-15-97; Ord. No. 2004-1690, 11-3-04) 
Note- Formerly § 8-136. 
Sec. 12-257. - Noise levels emitted from motor vehicles. 
(a)  Normal operation of a motor vehicle on a public right-of-way. No person shall operate a motor vehicle on a public right-of-way at any time in such manner that the sound (other than that emitted by the vehicle as originally manufactured) emits a noise, sound or vibration which annoy, disturb or perturbs reasonable persons with normal sensitivities or any sound which injures or endangers the comfort, relaxation, health, hearing, peace and safety of other persons. This section shall apply to all motor vehicles, whether publicly or privately owned, that are duly licensed. 
(b)  Radios and sound making devices. It is unlawful for any person operating a motor vehicle on a street or highway, within the limits of the city, to operate or amplify the sound produced by a radio, or other mechanical sound-making device or instrument from within the motor vehicle so that the sound is emitting a noise, sound or vibration which annoys, disturbs or perturbs reasonable persons with normal sensitiveness, or any sound which injures or endangers the comfort, relaxation, health, hearing, peace and safety other persons. 
(c)  Federal preemption. At such time as the administrator of the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency establishes the noise standards applicable to the operation of licensed interstate motor carriers pursuant to the Federal Noise Control Act of 1972 (Public Law 92-574), those standards shall be incorporated in this article by reference and the motor vehicle noise limits and measurement location set forth in this section shall be superseded with respect to those classes of motor vehicle operators covered by such federal standards. 
(d)  Off public right-of-way. No person shall operate a motorized vehicle or recreational device off a public right-of-way in such manner that the sound emits a noise, sound or vibration which annoys, disturbs or perturbs reasonable person with normal sensitiveness, or any sound which injures or endangers the comfort, relaxation, health, hearing, peace and safety of other persons. This section shall apply to all motorized vehicles and recreational devices, whether publicly licensed or not, including but not limited to trailers, motorcycles, minibikes, go-carts, snowmobiles, amphibious craft, dune buggies, raking vehicles, water ski towing devices, and watercraft. 
(Ord. No. CC-97-1538, 5-21-96; Ord. No. CC-97-1552, 4-15-97; Ord. No. 2004-1690, 11-3-04) 
Cross reference- Vehicles and traffic, ch. 17. 
Note- Formerly § 8-137. 
Sec. 12-258. - Violation notice. 
(a)  Generally. 
(1)  If an officer of the city police department determines that noise from any source violated the provisions of this article, the officer shall issue to the owner or operators of the source, a violation notice to appear in the Whiting City Court. 
(Ord. No. CC-97-1538, 5-21-96; Ord. No. CC-97-1552, 4-15-97; Ord. No. 2004-1690, 11-3-04) 
Note- Formerly § 8-138. 
Sec. 12-259. - Person liable. 
(a)  All persons owning, operating, or in charge or control of any equipment or premises who shall cause, suffer, allow, permit, or participate in any violation of this article shall be individually and collectively liable for any penalties imposed. This liability shall include any person who shall refuse to comply with or who shall assist in the violation of any of the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. CC-97-1538, 5-21-96; Ord. No. CC-97-1552, 4-15-97; Ord. No. 2004-1690, 11-3-04) 
Note- Formerly § 8-139. 
Sec. 12-260. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating any provisions of this chapter shall be fined not less than $50.00 and no more than $2,500.00 for each offense; and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Ord. No. CC-97-1538, 5-21-96; Ord. No. CC-97-1552, 4-15-97; Ord. No. 2004-1690, 11-3-04) 
Note- Formerly § 8-140. 
Secs. 12-261-12-290. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LOCOMOTIVE ENGINE WHISTLES AND BELLS[8] 

Footnotes:

Editor's note- Ord. No. CC-2003-1658, §§ 1, 2, adopted Dec. 30, 2003, was not specifically amendatory of the Code and has been included as art. X, div. 2, § 12-291 at the editor's discretion. 

Sec. 12-291. - Use of locomotive whistles and bells. 
(a)  No person operating or controlling any locomotive engine shall sound the locomotive engine's whistle and/or ring its bell, or allow the whistle to be sounded or the bell to be rung, during the locomotive engine's approach to the following railroad grade crossings located within the municipal boundaries of the City of Whiting, Lake County, Indiana, all of which are equipped with automatic, train-activated warning signals, as hereinabove described and in accordance with the provisions of IC 8-6-7.7-2, as amended from time to time: 
117th Street Crossings 
Front Street Crossings 
all in the City of Whiting, Lake County, Indiana. 
(b)  Any person who shall fail or neglect to comply with the provisions set forth in this section shall be held personally liable to the State of Indiana in a penalty of not less than $500.00 and not more than $1,000.00, to be recovered in a civil action commenced in the name of the State of Indiana in the Lake Circuit or Superior Court. 
(Ord. No. CC-2003-1658, §§ 1, 2, 12-30-03)

ARTICLE XI. - NUISANCE PROPERTY 

Sec. 12-300. - Definitions. 
    Nuisance property: A nuisance property for the purposes of this article shall consist of the following: 
(1)  Any property which has had three documented complaints to the Whiting Police Department concerning said property within a 90-day time period. 
(Ord. No. CC-2004-1682, 8-17-04) 
Sec. 12-301. - Classification of a nuisance property. 
(a)  Upon review of the documentation, the Whiting Police Chief may classify the property in question as a nuisance property. 
(b)  If the property in question is classified to be a nuisance property, the police department shall issue a citation containing notice to the owner of the property by forwarding said notice via U.S. Mail to the property at issue and by personally leaving a copy of the notice at the property at issue; said notice shall contain the date where the property owner must appear in the Whiting City Court. In the event that the property owner does not reside at the property at issue, the citation shall be sent to the owner's current residence, if that residence is within Lake County, Indiana. If the owner does not reside within Lake County, Indiana, then the citation shall be sent to the owner's agent residing in Lake County, Indiana (in accordance with chapter 9, art. III - Whiting Rental Registration Ordinance). 
(Ord. No. CC-2004-1682, 8-17-04) 
Sec. 12-302. - Types of property. 
    All provisions of this chapter shall apply to any residential and commercial property in the City of Whiting. 
(Ord. No. CC-2004-1682, 8-17-04) 
Sec. 12-303. - Penalty. 
    All violations of this chapter shall be prosecuted in accordance with Chapter 1, section 1-11 of the Code of Ordinances, City of Whiting, Indiana. 
(Ord. No. CC-2004-1682, 8-17-04) 
Secs. 12-304-12-330. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XII. - PORTABLE STORAGE UNITS[9] 

Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. CC-2008-1795, §§ 1-7, adopted November 18, 2008, did not specifically amend the Code; hence, inclusion as Ch. 12, Art. XII, §§ 12-331-12-337 was at the discretion of the editor. 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 15 et seq.; general traffic regulations, ch. 17, art. IV; Unified Development, App. A. 

Sec. 12-331. - Definitions. 
    [The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:] 
(a)  Portable storage unit (PSU) is any type of non-motorized container, structure, trailer or module which is intended and designed for the storage of personal property items, which is typically delivers and removed by vehicle, and which may be temporarily rented or owned by the owners or occupants of properties in the city. 
(b)  Site or property is any lot, parcel, tract, or plat of land located in any residential or commercial zoning district of the city, including public rights-of-way. 
(Ord. No. CC-2008-1795, § 1, 11-18-2008) 
Sec. 12-332. - Scope. 
(a)  This article shall not apply to or regulate portable storage units in areas which are zoned I-LIM (Low Impact Manufacturing) or I-HIM (High Impact Manufacturing). 
(b)  This article shall not apply to or regulate any portable storage unit used for a public works project as defined by the Indiana Statutes. 
(c)  The city reserves the right to suspend the requirements and fees for portable storage units in the event of a natural disaster. 
(Ord. No. CC-2008-1795, § 2, 11-18-2008) 
Sec. 12-333. - Requirements, limitations, and prohibition for usage. 
(a)  There shall be no more than one portable storage unit located on any site, property, or public right-of-way per address at any time in any area zoned residential or commercial 
(b)  No portable storage unit shall exceed 130 square feet in total area. 
(c)  No portable storage unit may be used for human habitation. 
(d)  No portable storage unit may be used as a detached permanent storage building, utility building, workshop, hobby shop or other commercial venture. 
(e)  Prior to the placement of any portable storage unit on any site, property or right-of-way within the city, the property owner, or the authorized occupant of the site or property must apply for and receive a permit from the city. The zoning department shall provide an application form that will require the signature or consent of the property owner, a diagram depicting the proposed location of the unit, and an affirmation of compliance with the provisions of this article. 
(f)  The request for the placement of a unit shall specify whether the placement is for a temporary period or an extended period. A temporary period shall be defined as a placement lasting 14 days or less. An extended placement is defined as a placement for 15 to 60 days. 
(g)  The cost of securing the permit and the department's review of the application and the proposed placement shall be $20.00 for a temporary placement or $50.00 for an extended placement. 
(h)  The city reserves the right to deny a permit at any time based on the placement of the unit interfering with a public event or a public works project. 
(Ord. No. CC-2008-1795, § 3, 11-18-2008) 
Sec. 12-334. - Duration of placement of units. 
(a)  Temporary storage unit permits are valid for a period of 14 calendar days from the date of issuance of the permit by the zoning department. 
(b)  Extended storage unit permits are valid for a period of 60 calendar days from the date of issuance of the permit by the zoning department. 
(c)  If a permit for an extended period requires approval of a public right-of-way obstruction, the permit shall be valid for a period of 60 days from the approval of the obstruction by an authorized city official. 
(d)  Temporary permits may not be renewed. 
(e)  Extended permits may be renewed once thereafter, for a period of renewal of no longer than an additional 60 days. 
(f)  The fee for a renewal of an extended permit shall be the same as the initial fee. 
(g)  No portable storage unit may remain on any site, property, or public right-of-way for a cumulative period of more than 120 days during any rolling 12 month period. 
(Ord. No. CC-2008-1795, § 4, 11-18-2008) 
Sec. 12-335. - Location of portable storate units. 
(a)  In a district zoned residential, a portable storage unit may be placed on a driveway, other paved surface, or where directed by the zoning department. If the zoning department recommends placement of the unit within the public right-of-way, and right-of-way obstruction form must be completed before placement. It shall be solely within the authority of the zoning department as to whether a unit should be placed on public or private property. 
(b)  In a district zoned commercial, a portable storage unit shall only be placed in the rear or side portion of the site or property. No unit shall be permitted to be placed in an area fronting a street, the front parking lot area of the site or property, fire lanes, passenger loading zones, sidewalks, or other public ways unless first recommended by the zoning department and approved by the board of public works. 
(c)  No portable storage unit may be placed in the public right-of-way on 119 th Street from Atchison Avenue to Front Street or on Indianapolis Boulevard from Atchison Avenue to 129 th Street 
(d)  If it is determined that a unit needs to be placed in any public right-of-way said placement shall not conflict with any other parking restriction listed in Whiting Municipal Code Chapter 17, Article XI Parking and Article XVII Schedules. 
(Ord. No. CC-2008-1795, § 5, 11-18-2008) 
Sec. 12-336. - Maintenace and prohibitions of hazardous materials or substances storage. 
(a)  All portable storage units shall be in good conditions and free from deteriorations, weathering, discoloration, rust, ripping, tearing, or other holes or breaks. The units shall maintain an appearance appropriate to its location, remain locked when not in use, and provide a weatherproof clear pouch for the exterior display of the city permit. 
(b)  With the exception of the name, address and phone number of the business entity that owns any portable storage unit, no commercial advertising shall be permitted on any such unit placed in the city. 
(c)  The placement and storage of hazardous, incendiary, combustible, noxious, or pernicious materials or substances within any unit is strictly prohibited. 
(d)  The city reserves the right to request a list of the contents for the use of the Whiting Fire Department when the department so requests for public safety purposes. 
(Ord. No. CC-2008-1795, § 6, 11-18-2008) 
Sec. 33-337. - Violations and penalties. 
A.  Any person who violates any of the provisions contained in this article shall be subject to the general penalty provisions of Whiting Municipal Code Section 1-11. 
B.  In the event that a portable storage unit remains in the public right-of-way in excess of the permitted time frame, the city reserves the right to remove the obstruction. 
(Ord. No. CC-2008-1795, § 7, 11-18-2008) 
Chapter 13 - PARKS AND RECREATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2; dogs in city parks, § 3-18; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 15. 
State Law reference- General powers concerning recreation, culture and community facilities, IC 36-10-2-1 et seq.; Park and Recreation Law, IC 36-10-3-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. CC-2014-1927, §§ 1-15, adopted Jan. 6, 2015, amended Art. I in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former Art. I, §§ 13-1-13-11, pertained to similar subject matter. See the Code Comparative Table for a detailed analysis. 

Sec. 13-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Designated area means an area that is classified by signs as being available for the purposes stated therein. 
    Motor vehicle means any type of vehicle operating by gas or oil, including, but not by way of limitation, automobiles, trucks, motor scooters, and motor bicycles. 
    Park means all city property which is owned or leased by the city and so designated for use as a park. 
    Park facilities means the pavilion, the gazebo, the formal garden, the boardwalk and over look, the pier, the bike paths, all facilities at Oil City Stadium, all fields at the Whiting Municipal Sports Complex, all city-owned playgrounds and pocket parks and/or any other space designated by the park authority. 
    Parking area means those areas designated for the purpose of parking vehicles. Such areas include areas located within the Whiting Lakefront Park, Whihala Beach, all roadways within the Lakefront Park and other overflow areas as designated. 
    Property means every and all types of property, both real property and personal property, including, but not by way of limitation, buildings, windows, public telephone booths, flowers, and grass. 
(Ord. No. CC-2014-1927, § 1, 1-6-15) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 13-2. - Applicability. 
    All provisions of this chapter shall apply to Whiting Lakefront Park, Whihala Beach, Oil City Stadium, Whiting Municipal Sports Complex, the bike paths, playgrounds and other city parks as applicable. 
(Ord. No. CC-2014-1927, § 2, 1-6-15) 
Sec. 13-3. - Operation of motorized vehicles on park or beach property. 
    It shall be unlawful to operate any motorized vehicle within the Lakefront Park or Whihala Beach except upon the public roadway. Motorized vehicles are prohibited from using the boardwalk, bike path, walkways or beach area. Park-owned vehicles, emergency vehicles, authorized construction vehicles and security vehicles are exempted from this prohibition. Further exemptions will be at the discretion of the park authority. 
(Ord. No. CC-2014-1927, § 3, 1-6-15) 
Sec. 13-4. - Bicycles; operating in unsafe manner prohibited. 
    It is unlawful to operate bicycles, scooters, skateboards or any other similar device upon the pathways and boardwalks of the parks in an unsafe or unreasonable manner, or in a manner which causes damage to public property. 
(Ord. No. CC-2014-1927, § 4, 1-6-15) 
Sec. 13-5. - Trash; littering. 
    It is unlawful for any person to litter any park or beach owned or operated by the city. Littering is considered to have occurred when any person or persons have failed to properly dispose of trash in marked containers located throughout all parks and beaches owned or operated by the city. Those persons leaving the parks and or beach are responsible for seeing that their trash is properly disposed of before leaving the park or beach. 
(Ord. No. CC-2014-1927, § 5, 1-6-15) 
Sec. 13-6. - Parking. 
    It shall be unlawful to park in any designated parking area or roadway within Whiting Lakefront Park and/or Whihala Beach without first either paying the appropriate fee as designated by meter or event; or by displaying a valid city-issued sticker/permit/placard. Vehicles in violation of the parking provisions will be subject to fines for parking violations and/or having the vehicle towed by order of the designated enforcement officer. Parking rates shall be established by the park authority. Overnight parking in the park is prohibited unless prior written authorization is given by the park authority. 
(Ord. No. CC-2014-1927, § 6, 1-6-15) 
Sec. 13-7. - Camping and overnight stays in park or beach. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to camp or stay overnight in any park or at Whihala Beach unless permitted as a special event by the park authority. 
(Ord. No. CC-2014-1927, § 7, 1-6-15) 
Sec. 13-8. - Fees for park facilities. 
    It shall be unlawful to use those park facilities for which a user fee has been established by the park authority without proper reservation and payment of appropriate fees as established by the park authority. The fees shall be included in the city fee schedule. The park authority reserves the right to approve or alter the rules and/or fees for special events which are approved by the authority. 
(Ord. No. CC-2014-1927, § 8, 1-6-15) 
Sec. 13-9. - Alcoholic beverages. 
    It is unlawful for any person to bring any alcoholic beverages into the park or beach, or consume, have in possession, sell, give away or handle any alcoholic beverages in the park or beach without proper authority. 
(Ord. No. CC-2014-1927, § 9, 1-6-15) 
Sec. 13-10. - Destruction of park or beach property. 
    It is unlawful to destroy, harm, vandalize, improperly use, or inflict any damage whatsoever upon any property or facility in a park or beach owned or operated by the city. 
(Ord. No. CC-2014-1927, § 10, 1-6-15) 
Sec. 13-11. - Grilling in park or beach. 
    Grilling in Whiting Lakefront Park or Whihala Beach shall be only be permitted in designated areas or with a special event permit issued by the park authority. Grilling is allowed with pavilion rentals. 
(Ord. No. CC-2014-1927, § 11, 1-6-15) 
Sec. 13-12. - Hours of Whiting Lakefront Park and Whihala Beach. 
    The hours of operation for the Whiting Lakefront Park and Whihala Beach shall be designated by the park authority. 
(Ord. No. CC-2014-1927, § 12, 1-6-15) 
Sec. 13-13. - Pier and revetment. 
    It shall be unlawful to dive, jump or enter into the water in any fashion from the fishing pier in Whiting Lakefront Park. It shall be unlawful to enter upon or climb upon the rock revetment along Lake Michigan in the Whiting Lakefront Park. 
(Ord. No. CC-2014-1927, § 13, 1-6-15) 
Sec. 13-14. - Enforceability. 
    All provisions of this chapter may be enforced by any duly authorized law enforcement officer, code enforcement officer, parking enforcement officer or any duly authorized inspector or designated code enforcement agent or assistant. 
(Ord. No. CC-2014-1927, § 14, 1-6-15) 
Sec. 13-15. - Violations. 
    Violations of this chapter shall be subject to the general penalty provision of Whiting Municipal Code section 1-11 as well as any other enforcement action specified herein. However, violations in section 13-4, bicycles, section 13-5, litter, section 13-6, parking, section 13-7, camping, and section 13-11, grilling, may be enforced pursuant to the provisions of the city violations bureau in Whiting Municipal Code sections 2-351 through 2-355. 
(Ord. No. CC-2014-1927, § 15, 1-6-15) 
Secs. 13-16-13-35. - Reserved.

Chapter 14 - REVENUE AND FINANCE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2; licenses and business regulations, ch. 10. 
State Law reference- Taxation, IC 6-1.1-1-1 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 14-1. - Cumulative capital improvement fund-Definition. 
    As used in section 14-2, "improvement" includes the construction, equipment, remodeling, extension, repair, and betterment of structures, including: 
(1)  Sanitary sewers and sanitary sewer tap-ins. 
(2)  Sidewalks. 
(3)  Curbs. 
(4)  Streets. 
(5)  Alleys. 
(6)  Pedestrian-ways or malls set aside entirely or partly, or during restricted hours, for pedestrian rather than vehicular traffic. 
(7)  Other paved public places. 
(8)  Parking facilities. 
(9)  Lighting. 
(10)  Electric signals. 
(11)  Landscaping, including trees, shrubbery, flowers, grass, fountains, benches, statutes, floodlighting, gaslighting, and structures of a decorative, educational, or historical nature. The term "capital improvement" shall not include salaries of any public officials or employees except those which are directly chargeable to a capital improvement. 
(Ord. No. 1084, § 2, 1965; Code 1979, § 4.04.020) 
State Law reference- Uses of capital improvement funds, IC 6-7-1-31.1, 36-9-16-2 et seq.; "improvement" defined, IC 36-9-1-2. 
Sec. 14-2. - Same-Created; source of moneys; purpose. 
    In accordance with the requirements of IC 6-7-1-31.1 there is created a special fund to be known as the cumulative capital improvement fund of the city, into which the cigarette taxes allotted to the city by reason of IC 6-7-1-30.1 shall be deposited. The fund shall be a cumulative fund, and all of the moneys deposited into the fund shall be appropriated and used solely for capital improvements as defined in section 14-1. None of such moneys shall revert to the general fund or be used for any purposes other than capital improvements. 
(Ord. No. 1084, § 1, 1965; Code 1979, § 4.04.010) 
State Law reference- Appropriations of cigarette tax funds to cities, IC 6-7-1-30.1; cumulative capital improvement fund, IC 36-9-16-1 et seq.; addition of surplus money from other accounts, IC 36-9-16-6. 
Sec. 14-3. - Local supplemental adult probation services fund. 
(a)  That there is hereby established a local supplemental adult probation services fund. 
(b)  That all probation users fee's collected shall be transferred to the clerk-treasurer of the city and be deposited into the local supplemental adult probation services fund. 
(c)  That the common council of the city shall appropriate money as needed from the local supplemental adult probationary services fund to the city court for the court's use in providing probation services to adults. 
(d)  That the following probation user's fee will be charged each person convicted of a misdemeanor and placed on probation: 
(1)  Fifty dollars initial probation user's fee. 
(2)  Ten dollars monthly probation user's fee for each month that the person remains on probation. 
(3)  Costs of laboratory test or series of tests to detect and confirm the presence of the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) antigen or antibodies to the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) if such tests are required by the court. 
(Ord. No. CC-96-1535, §§ 1-4, 3-5-96) 
Secs. 14-4-14-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - PROMOTIONAL FUND 

Sec. 14-31. - Establishment. 
    The mayor's promotional fund is established. The common council is authorized to budget and appropriate funds from the general fund or from other funds to pay the expenses incurred in promoting the betterment of the city. 
(Code 1979, § 4.16.010; Ord. No. 1273, § 1, 1982) 
Sec. 14-32. - Expenditures. 
    Expenditures from the mayor's promotional fund may include, but are not necessarily limited to, the following: 
(1)  Membership dues in local, regional, state and national associations of a civic, educational or governmental nature, which have as their purpose the betterment and improvement of municipal operations. 
(2)  Direct expenses for travel, meals, and lodging in conjunction with municipal business or meetings of organizations to which the city belongs. 
(3)  Expenses incurred in the promotion of economic or industrial development for the city, including meeting room rental, decorations, meals and travel. 
(4)  Commemorative plaques, certificates, or objects such as commemorative keys. 
(5)  Other purposes which are deemed by the mayor to directly relate to promotion or betterment of the city. 
(Code 1979, § 4.16.020; Ord. No. 1273, § 2, 1982) 
Sec. 14-33. - Authorization and claims for expenses. 
    No expenses shall be allowed from the mayor's promotional fund without prior authorization and approval of the mayor. Claims for expenses under this section shall be allowed as prescribed by law. 
(Code 1979, § 4.16.030; Ord. No. 1273, § 3, 1982) 
Sec. 14-34. - Promotional accounts for clerk-treasurer and council members. 
    Promotional accounts may be established for the clerk-treasurer and the members of the common council, subject to: 
(1)  Appropriation by the fiscal body; and 
(2)  Expenditure in accordance with the provisions of this section. 
(Ord. No. CC-2005-1702, 8-23-05) 
Secs. 14-35-14-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - RAINY DAY FUND[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. CC-2010-1836, §§ 1-6, adopted June 1, 2010, added provisions that were not specifically amendatory. At the editor's discretion, said provisions were included herein as §§ 14-51-14-56. 

Sec. 14-51. - Creation of rainy day fund. 
    There is hereby established a "rainy day fund" to receive transfers of unused and unencumbered funds raised by a general or special tax levy on taxable property within the city whenever the purpose of such tax levy has been fulfilled and an unused and unencumbered balance remains. 
(Ord. No. CC-2010-1836, § 1, 6-1-10) 
Sec. 14-52. - Purposes of the fund. 
    The funds on deposit in the rainy day fund may be used for the operation of the city and its various departments, when the city does not have sufficient levies or funds to pay such costs, including, but not limited to: 
(1)  Salaries and wages; 
(2)  Costs of services; 
(3)  Supplies; 
(4)  Equipment; 
(5)  Capital improvements; 
(6)  Grant programs; 
(7)  Property acquisitions; 
(8)  Any other lawful purpose permitted by state statutes for other revenues of the city. 
(Ord. No. CC-2010-1836, § 2, 6-1-10) 
Sec. 14-53. - Transfer to fund. 
    On or before December 31 st of each year, the mayor, clerk-treasurer, and city council shall determine the amount, if any, of any unused or unencumbered funds available to be transferred to the rainy day fund, which transfer may not exceed more than ten percent of the city's total budget for that fiscal year. 
(Ord. No. CC-2010-1836, § 3, 6-1-10) 
Sec. 14-54. - Source of funds. 
    The sources for the funding for the rainy day fund may include the following: 
(1)  Unused and unencumbered funds under I.C. 36-1-8-5(b)(2); 
(2)  Unused and unencumbered funds under I.C. 6-3.5-1.1-21.1 (CAGIT); I.C. 6-3.5-6-17.3 (COIT); or I.C. 6-3.5-7-17.3 (EDIT); 
(3)  Unused and unencumbered funds received as reimbursements to the city for prior expenditures; 
(4)  Unused and unencumbered funds received as a result of the compromise or settlement of claims or lawsuits by the city; 
(5)  Unused and unencumbered funds received from donations; 
(6)  Unused and unencumbered funds received from any other source, receipt of which is not otherwise prohibited by law. 
(Ord. No. CC-2010-1836, § 4, 6-1-10) 
Sec. 14-55. - Appropriations. 
    The common council may authorize the expenditure of funds from the rainy day fund by appropriations made in the same manner as other funds are appropriated that receive tax money for any purpose permitted under section 14-52 of this article. 
(Ord. No. CC-2010-1836, § 5, 6-1-10) 
Sec. 14-56. - Reduction of levy. 
    Pursuant to I.C. 36-1-8-5.1(f), the department of local government finance may not reduce the actual or maximum permissible levy of the city as a result of the balance in the rainy day fund. 
(Ord. No. CC-2010-1836, § 6, 6-1-10) 
Secs. 14-57-14-70. - Reserved.

The municipal fiscal officer is authorized to administer and enforce this section and to promulgate written guidelines consistent with its purposes. 
(Ord. No. CC-2013-1893, § 3, 4-16-13) 
Sec. 14-74. - Authority related to acceptance of bank or credit cards. 
(a)  The municipality, its executive departments and its utilities may contract with any of the following: 
(1)  A bank card or credit card vendor for acceptance of bank cards or credit cards. 
(2)  A third-party online collection service for acceptance of bank cards or credit cards. 
(b)  The municipality, its executive departments and its utilities may pay any applicable bank card or credit card service charge associated with the use of a bank card or credit card under this section. 
(c)  If there is a charge to the municipality, its executive departments or municipally owned utility for the use of a financial instrument, a fee may be collected equal to the amount of the charge from the person who uses the financial instrument. 
(Ord. No. CC-2013-1893, § 4, 4-16-13)

(5)  Bank card or credit card.

(1)  Cash. 
(2)  Check.
