Sec. 14-76. - Authorized financial instruments for clerk-treasurer. 
(a)  Payments may be made by clerk-treasurer for the municipality and its executive departments for any lawful purpose by any of the following financial instruments: 
(1)  Warrant or negotiable order of withdrawal pursuant to the provisions of I.C. 36-4-8 et seq., 5-11-10 et seq., and 5-13-5 et seq.; 
(2)  Bank card or credit card; provided, that it is expressly authorized by the proper board of jurisdiction, identifies the responsible officer for the card, and expressly sets forth the approved uses for it; 
(b)  Pursuant to I.C. 5-13-5-5, transactions or payments may be made by the clerk-treasurer for the municipality, and its executive departments for any lawful purpose set forth in this chapter by any of the following financial instruments: 
(1)  Electronic funds transfer; 
(2)  Wire funds or automated clearing house (ACH); 
(c)  In making payments under subsection (b) of this section the clerk-treasurer shall maintain adequate documentation of the transactions so that they may be audited as provided by law, and the use of the instruments set forth in subsection (b) of this section shall be limited to the purposes authorized under Whiting Municipal Code Section 2-105 Claim Payments in Advance of Council Allowance or for lawful purposes that may be identified by the clerk-treasurer which are authorized in writing and not inconsistent with this chapter. 
(Ord. No. CC-2013-1893, § 6, 4-16-13) 
Chapter 14.5 - SIGN ORDINANCE 

Sec. 14.5-1. - Purpose and title. 
(a)  The purposes of the ordinance from which this chapter was derived are: 
(1)  To regulate, classify, restrict, and control the location, size, type and placement of all signs and sign structure; 
(2)  To eliminate and prevent excessive and confusing sign displays which do not relate to the premises on which they are located within the city; 
(3)  To preserve the natural beauty and environment which is instrumental in attracting those who come to visit, trade, or set up residence; 
(4)  To safeguard, stabilize, and enhance property values; 
(5)  To protect public and private investment in buildings and open spaces; 
(6)  To insure a consistent and appropriate aesthetic environment; 
(7)  To license contractors who install signs and require permits for placement; and 
(8)  To protect the public health, safety and general welfare. 
(b)  The ordinance from which this chapter was derived shall be known as the City of Whiting Sign Ordinance. 
(Ord. No. CC-2009-1817, § 1, 7-21-09) 
Sec. 14.5-2. - Scope of application. 
(a)  Hereinafter, all construction, relocation, enlargement, alteration, modification or repair of signs within the city shall conform to the requirements of the ordinance from which this chapter was derived, all state and federal regulations concerning signs and advertising, and all state codes incorporated by reference into the municipal code. 
(b)  All signs located within the historic district as designated by city ordinance, shall adhere to the provisions of the ordinance from which this chapter was derived as well as the written rules, regulations and provisions of the Whiting historic preservation commission. All applications for signs in the historic district will also require a certificate of appropriateness from the commission prior to installation or repair. 
(Ord. No. CC-2009-1817, § 2, 7-21-09) 
Sec. 14.5-3. - Administration. 
    The building commissioner shall have the power to administer and enforce the provisions of the ordinance from which this chapter was derived. He may, at his discretion, delegate and assign the administrative, enforcement, and inspection duties hereunder to any duly authorized city inspector or sworn personnel of the Whiting police or fire department. 
(Ord. No. CC-2009-1817, § 3, 7-21-09) 
Sec. 14.5-4. - Severability. 
    If any provision of the ordinance from which this chapter was derived or the application thereof to any person or circumstance is held invalid, such invalidity shall not affect any other provision of the ordinance from which this chapter was derived, which can be given effect without the invalid provision or application, and to this end the provisions of the ordinance from which this chapter was derived are declared to be severable. 
(Ord. No. CC-2009-1817, § 4, 7-21-09) 
Sec. 14.5-5. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of the ordinance from which this chapter was derived, certain terms are defined in this section. When not inconsistent with context, words used in the present tense include the future and past tenses, words in the singular include the plural, words in the plural include the singular, and words in the masculine include the feminine and neuter. 
    Abandoned sign. Such business signs that advertise an activity, product or service which has not been conducted at that location in the last 90 days. 
    A-frame sign. A sign which is portable in nature, advertising a business at that location, which is taken in each evening by the owner. This includes sandwich board, sidewalk or curb signs. Said sign is only permitted so long as it does not obstruct the public right-of-way. 
    Animated sign. Any sign that includes action and/or motion, not including flashing or changing signs or clock and/or temperature displays. 
    Area of sign. The area or surface area of a sign is defined by the smallest perimeter fully enclosing the total surface devoted to the sign's message, together with any ornamentation, embellishment, and associated background, excluding any architectural ornamentation. If the message is on a surface, structure or frame specifically employed for holding signage, the entire surface area within the frame's border is counted. If the message is on a door, wall or other structural part of a building, only that portion of the door, wall or structure actually devoted to the message and associated symbols and background, if any, is counted. 
    Artisan sign. A non-illuminated sign not exceeding eight square feet in area placed on a site during the period that work is being engaged in, with the permission of the site's owner, displaying the name of the contractor or artisan improving the site or structure on the site. 
    Banner sign. A temporary sign composed of cloth, canvas or other lightweight material that may or may not be enclosed in a frame. 
    Bench sign. A sign on or attached to any structure or device intended for exterior public seating. 
    Campaign sign. Any sign, poster, billboard or other outdoor advertisement advocating the election or defeat or a particular candidate for public office, or group of candidates, or political party. 
    Changeable copy sign. A sign wherein provision is made for letters or characters to be placed in or upon the surface area either manually or electronically to provide a message. Such message may not be changed more often than daily, except for time and/or temperature displays. A changeable copy sign does not include any sign that meets the definition of a flashing sign. 
    Chaser sign. A sign which creates a running effect in a bank of lamps or tubes. 
    City. The City of Whiting, Indiana. 
    Construction sign. A non-illuminated sign giving the name(s) of contractors, architects, and lending institutions responsible for new construction or renovation on the premises. 
    Said sign may not exceed 36 square feet and must be removed no later than 15 days after the completion of the project. 
    Directional sign. A sign, the sole purpose of which is to direct he flow of vehicular or pedestrian traffic, indicate entrances or exits, transmit parking information or convey similar information. 
    Double-faced sign. A sign with two distinct faces of equal size, generally back-to-back, supported on the same structure and designed so that each face is viewed from a different direction. 
    Electronic reader board. A sign which contains a traveling message or a message which appears to be traveling, and usually in a horizontal direction. 
    Flashing sign. Any sign which contains a continually intermittent light or sequential flashing light source. This definition specifically includes signs that use intermittent lighting changes for the purpose of changing the graphics or copy within the copy area of a sign more often than daily as in an electronic reader board (defined herein) or message center (defined herein), except that such reader board or message center may display time and/or temperature readings which change more often than daily. 
    Freestanding sign. A sign erected on a freestanding frame, post or pole which is not attached to any other structure. 
    Ground sign. Any sign supported by uprights or braces in or upon the ground and not attached to any building. 
    Height. The vertical distance measured from the lowest ground level directly beneath the sign to the highest point at the top of the sign. The ground level shall be the lowest of natural grade or finished grade. 
    Home occupation sign. A sign designating an authorized home occupation in a residential district as said sign is permitted and regulated by the City of Whiting Unified Zoning and Subdivision Control Ordinance. 
    Illuminated sign. A sign having its own immediate source of internal or external lighting or a sign designed to give forth artificial light or reflect it from another source. 
    Inflatable signs. Any three-dimensional, ambient air-filled object depicting a container, figure, project or trade information, whether or not such object contains a message. This includes balloons. 
    Institution sign. A sign containing information about an on-site institution such as churches, schools, hospitals, rest homes, private clubs, and governmental, quasi-governmental, educational, charitable or religious organizations. 
    Integral signs. A sign which names a building, date of erection, monumental citations, commemorative tablets and the like when carved into stone, concrete or similar material or made of bronze, aluminum, or other permanent type construction and made an integral part of the structure. 
    Message center. A sign that contains a changing message within the copy area that remains on for a specified minimum period of time and blacks out for a specified minimum period of time between messages. Messages contained on the sign do not travel or appear to travel in any direction. 
    Off-premises sign. A sign attached to a building, the ground, or structure advertising a business, project, service or event conducted, sold or offered elsewhere than upon the same zoning lot. This definition includes billboards, poster boards, panels and other outdoor advertising signs. 
    Message. A sign's message includes its text, drawings, figures, logo and any associated background. 
    Permanent sign. Any sign which is not a portable sign. 
    Person. Any individual, association, corporation or other legal entity. 
    Portable sign. Any sign not permanently affixed to a building, structure or the ground which is intended to be moved or capable of being moved, whether or not on wheels or other special supports, but does not include A-frame, sandwich board, sidewalk or curb signs. 
    Projecting sign. Any sign supported by a building or other structure which projects over any street, sidewalk, alley, public way or public easement more than 12 inches from the face of the building or structure. 
    Real estate sign. A sign intended to convey information regarding the availability of the property on which the sign is located for sale, lease or rent and which is required to be removed within seven days of the sale, lease or rental of the property. 
    Roof sign. A sign erected on or extending above the roofline or parapet of any building or structure. 
    Sign. A name, display, identification, device, notice, figure, painting, drawing, message, placard, poster, word, bulletin board, symbol, letter, numeral, emblem, trademark, flag, banner, pennant, or other illustration which affixed to or painted or represented directly or indirectly upon a building, or other outdoor surface, or parcel of land and which directs attention to an object, project, place, activity, person, institution, organization, or business, and is visible from any alley, street, highway, sidewalk or other public way, whether such is placed out of doors or in windows. The term does not include any display of official notices of courts or other public offices, nor the flag, emblem or insignia of a nation, political unit, school, or religious group, time and temperature devices, barber poles or similar devices if there is no identification or advertising thereon. 
    Snipe sign. Any sign (whether attached in any way to a utility pole, tree, traffic control device or any object or the ground, or otherwise situated) on: 
(1)  Public property without the consent of the appropriate public body; or 
(2)  Private property without the consent of the owner or occupier thereof. 
    Special event sign. A temporary sign pertaining to events of civic, community, philanthropic, educational or religious organizations which are not conducted in connection with the operation of a commercial enterprise. 
    Wall sign. A sign attached or erected against the wall of a building or structure, or painted or applied to the exterior wall, with the sign face parallel to and less than 12 inches from the wall of the building or structure and not extending above the building face or parapet. 
    Window sign. A sign placed inside a window for purposes of viewing from outside the window. 
(Ord. No. CC-2009-1817, § 5, 7-21-09) 
Sec. 14.5-6. - General regulations. 
(a)  No sign shall be erected, installed, altered or maintained in any zoning district in the city except in conformity with the ordinance from which this chapter was derived. All signs shall comply with the particular regulations, if any, of the district in which they are located. 
(b)  Signs shall be maintained in an attractive and structurally safe condition. All exterior parts shall be painted, coated or made of rust inhibitive material. Any supporting structure shall be free of any bracing such as guide wires or cables and shall be designed as an architectural feature of the building. 
(c)  No sign shall obstruct any door, fire escape or free passage over any public right-of-way or create a traffic hazard. Signs shall be placed with care so as not to obscure unreasonably existing conforming signs on adjacent properties. 
(Ord. No. CC-2009-1817, § 6, 7-21-09) 
Sec. 14.5-7. - Permit required. 
    No person shall (through his own action or those of persons he hires or directs) commence to erect, alter, construct, or relocate any permanent sign or structure subject to the ordinance from which this chapter was derived, except for signs expressly exempted from the permitting process, without first obtaining a written sign permit from the building commissioner. No person shall engage in any work requiring a permit without having the written permit in his possession at the job site. 
(Ord. No. CC-2009-1817, § 7, 7-21-09) 
Sec. 14.5-8. - License required. 
    No person shall engage in the work of erecting, altering, constructing, or relocating any permanent sign which requires a sign permit unless such person holds a valid and current sign license issued by the building commissioner and has such sign license in his possession at the job site. 
(Ord. No. CC-2009-1817, § 8, 7-21-09) 
Sec. 14.5-9. - Permit application procedure. 
    Application for a sign permit may be made by the owner or agent of the sign or by sign licensee acting on such person's behalf. Applications shall be accompanied by the required fee and shall be made on a form provided by the building commissioner and shall contain or have attached thereto the following information: 
(1)  Name, address, and telephone number of the applicant; 
(2)  Name, address, and telephone number of the sign licensee who will erect, alter, construct or relocate the sign (if not the applicant); 
(3)  Name, address, and telephone number of the person or firm for whom the sign is being made or installed (if not the applicant); 
(4)  The position of the sign or advertising; 
(5)  Two blue prints or ink drawings to scale of the plans and specifications and method of construction, attachment to the building or other structure or placement in the ground; 
(6)  If required by the building commissioner, a copy of the stress sheets and calculations showing the structure's dead load and wind pressure capacities; 
(7)  If the sign includes electrical service, a description of the service to be installed; 
(8)  Written consent or other proof of authorization of the owner of the building, structure, or land to which or on which the sign is to be erected; 
(9)  Such other information as the building commissioner may require demonstrating full compliance with the ordinance from which this chapter was derived, other city ordinance, or any applicable requirement of state or federal law. 
(Ord. No. CC-2009-1817, § 9, 7-21-09) 
Sec. 14.5-10. - Issuance of sign permit. 
(a)  The building commissioner shall, within 30 days of the filing if the completed application, grant such permits if, and only if: 
(1)  The application contains all necessary information; 
(2)  The appropriate sign permit fee has been paid; 
(3)  The person erecting, altering, constructing, or relocating the sign holds a valid and current sign license; 
(4)  If the sign requires electrical service, proof that the electrical work will be done by a licensed electrician; 
(5)  The sign complies with the ordinance from which this chapter was derived, all other city ordinances, and all applicable state and federal laws. 
(b)  The building commissioner may grant a permit on the condition that the work is stopped at specified time(s) to permit inspection(s). If the building commissioner denies such permit, he shall state the reason(s) therefor to the applicant. If the building commissioner fails to take any action within 30 days, the application is deemed granted. All denials may be appealed to the board of public works and safety of the City of Whiting. 
(Ord. No. CC-2009-1817, § 10, 7-21-09) 
Sec. 14.5-11. - Application for sign license. 
(a)  Any person or firm desiring a sign license shall apply on a form provided by the clerk-treasurer and tender the required fee and proof of the required bond. The application shall include the applicant's name (whether an individual or firm), address, and telephone number. Such license shall, unless revoked, be valid for the balance of the calendar year in which it is issued. Licenses may be renewed annually. 
(b)  Every person or firm erecting, altering or removing any non-exempt sign within the city shall be required to file a bond with the Lake County recorder in conformance with I.C. 22-11-3.1-2. 
(Ord. No. CC-2009-1817, § 11, 7-21-09) 
Sec. 14.5-12. - Permit and license fees. 
    The building commissioner shall maintain a schedule of fees for sign permits and sign licenses. The amounts for such permits and licenses and renewals thereof shall be set by the common council in the city's fee ordinance. 
(Ord. No. CC-2009-1817, § 12, 7-21-09) 
Sec. 14.5-13. - Exemptions from permit requirements. 
    No permit will be required for the following signs: 
(1)  A-frame, sandwich board, sidewalk or curb sign; 
(2)  Integral signs; 
(3)  Campaign signs; 
(4)  Artisan signs; 
(5)  Institution signs; 
(6)  Directional signs; 
(7)  Real estate signs; 
(8)  Special event signs; or 
(9)  Window signs. 
(Ord. No. CC-2009-1817, § 13, 7-21-09) 
Sec. 14.5-14. - Prohibited signs. 
    The following signs are prohibited in the City of Whiting unless designated as a legal nonconforming sign by the building commissioner or authorized by the board of public works and safety in a PUD-District: 
(1)  All prohibitions contained in Table T-1; 
(2)  Moving signs; 
(3)  Off-premises signs and billboards, except as those signs are owned, controlled or permitted by the board of public works and safety; 
(4)  Signs on non-working vehicles or trailers placed on the premises for the purpose of advertising; 
(5)  Signs that create a safety hazard; 
(6)  Signs that by their wording, color or locations resemble or conflict with traffic control signs or devices; 
(7)  Signs that obstruct any door, window, fire escape or other emergency exit; 
(8)  Signs which emit an audible sound, odor or visible matter. 
(Ord. No. CC-2009-1817, § 14, 7-21-09; Ord. No. CC-2013-1891, § 1(§ 14), 4-2-13) 
Sec. 14.5-15. - Non-conforming uses and signs. 
(a)  Any sign lawfully erected, constructed or installed prior to the effective date of the ordinance from which this chapter was derived and maintained in conformance with the requirements of the ordinance from which this chapter was derived shall be permitted to continue as a legal non-conforming sign. 
(b)  Modifications or alterations made to or the enlargements or relocation of legal non-conforming signs shall be prohibited, unless said modifications, alterations, enlargement or relocation serves to make the sign more conforming or in conformance with the requirements of the ordinance from which this chapter was derived. 
(c)  Any person aggrieved by a decision of the building commissioner or his designee has the right to appeal to the board of public works and safety within 14 days of the date of the issuance of the ruling by the building commissioner. 
(Ord. No. CC-2009-1817, § 15, 7-21-09) 
Sec. 14.5-16. - Political signs. 
(a)  Outdoor political signs shall be constructed in a manner that will not create a public hazard or nuisance. 
(b)  Outdoor political signs shall be removed within seven days of the advertised election. 
(c)  No political sign may be placed in a parkway, street, alley, sidewalk or any other public right-of-way. 
(Ord. No. CC-2009-1817, § 16, 7-21-09) 
Sec. 14.5-17. - Standards by district. 
(a)  The Table T-1 below designates the types of signs and the zoning districts in the city. 
(b)  The table has designations which cover each type of sign defined in the ordinance from which this chapter was derived in each zoning district. 
(c)  The table designations are as follows: 
(1)  "A" means the sign is authorized for that zoning district. 
(2)  "P" means the sign is prohibited for that zoning district. 
(3)  "B" means the board of public works and safety shall make a determination whether to authorize or prohibit the sign. 
(4)  "N/A" means the sign is not applicable to that zoning district. 
(d)  If a sign is authorized in a zoning district, it shall not be installed until a permit is issued. 
(e)  If a sign is prohibited in a district, it may not be installed or approved. 
(f)  If the area is zoned PUD, every sign must first receive approval from the board of public works and safety.

(Ord. No. CC-2009-1817, § 17, 7-21-09; Ord. No. CC-2013-1891, § 2(§ 17), 4-2-13) 
Sec. 14.5-18. - Abandoned signs. 
(a)  The owner of property on which a sign advertising a use, facility, product or event that is no longer sold, conducted or available on the premises shall remove the sign and the related hardware within 90 days of the discontinuance. 
(b)  Signs remaining after said 90 days shall be considered abandoned signs and may be removed by the city, with the cost of such removal charged to the property owner(s). 
(c)  In the event that the property owner(s) fails to reimburse the city for the expenses of removing the abandoned sign within 60 days of having received notice to do so by the clerk-treasurer, the city may place a lien on the property for the amount due. 
(Ord. No. CC-2009-1817, § 18, 7-21-09) 
Sec. 14.5-19. - Height, number and size restrictions. 
(a)  Authorized signs shall be limited in size in accordance with the limitations in Table T-2. 
(b)  All size measurements are for total square footage. 
(c)  In the event of special circumstances, a property owner may petition for a sign which exceeds the square footage permitted in Table 2 for a particular sign by filing a written request with the board of public works and safety. Said petition shall include a drawing of the sign, the proposed size, and the reason and necessity for a sign larger than permitted. 
(d)  The board of works shall either grant or deny the petition within 30 days of receipt of all of the required information. 
(e)  Any legal non-conforming signs in existence at the time the ordinance from which this chapter was derived is enacted shall be permitted to at the current size so long as it is properly maintained. 
(f)  Setbacks for signs shall be governed by the rules of the zoning district. 
(g)  No sign shall be permitted with a height exceeding 20 feet from the perpendicular ground it is located upon. 
(h)  No more than one sign per business entrance shall be permitted at any location with the exception of the shingle signs in the historic district. 
(i)  If a sign falls under multiple definitions, the size with be governed by the most restrictive square footage unless an appeal for a different size is granted by the board of public works and safety. 
TABLE T-2 Type of sign Square footage limitation Artisan 8 Banner 36 Campaign 32 Changeable copy 32 Construction 36 Directional 24 Double-faced 32 for each side Electronic reader board 12 Flashing 16 Freestanding 16 Ground 16 Illuminated 24 Institution 16 Integral 12 Message center 10 Projecting 16 Real estate 12 Special event 16 Wall 25% of wall area Window N/A  
(Ord. No. CC-2009-1817, § 19, 7-21-09; Ord. No. CC-2013-1891, § 3(§ 19), 4-2-13) 
Sec. 14.5-20. - Rights, remedies and authority. 
(a)  The building commissioner or his delegate may issue a stop order commanding that work on a sign cease if: 
(1)  The sign requires a permit and none has been issued; 
(2)  The person or firm erecting, altering, removing, or constructing the sign does not have a valid sign license; 
(3)  The sign violates any provision of the ordinance from which this chapter was derived; or 
(4)  The continuation of the work otherwise threatens public safety. 
(b)  The building commissioner may revoke the sign license of any person or firm if such person or firm: 
(1)  Has been found to have committed three violations of the ordinance from which this chapter was derived; 
(2)  Has ignored a stop order issued by the building commissioner; 
(3)  Has commenced erection or construction of a non-exempt sign without obtaining a permit therefor; or 
(4)  Has engaged in actions resulting in a forfeiture of the bond. Such person or firm may apply for a new sign license no sooner than six months after the date of revocation. 
(c)  The building commissioner or his designee shall have the right to inspect all signs for which a permit is required. Footing inspections may be required by the building commissioner for all signs having footings. All signs containing electrical wiring shall be subject to electrical inspections and all city ordinances relating thereto. 
(d)  The building commissioner or his designee may institute a suit for injunction in an appropriate court to restrain an individual from violating the provisions of the ordinance from which this chapter was derived and may also institute a suit for a mandatory injunction directing the removal of any structure or improvement. Such remedy shall be in addition to all other remedies, fines and enforcement tools set forth in this or any other city ordinance. 
(e)  In order to determine if any sign or sign structure is unlawfully erected, altered or maintained, the building commissioner or any duly authorized city inspector may enter onto that property to investigate the matter and may take appropriate action to bring such sign or structure into compliance. However, before action to bring into compliance may be taken, all persons holding a substantial interest in the sign or structure must be notified and given a reasonable opportunity to bring the sign or structure into compliance, except that the city may, without such notice, take any steps necessary to alleviate immediate public danger. The city's cost for any work done on the site may be recouped from any person chargeable with the violation. 
(f)  In addition to any and all other remedies set forth in the ordinance from which this chapter was derived for a violation thereof, the building commissioner or his designee may remove any snipe sign located anywhere or any campaign sign from the public right-of-way and confiscate it. 
(Ord. No. CC-2009-1817, § 20, 7-21-09) 
Sec. 14.5-21. - Notice of violation and presumption of identity. 
(a)  When written notice of violation of any provision of the ordinance from which this chapter was derived has been served on the property owner, agent, occupant, contractor, builder, or sign licensee, such violation shall be discontinued. Unless the building commissioner specifies a particular time by which the violation must be removed, it shall be assumed that each day the violation continues constitutes a separate violation. 
(b)  Unless circumstances clearly show otherwise, there exist the following presumptions in connection with any existing sign (including snipe signs) which violates any provision of the ordinance from which this chapter was derived: 
(1)  The sign was erected at its location by, or with the consent of, the owner and the occupier of the site; 
(2)  The sign was erected by, or with the consent of, the company or business advertised thereon; and 
(3)  The sign was erected by, or with the consent of, the promoter of the item or event advertised thereon (including in the case of the advertisement of available residential housing, the realtor or other promoter thereof). 
(c)  Any person cited for a violation may rebut any such presumption by introducing evidence of the non-existence of the presumed fact sufficient to prove by a preponderance of the evidence that the presumed fact is not true. 
(Ord. No. CC-2009-1817, § 21, 7-21-09) 
Sec. 14.5-22. - Appeals. 
    Any person aggrieved by a decision of the building commissioner shall have a right to appeal such decision within 30 days to the City of Whiting board of public works and safety. 
(Ord. No. CC-2009-1817, § 22, 7-21-09) 
Sec. 14.5-23. - Fines for violations. 
    Any violation of any provision of the ordinance from which this chapter was derived shall be subject to the general penalty provision of Whiting Municipal Code Section 1-11. 
(Ord. No. CC-2009-1817, § 23, 7-21-09) 
Chapter 15 - STREETS, SIDEWALKS AND OTHER PUBLIC PLACES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2; buildings and building regulations, ch. 4; cable communications, ch. 5; fires in streets or other locations, § 7-121; litter, § 8-26 et seq.; handbills, § 8-51 et seq.; advertising benches, § 10-76 et seq.; mobile homes, ch. 11; parks and recreation, ch. 13; utilities, ch. 16; vehicles and traffic, ch. 17; snow removal routes, § 17-426 et seq.; street cleaning, § 17-451 et seq. 
State Law reference- Local powers as to public ways, IC 36-9-2-5 et seq.; Municipal and County Barrett Law, IC 36-9-18 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 15-1. - Street commissioner-Office created. 
    There is hereby established the position of street commissioner. 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 
Sec. 15-2. - Same-Salary. 
    The fixing of the salary for the street commissioner shall be done on a yearly basis by the common council pursuant to existing state statutes. 
(Code 1962, § 7-502; Code 1979, § 2.12.020; Ord. No. 1419(part), 1989) 
Sec. 15-3. - Same-Duties. 
    The duties and responsibilities of the street commissioner shall be those as stated in existing state statutes, city ordinances and those duties deemed necessary by the mayor and board of public works and safety during emergency and nonemergency conditions. 
(Code 1962, § 7-503; Code 1979, § 2.12.030; Ord. No. 1419(part), 1989) 
State Law reference- Jurisdiction of city over streets, etc., IC 36-1-3-9. 
Sec. 15-4. - Snow and ice removal from sidewalks-Generally. 
(a)  No property owner shall permit snow to accumulate and remain on any public right-of-way sidewalks in front or on the side of his/her property for a period longer than 48 hours, following the end of a snowfall event. 
(b)  No person shall direct, deposit or place snow removed from any sidewalk, parkway, parking space, or private driveway, inclusive of the driveway apron located upon the public right-of-way, upon or onto any public road, street or alley in the path of vehicular traffic. 
(c)  No person shall direct, deposit or place snow upon any parkway located within the public right-of-way except those that are directly adjacent to the sidewalk abutting the private property from which the snow is being removed. 
(Code 1962, § 17-401; Code 1979, § 12.16.010; Ord. No. CC-2015-1945, § I, 10-6-15) 
Sec. 15-5. - Civil penalty for failure to comply with section 15-4. 
(a)  In the event of failure of any owner or owners of any premises to cause the removal of snow as described in section 15-4, the street commissioner or a duly authorized code enforcement officer may issue a violation notice. The civil penalty for the first notice shall be $50.00. The civil penalty for the second and third notices shall be $250.00. 
(b)  In the event the same owner (even if for different properties) receives more than three violation notices in a 12-month period, the street commissioner or duly authorized code enforcement officer may issue a court citation. The violation issued a court citation will be subject to the general penalty provisions of WMC section 1-11. 
(Code 1962, § 17-403; Code 1979, § 12.16.020; Ord. No. CC-2015-1945, § II, 10-6-15) 
Secs. 15-6-15-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - STREETS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 15-31-15-40. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - EXCAVATIONS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Power of city to regulate excavations, IC 36-7-2-6. 

Sec. 15-41. - Permit required. 
    Every person desiring to dig or make any hole, trench or excavation in any public street, alley or highway within the corporate limits of the city shall before so doing obtain permission from the street commissioner or from such other person performing the duties of the street commissioner; provided, however, that no such permit shall be granted until a bond or bonds have been filed in the office of the city clerk-treasurer, as provided in this division. 
(Code 1962, § 22-301; Code 1979, § 12.12.010) 
Sec. 15-42. - Bond required. 
    Upon obtaining a permit as provided for in section 15-41, a person shall present such permit to the city clerk-treasurer, who shall require such person so desiring to dig any such hole, or make any such excavation, or dig any such trench within any public street, alley or public highway within the city to file with him a bond in the penal sum of $1,000.00 with at least one resident freehold surety owning real estate in the city of the value of at least double the amount of such bond, over and above any and all encumbrances and any and all indebtedness and exemption, all of which shall be duly verified under oath thereon by the surety, which bond shall be approved by the city clerk-treasurer. 
(Code 1962, § 22-302; Code 1979, § 12.12.020) 
Sec. 15-43. - Freehold resident surety bond. 
    Any person may, in lieu of filing a bond in the penal sum of $1,000.00, as provided for in section 15-42, file a bond in the penal sum of $5,000.00 with at least two resident freehold sureties owning real estate in the county of the value of more than double the amount of such bond, over and above any and all encumbrances and any and all indebtedness and exemption, which bond shall be approved by the city clerk-treasurer as set forth in section 15-42. In the event of the filing of such bond in the penal sum of $5,000.00 as set forth in this section, the person shall not be obliged to file separate bonds for each permit obtained in accordance with the provisions of section 15-41, but such bond in the penal sum of $5,000.00 shall be in lieu of such other bonds and be good to the end of the calendar year from the date of the filing of the same. However, in all cases where sureties are required under the provisions of this division, approved surety companies may be submitted in lieu of the resident sureties; provided further, that the filing of the bond as provided for in this section shall not relieve the person from the necessity of obtaining a permit for each time he desires to dig or make any hole, trench or excavation as set forth in this division. 
(Code 1962, § 22-303; Code 1979, § 12.12.030) 
Sec. 15-44. - City held harmless; street restored. 
    Any bond or bonds filed by any person under the provisions of this division shall contain the provision and be conditioned that he shall and will use all care and caution in the digging of any such hole, and the making of any such excavation upon any such public street, alley or public highway within the city, and shall hold the city free and harmless of any and all damage caused by reason of the digging of any such holes or the making of any such excavation or trenches; and shall be further conditioned in case such digging or excavating is to be done in any street or highway within the city, that the same shall be again placed in the same condition as it was before the digging or excavating. Such permit, when issued by the street commissioner or other authorized person on his behalf, shall designate the place where such digging or excavating is to be made and done. 
(Code 1962, § 22-304; Code 1979, § 12.12.040) 
Sec. 15-45. - Unlawful to excavate or dig without permit. 
    It is unlawful for any person to dig any hole, make any excavation, or make or dig any trench within any public street, alley or public highway within the city without first obtaining a written permit to do so and filing a bond as provided for in sections 15-42 and 15-43. 
(Code 1962, § 22-305; Code 1979, § 12.12.050) 
Secs. 15-46-15-65. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SIDEWALKS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Secs. 15-66-15-75. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - REPAIRS 

Sec. 15-76. - Dangerous sidewalks; repair required. 
    Whenever any sidewalk within the limits of the city becomes in the opinion of the street committee, street commissioner, or city marshal dangerous and unsafe for public use and the same may in the opinion of such street committee, street commissioner, or city marshal be made safe without the construction of a new sidewalk, the street committee, street commissioner or city marshal shall give written notice to the owner of the lot, lots or land adjoining the sidewalk, if a resident of the city, for 24 hours to repair the same. If the owner of the lot, lots or land is not a resident of the city, no notice at all shall be necessary. After the 24 hours have elapsed, or in case such owner is a nonresident of the city, immediately upon the discovery of the dangerous sidewalk, the chairman of the street committee, street commissioner, or the marshal shall cause the same to be repaired in such manner as to make the sidewalk safe. 
(Code 1962, § 22-201; Code 1979, § 12.04.010) 
Sec. 15-77. - Assessment of costs of repairs against land. 
    When any dangerous sidewalk has been repaired as provided for in section 15-76, the street committee, street commissioner, or city marshal shall report to the common council the cost of making the repairs, giving in such report the cost of making the repairs in front of each lot or parcel of land, including the cost for service of notice, and shall state in the report that the same was repaired on account of being an unsafe and dangerous sidewalk. The common council shall then allow and pay to the person making such repairs the amount due him therefor and shall assess the cost of making the repairs against the lot or parcel of land fronting on the portion of sidewalk so repaired. 
(Code 1962, § 22-202; Code 1979, § 12.04.020) 
Sec. 15-78. - Assessment to be lien against land; collection of costs. 
    The costs mentioned in section 15-77, when so assessed by the common council, shall become a lien upon the lot or land against which the same is assessed and shall be collected in the same manner that liens for street improvements are collectable under the laws in force at the time of making such assessment. 
(Code 1962, § 22-203; Code 1979, § 12.04.030) 
Sec. 15-79. - Repair with asphalt prohibited. 
(a)  For the purposes of this section the words set out in this subsection shall have the following meanings: 
    Person means any human being, firm, corporation, or partnership, their agents, representatives, contractors, and subcontractors, including any governmental entity, district, or department of any artificial legal entity. 
    Sidewalk means that portion of a street between the curblines, or the lateral lines of a roadway, and the adjacent property lines intended for the use of pedestrians. 
(b)  It is unlawful for any person or any abutting property owner to construct or repair a sidewalk with asphalt. 
(c)  This section does not repeal any existing ordinances but is supplemental to any ordinance or state statute referring to sidewalks and curbs. 
(Code 1979, § 12.04.040; Ord. No. 1258, §§ 1-4, 1981) 
State Law reference- "Sidewalk" defined, IC 9-4-1-14. 
Secs. 15-80-15-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - OBSTRUCTIONS 

Sec. 15-101. - Leaving cellar or vault open in street or sidewalk. 
    It is unlawful for any person to leave or keep open any cellar door or grating of any kind whatsoever, or vault which opens upon any sidewalk or public highway, or suffer the same to be left or kept open. 
(Code 1962, § 17-511; Code 1979, § 12.08.010) 
Sec. 15-102. - Obstruction of public ways. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, entity, contractor or utility provider to encumber or obstruct any street, alley, sidewalk, public ground, building or parkway in the city with any material, substance, vehicle, or thing whatsoever. 
    Any person, entity, contractor, or utility provider which finds it necessary to encumber or obstruct the public way for the purpose of making repairs to the public way or to property adjacent to the public way must make written application to the board of public works and safety at least 14 calendar days prior to the encumbrance or obstruction of the public way. 
    In the case of an emergency, the person, entity, contractor, or utility provider must contact the administrative aide to the mayor in order to notify the city of the emergency and document the need for the encumbrance or obstruction of the public way. A written application must be submitted to the board at its next available meeting for ratification. 
    The board will not deny permission so long as the obstruction or encumbrance is necessary, of a limited duration, and all appropriate safety precautions are taken to protect the general public. 
    Any person, entity, contractor or utility provider which is granted permission to encumber or obstruct the public way will be held responsible for ensuring that the public way is returned to the condition it was in prior to the obstruction or encumbrance. 
    Any violation of this section shall be subject to the general penalty provisions of Whiting Municipal Code section 1-11. 
    This section shall be enforceable by any duly authorized city inspector, law enforcement officer, the building commissioner and the streets and sanitation commissioner or any deputy so designated by either commissioner. 
    This section does not serve to restrict or prohibit any activities which may be permitted under another city ordinance. 
(Ord. No. CC-2005-1718, §§ 1-8, 7-5-05) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. CC-2005-1718, §§ 1-8, adopted July 5, 2005, was not specifically amendatory of the Code and has been included as § 15-102 at the discretion of the editor. 
Sec. 15-103. - Material left in street at night; red light and railing required. 
    It is unlawful and deemed disorderly conduct for any person placing material of any nature in or upon any street, alley or highway in the city to maintain or permit such material to remain in or upon such street, alley or highway in the nighttime unless such person causes a red light to be placed on such material, erects a fence or railing about the same and keeps the red light burning during each night such materials so remain upon the street, alley or public highway. 
(Code 1962, § 17-514; Code 1979, § 12.08.030) 
Sec. 15-104. - Throwing glass or nails upon street. 
    It is unlawful and deemed disorderly conduct for any person to place, throw or cast any broken glass, bottles, nails, tacks, or sharp metal of any kind in or upon any street or highway in the city. 
(Code 1962, § 17-523; Code 1979, § 12.08.050) 
Sec. 15-105. - Placing materials on streets or sidewalks unlawful; permit requirements. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person to place in or upon any public street or sidewalk within the corporate limits of the city any boxes, goods, wares, merchandise or building material of whatsoever nature. However, if it becomes necessary for any person to place building material, such person shall obtain a written order from the street commissioner, which order shall be presented to the city clerk-treasurer, who shall thereupon execute a written permit signed by the clerk-treasurer, and sealed with the corporate seal of the city. The clerk-treasurer shall keep a record of all such permits as executed. Such permit shall name and designate the street and number of the lot or lots adjacent to such street where such building material is to be placed. No such permit shall be valid for more than 30 days from the date of the same. 
(b)  The person obtaining such permit shall so place such building material that the same shall be safe and secure and shall place at least three red lights upon such building material and so many additional lights as the chief of police may require. Any such person so receiving such permit shall be liable for any and all damages caused by reason of the placing of such building material upon such street and the acceptance of such permit by such person shall constitute an agreement to hold and save the city harmless of any and all damages by reason of the placing of such building material on, in or upon such street. 
(Code 1962, § 22-101; Code 1979, § 12.08.060) 
Secs. 15-106-15-125. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - HOUSE NUMBERS 

Sec. 15-126. - System established. 
(a)  The board of public works and safety is authorized and directed forthwith to establish and maintain a uniform system of numbering houses and buildings situated on all public streets, avenues, alleys and highways in the city, such numbering to be accomplished strictly in accordance with the blueprints which are on file in the city clerk-treasurer's office and made a part of this article, and strictly in accordance with the following:

(b)  In establishing the system, 115th Street in the City of Hammond produced east into the corporate limits of the City of Whiting shall constitute the base line from which all of the streets, avenues, alleys and highways running north and south shall be numbered upon the basis of 100 numbers to each standard block of approximately 660 feet or 800 numbers to a mile; Atchison Avenue shall constitute the base line from which all streets, avenues, alleys and highways running east and west shall be numbered, upon the basis of 100 numbers to each standard block of approximately 660 feet; provided, however, that in all streets running in all directions in the city, each 25 feet in each block shall receive a number. All buildings, houses, barns and sheds fronting on public alleys shall be numbered to correspond with the numbers on the streets. 
(c)  In such numbering, all even numbers shall be assigned to the west side of such streets, avenues, alleys and highways, and all odd numbers shall be assigned to the east side of such streets, avenues, alleys and highways. In such numbering, the even numbers shall be assigned to the south side of all east and west streets, avenues, alleys and highways, and the odd numbers shall be assigned to the north side thereof. 
(d)  All diagonal streets bearing from zero degrees to 45 degrees, inclusive, from north to east, north to west, south to east, and south to west shall be considered as north and south streets; all other diagonal streets having a bearing of more than 45 degrees from north to east, north to west, south to east and south to west shall be considered as east and west streets. 
(Code 1962, § 10-101; Code 1979, § 12.20.010) 
Sec. 15-127. - Duty of owners. 
(a)  When each structure in the city has been assigned a respective number, it shall thereupon be the duty of the owner or agent in possession of such structure to immediately, at his own expense, to display suitable numbers at a conspicuous place at the front entrance to such structure. Such numbers remain easily and distinctly read from the public way. 
(b)  If there is a garage or structure at the rear of the property, suitable numbers must be displayed in a conspicuous place on the side of the garage or structure facing the alley. If there is no garage or structure at the rear of the property, such numbers shall be displayed on a rear fence or rear entrance of the structure referred to in subsection (a). Such number shall remain easily and distinctly read from the alley or public way. 
(c)  Such numbers shall be at least three inches in height. 
(Code 1962, § 10-102; Code 1979, § 12.20.020; Ord. No. CC-2004-1674, 5-5-04) 
Sec. 15-128. - Numbers for new buildings. 
    Whenever any new structure is erected, it shall be the duty of the city engineer to assign a proper number to such structure and it shall thereupon be the duty of the owner or agent in possession of such structure to comply with section 15-127. 
(Code 1962, § 10-103; Code 1979, § 12.20.030; Ord. No. CC-2004-1674, 5-5-04) 
Sec. 15-129. - Violation. 
    It shall be the duty of the building commissioner to enforce all provisions of this article. If the owner or agent in possession refuses to comply with this article after being duly notified by the building commissioner, such owner or agent in possession shall be deemed in violation of this article. 
(Code 1962, § 10-104; Code 1979, § 12.20.040; Ord. No. CC-2004-1674, 5-5-04) 
Sec. 15-130. - Penalty. 
    Any individual violating any provisions of this article shall be fined in accordance with Chapter 1, section 1-11 in the Code of Ordinances, City of Whiting, Indiana. 
(Code 1962, § 10-105; Code 1979, § 12.20.050; Ord. No. CC-2004-1674, 5-5-04) 
Secs. 15-131-15-150. - Reserved.
