ARTICLE VII. - BLOCK PARTIES 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 15-241. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Hosts refers to the individuals or organizations applying for a block party permit. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1494, § 10.06.010D, 12-7-93) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 15-242. - Authorization. 
    In accordance with the provisions of this article, a street may be temporarily closed for a block party or any similar occurrence to be conducted within an area not exceeding one city block in the city, provided that at least two-thirds of the area is residentially zoned and a majority of owners, residents, or tenants of properties fronting upon such closed area consent and which event is hosted and sponsored solely by such owners, residents or tenants of properties, and is not for commercial, fundraising, advertising purposes or for profit-making purposes. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1494, § 10.06.020, 12-7-93) 
Sec. 15-243. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating any provision of this article shall be subject to a fine of not less than $25.00 and not more than $2,500.00. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1494, § 10.06.140, 12-7-93) 
Secs. 15-244-15-265. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PERMIT 

Sec. 15-266. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to participate in, advertise for or in any way promote, organize, control, manage, solicit, or induce participation in a temporary street closure unless a permit under this article has first been obtained from the board of public works and safety. It shall be unlawful for any person to violate any of the terms of a permit issued for such temporary street closure or any other provisions of this article, or join or participate in any such permitted activity over the objection of the permittee, nor in any matter interfere with the progress or orderly conduct of a temporary street closure. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1494, § 10.06.030, 12-7-93) 
Sec. 15-267. - Application; form; contents. 
    An application for a permit for temporary street closure shall be made upon a form provided by the city and shall contain all of the following information: 
(1)  The name, residence and business name (if applicable), and phone number of each person and/or organization acting as hosts of the block party: 
a.  Sponsoring a temporary street closure; 
b.  Having an interest or position of management or control in such organization; and 
c.  All who are or will be engaged in organizing, promoting, controlling, managing or soliciting participation in such temporary street closure. 
(2)  The date or dates and beginning and ending hours of such temporary street closure. 
(3)  The block in which such closure will occur. 
(4)  The estimated number of persons who will participate. 
(5)  The purpose of the temporary street closure. 
(6)  Whether parking is requested to be retracted or prohibited during such closure. 
(7)  Whether any sound amplification equipment is proposed to be used, and if so, information describing such sound amplification equipment. 
(8)  Such other information as the chief of police deems reasonably necessary in order to carry out the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1494, § 10.06.040, 12-7-93) 
Sec. 15-268. - Time of filing application. 
    The application shall be filed by the applicable block party hosts in sufficient time for the board of public works and safety to consider the application at its regularly scheduled meeting immediately preceding the date requested for the block party. Failure to file within such period is sufficient grounds for denial of a permit. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1494, § 10.06.050, 12-7-93) 
Sec. 15-269. - Barricades; litter collection. 
    Applicants for permits under this article shall provide and remove such barricades and warning devices as are necessary under the direction of the chief of police. The city shall provide for the collection and removal of all trash, garbage, and litter caused by or arising out of such temporary street closure. Applicants are responsible for placing trash, garbage and litter in containers provided by the city. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1494, § 10.06.060, 12-7-93) 
Sec. 15-270. - Claims for damages. 
    Applicants for permits under this article shall agree to assume the defense of and indemnify and save harmless the city, its councilpersons, boards, commissions, officers, employees and agents, from all suits, actions, damages or claims to which the city may be subjected of any kind or nature whatsoever resulting from, caused by, arising out of or as a consequence of the temporary street closure and the activities permitted in connection therewith. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1494, § 10.06.070, 12-7-93) 
Sec. 15-271. - Personnel cost. 
    Applicants for permits under this article shall pay the cost of city personnel who are required by the city to work overtime hours or other than regular shift or perform duties during or as a result of the temporary street closure. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1494, § 10.06.080, 12-7-93) 
Sec. 15-272. - Compliance. 
    Prior to issuance of a permit under this article, all applicable ordinances, rules, and regulations shall be complied with and all required permits and licenses shall be secured in connection with the temporary street closure, or the proposed activities associated therewith including, but not limited to, charitable solicitations, collections or acceptance of gratuities, the sale of food, beverages or other merchandise, or the use of candles, torches, fires, or other combustibles. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1494, § 10.06.090, 12-7-93) 
Sec. 15-273. - Conditions for issuance. 
    Any permit granted under this article shall contain conditions reasonably calculated to reduce or minimize the dangers and hazards to vehicular or pedestrian traffic and the public health, safety, tranquility, morals or welfare, including, but not limited to, changes in time, duration, numbers or participants, or sound. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1494, § 10.06.100, 12-7-93) 
Sec. 15-274. - Standards for issuance. 
    A permit shall be issued by the board of public works and safety when, from a consideration of the application and from such other information as may otherwise be obtained, all of the following circumstances exist: 
(1)  The applicant has not knowingly and with intent to deceive, made any false, misleading or fraudulent statements of material fact in the application for a permit or in any other document required pursuant to this article. 
(2)  The applicant has met the standards in this article and agrees to such conditions as are imposed in the permit. 
(3)  The time, duration and size of the temporary street closure will not substantially disrupt the orderly and safe movement of other traffic. 
(4)  The temporary street closure is of a size or nature that it will not require the diversion of so great a number of police officers of the city to properly police the areas contiguous thereto as to prevent normal police protection to the city. 
(5)  The concentration of persons will not unduly interfere with proper fire and police protection of, or ambulance service to, areas contiguous to such street closure. 
(6)  The temporary street closure will not interfere with the movement of firefighting equipment en route to a fire. 
(7)  The temporary street closure will not unduly interfere with the operation of parks, hospitals, churches, schools or other public and quasi-public institutions in the city. 
(8)  The applicant has provided reasonable means for informing all persons listed in section 15-267(1) and all persons participating in a temporary street closure of the terms and conditions of such permit and the laws applicable thereto. 
(9)  The temporary street closure will not conflict with or interfere with another temporary street closure for which a permit has been granted. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1494, § 10.06.110, 12-7-93) 
Sec. 15-275. - Notice of issuance or denial. 
    Written notice of the issuance or denial of a permit under this article shall be provided to the applicant within five days of receipt of an application or as soon as practicable if received less than 14 days in advance of the proposed date of the temporary street closure. If a permit is denied, the written notice shall state the reasons for denial. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1494, § 10.06.120, 12-7-93) 
Sec. 15-276. - Waiver of time limitations. 
    The chief of police may waive the time limitation of section 15-268 for filing an application if it is found that unusual circumstances or good cause exists and no unreasonable burden upon the city or its citizens will be created thereby. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1494, § 10.06.130, 12-7-93) 
Sec. 15-277. - Revocation. 
    Any permit for a temporary street closure issued pursuant to this article may be revoked by the chief of police at any time when by reason of emergency, disaster, calamity, disorder, riot, traffic conditions, violation of this article or of any permit conditions, or undue interference with the tranquility, morals or welfare of the public or property requires such a revocation. Notice of revocation of a permit shall be delivered in writing to at least one person named upon the permit by personal service or by certified mail, or if the closure has commenced, orally, or in writing, by personal contact or service, or by telephone. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1494, § 10.06.140, 12-7-93) 
Chapter 15.5 - TELECOMMUNICATIONS ORDINANCE[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Res. No. 2006-01, § 14, adopted September 12, 2006, renumbered App. A, Ch. 4 as a new Ch. 15.5. See the Code Comparative Table-Ordinance Disposition. 

Sec. 15.5-1. - Short Title. 
    This ordinance shall be known and may be cited as the "Whiting Telecommunications Regulation Ordinance" of the City of Whiting, Lake County, Indiana and hereafter referred to as the "ordinance." 
(Res. No. 2006-01, § 14, 9-12-2006) 
Sec. 15.5-2. - Purpose and Intent. 
    In order to accommodate the communication needs of residents and businesses while protecting the public health, safety, and general welfare of the community, the Common Council of the City of Whiting finds that regulations relating to the location and design of wireless telecommunication facilities are necessary to: 
(a)  Facilitate the provisions of wireless telecommunication services to the residents and businesses of the City; 
(b)  Minimize the visual effects of towers and associated buildings or structures through proper design and siting standards; 
(c)  Maximize the use of existing and approved towers and buildings to accommodate multiple antennas in order to reduce or keep to a minimum the number of towers needed to serve the community; and 
(d)  Avoid damage to adjacent properties from tower failure through structural standards and setback requirements; 
(Res. No. 2006-01, § 14, 9-12-2006) 
Sec. 15.5-3. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this ordinance, the following terms, phrases, words, and their derivations shall have the meaning given herein. When not inconsistent with the context, words used in the present tense include the future, words in the plural include the singular, and words in the singular include the plural. The word "shall" is mandatory and not merely directory. 
    Accessory Equipment Structure. A building or cabinet-like structure located adjacent to or in the immediate vicinity of a wireless telecommunications tower or antenna to accommodate, hold, or contain equipment customarily incidental to the receiving or transmitting or wireless broadcasts, cellular telephone calls, voice message and paging services. 
    Antenna. Equipment used for transmitting or receiving radio frequency signals, which are attached to a tower, building or other structure, usually consisting of a series of directional panels, microwave or satellite dishes, or omnidirectional "whip" antennas. 
    Antenna Support Structure. Any building, pole, telescoping mast, tower, tripod, or any other structure which supports an antenna. 
    Base Transceiver Station. Equipment that provides the link between wireless communications and land-based public telephone switching networks, including radio frequency transceivers, back-up power amplifiers, and signal processing hardware, typically contained in an accessory equipment structure. 
    Co-Location. The location of wireless telecommunications equipment from more than one (1) provider on a common tower, building or structure. 
    Commercial Receiving and/or Transmitting Antenna. Any antenna erected to transfer information for commercial use. 
    Mast. The vertical pole portion to which the antenna, transmitter, or other type of installation is attached. 
    Personal Wireless Facilities. The transmitters, antenna structures, and other type of installations used for the provision of personal wireless services. 
    Personal Wireless Services. Licensed commercial wireless communication services including cellular telephones, personal communication services (PCS), enhanced specialized mobilized radio (EMR), paging and similar services. 
    Public Property. Land and/or building structures owned or operated by a municipal government. 
    Public Utility. Persons, corporations, or governments supplying gas, electric, transportation, water, sewer, or land line telephone services to the general public. For the purposes of this ordinance, personal wireless services shall not be considered public utility uses, and are defined separately. 
    Search Area. A telecommunications company's service area. 
    Stealth Antenna. A camouflaged antenna not readily visible. 
    Tower. Any pole, spire, structure, or combination thereof, to which antennas could be attached, or which is designed for any antenna to be attached, and all supporting lines, cables, wires and braces. 
    Uniform Building Code (UBC). Published by the International Conference of Building Officials and referenced by the State of Indiana to provide jurisdictions with building-related standards and regulations. 
(Res. No. 2006-01, § 14, 9-12-2006) 
Sec. 15.5-4. - Existing Antennas and Towers. 
    Antennas, towers, and accessory structures as of the date of adoption of this ordinance that do not meet or comply with this section are subject to the following provisions: 
(a)  Legal Non-Conforming Towers: 
(1)  Towers may continue in use for the purpose now used and as now existing but may not be replaced or structurally altered without complying in all respects with this ordinance. 
(2)  If such towers are damaged or destroyed due to any reason or cause at all (unless the user or owner voluntarily removes the tower), the tower may be repaired and restored to its former use, location, and physical dimensions upon obtaining a building permit. The location and physical dimensions shall remain as they were before the damage or destruction. If extensive major repairs are required which, in effect, entail more than a 50 percent replacement cost of the tower, the remaining tower structure must be removed. 
(Res. No. 2006-01, § 14, 9-12-2006) 
Sec. 15.5-5. - Interpretation and Applicability. 
(a)  This ordinance shall be interpreted consistent with the provisions of the Federal Communications Act of 1934 as amended by the Telecommunications Act of 1996, as amended and supplemented from time to time. 
(b)  This ordinance shall apply to all persons, partnerships, corporations and other entities seeking to locate, site, place, modify or construct wireless telecommunications facilities within the corporate boundaries of the City. 
(c)  This ordinance reserves to the City all authority contained in state law and existing city ordinance regarding land use, zoning, and regulation which has not been preempted by the federal government pursuant to Section 704 of the Telecommunications Act of 1996 as to the placement, construction, and modification of personal wireless service facilities. 
(d)  This ordinance exempts and does not apply to the use or location of private, residential citizen band radio towers, amateur radio towers or television antennas when they are sited and used in accordance with Chapter 18 titled Zoning, of the Code of Ordinances. 
(Res. No. 2006-01, § 14, 9-12-2006) 
Sec. 15.5-6. - Inspections and Violations. 
(a)  All applicants for monopoles, antennas and the like must obtain a building permit and are subject to inspection by the Whiting Building Commissioner to enforce compliance with Uniform Building Code (UBC) construction standards. 
(b)  Notice of violations will be sent by registered mail or certified mail, return receipt; to the owner of the tower. The owner will have thirty (30) days from the date the notification is issued to make repairs. The owner will notify the Building Commissioner that the repairs have been made, and as soon as possible thereafter, another inspection will be made and owner notified of the results. 
(Res. No. 2006-01, § 14, 9-12-2006) 
Sec. 15.5-7. - Allowances for Towers and Antennas by Zoning District. 
(a)  Permitted Uses, All Districts. Wireless telecommunication towers and antennas, including accessory equipment structures, shall be allowed in all zoning districts as a permitted use only in the following circumstances as provided. 
(1)  City-Owner Tower and/or Structure Facilities. Upon issuance of Federal Communications Commission (FCC) Permits and Licenses, wireless telecommunication antennas shall be permitted upon a City-owned tower and/or structure facility provided that an applicant has: 
a.  Incorporated the applicable Performance Standards of Section 8 of this ordinance; 
b.  An approved lease agreement with the City; 
c.  Obtained a building permit from the City; and 
d.  Paid all applicable fees. 
(2)  Co-Location on Existing Towers. Wireless telecommunication antennas shall be permitted to be attached to existing towers within the City in accordance with the applicable siting guidelines and Performance Standards of Section 8 of this ordinance only after an applicant has: 
a.  A written statement of approval from the tower owner or lessor; 
b.  Obtained a building permit from the City; and 
c.  Paid all applicable fees. 
(3)  Utility Poles. 
a.  Wireless telecommunication antennas shall be permitted to be attached to utility poles and lattice utility poles only after an applicant has: 
1.  A written statement of approval from the utility pole owner or lessor; 
2.  Obtained a building permit from the City; and 
3.  Paid the applicable fees. 
b.  The height of the antenna shall not extend more than six (6) feet above the existing utility pole. 
(b)  Special Exceptions, Specific Districts. 
(1)  Wireless telecommunication towers and antennas shall be allowed those zoning districts specified in the Table 1, Special Exceptions Framework with the approval of a Special Exception in accordance with procedures set forth in Chapter 18, Article XVII specifically Sections 18-503 through 18-506 of the Code of Ordinances. 
(2)  Such provisions are made with Co-Location Requirements stated in Section 7 of this ordinance, Performance Standards in Section 8 of this ordinance and specific Procedural Requirements in Section 10 of this ordinance. 
(3)  Special Exemptions are not required for towers and/or antennas used by the City of Whiting, any municipal agency, or other public agency for public safety purposes. 
(4)  The height limitations listed in Table 1, Special Exceptions Framework shall include all parts of the wireless telecommunications tower arid antenna structure. 
(5)  As applicable, all FAA regulations must be met, and proof thereof supplied to the City prior to granting any permit or the commencement of any construction. 
Table 1 
Special Exceptions Framework 
Zoning Districts Height Limitations R-SF, R-MD Not allowed on residential developed. R-HD Allowed 6 feet above the height of the roof only if mounted on educational facilities, religious institutions, government or public utility buildings, or in "upward thrusting elements" such as church steeples, bell towers or smokestacks. C-NC, C-DB, C-BB 75 feet above ground level. I-LIM, I-HIM 250 feet above ground level.  
(Res. No. 2006-01, § 14, 9-12-2006; Ord. No. CC-2018-1984, §§ 1, 2, 3-6-18) 
Sec. 15.5-8. - Co-Location Requirements. 
    A application for a new wireless telecommunication tower shall not approved unless the applicant documents to the satisfaction of the City that the antenna planned for the proposed tower cannot be accommodated on an existing or approved tower or commercial or industrial building within the applicant's search area, transcending municipal borders, due to one or more of the following: 
(a)  The antenna would exceed the structural capacity of the existing or approved tower or commercial building; 
(b)  The antenna would cause interference with other existing or planned equipment at the tower or building; 
(c)  Existing or approved towers and commercial buildings cannot reasonably accommodate the antenna at a height necessary for the proposed antenna to function; 
(d)  Existing or approved towers and commercial buildings are outside of the documented search area; and 
(e)  The owners or lessors of the existing or approved towers and commercial buildings are unwilling to allow co-location upon their facilities. 
(Res. No. 2006-01, § 14, 9-12-2006) 
Sec. 15.5-9. - Performance Standards. 
(a)  The requirements of this section apply to all wireless telecommunications towers and antennas erected, constructed, placed, or replaced in the City of Whiting. 
(b)  All wireless telecommunication towers and antennas shall be designed and situated to be visually unobtrusive to minimize the impact upon adjacent, contiguous land-uses and shall conform to the following design and siting criteria: 
(1)  Setbacks. 
a.  The minimum setback from any property line or public right-of-way for a wireless telecommunication tower is thirty (30) feet, unless abutting a residential district. 
b.  If a wireless telecommunication tower abuts a residential district, the setback distance shall be a least half the height of the proposed tower. 
c.  Setbacks for all accessory buildings and equipment structures associated with wireless telecommunication towers and antennas shall comply with the zoning district in which the facility is located. 
(2)  Accessory Buildings and Equipment Structures. All buildings and structures accessory to an antenna system and/or tower shall be architecturally designed to blend in with the surrounding building character and the environment. 
(3)  Fencing. When deemed applicable by the Whiting Building commissioner (and/or required by the City Fence Ordinance) appropriate safety fencing shall be incorporated with the site accommodating a tower, accessory building, or equipment structures. 
(4)  Landscaping and Screening. When deemed applicable by the Whiting Building Commissioner, proper landscaping and screening shall be incorporated into the site accommodating a tower, accessory building, or equipment structure. 
(5)  Color. 
a.  Wireless communication towers and antennas shall be of a neutral color such as light gray, brown, shades of vegetative green, or sky blue except as directed by the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA). 
b.  Wireless communication towers and antennas shall be designed to minimize visibility and to blend into the surrounding character of the neighborhood and its adjacent environment. 
(6)  Construction Type and Materials. 
a.  Towers with antennas shall be designed to withstand applicable wind load requirements as prescribed in the Uniform Building Code. 
b.  Towers and/or antenna systems shall be constructed of or treated with only corrosion resistant materials. 
(7)  Roof-Mounted Wireless Communication Antennas. 
a.  Pitched-roof mounted wireless telecommunication antennas shall not be permitted on buildings unless they are stealth antennas incorporated into upward thrusting architectural elements, such as but not limited to: 
1.  Church steeples; 
2.  Spire or bell-towers; or 
3.  Smokestacks. 
b.  Flat-roof mounted wireless telecommunication antennas may not be more than six (6) feet (the height of the antenna and mounting hardware) above the highest point of the roof to which the antenna is attached. 
(8)  Structurally-Mounted Wireless Communication Antennas. 
a.  Telecommunication antennas mounted on sides of buildings shall be attached as close as possible to the building side; however, it shall not protrude no more than the length of the antenna. 
b.  Structurally mounted antennas not affixed to towers shall be installed to blend into the design and contours of the structure. 
(9)  Lights. Neither towers nor antennas shall have affixed or attached to them in any way any lights, reflectors, flashers, daytime strobes, steady nighttime light, or other illuminating devices, except as required by the Federal Aviation Agency (FAA) or the Federal Communications Commission (FCC). 
(10)  Signs and Advertising. Any signs and/or advertising messages shall be prohibited from being affixed to a tower or antenna structure b. An unobtrusive indicator sign detailing emergency and safety information of a size no larger than two (2) feet by two (2) feet shall be exempt for the purposes of public safety. 
(11)  Other Attachments. No tower or antenna shall have constructed thereon or attached thereto any platform, catwalk, crow's nest, or like structure for the purpose of human support, except during periods of construction and repair. 
(Res. No. 2006-01, § 14, 9-12-2006) 
Sec. 15.5-10. - Procedural Requirements. 
(a)  Applicants proposing to erect wireless telecommunication towers and/or antennas that require a Special Exception shall follow the procedures set forth in Chapter 18, Article XVII specifically Sections 18-503 through 18-506 of the Code of Ordinances for the City of Whiting. 
(b)  Additional application materials shall include the following: 
(1)  A document from the property owner or lessor that allows the applicant to apply for a special exception and building permit to erect a wireless telecommunications tower and/or antenna; 
[2]  A site plan to scale which shows: 
a.  Property lines; 
b.  Location of the wireless telecommunications tower or antenna on the property; 
c.  Any accessory buildings or equipment structures; 
d.  All setback distances; 
e.  All fencing including the type; and, 
f.  Proposed landscaping for screening. 
(3)  Sufficient information to show that the construction, installation, and the maintenance schedule of the wireless telecommunication tower and/or antenna will not create a safety hazard or damage the property or other persons. 
(Res. No. 2006-01, § 14, 9-12-2006) 
Sec. 15.5-11. - Building Permits. 
(a)  Applicants proposing to erect wireless telecommunication towers and/or antennas shall obtain a building permit from the City of Whiting as approved by the Whiting Building Commissioner. 
(b)  Building permits shall be issued by the City only after recommendation by the Building Commissioner and, as applicable, upon favorable recommendation by the Whiting Board of Zoning Appeals of a Special Exception to the Whiting Common Council and with its legislative approval per IC § 36-7-4-918.6. When no Special Exception is required, the applicant shall provide to the City all information as required by this ordinance and other applicable ordinances of the City at the time of application for a building permit. 
(c)  Towers and antennas are subject to plan review and inspection by the City of Whiting building Commissioner (or designated Consultant) to determine compliance with Uniform Building Code (UBC) construction standards. 
(d)  In addition to Performance Standards information as required in Section 9 of this ordinance, necessary information accompanying the application for a building permit shall include: 
(1)  A report and plan from a registered professional engineer (PE.) that specifies the following information: 
a.  Site and landscape plans drawn to scale; 
b.  A description of the tower with technical reasons for its design; 
c.  The tower height and design, including cross-section and elevation, 
d.  The height above ground level for all potential mounting positions for co-located antennas and the minimum separation distances between antennas; 
e.  Structural integrity for the tower's proposed uses including mounting designs and materials list; 
f.  The general capacity of the tower, including the number and type of antennas to insure ANSI standards are met; 
g.  A statement of intent on whether excess space will be leased; 
h.  Proof of ownership of the proposed site or authorization to utilize it; 
i.  Copies of any easements necessary; 
j.  A visual study depicting "where within a mile radius any portion of the proposed tower could be seen;" and 
k.  The registered professional engineer's (PE.) stamp and registration number. 
(Res. No. 2006-01, § 14, 9-12-2006) 
Sec. 15.5-12. - Non-Interference. 
    All new or existing telecommunication's services shall comply with all relevant Federal Communication Commission (FCC) standards and shall not interfere with public safety and other city and private telecommunications operations. 
(Res. No. 2006-01, § 14, 9-12-2006) 
Sec. 15.5-13. - Insurance. 
    The applicant shall provide the City of Whiting with proof of appropriate level of liability insurance which protects against losses due to personal injury or property damage resulting from the construction or collapse of the tower, antennas or accessory equipment. 
(Res. No. 2006-01, § 14, 9-12-2006) 
Sec. 15.5-14. - Obsolete or Unused Towers. 
(a)  All obsolete or unused towers and accompanying accessory facilities shall be removed within one hundred eighty (180) days of the cessation of operations unless a time extension is approved by the Whiting Board of Public Works and Safety. 
(b)  If the tower is not removed, it shall be deemed a nuisance pursuant to Indiana State Statutes. 
(c)  In the event a tower is determined to be a nuisance, the City may act to abate such nuisance and require the removal of the tower at the property owner's expense. The owner shall provide the City with a copy of the notice of the Federal Communication Commission's (FCC) intent to cease operations and shall be given one hundred eighty (180) days from the date of ceasing operations to remove the obsolete tower and all accessory structures. In the case of multiple operators sharing the use of a single tower, the owner shall provide the City with a copy of the notice of the Federal Communication Commission's (FCC) intent to cease operations and shall be given one hundred eighty (180) days from the date of the final user ceasing operations to remove the obsolete tower and all accessory structures. 
(d)  The equipment on the ground shall not be removed until the tower structure has first been dismantled. After all facilities are removed, the site shall be restored to its original condition or to an improved state. 
(Res. No. 2006-01, § 14, 9-12-2006) 
Sec. 15.5-15. - Removal of Abandoned Towers. 
(a)  Any wireless telecommunication tower and/or antenna that ceases to be used for a period of one hundred eighty (180) days shall be deemed abandoned. 
(b)  The property owner and/or lessee of an abandoned wireless telecommunication tower and/or antenna shall remove the tower and/or antenna. 
(c)  If the owner and/or lessee fails to remove a wireless telecommunication tower and/or antenna after it has been abandoned or determined to be abandoned, it may be removed by the City (or designated agent) with the costs of such removal assessed against the owner or lessee of the tower. 
(d)  After all facilities have been removed, the site shall be restored to its original condition or to an improved state. 
(Res. No. 2006-01, § 14, 9-12-2006) 
Sec. 15.5-16. - Repeal. 
    All ordinances or parts of ordinances in conflict with the provisions of this ordinance are hereby repealed. 
(Res. No. 2006-01, § 14, 9-12-2006) 
Sec. 15.5-17. - Full Force and Effect. 
    This ordinance shall be in full force and effect from and after its passage and approval according to law. 
(Res. No. 2006-01, § 14, 9-12-2006) 
Chapter 15.7 - TREE ORDINANCE[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Res. No. 2006-01, § 14, adopted September 12, 2006, renumbered App. A, Ch. 5 as a new Ch. 15.7. See the Code Comparative Table-Ordinance Disposition. 

Sec. 15.7-1. - Short Title. 
    This ordinance shall be known and may be cited as the "Whiting Municipal Tree Ordinance" of the City of Whiting, Lake County, Indiana and hereafter referred to as the "ordinance." 
(Res. No. 2006-01, § 14, 9-12-2006) 
Sec. 15.7-2. - Purpose and Intent. 
A.  It is the purpose of this ordinance to promote and protect the public health, safety, and general welfare of the City of Whiting by regulation of the planting, maintenance, and removal of trees or shrubs. 
B.  It is the intent of the Common Council for the City of Whiting that the terms of this ordinance shall be construed so as to promote: 
1.  The planting, maintenance, and survival of desirable trees with the City of Whiting; and 
2.  The protection of community residents from personal injury and property damage, and the protection of the City of Whiting from property damage, caused or threatened by the improper planting, maintenance, or removal of trees within the City of Whiting. 
(Res. No. 2006-01, § 14, 9-12-2006) 
Sec. 15.7-3. - Applicability. 
    This ordinance provides full power and authority over all trees, shrubs, and other plants located within rights-of-way, public parks, and other public places of the City of Whiting; and over trees and shrubs located on private property which constitute a hazard or threat to the public health and/or safety. 
(Res. No. 2006-01, § 14, 9-12-2006) 
Sec. 15.7-4. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this ordinance, the following terms, phrases, words, and their derivations shall have the meaning given herein. When not inconsistent with the context, words used in the present tense include the future, words in the plural include the singular, and words in the singular include the plural. The word "shall" is mandatory and not merely directory. 
    Adjacent Landowner is any private property owner whose land abuts a public right-of-way or any publicly owned land. 
    Large Trees are designated as those attaining a mature height of forty-five (45) feet or more. 
    Medium Trees are designated as those attaining a mature height of thirty (30) to forty-five (45) feet. 
    Public Park (or Park) shall include all parks and open-spaces having individual names which come under the jurisdiction of the Whiting Board of Public Works and Safety, the Whiting Park Board, or the Whiting Parks and Recreation Department. 
    Park Tree I is a tree located in any public park. 
    Parkway is that part of a right-of-way between the curb and the sidewalk usually used for utility services, tree plantings, etc. (also known as a treelawn). 
    Private Tree is any tree or shrub growing on private property. 
    Property Owner shall mean the person owning such property as shown by the County Recorder's records for Lake County, Indiana. 
    Public Nuisance (with respect to trees or shrubs) shall mean any tree or shrub with an infectious disease or insect problem; dead or dying tree or shrub; any tree, tree limb, shrub, or shrub limb that obstructs street regulatory signals, traffic regulatory signs, or the free passage of pedestrians or vehicles; and any tree or shrub that poses a threat to the general health and safety of the public. The following may be declared as public nuisances pursuant to this ordinance: 
1.  Any dead or dying tree or shrub whether located on public or private property; 
2.  Any otherwise healthy tree or shrub which harbors insects or diseases which reasonably may be expected to injure or harm any tree or shrub whether located on public or private property; 
3.  Any tree or shrub or portion thereof which by reason of location or condition constitutes an imminent danger to the health, safety, or welfare of the general public whether located on public or private property; 
4.  Any tree or shrub or portion thereof which obstructs the free passage of pedestrian or vehicular traffic or which obstructs a street traffic regulatory signal or sign whether located on public or private property; and 
5.  Any tree or shrub or portion thereof which dangerously obstructs the view in the "visibility triangle" as determined by Whiting Police Traffic Captain whether located on public or private property pursuant to this ordinance. 
    Public Property shall include all property owned by the City of Whiting, Indiana. 
    Public Trees shall include all shade and ornamental trees now or hereafter growing on public property. 
    Right-of-Way is the strip of land acquired by reservation or dedication in which is intended to be occupied by a street, crosswalk, public way for use by the 
    Sidewalk Parkway or Sidewalk Treelawn is the area between the curb and a property line which includes the sidewalk and open sections of sidewalk for public trees. 
    Small Trees are designated as those attaining a mature height of twenty (20) to thirty (30) feet. 
    Street means the entire width of every public way or right-of-way when any part thereof is open to the public, as a matter of right-of-way, for purposes of vehicular and/or pedestrian traffic. 
    Street Trees shall be all trees and shrubs located within the parkways, treelawns, sidewalk parkways or sidewalk treelawns within the City of Whiting. 
    Traffic Regulatory Signal shall mean any lighted, flashing or electronic traffic signal, which regulates the flow and circulation of vehicular traffic. 
    Traffic Regulatory Sign shall mean any metal regulatory sign attached to a post or pole for the purpose of regulating the flow and circulation vehicular traffic. 
    Treelawn is that part of a right-of-way between the curb and the sidewalk usually used for utility services, tree plantings, etc. (also known as a parkway). 
    Tree Topping is defined as the severe cutting back of limbs to stubs within a tree's crown to such a degree so as to remove the normal canopy and to disfigure a tree's shape. 
    Trees and Shrubs shall mean all vegetation, woody or otherwise, except lawn grass and flowers less than twenty-four (24) inches in height. 
Sec. 15.7-5. - Creation and Establishment of a City Tree Board. 
    There is hereby created and established a tree board for the City of Whiting, Lake County, Indiana with its functions and duties limited to those set forth in this ordinance. The board shall be known officially as the "Whiting Tree Board" and hereafter may be referred to as the "Board". 
(Res. No. 2006-01, § 14, 9-12-2006) 
Sec. 15.7-6. - Board Composition. 
A.  The Whiting Tree Board shall consist of five members all of whom must be citizens and residents of the City of Whiting. 
B.  The Whiting Tree Board membership shall be appointed as follows: 
1.  One (1) member shall be appointed by the chief executive of the municipality (the mayor of the City of Whiting) other than a member appointed by the Whiting Common Council and the Whiting Park Board; 
2.  One (1) member shall be appointed by the Whiting Common Council other than a member appointed by the chief executive of the municipality and the Whiting Park Board; and 
3.  One (1) member shall be appointed by the Whiting Park Board other than a member appointed by the chief executive of the municipality and the Whiting Common Council. 
C.  In addition to the three appointed Board members, the Board shall consist of the Whiting Parks and Recreation Superintendent and the Whiting Street Commissioner as ex-officio members. 
D.  Upon the approval of the entire Board, ex-officio members of the Board may appoint a qualified member of their staff as their alternate to the Board to represent them in their absence. 
(Res. No. 2006-01, § 14, 9-12-2006) 
Sec. 15.7-7. - Terms of Office. 
    On the Whiting Tree Board, when an initial term of office expires, each new Board appointment is for a term of three (3) years. 
A.  Upon the establishment of the Board, the Board members, excluding ex-officio members, shall be appointed initially for the following terms of office: 
1.  One (1) of the three (3) appointed Board members shall serve for a term of one (1) year; 
2.  One (1) of the three (3) appointed Board members shall serve for a term of two (2) years; 
3.  One (1) of the three (3) appointed Board members shall serve for a term of three (3) years. 
B.  The terms of Board members shall start on a common date; however each Board member's term expires on the first Monday of January of the first, second, and third years, respectively, after the year of the Board member's respective appointment. 
C.  A member of the Board shall serve until a successor is appointed and qualified (qualified meaning to accept the appointment). A member is eligible for reappointment at the conclusion of his or her Board term. 
D.  Within thirty (30) days following the expiration of the term of any appointed Board member, a successor shall be appointed by the appropriate appointing authority. The appointed successor shall serve for a term of three (3) years. Should a Board member resign or be removed from the Board, a successor shall be appointed by the appropriate appointing authority and shall serve for the remainder of the unexpired term. 
E.  The Board members appointed shall serve at the pleasure of the appointing authority. 
(Res. No. 2006-01, § 14, 9-12-2006) 
Sec. 15.7-8. - Board Officers. 
    At the initial meeting of the Board or at the first meeting of each calendar year, the Board shall elect a chairperson, a vice-chairperson and a secretary from the Board membership. 
(Res. No. 2006-01, § 14, 9-12-2006) 
Sec. 15.7-9. - Duties of the Board. 
    The Board shall perform and be responsible for the following duties. 
A.  Within a reasonable time after the appointment of the Board, the secretary of the Board shall call a meeting of the Board to adopt rules of procedure for all regular and special meetings to fulfill the duties pursuant to this ordinance; 
B.  The Board shall advise and consult the City of Whiting's Common Council on any matter pertaining to this Municipal Tree Ordinance and its enforcement. The topics under which this advice and consultation may be given may include, but are not limited to, any of the following: 
1.  Amendments to the Municipal Tree Ordinance; 
2.  The development of an "Official Comprehensive City Tree Plan"; 
3.  Development of policies and procedures regarding the care, preservation, selection, planting, transplanting, pruning, maintenance, and removal of trees or shrubs within the City of Whiting. 
4.  Establishment of educational and informational programs; and 
5.  Expenditure of Board funds as appropriated by the Common Council; 
C.  The Board shall hold regular meetings at which the subject of trees, insofar as it relates to the City of Whiting, may be discussed by its Board members, its officers, and all other interested parties. 
D.  It shall be the responsibility of the Board to study, investigate, counsel and develop and/or update annually, and administer a written plan for the care, preservation, selection, planting, transplanting, pruning, maintenance, and removal of trees or shrubs within the City of Whiting. The acceptance and approval of the plan by both the Board and the Whiting Board of Public Works and Safety shall constitute it as the "Official Comprehensive City Tree Plan" for the City of Whiting, Lake County, Indiana. 
(Res. No. 2006-01, § 14, 9-12-2006) 
Sec. 15.7-10. - Board Compensation. 
    The five members of the Whiting Tree Board shall serve their respective appointed terms without compensation. 
(Res. No. 2006-01, § 14, 9-12-2006) 
Sec. 15.7-11 - Board Operation and Business. 
A.  The Board shall adopt a set of administrative rules and procedures so that the Board may effectively and efficiently conduct board business. The Board's administrative rules and procedures should include sections on officers, Board meetings, order of business, committees, and any other sections deemed necessary by the Board. The Board shall adopt a set of administrative rules and procedures at its initial or first meeting. 
B.  The Board shall review its "Administrative Rules and Procedures" as needed or on an annual basis for any additions, deletions, amendments, or revisions. 
(Res. No. 2006-01, § 14, 9-12-2006) 
Sec. 15.7-12. - Tree Species Recommended for Planting. 
A.  The Board shall develop and maintain a list of desirable small, medium and large trees for planting on public property. 
B.  In addition, the Board shall develop, maintain and enforce a list of trees not desirable or suitable for planting on public property. 
(Res. No. 2006-01, § 14, 9-12-2006) 
Sec. 15.7-13. - Tree Spacing. 
A.  The spacing of public trees will be in accordance with the three (3) species size classes listed in section 15.7-12 of this ordinance. 
B.  Public trees may not be planted closer to one another than the following spacing limits: small trees, fifteen (15) feet; medium trees, twenty (20) feet; and large trees, twenty-five (25) feet. 
C.  Per the Whiting Tree Board, exceptions to street tree spacing standards may be allowed in special plantings which are approved by the Whiting Tree Board and the Whiting Board of Public Works and Safety. 
(Res. No. 2006-01, § 14, 9-12-2006) 
Sec. 15.7-14. - Distance from Curb, Curb Lines and Sidewalk. 
A.  The distance street trees may be planted from curbs or curb lines and sidewalks will be in accordance with three (3) species size classes listed in section 15.7-12 of this ordinance. 
B.  A street tree may not be planted closer to any curb, curb line or sidewalk than the following distance limits: small and medium trees, two (2) feet and large trees, three (3) feet. 
C.  Per the Whiting Tree Board, exceptions to planting distance from curb, curb line or sidewalk standards may be allowed in special plantings which are approved by the Whiting Tree Board and the Whiting Board of Public Works and Safety. 
(Res. No. 2006-01, § 14, 9-12-2006) 
Sec. 15.7-15. - Distance from Street Corners. 
A.  A public tree shall not be planted within twenty (20) feet of any street corner, measured from the point of nearest intersecting curbs or curb lines. 
(Res. No. 2006-01, § 14, 9-12-2006) 
Sec. 15.7-16. - Street, Sidewalk or Corner Clearance. 
A.  There shall be a public tree clearance area standard of thirteen (13) feet above any street surface and eight (8) feet above any sidewalk surface. 
B.  Private tree overhanging the right-of-way within the City of Whiting shall be properly prune so that the branches of the private tree(s) shall not severely obstruct the light from any street lamp or obstruct the view of any street intersection. Said owners of trees on private property shall remove or cause to have removed all dead, diseased, or dangerous trees, or broken or decayed limbs which constitute a hazard to the safety to the public. 
(Res. No. 2006-01, § 14, 9-12-2006) 
Sec. 15.7-17. - Distance from Fireplugs. 
    A public tree shall not be planted within ten (10) feet of any fireplug so that adequate spacing and clearance is allowed in cases of emergency. 
(Res. No. 2006-01, § 14, 9-12-2006) 
Sec. 15.7-18. - Distance from Traffic Regulatory Signals and Signs. 
    A public tree shall not be planted within fifteen (15) feet of any traffic regulatory signal or sign in order to allow the necessary line of sight or vision of the traffic regulatory signal or sign. 
(Res. No. 2006-01, § 14, 9-12-2006) 
Sec. 15.7-19. - Utility Overhead or Underground Clearance. 
    Large trees may not be planted under or within ten (10) lateral feet of any overhead utility wire or line, or over or within three and one-half (3.5) lateral feet of any underground water line, sewer line, transmission line or other utility line or wire. 
(Res. No. 2006-01, § 14, 9-12-2006) 
Sec. 15.7-20. - Public Tree Care by the City. 
    The City of Whiting shall have the right to cut, trim, prune, spray, remove or otherwise treat any public trees as may be necessary to insure public safety or to preserve or enhance the symmetry and beauty of such public places and grounds. 
(Res. No. 2006-01, § 14, 9-12-2006) 
Sec. 15.7-21. - Tree Pruning. 
A.  The City of Whiting shall have the right to prune any public tree or shrub located on public property which includes those trees growing in the right-of-way, public parks, parkways, treelawns, sidewalk parkways and sidewalk treelawns. 
B.  The City of Whiting shall have the right to prune any tree, shrub or plant located on private property when it interferes with the proper spread of light along the street from a street light or when it interferes with the proper visibility of any traffic regulatory signal or sign or sight triangle at any intersection. 
(Res. No. 2006-01, § 14, 9-12-2006) 
Sec. 15.7-22. - Tree Topping. 
A.  It shall be unlawful for any person, firm, or City department to top any public tree. 
B.  Public trees severely damaged by storms, other natural causes, acts of God, or certain trees under utility wires, lines or other obstructions where other pruning practices are impractical may be exempt from this section for a temporary period and shall be removed at the earliest available time. 
(Res. No. 2006-01, § 14, 9-12-2006) 
Sec. 15.7-23. - Public Utility Company Work Standards. 
A.  A public utility company tree trimming policy must be reviewed by the Board prior to any trimming within the City of Whiting by said public utility company. 
B.  Tree limbs that grow near high voltage electric conductors or any other utility lines shall be maintained clear of such corridors by the public utility company. 
C.  All public utility companies shall notify the Whiting Tree Board, in writing, a minimum of thirty (30) days prior to any activities related to any work or acts related to the cutting, trimming, pruning, spraying, removing or otherwise treating public trees for the purpose of maintaining safe line clearance. 
D.  The public utility company shall carry out all such related work activities in accordance with accepted tree trimming policy of the public utility company, the standards of the Whiting Tree Board and this ordinance. 
(Res. No. 2006-01, § 14, 9-12-2006) 
Sec. 15.7-24. - Tree and Shrub Removal. 
A.  The City of Whiting shall have the right to remove any dead, dying, diseased, or hazardous public tree or shrub located on public property which includes those trees and shrubs growing in the right-of-way, public parks, parkways, treelawns, sidewalk parkways and sidewalk treelawns. 
B.  The City of Whiting shall have the right to remove any dead, dying, diseased, or hazardous tree or shrub located on private property when deemed to be a public nuisance in accordance with this ordinance. 
C.  The Whiting Tree Board shall have the authority to recommend in writing to the Whiting Board of Public Works and Safety the removal of any tree or part thereof on public or private property which by reason of its nature is injurious to sewer lines, utility or other public improvements, or which is affected with any injurious fungus, insect, or other pest. 
(Res. No. 2006-01, § 14, 9-12-2006) 
Sec. 15.7-25. - Removal of Stumps. 
    If a public tree is removed, the stumps shall also be removed below the surface of the ground so that the top of the stump shall not project above the surface of the ground or the average grade level. 
(Res. No. 2006-01, § 14, 9-12-2006) 
Sec. 15.7-26. - Landscaping. 
A.  In any new industrial, commercial, residential subdivision or public property development, the Board shall review any and all landscaping plans. The Board may require public trees to be planted in any of the public parks, parkways, treelawns, sidewalk parkways and sidewalk treelawns, parking lots, or other public places abutting lands henceforth developed and/or subdivided. 
B.  The Board may require the owner or developer of said property to be developed to replace, in kind, any and all trees, shrubs or other plants removed due to any new development. Those trees replaced by the owner or developer of said property to be developed shall be in accordance with the Board's list of desirable trees for planting within the City of Whiting. 
(Res. No. 2006-01, § 14, 9-12-2006) 
Sec. 15.7-27. - Adjacent Landowner Responsibility. 
A.  No person shall plant or remove a tree in a public place which includes public parks, parkways, treelawns, sidewalk parkways and sidewalk treelawns or other public places without first receiving written approval from the Whiting Tree Board. 
B.  The Board shall review and approve all tree planting and removal requests submitted to the Board in writing. 
(Res. No. 2006-01, § 14, 9-12-2006) 
Sec. 15.7-28. - Abuse or Mutilation of Public Trees. 
A.  No person shall damage, cut, carve, transplant, or remove any public tree; attach any rope, wire, nail, staple, advertising posters, or other contrivance to any public tree; allow any gaseous liquid or solid substance which is harmful to a public tree to come in contact with them; or to set fire or permit any fire to burn when such fire or the heat thereof will injure any portion of a public tree. 
(Res. No. 2006-01, § 14, 9-12-2006) 
Sec. 15.7-29. - Placing Materials on Public Property. 
A.  No person shall deposit, place, store, or maintain upon any public place, any stone, brick, sand, concrete, or other materials which may impede the free passage of water, air, fertilizer, to the roots of a public tree growing therein. 
B.  Per the Whiting Tree Board, exceptions to this section may be allowed if approved by the Whiting Tree Board and the Whiting Board of Public Works and Safety. 
(Res. No. 2006-01, § 14, 9-12-2006) 
Sec. 15.7-30. - Private Trees. 
A.  The Whiting Tree Board or a designated representative of the Whiting Tree Board as an arborist shall have the authority to enter onto private property whereon there is located a tree, tree limb, shrub, or shrub limb that is suspected to be a public nuisance. 
B.  The Whiting Tree Board shall have the authority to recommend in writing to the Whiting Board of Public Works and Safety the removal of any dead or diseased tree, tree limb, shrub, or shrub limb on private property within the City of Whiting, when such tree, tree limb, shrub, or shrub limb constitutes a hazard or threat to life and property, or harbor insects or disease which constitute a potential threat to other trees within the City of Whiting. 
C.  The Whiting Tree Board will notify in writing the Whiting Board of Public Works and Safety and the property owner of such a tree, tree limb, shrub, or shrub limb that is suspected to be a public nuisance, all in accordance with section 15.7-31 of this ordinance. 
(Res. No. 2006-01, § 14, 9-12-2006) 
Sec. 15.7-31. - Public Nuisance Notification. 
    Any tree or shrub deemed to be public nuisance by the Whiting Tree Board pursuant to this ordinance and which is located on private property shall be cut, trimmed, pruned, sprayed, removed or otherwise treated by the property owner or his/her agent in whatever fashion is required to cause the abatement of the nuisance. 
    A property owner may not be found in violation of this ordinance unless and until the following requirements have been satisfied: 
    The Whiting Tree Board shall provide written notice, to be personally serviced or sent by mail, to the property owner of record which shall include the following information: 
1.  Describe the kind of tree, shrub, or other plant or plant part which has been declared to be a public nuisance, its location on the property; and the reason for declaring it a public nuisance including the section(s) of this ordinance for which the property owner is in violation; 
2.  Describe by legal description or by street number the location or premises or location of the public nuisance; 
3.  State the actions that the property owner may undertake to abate the public nuisance; and 
4.  Require the elimination of the nuisance no less than thirty (30) days after the notice is delivered or sent to the property owner of record. 
(Res. No. 2006-01, § 14, 9-12-2006) 
Sec. 15.7-32. - Immediate Threat by a Public Nuisance. 
A.  The Whiting Tree Board shall have the authority to recommend in writing to the Whiting Board of Public Works and Safety the immediate abatement of any public or private tree deemed to be a public nuisance as defined by this ordinance provided that said public nuisance is determined by the Whiting Tree Board or an agent of the Whiting Tree Board to be an immediate threat to person or property. 
B.  The Whiting Tree Board is hereby empowered to seek from any court of competent jurisdiction an order directing immediate abatement of any public nuisance. 
(Res. No. 2006-01, § 14, 9-12-2006) 
Sec. 15.7-33. - Claims. 
    In the event that a public nuisance is not abated by the date specified in the notice prepared by the Whiting Tree Board and mailed to the property owner of record who is in violation of this ordinance, the Whiting Tree Board has the authority to cause the abatement of said public nuisance. The reasonable cost of such abatement may be filed as a lien against the property upon which the public nuisance was located. In addition, the owner of the property upon which the nuisance is located shall be subject to penalties as described in section 15.7-41 of this ordinance. 
(Res. No. 2006-01, § 14, 9-12-2006) 
Sec. 15.7-34. - Tree Protection. 
A.  Upon the discovery of any destructive or communicable disease or other pestilence which endangers the general growth or health of trees, or threatens to spread disease or insect infestations, the Whiting Tree Board shall immediately cause written notice to be served to the property owner of record upon which such disease or infested tree is situated. The notice shall require said property owner to eradicate, remove, treat or otherwise control such a condition within reasonable time to be specified in said notice in accordance with section 15.7-31 of this ordinance. 
B.  The Whiting Tree Board shall prepare a set of guidelines and standards which addresses public trees near or adjacent to a construction site or area and which applies to preserving a specified percentage of forested land, open space, or to paying into a tree planting fund so as to minimize the net loss of tree cover in the City of Whiting. Upon approval by the Whiting Common Council, the guidelines and standards shall be known as the "Official Tree Protection Plan". 
C.  The Whiting Tree Board or a designated arborist representing the Whiting Tree Board shall have the authority and responsibility of locating, selecting, and identifying any tree which qualifies as a "landmark tree." A public or private tree may qualify as a "landmark tree" if it meets one or more but is not limited to of the following criteria: species rarity, age, association with an historical event or person, abnormality, or scenic and/or aesthetic enhancement. The Whiting Tree Board shall determine and approve any tree's status as a "landmark tree." 
(Res. No. 2006-01, § 14, 9-12-2006) 
Sec. 15.7-35. - Written Approval. 
A.  A person, firm or business may not perform any work or acts of cutting, trimming, pruning or removing public trees without first obtaining written approval to do such acts or work from the Whiting Tree Board for which no fee shall be charged. 
B.  Members of the Whiting Tree Board, agents of the Whiting Tree Board, and tree service firms, businesses and contractors retained by the City of Whiting to cut, trim, prune, spray, remove or otherwise treat public trees shall be exempt from receiving written approval. 
C.  Minor trimming or pruning of mature public trees by adjacent landowners for the specific purposes of maintaining street and sidewalk clearance shall be exempt from requiring written approval from the Whiting Tree Board. 
(Res. No. 2006-01, § 14, 9-12-2006) 
Sec. 15.7-36. - Written Approval Issuance. 
    The Whiting Tree Board shall issue said written approval at any regular or special meeting of the Whiting Tree Board. 
(Res. No. 2006-01, § 14, 9-12-2006) 
Sec. 15.7-37. - General Contractors License Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any firm, business tree service or contractor to plant, cut, trim, prune, spray, remove or otherwise treat public or private trees without first obtaining a general contractors license from the City of Whiting. 
(Res. No. 2006-01, § 14, 9-12-2006) 
Sec. 15.7-38. - Interference. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to unreasonably prevent, delay or interfere with the Whiting Tree Board, the Whiting Board of Public Works and Safety or any of its agents, while engaging in and about the cutting, trimming, pruning, spraying, removing or otherwise treating public or private trees pursuant to this ordinance. 
(Res. No. 2006-01, § 14, 9-12-2006) 
Sec. 15.7-39. - Enforcement. 
    The Whiting Tree Board or a designated arborist representing the Whiting Tree Board has the authority and power to promulgate and enforce rules, regulations, and specifications concerning the cutting, trimming, pruning, spraying, removal or otherwise treatment of public or private trees within the City of Whiting. 
(Res. No. 2006-01, § 14, 9-12-2006) 
Sec. 15.7-40. - Appeal to the Whiting Board of Public Works and Safety. 
A.  The Whiting Board of Public Works and Safety shall have the right to review the conduct, acts, and decisions of the Whiting Tree Board. Any person may appeal any decision or finding of the Whiting Tree Board to the Whiting Board of Public Works and Safety. 
B.  The Whiting Board of Public Works may hear the matter and make a final decision at any regular meeting of the Whiting Board of Public Works and Safety. 
(Res. No. 2006-01, § 14, 9-12-2006) 
Sec. 15.7-41. - Violation and Penalty. 
    The penalty or penalties for violation of the Municipal Tree Ordinance shall be the same as provided in the General Penalty section of the Whiting Municipal Code. 
(Res. No. 2006-01, § 14, 9-12-2006) 
Sec. 15.7-42. - Severability. 
    Should any section, clause, or provision of this ordinance be declared by the courts to be invalid, the same shall not affect the validity of the ordinance as a whole, or parts thereof, other than the part so declared to be invalid. 
(Res. No. 2006-01, § 14, 9-12-2006) 
Sec. 15.7-43. - Repeal. 
    Ordinance No. CC-92-1438 as well as ordinances or parts of ordinances in conflict with the provisions of this ordinance are hereby repealed. 
(Res. No. 2006-01, § 14, 9-12-2006) 
Sec. 15.7-44. - Full Force and Effect. 
    This ordinance shall be in full force and effect from and after its passage and approval according to law. 
(Res. No. 2006-01, § 14, 9-12-2006) 
Chapter 16 - UTILITIES[1]

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 16-1-16-25. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - CONNECTIONS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Barrett Law funding for municipality, IC 36-9-19-1 et seq.; required connections to sewer systems, IC 36-9-23-30. 

Sec. 16-26. - Common council to authorize improvements and give notice to property owners. 
    Whenever the common council deems it expedient to pave or improve any roadway or part of a street or alley permanently, in the manner and in the form and in accordance with an act of the General Assembly of the state entitled "An Act Concerning Municipal Corporations," approved March 6, 1905, the common council shall, in a declaratory resolution authorizing the improvement, or subsequent thereto, provided by resolution the number, location and kind of service pipe for sewer and water connection to accommodate the abutting property, the material to be used and the manner of laying same from the mains in such streets to a point within the curbline of the roadway of the street. The common council shall give notice by publication in a newspaper in the city, for two consecutive weeks to the owners of the abutting property, to make the connections in the manner provided for in the resolution within 30 days from the last publication of the notice. 
(Code 1962, § 21-201; Code 1979, § 13.16.010) 
Sec. 16-27. - Time to make connection; assessment; notice and hearing. 
    If the connections provided for in section 16-26 are not made and laid to the designated points within the specified time, the common council shall cause the connections as provided in the resolution to be made, and the cost thereof shall constitute an assessment and shall be a lien on the real estate of the property abutting thereon and shall be collected in the same manner as assessments for street improvement are now collected by law; provided, however, that in all cases, upon the completion of the connections, the common council shall give notice of a special hearing therein and will determine at such time and place the question of the special benefits arising upon and by reason of the improvement as now provided by law and in accordance with an act of the General Assembly of the state entitled "An Act Concerning Municipal Corporations," approved March 6, 1905, and the assessment, after the hearing, shall be referred for collection; provided, however, that the privilege of paying such assessment for such connections in ten annual installments shall not apply to such assessment or such connections. 
(Code 1962, § 21-202; Code 1979, § 13.16.020) 
Sec. 16-28. - Backflow prevention policy. 
(a)  A cross connection shall be defined as any physical connection or arrangement between two otherwise separate systems, one of which contains potable water for the City of Whiting Water System, and the other, water from a private source, water of unknown or questionable safety, or steam, gases, or chemicals, whereby there may be a flow from one system to the other, the direction of flow depending on the pressure differential between the two systems. 
(b)  No person, firm, or corporation shall establish or permit to be established or maintain or permit to be maintained any cross connection. No interconnection shall be established where potable water from a private, auxiliary, or emergency water supply or distribution system of said municipality, unless such private, auxiliary, or emergency water supply and the method of connection and use of such supply shall have been approved by the Whiting Municipal Water Department and by the Indiana Department of Environmental Management in accordance with 327 IAC 8-10. 
(c)  It shall be the duty of the Whiting Municipal Water Department to cause inspections to be made of all properties served by the public water system where cross connections with the public water system is deemed possible. The frequency of inspections and reinspections based on potential health hazards involved shall be as established by the Whiting Municipal Water Department. 
(d)  Upon presentation of credentials, the representative of the Whiting Water Department shall have the right to request entry at any reasonable time to examine any property served by a connection to the public water system of Whiting for cross connections. On request, the owner, lessee, or occupant of any property so served shall furnish to the inspection agency any pertinent information regarding the piping system or systems on such property. The refusal of access or refusal of requested pertinent information shall be deemed evidence of the presence of cross connections. 
(e)  The Whiting Municipal Water Department is hereby authorized and directed to discontinue water service to any property wherein any connection in violation of this section exists, and to take such other precautionary measures deemed necessary to eliminate any danger of contamination of the public water system. Water service shall be disconnected only after reasonable notice is served on the owner, lessee, or occupants of the property or premises where a violation is found or suspected to exist. Water service to such property shall not be restored until the cross connection(s) has been eliminated in compliance with the provisions of this section. 
(f)  If it is deemed by the Whiting Municipal Water Department that a cross connection or emergency endangers public health, safety, or welfare and requires immediate action, and a written finding to that effect if filed with the Clerk-Treasurer of the City of Whiting and delivered to the consumer's premises, service may be immediately discontinued. The consumer shall have an opportunity for hearing within ten days of such emergency discontinuance. 
(g)  All consumers using toxic or hazardous liquids, all hospitals, mortuaries, wastewater treatment plants, laboratories, and all other hazardous users install and maintain a reduced-pressure-principle backflow preventer in the main water line serving each building on the premises. The backflow preventer must be installed in an easily accessible location not subject to flooding or freezing. 
(Ord. No. CC-2002-1616, §§ 1-7, 3-19-02) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. CC-2002-1616, §§ 1-7, adopted March 19, 2002, was not specifically amendatory of the Code and has been included as § 16-28 at the discretion of the editor. 
Secs. 16-29-16-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - WATER[3] 
Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Water in mobile home parks, § 11-8. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 16-51. - Interference with water supply. 
    It is unlawful and shall be deemed disorderly conduct for any person, without permission of the proper city authorities, to open or attempt to open any public stopcock or in any way or manner injure or interfere with the water source or supply of the city or any apparatus pertaining thereto. 
(Code 1962, § 17-520; Code 1979, § 13.24.010) 
Secs. 16-52-16-60. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - RATE-MAKING PROCEDURES 

Sec. 16-61. - Adoption of IC 8-1.5-3-8.1. 
    The common council does hereby expressly adopt IC 8-1.5-3-8.1 for purposes of establishing rates to be charged by the water department. The rates to be charged by the water department shall be fair, nondiscriminatory, reasonable and just. 
(Code 1979, § 13.18.010; Ord. No. 1399, § 1, 1989; Ord. No. CC-2006-1742, § 1, 2-7-06) 
Editor's note- Section 2 of Ord. No. CC-2006-1742 provided that said amendment is done nunc pro tunc to February 21, 1989 to reflect the original intent of the council at that time. 
Sec. 16-62. - Findings to support rates. 
    The common council does hereby expressly agree to provide sufficient findings to support the fair, nondiscriminatory, reasonable and just rate adjustments to be charged by the water department. Such findings shall consist of financial reports indicating a financial need for a rate adjustment. 
(Code 1979, § 13.18.020; Ord. No. 1399, § 2, 1989) 
Sec. 16-63. - Procedures. 
    Rates and charges to be collected by the water department can only be implemented after the public is allowed to remonstrate at a public hearing and only after approval by ordinance by the common council. The following procedures must be followed by the common council when adopting ordinances establishing rates and charges to be collected by the water department: 
(1)  At least 30 days before the final vote of an ordinance adjusting rates to be charged by the water department, the council shall mail written notice of the meeting to all rate payers of the utility. Such notice shall have the time, date and location of the meeting and invite rate payers to attend and to express their views. 
(2)  Notice of the meeting at which final consideration of any rate adjusting ordinance is to be considered must be published at least twice prior to the meeting. Such notice shall have the time, date and location of the meeting and should invite all interested citizens and rate payers to attend and express their views of the rate adjustments. Publication should be in a newspaper of general circulation within the city. 
(3)  Copies of the proposed ordinance adjusting rates shall be posted in three locations within the city: the city hall, the public library, and the police department. 
(Code 1979, § 13.18.030; Ord. No. 1399, § 3, 1989) 
Sec. 16-64. - Review of commission and court rulings. 
    It is the express desire of the common council that the legal department constantly monitor rulings and decisions of the state utility regulatory commission and applicable court decisions to ensure that the procedures and methods used by the common council and the water department to establish and adopt rates are current, lawful, and in the best interests of the rate payers and citizens of the city. 
(Code 1979, § 13.18.040; Ord. No. 1399, § 4, 1989) 
Secs. 16-65-16-75. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - RATES
