(15)  That the parade or motorcade continue to move at a fixed rate of speed and that any willful delay or willful stopping of the parade or motorcade, except when reasonably required for the safe and orderly conduct of the parade or motorcade, shall constitute a violation of the permit. 
(16)  Such other requirements as are found by the chief of police to be reasonably necessary for the protection of persons or property. 
All conditions of the permit shall be complied with so far as reasonably practicable. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1495, § 10.07.070, 12-7-93) 
Sec. 17-291. - Appeal procedure. 
(a)  Upon a denial by the chief of police of an application made pursuant to section 17-288, the applicant may appeal from the determination of the chief of police within five days thereafter to the city council by filing a written notice of appeal for hearing by the city council at its next meeting. Upon such appeal the city council may reverse, affirm, or modify in any regard the determination of the chief of police. 
(b)  If an application is not filed within the required time, as specified in section 17-288, the applicant may request a waiver of such requirement by the city council at its next regular meeting, or at a special meeting which may be called prior thereto by the city council to consider such matter, and the city council, if it finds unusual circumstances and in the exercise of its sound discretion, may waive such requirement. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1495, § 10.07.080, 12-7-93) 
Sec. 17-292. - Officials to be notified. 
    Immediately upon the granting of a permit for a parade or motorcade, the chief of police shall send a copy thereof to the following: 
(1)  The mayor. 
(2)  The fire chief. 
(3)  The street commissioner. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1495, § 10.07.090, 12-7-93) 
Sec. 17-293. - Revocation. 
    Any permit for a parade or motorcade issued pursuant to this chapter may be summarily revoked by the chief of police at any time when by reason of disaster, public calamity, riot or other emergency, the chief of police determines that the safety of the public or property requires such revocation. Notice of such action revoking a permit shall be delivered in writing to the permittee by personal service or by certified mail. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1495, § 10.07.100, 12-7-93) 
Secs. 17-294-17-325. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - SPECIAL STOPS OR YIELD RIGHT-OF-WAY[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
State Law reference- Power of city to designate through highways and stop intersections, IC 9-4-1-28(a)(6); special stops, IC 9-4-1-106 et seq. 

Sec. 17-326. - Stop signs. 
(a)  When stop signs are erected upon streets intersecting a through street, at the entrances thereto or at the entrance to any intersection so designated in the traffic code, every driver of a vehicle shall stop at every sign or at a clearly marked stop line before entering the intersection. 
(b)  When stop signs are erected upon all four streets at any intersection so designated in the traffic code, every vehicle shall stop at every sign or at a clearly marked stop line before entering the intersection. The first vehicle reaching an intersection shall, after stopping, have the right-of-way to proceed. 
(c)  No driver shall enter an intersection or a marked crosswalk unless there is sufficient space on the other side of the intersection or crosswalk to accommodate the vehicle he is operating without obstructing the passage of other vehicles or pedestrians, notwithstanding any traffic control signal indication to proceed. 
(d)  When stop signs are erected upon three streets at any intersection so designated in the traffic code, every vehicle shall stop at every sign or at a clearly marked stop line before entering the intersection. The first vehicle reaching an intersection shall, after stopping, have the right-of-way to proceed. 
(Code 1962, § 24-148; Code 1979, § 10.20.020; Ord. No. CC 93-1493, § 10.04.180, 12-7-93; Ord. No. CC-97-1554, § 1, 4-15-97) 
Sec. 17-327. - Yield right-of-way signs. 
    When yield right-of-way signs are erected at any intersection designated in the traffic code, every vehicle approaching such a sign shall reduce its speed to ten miles per hour and may proceed through the intersection if it can do so without danger of collision with any vehicle approaching an intersecting street. If there is a danger of collision with an approaching vehicle then the vehicle approaching the yield right-of-way sign shall reduce its speed or stop to allow the vehicle to clear the intersection. 
(Code 1962, § 24-150; Code 1979, § 10.20.040; Ord. No. CC 93-1493, § 10.04.190, 12-7-93) 
Sec. 17-328. - Through streets. 
(a)  Those streets and parts of streets as designated in schedules contained in ordinances governing the traffic code are declared to be through streets for the purpose of this section. Through streets shall have the right-of-way over all other streets, except intersecting through streets, in which case the state law governing rights-of-way shall govern unless the right-of-way at an intersection is governed by traffic signals or stop signs under the traffic code. 
(b)  Whenever any ordinance of this city designates and describes a through street, it shall be the duty of the police department to place and maintain a stop sign on each and every street intersecting such through street unless otherwise provided by the traffic code. 
(Code 1962, § 24-147; Code 1979, § 10.20.010) 
Secs. 17-329-17-360. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XI. - PARKING[8] 
Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
State Law reference- Power of city to regulate parking, IC 9-4-1-28(a)(1); stopping, standing and parking, IC 9-4-1-112 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 17-361. - Methods designated. 
(a)  Parallel parking. Except where angle parking is permitted by the traffic code, parallel parking shall be executed throughout the city. A vehicle stopped or parked upon a city street shall be stopped or parked with the wheels of the vehicle parallel with and within 12 inches of the curb. 
(b)  Angle parking. Angle parking in the city is prohibited except on the streets and places designated in schedules contained in ordinances governing the traffic code. 
(Code 1962, § 24-106; Code 1979, § 10.28.010; Ord. No. CC 93-1492, § 10.28.010, 12-7-93) 
Sec. 17-362. - Parking for more than 24 hours on a public street. 
(a)  Using the public streets of the city for purposes of storing vehicles or parking vehicles for a period of time exceeding 24 consecutive hours shall be deemed a violation of this division. 
(b)  Any person who desires or needs to park a motor vehicle upon any public street in the city for a period of time exceeding 24 consecutive hours may do so and not be deemed in violation of this division provided that the person notifies the police department. Prior to granting a waiver of the 24 consecutive hour time restriction, the police department shall be required to determine that: 
(1)  The safety of the persons traveling on the street upon which it is desired to park such motor vehicle will not be endangered. 
(2)  The reasons stated for parking a motor vehicle more than 24 consecutive hours are such that the granting of a waiver is necessary and reasonable. 
(3)  There is no other location in which the motor vehicle could be parked for such a period and which request to relocate the vehicle is reasonable to the owner. 
(c)  Upon determining that a waiver is justified, the police department shall record for its records the name, address and telephone phone number of the person seeking a waiver along with a detailed description of the vehicle involved. The police department shall be charged with the responsibility of determining that the waiver is enforced and upon expiration, that the vehicle is removed from the location. 
(d)  Exceptions to the 24-hour parking restriction are any properly licensed and plated motor vehicles that are mechanically sound and operable and are owned or registered to a residential property owner and parked on the street area directly in front of said property. 
(Code 1962, § 24-128; Code 1979, § 10.28.070; Ord. No. CC 93-1492, § 10.28.080, 12-7-93; Ord. No. CC-2002-1621, § A3, 5-8-02) 
Sec. 17-362A. - License plates; required. 
    Parking a motor vehicle anywhere within the boundaries of the City of Whiting without current (non-expired) state issued motor vehicle license plates attached is prohibited. An exception to this provision shall be a vehicle that is not in public view by virtue of being stored in an enclosed garage or shelter. 
(Ord. No. CC-2002-1621, § B1, 5-8-02; Ord. No. CC-2004-1689, 10-19-04) 
Sec. 17-362B. - Defective vehicles. 
(a)  Parking a motor vehicle, in which a defect, mechanical problems or leak is causing any automotive or mechanical fluids or oils to be released to the pavement on any public street, right-of-way, sidewalk, alley or other public property, is prohibited. 
(b)  Parking a motor vehicle which is inoperable for longer than 48 hours anywhere within the boundaries of the City of Whiting is prohibited. An exception to this provision shall be a vehicle that is not in public view by virtue of being stored in an enclosed garage or shelter. 
(c)  Storing motor vehicles parts or components of any kind for longer than 48 hours anywhere within the boundaries of the City of Whiting is prohibited. An exception to this provision shall be any motor vehicle parts or components that are not in public view by virtue or being stored in an enclosed garage or shelter. 
(Ord. No. CC-2002-1621, § B2, 5-8-02; Ord. No. CC-2004-1689, 10-19-04) 
Sec. 17-363. - Time limits on certain streets. 
    When signs are erected in a block giving notice thereof, no person shall park a vehicle for longer than the time indicated on the sign between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. of any day, except Sundays and legal holidays. Streets subject to parking time limits shall be designated as such in the traffic code. 
(Code 1962, §§ 24-130-24-132; Code 1979, §§ 10.28.090-10.28.110; Ord. No. CC 93-1492, § 10.28.070, 12-7-93) 
Sec. 17-364. - Designated prohibited parking provisions. 
(a)  No person shall stop or park a vehicle, except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic, or in compliance with a law or the directions of a police officer or traffic control device, in any of the following places: 
(1)  On any sidewalk or parkway. 
(2)  In front of a public or private driveway. 
(3)  Within an intersection. 
(4)  On a crosswalk. 
(5)  Within ten feet of a crosswalk or any intersection. 
(6)  Within four feet of either side of a fire hydrant. 
(7)  Within ten feet of a traffic control signal, beacon or sign of the approaching side. 
(8)  At any place where an official sign prohibits parking, stopping or standing. 
(9)  Alongside or opposite any street excavation or obstruction when stopping, standing or parking would obstruct traffic. 
(10)  Within six feet of a driveway entrance to any fire department station and on the side opposite the entrance to any such station within 75 feet of such entrance. 
(11)  Within ten feet of the nearest rail of a railroad grade crossing. 
(12)  a.  Parking is prohibited in any area designated by a yellow curb line except for City of Whiting emergency vehicles or other city vehicles on official city business. 
b.  It shall be the duty of the Chief of Police of the City of Whiting and/or his/her designee to: 
1.  Identify the need for a yellow painted curb designating a restricted parking area; 
2.  Identify the need for the removal of an unlawful or unnecessary yellow painted curb; 
3.  Submit a written request for approval to designate or remove any yellow painted curb to the common council for its approval by simple majority vote; 
4.  Upon approval of the common council, authorize the painting or removal of a yellow painted curb; 
5.  Record and identify the locations of authorized and approved yellow painted curb parking restrictions and make said list available as a matter of public record. 
(b)  No person shall park any vehicle upon a street or in an alley under such conditions as to create a traffic hazard. For purposes of this section, a traffic hazard will be deemed to exist when the vehicle is parked in such a fashion as to impede normal vehicle traffic through the street or alley or the vehicle blocks the driveway entrance to any abutting property. 
(c)  No person shall stand or park a vehicle upon any roadway, sidewalk or parkway for the principal purpose of: 
(1)  Displaying it for sale. 
(2)  Repair or installing devices except in those instances involving emergency repairs. 
(3)  Selling merchandise therefrom unless authorized by proper permits. 
(d)  No person shall park a non-conforming vehicle in an area that is designated for restricted parking as follows: 
(1)  No truck, van or SUV parking. 
(2)  Compact cars only. 
(Code 1962, § 24-143; Ord. No. 1192, § 1, 1977; Code 1979, §§ 10.28.120, 10.28.170; Ord. No. CC 93-1492, § 10.28.40, 12-7-93; Ord. No. CC-2001-1610, § 1, 10-2-01; Ord. No. CC-2002-1623, § 1, 7-2-02; Ord. No. CC-2004-1689, 10-19-04; Ord. No. CC-2006-1749, §§ 1-4, 6-6-06) 
Sec. 17-365. - Presumption in reference to illegal parking. 
    In any prosecution charging a violation of any provision of any law or regulation governing the parking or standing of a vehicle, proof that the particular vehicle described in the notice to appear was parked in violation of any such law or regulation, together with proof that the defendant named in the complaint was at the time of such violation the registered owner of such vehicle, will constitute prima facie evidence that such registered owner was the person who parked such vehicle at the time and place and for the time during which such violation occurred. 
(Code 1962, § 24-161; Code 1979, § 10.28.160; Ord. No. CC 93-1492, § 10.28.090, 12-7-93) 
Sec. 17-366. - Trailer, camper, motor home and boat parking prohibition. 
(a)  It shall be a violation of this division for any person to park, store or permit to be parked or stored, any motor home, trailer, camper, canopy, boat and boat trailer, bus camper, bus and/or house trailer on any street, alley or right-of-way in the city for any period of time other than for a temporary period of time. For the purposes of this section, a temporary time period shall not exceed four hours. An exception to this provision is a legally parked construction trailer located at a construction site where a valid building, electrical or demolition permit has been issued where the temporary time period shall not exceed ten hours. 
(b)  The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Boat means any structure designed to float and operate on waterways. 
    Camper means a structure designed to be mounted upon a vehicle, usually a truck, which provides facilities for human habitation or for temporary outdoor or recreational lodging. 
    Canopy means a structure designed to be mounted upon a vehicle, usually a truck, which provides security or shelter for things or persons under the structure that is the canopy. 
    Motor home means a motorized vehicle originally designed, reconstructed or permanently altered to provide facilities for human habitation. 
    Trailer means a nonmotorized vehicle designed for being drawn by or used in conjunction with a motorized vehicle. 
(c)  Parking a trailer, camper or motor home anywhere within the boundaries of the City of Whiting without the appropriate current (non-expired) state issued license plates attached is prohibited. An exception to this provision shall be any vehicle that is not in public view by virtue of being stored in an enclosed garage or shelter. 
(Ord. No. 1190, § 1, 1977; Ord. No. 1242, 1979; Code 1979, § 10.28.190; Ord. No. CC 93-1492, § 10.28.040, 12-7-93; Ord. No. CC-2002-1621, § A4, 5-8-02; Ord. No. CC-2004-1689, 10-19-04) 
Sec. 17-367. - Beach parking prohibition. 
(a)  Beach parking is prohibited on any city street and is only permitted at Whihala Beach, in the Whiting Lakefront Park, or any other public area specifically designated by the city upon payment of the designated fee(s). 
(b)  Any vehicle which parks on a city street for the sole purpose of using the beach may and/or will be towed by any police officer of the city or may be issued a parking violation notice by any police officer of the city, code enforcement officer, parking enforcement officer, or any other duly authorized enforcement officer of the city. 
(c)  The fine for a violation of the beach parking prohibition shall be $200.00 for the first offense and $500.00 for each subsequent offense. Any vehicle deemed in violation of this provision may be towed pursuant to the authority of a city police officer. A violator shall have 30 days to either pay the ticket or request a court date in the Whiting City Court in order to protest the ticket. A late fee of $25.00 may be added after every 30 days of non-payment from the original date of issuance of the violation. 
(Ord. No. CC-2011-1852, § 3, 6-7-11; Ord. No. CC-2012-1874, § 1, 5-1-12; Ord. No. CC-2012-1879, § 1, 7-10-12; Ord. No. CC-2015-1933, § 1, 5-19-15; Ord. No. CC-2018-1987, § 1, 8-7-18) 
Sec. 17-368. - Prohibition of parking of semitractors, semitrailers, trucks and school buses. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to park any semitractor, semitrailer or truck exceeding five tons or any school bus on the streets of any residential area. Streets subject to parking time limits shall be designated as such in the traffic code. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1492, § 10.28.060, 12-7-93; Ord. No. CC-2006-1751, § 2, 6-6-06) 
Sec. 17-369. - Parking prohibited during certain hours and on certain streets. 
    When signs are erected in each block giving notice thereof, no person shall park a vehicle between the hours specified or days specified in schedules contained in ordinances governing the traffic code, on any day except Saturday, Sunday and legal holidays within the district, or upon the streets described in such schedules. 
(Code 1962, § 24-129; Code 1979, § 10.28.080; Ord. No. CC-97-1554, § 5, 4-15-97) 
Sec. 17-370. - Bus loading zones designated. 
    The areas and portions of streets and highways as set out in schedules contained in ordinances governing the traffic code shall be known as bus loading zones. 
(Code 1962, § 24-134; Code 1979, § 10.32.010) 
Sec. 17-371. - Taxi loading zones designated. 
    The areas and portions of streets and highways as designated in schedules contained in ordinances governing the traffic code, shall be known as taxi loading zones. 
(Code 1962, § 24-138; Code 1979, § 10.32.050) 
Sec. 17-372. - Freight loading zones designated. 
    The areas and portions of streets and highways as designated in schedules contained in ordinances governing the traffic code shall be known as permanent freight loading zones, and no person shall stop and park a vehicle for any purpose or for any period of time in any such zone except for the expeditious loading or unloading of freight and merchandise. 
(Code 1962, § 24-142; Code 1979, § 10.32.090; Ord. No. CC-2002-1621, § A6, 5-8-02) 
Sec. 17-372A. - Temporary freight loading zones designated. 
    The areas and portions of streets and highways as designated in schedules contained in ordinances governing the traffic code shall be known as temporary freight loading zones, and no person shall stop and park a vehicle for any purpose during the hours of 7:00 a.m. through 6:00 p.m. in any such zone except for the expeditious loading or unloading of freight and merchandise. 
(Ord. No. CC-97-1554, § 9, 4-15-97; Ord. No. CC-2004-1689, 10-19-04) 
Sec. 17-372B. - Permanent passenger loading zones designated. 
    The areas and portions of streets and highways as designated in schedules contained in ordinances governing the traffic code shall be known as permanent passenger loading zones and no person shall stop and park a vehicle for any purpose or for any period of time in any such zone except for the expeditious loading or unloading of passengers. 
(Ord. No. CC-99-1588, § A, 11-16-99) 
Sec. 17-373. - Night parking prohibited on certain streets. 
    No person shall park a vehicle on any of the streets or parts of streets described in schedules contained in ordinances governing the traffic code between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 7:00 a.m., except physicians on emergency calls and except on Saturday, Sunday and holidays. 
(Code 1962, § 24-146; Code 1979, § 10.28.150; Ord. No. CC-2002-1621, § A7, 5-8-02) 
Sec. 17-374. - Notice on vehicles in violation of regulations. 
    Whenever any motor vehicle with or without a driver is found parked or stopped in violation of any of the restrictions imposed by the traffic code or other ordinances relating to traffic, the officer finding such vehicle shall take its registration number and any other information displayed on such vehicle which may identify its owner or user, and shall conspicuously affix to such vehicle a notice in writing on forms provided by the city clerk-treasurer for the driver to answer to the charge against him within 72 hours, during the hours and at the place specified in the notice. The officer shall send one copy of such notice to the traffic captain and one copy to the administrator of the city court for appropriate filing action. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1492, § 10.28.100, 12-7-93) 
Sec. 17-375. - Penalty. 
    Any vehicle deemed in violation of any provision of this division may be towed pursuant to the authority of a city police officer. Any violation of a provision of this division is subject to a fine of $100.00 unless a different fine is specified for that specific violation. A violator shall have 30 days to either pay the ticket or request a court date in the Whiting City Court in order to protest the ticket. A late fee of $25.00 may be added after every 30 days of non-payment from the original date of issuance of the violation. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1492, § 10.28.110, 12-7-93; Ord. No. CC-2002-1621, § A8, 5-8-02; Ord. No. CC-2015-1933, § 2, 5-19-15) 
Secs. 17-376-17-390. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - PARKING FOR PERSONS WITH A PHYSICAL DISABILITY[9] 

Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. CC-2014-1919, § 1, adopted Oct. 7, 2014, provides that all current handicapped parking permits issued for a specific residence will be revoked and all permit holders must reapply under the revised ordinance procedures. Current permit holders shall have 60 days from date of passage of this ordinance in which to reapply for a handicapped parking permit at a specific residence.   Subsequently, § 2 of said ordinance changed the title of Div. 2 from "Handicap Parking" to read as herein set out. 
State Law reference- Parking facilities for physically handicapped persons, IC 4-28-10-24, 5-16-9-1 et seq. 

Sec. 17-391. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates different meaning: 
    Motor vehicle has the meaning set forth in IC 9-13-2-105. 
    Person with a physical disability means a person who has been issued a placard under IC 9-14-5 or a person with a disability registration plate for a motor vehicle by the bureau of motor vehicles under IC 9-18-22. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1491, § 10.30.010(B), (C), 12-7-93; Ord. No. CC-2014-1919, § 3, 10-7-14) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 17-392. - Spaces in private or public parking facilities. 
(a)  Location of handicap parking spaces. 
(1)  Handicap parking spaces serving a particular building shall be accessible. Designated handicap parking spaces and shall be located in parking facilities serving a particular building on the shortest accessible route of travel from the adjacent parking facilities to an accessible entrance of the particular building that the parking facility serves. 
(2)  In buildings with multiple handicap accessible entrances with adjacent parking, accessible handicap parking spaces shall be dispersed and located closest to the accessible entrances. 
(3)  In such cases where parking facilities do not serve a particular building, accessible handicap parking spaces shall be designated and located in the parking facilities on the shortest accessible route of travel to an accessible pedestrian entrance of the parking facility. 
(4)  There shall also be provided handicap parking spaces at various locations throughout the city's commercial business district (CBD), which shall be defined as the area of 119th Street from Ohio and Schrage Avenues on the east to Atchison Avenue on the west. Handicap parking spaces located along the commercial business district shall be: 
a.  Clearly identified by the international handicapped symbol. 
b.  Designated as reserved handicap parking spaces in the traffic code. 
c.  Located closest to accessible entrances of stores along the commercial business district. 
(b)  The size of handicap parking spaces shall be as follows: 
(1)  Accessible, designated handicap parking spaces shall be a minimum of eight feet or 96 inches in width. 
(2)  Accessible, designated handicap parking spaces shall be a minimum of 20 feet in length. 
(3)  Accessible, designated handicap parking spaces shall have a passenger loading zone which shall provide a reserved accessible aisle of at least five feet or 60 inches in width along the length of the handicap parking space. Handicap parking space passenger loading zones may be central to two handicap parking spaces so that each may utilize the loading zone. 
(c)  The minimum number of designated or reserved handicap parking spaces for a particular parking facility shall be as follows: 
(1)  In a parking facility serving a particular building, accessible designated handicap parking spaces shall be reserved in the following manner: 
Total Number of Parking 
Spaces in Facility Minimum Number 
of Spaces 1-25 1 25-50 2 50-100 3 101+ 4 percent 
of the total spaces  
(2)  In a parking facility not serving a particular building, four percent of the total parking spaces, rounded to next whole number, shall be reserved and designated as handicap parking spaces. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1491, § 10.30.020, 12-7-93) 
Sec. 17-393. - Spaces on residential streets. 
(a)  The board of public works and safety is hereby authorized and empowered to grant to an eligible person with a physical disability as defined herein the exclusive use of a parking space adjacent to or directly in front of the person's place of residence. 
(b)  Residents meeting the definition of a person with a physical disability may apply for the special parking privilege by completing the application available at the office of the city clerk-treasurer and returning said form. The application must contain a copy of the person's handicapped placard issued under IC 9-14-5 or a copy of the disability registration license plate for the motor vehicle issued under IC 9-18-22. 
(c)  The grant of the reserved parking space shall be in effect for two years from the date of issuance by the board of public works and safety. An applicant will be required to reapply, subject to continued eligibility, every two years for the reserved parking space permit. 
(d)  Upon receipt of an application for a reserved parking space for a person with a disability on a residential street, the board shall review the application and grant or deny the application within 30 business days of receipt thereof. 
(e)  Permits are subject to the following conditions: 
(1)  No more than one space may be reserved at the applicant's place of residence. 
(2)  No applicant shall be granted a reserved space if the applicant has access to off-street parking at the applicant's place of residence unless special circumstances as determined by the board of public works justify the request. 
(f)  Each reserved space shall be assigned an identification number. 
(g)  Upon the granting of the reserved space, the board shall: 
(1)  Issue to the applicant a reserved parking permit with the identification number; 
(2)  Mark the reserved space with distinctive painting on the curb; 
(3)  Install a sign restricting the use of the space to the permit holder only and said sign shall contain the permit number. 
(h)  The permit holder shall: 
(1)  Display the permit issued by the board in the windshield of the vehicle which was issued the placard or disability registration plate by the bureau of motor vehicles; 
(2)  Promptly notify the board when the applicant changes vehicles, no longer has been issued the placard or disability registration plate, no longer has a vehicle registered to the premises or when any other circumstances have changed and the reserved space is no longer required. 
(i)  The board shall maintain a log which shall contain the following information: 
(1)  Address to which reserved permit has been issued; 
(2)  Placard or plate number justifying issuance of permit; 
(3)  Expiration of permit. 
(j)  Permits may be revoked and signage removed upon any of the following: 
(1)  Death of the permit holder; 
(2)  Failure to provide current placard or disability plate registration information; 
(3)  Submission of a fraudulent application for a reserved permit. 
(4)  Repeated parking of the placarded vehicle in parking spots other than the reserved space. 
(k)  In the event a business, school, church or other non-profit organization (hereinafter referred to as "agency") determines that handicapped parking on the residential street adjacent to the facility is needed for the use of the agency, said agency may make application to the chief of police for the placement of up to two handicapped parking only signs. 
(l)  The chief of police or his/her designee shall review the application and determine the following: 
(1)  Is the reserved parking requested by the agency needed at that location; 
(2)  Is there sufficient space on the residential street to place the reserved parking; 
(3)  Should there be time limitations to the parking designation; 
(m)  Once the chief of police or his/her designee completes his/her review, s/he should make written recommendation to the common council as to whether the request for reserved handicapped parking should be granted and if time limitations should be imposed. 
(n)  Upon receipt of the recommendation of the chief, the common council shall act upon the request by resolution. 
(o)  If the request is granted, the location of the reserved parking shall be added to Whiting Municipal Code Section 17-667, Schedule 22-Handicapped parking spaces. 
(p)  In the event the request is denied, the agency shall have the right to appeal to the board of public works and safety within 30 business days of the action denying the request to have the matter reviewed. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1491, § 10.30.020, 12-7-93; Ord. No. CC-2002-1621, § A9, 5-8-02; Ord. No. CC-2004-1689, 10-19-04; Ord. No. CC-2006-1750, § 2, 6-6-06; Ord. No. CC-2014-1919, § 4, 10-7-14) 
Sec. 17-394. - Unauthorized use of space. 
(a)  No person except a person driving pursuant to a handicap parking permit shall park any motor vehicle in any parking space designated and reserved for a handicapped person. 
(b)  This section shall apply not only to handicap parking spaces reserved on public streets, but also in parking lots owned or operated by the city as well as in all private parking areas in the city. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1491, § 10.30.030, 12-7-93) 
Sec. 17-395. - Permit issued by another state. 
    Any handicapped driver exhibiting a handicap parking permit issued by another state may park a vehicle in a handicap parking space reserved for handicap vehicles in both private and public parking facilities. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1491, § 10.30.040, 12-7-93) 
Sec. 17-396. - Penalty. 
(a)  Any vehicle deemed in violation of any provision of this division may be impounded pursuant to the towing ordinance then in effect for the city with the costs of towing and storage the responsibility of the vehicle's owner of record. 
(b)  Any person violating any provision of this ordinance shall be fined the sum of $200.00 for the first violation and $400.00 for any subsequent violation. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1491, § 10.30.050, 12-7-93; Ord. No. CC-2005-1732, § 1, 9-6-05; Ord. No. CC-2006-1750, § 1, 6-6-06) 
Secs. 17-397-17-425. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - SNOW REMOVAL ROUTES[10] 

Footnotes: 
--- (10) --- 
Editor's note- A former section pertaining to snow removal was derived from Code 1962, § 24-127(b); Code 1979, § 10.28.060. This division is also deemed to supersede Code 1979, § 10.80.220; Ord. No. 1397, 1989. 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 15. 

Sec. 17-426. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Primary snow removal route means both sides of 119th Street from Ohio and Schrage Avenues to Atchison Avenue. 
    Secondary snow removal route means both sides of Ohio Avenue from 119th Street to Oliver Street, both sides of Oliver Street from Ohio Street to 117th Street, both sides of Schrage Avenue from 119th Street to 129th Street, both sides of New York Avenue from Ohio to the corporate limits of the city (south of Steiber Street), both sides of 119th Street from Schrage and Ohio Avenues to Front Street, both sides of 117th Street from Atchison Avenue to the entrance of Whiting Park, both sides of 121st Street from Schrage Avenue to Indianapolis Boulevard, including the north side of 121st Street from Indianapolis Boulevard to Atchison Avenue. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1490, § 10.29.010(A), (B), 12-7-93) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 17-427. - Parking regulations on primary snow removal route. 
(a)  Signs. The street commissioner is hereby authorized to post snow removal route signs on primary snow removal routes designating such street as a snow removal route. All parking regulations for such routes shall be in effect from November 1 through and including April 30 of the following year. 
(b)  Restrictions. No vehicle may park in a designated primary snow removal route when snow exceeds two inches during the hours of 7:00 p.m. through 7:00 a.m. of the following morning. Any vehicle parked in such snow removal routes when snow exceeds two inches is in violation of this division and may be towed upon order of the street commissioner pursuant to the provisions of the towing ordinance of the city in effect. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1490, § 10.29.020, 12-7-93; Ord. No. CC-2008-1803, § 1, 11-18-2008; Ord. No. CC-2008-1803, § 1, 11-18-08) 
Sec. 17-428. - Parking regulations on secondary snow removal route. 
(a)  Declaration by mayor. Whenever the mayor finds, on the basis of falling snow, sleet or freezing rain, or on the basis of a forecast by the United States Weather Service or other weather service of snow, sleet, or freezing rain that weather conditions will make it necessary that motor vehicle traffic be expedited and that parking on streets designated as secondary snow removal route streets be prohibited or restricted for snow plowing and other purposes, the mayor shall put into effect a parking prohibition as necessary by declaring it in effect. 
(b)  Restrictions. Once in effect, a parking prohibition or restriction under this section shall remain in effect until terminated by announcement of the mayor in accordance with this division, except that any street area which has become substantially clear of snow and ice from curb to curb for the length of the entire block shall be automatically excluded there from. While the prohibition is in effect, no person shall park or allow to remain parked any vehicle on any portion of a secondary snow removal route to which it applies. While the prohibition is in effect, no person shall park or allow to remain parked any vehicle on any secondary snow removal route during the time of 7:00 p.m. until 7:00 a.m. of the following day. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1490, § 10.29.030, 12-7-93; Ord. No. CC-2008-1803, § 2, 11-18-2008; Ord. No. CC-2008-1803, § 2, 11-18-08) 
Sec. 17-429. - Citywide snow emergency. 
(a)  Whenever the mayor finds, on the basis of falling snow, sleet or freezing rain, or on the basis of a forecast by the United States Weather Service or other weather service of snow, sleet or freezing rain that weather conditions will make it necessary that motor vehicle traffic be expedited and that parking on city streets other than those designated as primary or secondary snow removal routes be prohibited or restricted for snow plowing and other purposes, the mayor shall declare that a snow emergency exists. 
(b)  Upon such declaration by the mayor, the street commissioner, with assistance from the police department, shall be empowered to implement such parking restrictions as necessary to effectively clear all affected streets. The street commissioner shall have authority to order that vehicles in violation of a parking prohibition in effect as a result of citywide snow emergency be impounded in accordance with the provisions of the city's towing ordinance then in effect, with the owners of the vehicle responsible for the cost of towing and the cost of storage of any impounded vehicles. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1490, § 10.29.040, 12-7-93) 
Sec. 17-430. - Provisions temporarily effective to take precedence. 
    Any provision of this division which becomes effective by declaration of the mayor or upon the occurrence of certain weather conditions shall, while temporarily in effect, take precedence over other conflicting provisions of law normally in effect, except that it shall not take precedence over provisions of law relating to traffic accidents, emergency travel of authorized emergency vehicles or emergency traffic directions by a police officer. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1490, § 10.29.050, 12-7-93) 
Sec. 17-431. - Methods of mayoral declarations. 
(a)  Mayor declaration. When deemed necessary under the applicable sections of this division, mayoral declarations shall be publicly announced by means of broadcasts or telecasts from stations with a normal operating range covering the city, and the mayor may cause such declaration to be further announced in newspapers of general circulation whenever feasible. Additionally, members of the police department may be used to personally deliver notice of such declarations via police loudspeakers or door-to-door contacts. Each announcement shall describe the action taken by the mayor, including the time it became or will become effective, and shall specify the streets or areas affected. A parking prohibition or restriction declared by the mayor shall specify whether it is applicable to secondary snow removal routes or whether a citywide emergency is in effect. Such prohibitions or restrictions shall not go into effect until at least two hours after they have been announced on any day; provided, however, that one announcement in a newspaper of general circulation shall be sufficient. 
(b)  Record. The mayor shall make or cause to be made a record of each time and date when any declaration is announced to the public in accordance with this division. Such record shall be made at the next regular board of public works and safety meeting in the city. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1490, § 10.29.060, 12-7-93; Ord. No. CC-2002-1621, § A10, 5-8-02) 
Sec. 17-432. - Evidence with respect to vehicles parked or left in violation of division. 
    In any prosecution with regard to a vehicle parked or left in a place or in a condition in violation of any provision of this division, proof that the particular vehicle described in the complaint was parked or left in violation of a provision of this division, together with proof that the defendant named in the complaint was at the time the registered owner of such vehicle, shall constitute prima facie evidence that the defendant was the person who parked or left the vehicle in violation of this division. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1490, § 10.29.060, 12-7-93) 
Sec. 17-433. - Official snow removal map. 
    An official map, formally approved by the board of public works and safety, designating primary and secondary snow removal routes shall be kept on file with the street commissioner. 

(Ord. No. CC-93-14-0, § 10.29.070, 12-7-93; Ord. No. CC-2002-1621, § A11, 5-8-02) 
Sec. 17-434. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating any provisions of this division shall be fined not less than $100.00 and not more than $2,500.00 for each offense; and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. Any parking violation requiring impounding of a vehicle is a separate offense from this penalty provision. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1490, § 10.29.080, 12-7-93) 
Secs. 17-435-17-450. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - STREET CLEANING[11] 

Footnotes: 
--- (11) --- 
Cross reference- Streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 15. 

Sec. 17-451. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Business district means both sides of 119th Street from Atchison Avenue to Ohio and Schrage Avenues. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1502, § 10.12.010(B), 12-7-93) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 17-452. - Establishment and administration of program. 
    Pursuant to the terms of this division, there is hereby established an official street cleaning program within the city that shall be administered by the street commissioner. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1502, § 10.12.020, 12-7-93) 
Sec. 17-453. - Procedures. 
(a)  Locations; times. Street cleaning within the city shall be done pursuant to the following procedures: 
(1)  Weather permitting and assuming that the applicable streets are clear of ice and snow from curb to curb, on Tuesdays of each week, unless the Tuesday is an official legal holiday in which case the cleaning shall be on the next business day, the odd-numbered side (east side) of all streets of the city, except the business district, shall be swept clean. The odd-numbered side of all streets north of 119th Street shall be swept clean between 7:00 a.m. and 11:30 a.m., and the odd-numbered side of all streets south of 119th Street shall be swept clean between 12:30 p.m. and 2:30 p.m. 
(2)  Weather permitting and assuming that the applicable streets are clear of ice and snow from curb to curb, on Thursdays of each week, unless the Thursday is an official legal holiday in which case the cleaning shall be on the next business day, the even-numbered side (west side) of all streets of the city, except the business district shall be swept clean. The even-numbered side of all streets north of 119th Street shall be swept clean between 7:00 a.m. and 11:30 a.m., and the odd-numbered side of all streets south of 119th Street shall be swept clean between 12:30 p.m. and 2:30 p.m. 
(b)  Notification. The street commissioner or his designee shall provide 24 hours' notice to the residents of streets subject to cleaning. Such notice shall be given by any reasonable method, provided that the residents of the affected streets are properly notified. If the scheduled street cleaning is canceled due to inclement weather, the street commissioner shall not be required to notify residents of the cancellation. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1502, § 10.12.030, 12-7-93) 
Sec. 17-454. - Business district cleaning. 
(a)  On Mondays and Wednesdays of each week, the business district shall be swept clean in its entirety from 7:00 a.m. to 7:30 a.m. If a Monday or Wednesday is a legal holiday, such street sweeping shall be canceled for that day and shall resume on the next Monday of Wednesday immediately following the holiday. 
(b)  Passage, notice by subsequent publication, and distribution to residents and businesses within the business district of this division shall serve as notice to all residents and businesses located in the business district of the implementation of this street cleaning program. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1502, § 10.12.040, 12-7-93) 
Sec. 17-455. - Parking prohibition and towing. 
(a)  Any vehicle parked on any street side, scheduled to be swept clean, including the business district, is deemed in violation of this division. Vehicles in violation of the street cleaning parking prohibition may be towed away, or removed upon the direction of the street commissioner and under the supervision of a duly authorized member of the police department pursuant to the provisions of the city's existing towing ordinance then in effect. No person shall recover any vehicle removed pursuant to this division without first paying the cost of removal and the cost of storage. Any payments required by this section shall not be construed as a penalty so as to preclude prosecution for violation of any of the provisions of this section. 
(b)  In any prosecution with regard to a vehicle parked or left in a place or in a condition in violation of any provision of this division, proof that the particular vehicle described in the complaint was parked or left in violation of a provision of this division, together with proof that the defendant named in the complaint was at the time the registered owner of such vehicle, shall constitute prima facie evidence that the defendant was the person who parked or left the vehicle in violation of this division. 
(Code 1962, § 24-127(a); Code 1979, § 10.28.050; Ord. No. CC 93-1502, § 10.12.050, 12-7-93) 
Sec. 17-456. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating any provision of this division shall be fined not less than $25.00 nor more than $2,500.00 for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1502, § 10.12.060, 12-7-93) 
Secs. 17-457-17-485. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XII. - BICYCLES; MOTORCYCLES; MOPEDS; DRIVING ON SIDEWALKS[12] 

Footnotes: 
--- (12) --- 
State Law reference- Power of city to regulate bicycles, IC 9-4-1-28(a)(8); operation of bicycles, IC 9-4-1-93 et seq. 

Sec. 17-486. - Riding bicycles generally. 
    Every person riding a bicycle upon any street shall be subject to the provisions of this chapter applicable to drivers of a vehicle, except those provisions which can have no application to one riding a bicycle. Provided that, except on 119th Street, bicycles may be ridden on the sidewalks when no pedestrians are present. Except where otherwise provided, a bicycle rider has the same right to use any part of a street as does the driver of a motor vehicle. Under no circumstances may a person riding a bicycle on any sidewalk owned and operated by the city operate a bicycle in such a manner that the sidewalk is obstructed, thereby preventing pedestrians from utilizing the sidewalk. 
(Code 1962, § 17-509; Code 1979, § 10.56.010; Ord. No. CC 93-1493, § 10.04.120, 12-7-93) 
Sec. 17-487. - Number of persons riding on bicycle or moped. 
    It shall be unlawful for more than one person to ride upon any bicycle propelled by human power upon any street, or for more than one person to ride upon a moped. This section shall not prohibit two persons riding a bicycle built for two, or a child riding in a secure child seat behind the other person on the bicycle. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1496, § 10.05.230, 1-4-94) 
Sec. 17-488. - Driving motor vehicles on sidewalks. 
    No person shall operate a moped, motorcycle or any other motor vehicle upon or within any public sidewalk area, or upon any sidewalk or upon any bike path or walking lane except to cross it upon a permanent or duly authorized driveway. This prohibition shall not apply to the use of snow removal machines. 
(Code 1962, § 17-509; Code 1979, § 10.56.010; Ord. No. CC 93-1493, § 10.04.140, 12-7-93; Ord. No. CC 93-1513, § 3, 4-19-94) 
Driving vehicle within sidewalk area, § 17-109. 
Secs. 17-489-17-510. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XIII. - ABANDONED VEHICLES 

Sec. 17-511. - Police-ordered towing; board of public works and safety; fees. 
    IC 9-22-1-1 et seq. is incorporated by reference as fully as if set out at length in this article. All police-ordered tows shall occur in accordance with IC 9-22-1-1 et seq. and this section. 
(Code 1979, § 10.68.010; Ord. No. 1352(part), 1986; Ord. No. CC 93-1461, § 1, 3-2-93) 
Sec. 17-512. - Administration by board. 
    The board of public works and safety shall be responsible for administrating all police-ordered towing in accordance with IC 9-22-1-29. 
(Code 1979, § 10.68.020; Ord. No. 1352(part), 1986; Ord. No. CC 93-1461, § 2, 3-2-93) 
Sec. 17-513. - Fees. 
[(a)  Generally.] A towing service performing a police-ordered tow may charge only a reasonable fee for the services, but in no event shall fees exceed the following prescribed maximums: 
(1)  Tow of any vehicle, except for semitrailers, tractors and buses. 
a.  Daytime hours, $85.00. 
b.  After sunset, $85.00. 
(2)  Daily storage of $20.00 per day beginning after the first 24 hours have expired, for which no storage fee shall be charged. 
(3)  Tows where dollies are used, tires have to be replaced, a vehicle is turned over, or a flatbed tow truck is used, $110.00 
(4)  Tow of semitrailers, tractors, buses, etc., $200.00. 
(5)  Daily storage of $35.00 per unit per day for semitrailers, tractors and buses after the first 24 hours have expired, for which no storage fee shall be charged. 
(b)  Administrative fee for towing vehicles. 
(1)  Whenever the Whiting Police Department orders that a vehicle be towed from any location in the city and that vehicle is later claimed by the owner or sold at auction, the designated towing service authorized to tow that vehicle shall assess against the owner of record an administrative fee of $20.00 which shall be collected in addition to any and all other applicable towing charges. 
(2)  The administrative towing fee created by this section shall be added to the towing bill assessed by the authorized towing service as part of the authorized towing bill. 
(3)  The administrative towing fee created by this section shall be forwarded by the authorized towing service to the City of Whiting Clerk-Treasurer within 30 days of vehicle sale date at auction, or within 30 days of release of vehicle. 
(4)  Any administrative fee so received shall be deposited in the city's general fund. 
(c)  Collection of administrative fee by police department. The police department, at its discretion and in lieu of the above language, may choose to collect the towing administrative fee authorized in this section at the police department. In such instance, a receipt shall be given on the prescribed form and funds forwarded to the clerk-treasurer for deposit in accordance with this section. 
(Code 1979, § 10.68.040; Ord. No. 1352(part), 1986; Ord. No. 1393, § 2, 1989; Ord. No. CC 93-1461, § 3, 3-2-93; Ord. No. CC-98-1562, 5-19-98; Ord. No. CC-2002-1621, § A12, 5-8-02; Ord. No. CC-2005-1714, §§ 1-4, 4-19-05; Ord. No. CC-2005-1720, § 1, 7-5-05) 
Secs. 17-514-17-545. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XIV. - RAILROADS 

Sec. 17-546. - Signals. 
(a)  The driver of a vehicle approaching a railroad grade crossing, when a signal device gives warning of the immediate approach of a train, shall stop within 50 feet but not less than ten feet from the nearest track of such railroad and shall not proceed until he can do so safely. 
(b)  The driver of a vehicle shall stop at and not traverse such grade crossing when a crossing gate is lowered or when a flagman or automatic signal warns of the approach of a train. 
(c)  The driver of any motor vehicle carrying passengers for hire, or any school bus carrying any school children, or any vehicle carrying explosives or flammable liquid as cargo, shall stop such vehicle within 50 feet but less than ten feet from the nearest rail of the tracks and shall listen and look in both directions along such track from which a train might come, before proceeding across such tracks at a grade crossing. Provided that no such stop need be made at any such crossing where a police officer directs traffic to proceed. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1496, § 10.05.260, 1-4-94) 
Secs. 17-547-17-575. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XV. - SKATEBOARDS, TOY VEHICLES; NONMOTORIZED DEVICES 

Sec. 17-576. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Business district means that area within the following boundaries: 119th Street, both sides, from Atchison Avenue to Schrage and Ohio Avenues. 
    Skateboard means any board or platform device having at least two axles with wheels at each end of a style commonly occurring on roller skates, or any other similar device, such device intended to be ridden by a person who propels himself by pushing the platform and then riding upon it as it coasts. 
    Toy vehicles means coasters, scooters, roller skates, or any other nonmotorized device with wheels or rollers upon which a person may ride. This definition does not apply, so long as they are used for the purposes for which they are intended, to wagons, wheelchairs and strollers or other devices designed and used for the purpose of transporting children, infants, physically handicapped, or incapacitated persons, or to bicycles, or to carts or other devices intended and used for transporting merchandise or materials. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1498, § 10.08.010, 12-7-93) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 17-577. - Operation on street. 
    No person shall roller skate or operate a skateboard or toy vehicle on a public street if there is a sidewalk adjacent to such street. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1498, § 10.08.020, 12-7-93) 
Sec. 17-578. - Clinging to vehicle. 
    No person operating a skateboard, toy vehicle, or other nonmotorized device shall attach himself to any vehicle upon a roadway. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1498, § 10.08.030, 12-7-93) 
Sec. 17-579. - Yield right-of-way. 
    Any person operating a skateboard or other toy vehicle must yield the right-of-way to any pedestrian or motor vehicle. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1493, § 10.08.040, 12-7-93) 
Sec. 17-580. - Skateboards on private property. 
(a)  No person shall operate a skateboard or toy vehicle on the premises of any business, residence, or other private property in violation of a sign complying with this section. 
(b)  Areas in which skateboarding or operation of a toy vehicle is prohibited must be indicated by one or more signs which are positioned to provide notice and which contain the words "No Skateboarding" or any other word or combination of words indicating that skateboards or operation of a toy vehicle is prohibited. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1493, § 10.08.050, 12-7-93) 
Sec. 17-581. - Skateboard or toy vehicle in business district. 
    No person shall operate a skateboard or toy vehicle within the business district. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1493, § 10.08.060, 12-7-93) 
Sec. 17-582. - Damaging city property. 
    No person shall operate a skateboard or toy vehicle on or against any city-owned property which may suffer damage by such use. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1493, § 10.08.070, 12-7-93) 
Sec. 17-583. - Skateboard ramps. 
    No person shall use or place a ramp, jump, or any other device used to force a skateboard, toy vehicle or an individual wearing any type of skating device, off the pavement on the grounds of any city-owned parking lot, park, sidewalk or a city street, unless the area has been specifically and intentionally designated for such use by the appropriate local authorities. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1493, § 10.08.080, 12-7-93; Ord. No. CC-2002-1621, § A13, 5-8-02) 
Sec. 17-584. - Agreement for impoundment. 
    In place of any other penalty provided by state law or city ordinance, any person violating this article may, for a just offense, agree to have the skateboard or toy vehicle impounded by the police department for one week. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1493, § 10.08.090, 12-7-93) 
Sec. 17-585. - Bicycles not included. 
    The operation of bicycles is covered by other provisions and is not intended to be regulated by this article. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1493, § 10.08.100, 12-7-93) 
Sec. 17-586. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating any provision of this article shall be fined not less than $25.00 nor more than $2,500.00 for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1493, § 10.08.110, 12-7-93) 
Secs. 17-587-17-610. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XVI. - PEDESTRIANS[13] 

Footnotes: 
--- (13) --- 
State Law reference- Pedestrians, IC 9-4-1-86 et seq. 

Sec. 17-611. - Crossing roadway generally. 
(a)  At no place shall a pedestrian cross any roadway other than by the most direct route to the opposite curbing, and when crossing at any place other than a crosswalk he shall yield the right-of-way to all vehicles upon the roadway. 
(b)  No person shall stand or loiter in any roadway other than in a safety zone, if such act interferes with the lawful movement of traffic. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1499, § 10.09.10, 12-7-93) 
Sec. 17-612. - Traffic control signal. 
    At intersections where traffic is directed by a policeman or by a traffic control signal, it shall be unlawful for any pedestrian to cross the roadway other than with released traffic, if such crossing interferes with the lawful movement of traffic. At intersections where there are special pedestrian traffic control signals, pedestrians shall proceed across the intersection only when the signal facing them exhibits the appropriate crossing signal (i.e., either the word "walk" or the universal pedestrian symbol indicated by a person walking). 
(Code 1962, § 24-105; Code 1979, § 10.40.010; Ord. No. CC 93-1499, § 10.09.20, 12-7-93) 
Sec. 17-613. - Standing on sidewalk. 
    It shall be unlawful for a pedestrian to stand upon any sidewalk except as near as reasonably possible to the building line or curb lines, if such standing interferes with the use of the sidewalk by other pedestrians. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1499, § 10.09.30, 12-7-93) 
Sec. 17-614. - Use of crosswalk; yield to vehicle. 
(a)  Between intersections within one block or less of each other, at which traffic control signals are in operation, pedestrians shall not cross at any place except in a crosswalk. 
(b)  In the business district, which is defined as both sides of 119th Street from Atchison Avenue to Schrage and Ohio Avenues, no pedestrians shall cross a roadway other than in a crosswalk. 
(c)  A pedestrian may not suddenly leave a curb or other place of safety and walk or run into the path of a vehicle that is so close as to constitute an immediate hazard. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1499, § 10.09.40, 12-7-93) 
Sec. 17-615. - Walking along or standing in roadway. 
(a)  Where sidewalks are provided, it shall be unlawful for any pedestrian to walk along and upon an adjacent roadway. 
(b)  Where sidewalks are not provided, any pedestrian walking along and upon a highway shall when practicable walk only on the left side of the roadway or its shoulder facing traffic, and upon meeting a vehicle shall step off to the left. 
(c)  No person shall stand in a roadway for the purpose of soliciting a ride from the driver of any vehicle. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1499, § 10.09.50, 12-7-93) 
Sec. 17-616. - Blind pedestrians; right-of-way. 
    Any blind person who is carrying in a raised or extended position a cane or walking stick which is white in color or white tipped with red, or who is being guided by a dog, shall have the right-of-way in crossing any street or highway, whether or not traffic on such street or highway is controlled by traffic signals, anything in this article to the contrary notwithstanding. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1499, § 10.09.60, 12-7-93) 
Sec. 17-617. - Penalty. 
    Any person violating any provision of this article shall be fined not less than $25.00 for each offense nor more than $2,500.00, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Ord. No. CC 93-1499, § 10.09.60, 12-7-93) 
Secs. 17-618-17-645. - Reserved.

APPENDIX A - UNIFIED DEVELOPMENT ORDINANCE[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. CC-2011-1851, § 2, adopted June 21, 2011, repealed the former App. A, §§ 1.1-1.12, 2.1, 2.2, 3.1-3.4, 4.1-4.8, 5.1-5.9, 6.1-6.14, 7.1-7.13, 8.1-8.8, 9.1-9.8, 10.1-10.8, 11.1-11.8. Section 3(Exh. B) of said ordinance enacted a new App. A as set out herein. The former App. A pertained to Unified Zoning and Subdivision Control and derived from Ord. No. CC-2001-1611, adopted Nov. 11, 2001, as amended. Amendments to the ordinance are indicated by parenthetical history notes following amended provisions. The absence of a history note indicates that the provision remains unchanged from the original ordinance. Obvious misspellings and punctuation errors have been corrected without notation. Additions made for clarity are indicated by brackets. 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2; animals, ch. 3; buildings and building regulations, ch. 4; cable communications, ch. 5; smoke prevention and abatement, § 8-76 et seq.; housing, ch. 9; licenses and business regulations, ch. 10; mobile homes, ch. 11; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 15. 

1.0. - DEFINITIONS 

1.1. - General. 
    The definitions contained in this section shall be observed and applied in the interpretation of all sections of this Ordinance, except where the context clearly indicates otherwise. Furthermore, words used in the present tense, singular number, and masculine gender, shall also mean the future, plural, and feminine. 
1.2. - General Zoning Definitions. 
    The following words and terms appearing in this Ordinance shall have the following meanings: 
    Abandonment: The relinquishment of property or a cessation of the use of the property for a continuous period of one (1) year by the owner. 
    Accessory Building, Structure, or Use: A building, structure, or use which: 
a.  Is subordinate to and serves a principal building, structure, or use in area, extent, or purpose. 
b.  Contributes to the comfort, convenience, or necessity of occupants of the principal buildings, structures, or principal uses served. 
c.  Does not alter or change the character of the premises. 
d.  Is located on the same zoning lot as the principal building, structure, or use. 
e.  Conforms to the setback, height, bulk, lot coverage, and other requirements of this Ordinance unless otherwise provided for by this Ordinance. 
f.  May not be constructed prior to the time of construction of the principal building or structure. 
g.  Is not designed for human occupancy as a dwelling or commercial use. 
    Accessory Dwelling Unit: An accessory dwelling that is subordinate to the single-family primary dwelling and shall not be more than forty-five percent (45%) of the square footage of the primary dwelling unit. 
    Administrator, Zoning: The officer appointed by the Mayor and/or delegated the responsibility for the administration of this Ordinance's regulations by the Mayor and Plan Commission. 
    Adult Bookstore: An establishment having as a majority of its stock in trade or its dollar volume in trade, books, magazines, periodicals or other printed matter, or photographs, films, motion pictures, video cassettes, slides, tapes, records, or other forms of electronic conveyance or visual or audio representations which are distinguished or characterized by their emphasis on matter depicting, describing, or relating to sexual activities or sexual anatomical areas. 
    Adult Entertainment Business: An adult bookstore, adult motion picture theater, adult cabaret, or adult live entertainment arcade, or like uses. 
    Advisory Plan Commission: A planning commission serving a single local government jurisdiction established as defined under IC § 36-7-1-2 (1983) as amended. The Whiting Plan Commission is an Advisory Plan Commission. 
    Aesthetics: The pleasantness of the total environment related to the perceptual aspects of the surroundings including their appearance to the eye and the comfort and enjoyment offered to the other senses. 
    Aisle: See "Maneuvering Space." 
    Alley: A public right-of-way, other than a street, road, crosswalk, or easement, that provides secondary access to abutting properties. 
    Animal Hospital/Clinic: See "Veterinary Animal Hospital/Clinic." 
    Animal Shelter: See "Kennel." 
    Annexation: The process by which a municipality may add territory to itself, as specified in IC § 36-4-3-1 to 36-4-3-21, as amended. 
    Apartment: One (1) or more rooms in an apartment building or combination apartment and commercial building, arranged, intended, designed, or occupied on a rental basis as a dwelling unit of a single family, an individual, or a group of individuals. 
    Apartment Building: A multi-family housing structure designed and constructed to accommodate three (3) or more apartments, in contrast to a single or two-family dwellings converted for multi-family use. 
    Applicant: The owner, owners, or legal representative of real estate who makes application to the Plan Commission and/or Board of Zoning Appeals for action by said commission or board affecting the real estate owned thereby. 
    Arterial Street: See "Street, Arterial." 
    Attached Building: A building that is structurally connected to another building by a foundation, wall, or roof line. Carports, garages, porch awnings and the like shall be considered attached buildings and abide by all regulations pertaining to primary buildings. 
    Auto Repair, Major: Engine rebuilding or major reconditioning of worn or damaged motor vehicles or trailers; collision service, including body, frame, or fender straightening or repair; and overall painting of vehicles. 
    Auto Repair, Minor: Incidental repairs, replacement of parts, and motor service to automobiles but excluding any operation specified under "Automobile Repair, Major." 
    Automobile Service Station: Any building or premises used for the dispensing, sale, or offering for sale at retail to the public, automobile fuels stored only in underground tanks and located wholly within the lot lines; lubricating oil or grease for the operation of automobiles; and the sale and installation of tires, batteries, other minor accessories, and minor auto repair, but not including a bulk plant, conducting of major auto repairs, automobile wrecking, automobile sales, or automobile laundries; provided, however, that the washing of individual automobiles where no chain conveyor is employed may be included. 
    Awning: A temporary roof-like cover that projects from the wall of a building and may overhang the public way. 
    Barrier Curb: See "Curb, Barrier." 
    Bed and Breakfast Facility: An owner occupied or owner employee occupied residence containing no more than six (6) guest rooms for hire, for lodging by pre-arrangement for periods not to exceed three (3) consecutive weeks and providing for occasional meals daily (usually breakfast) and not a hotel, boarding, lodging house or motel. 
    Berm: A man-made, formed, earth mound of definite height and width used for landscaping and obscuring purposes, the intent of which is to provide a transition between uses of differing intensity. 
    Bicycle-Compatible Roadway: A road designed to accommodate the shared use of the roadway by bicycles and motor vehicles. 
    Bicycle Lane: A lane at the edge of a roadway reserved and marked for the exclusive use of bicycles. 
    Bicycle Path: A pathway designed to be used by bicyclists. 
    Block: Property abutting on one side of a street and lying between the two (2) nearest intersecting or intercepting streets, intersecting railroad, intersecting waterway, or the end of a dead end street. 
    Block, Improved: A block where twenty-five percent (25%) or more of the lots on the block frontage are occupied by buildings. An Improved Block shall contain at least three (3) lots or parcels, each containing a legally established building. For the purposes of determining front setbacks for new buildings, an Improved Block consists of one (1) side of the street, not interrupted by any streets, alleys, or other rights-of-way. In any case where a proposed building site has no buildings within three hundred (300) feet in either direction on the same side of the street, the property shall be considered to be an Unimproved Block. 
    Block, Unimproved: Any block lacking sufficient existing buildings to meet the definition of an Improved Block. 
    Blow-Off: An outfall in a pipe through which water or sediment can be discharged from a lower sewer. 
    Board: The City of Whiting Board of Zoning Appeals or any division thereof, as the case may be. 
    Boarding House: An establishment with lodging for five or more persons where meals are regularly prepared and served for compensation and where food is placed upon the table family style, without service or ordering of individual portions from a menu. 
    Bond: Any form of security including a cash deposit, surety bond, collateral, property, or instrument of credit in an amount and form satisfactory to the Plan Commission. All bonds shall be approved by the Plan Commission wherever a bond is required by these regulations. 
    Buffer Landscaping: Any trees, shrubs, walls, fences, berms, space, or related landscaping features required under this Ordinance on private lots, and privately maintained, for buffering lots from adjacent properties or public rights-of-way for the purpose of increasing privacy and aesthetics. 
    Bufferyards: An area adjacent to front, side and rear property lines, measured perpendicularly from adjacent property lines and/or right-of-way lines, intended to provide attractive spaces to reduce the impacts of proposed uses on adjacent property or natural features and to screen incompatible uses from each other. Buffers also help to maintain existing trees or natural vegetation, to block or reduce noise, glare or other emissions and to maintain privacy. 
    Building: A structure having a roof supported by columns or walls, for the shelter, support, or enclosure of persons, property, or animals; and when separated by division walls from the ground up and without openings, each portion of such building shall be deemed as a separate building. 
    Building Area: The horizontal area of the buildings on a lot, measured from the outside exterior walls, excluding open areas or terraces, stairs, unenclosed porches or decks, and architectural features that project no more than two (2) feet. 
    Building Code: The City ordinance establishing and controlling the standards for constructing mechanical equipment, and all forms of permanent structures and related matters within the City. Also referred to herein as the Whiting Building Code. 
    Building, Detached: A building having no structural connection with another building. 
    Building Footprint: The profile of a building or structure as viewed from above the roof looking downward toward ground level. 
    Building Line: The line that establishes the minimum permitted distance on a lot between the building and property lines or right-of-way. 
    Building, Principal: A building in which is conducted the main or principal use of the lot on which said building is situated. Where a substantial part of an accessory building is attached to the principal building in a substantial manner, as by a roof, such accessory building shall be counted as a part of the principal building. 
    Burn Barrel: Any container used for the outdoor incineration of waste material, yard debris, etc. 
    Business: The engaging in the purchase, sale, barter, or exchange of goods, wares, merchandise, or services, or the maintenance or operation of offices, recreational, or amusement enterprises. 
    Business District: Refers to C-DB and C-BB Districts. 
    Board of Zoning Appeals: The Board of Zoning Appeals of the City [of] Whiting, Indiana. 
    Campground: Any site, lot, field, or tract of land designed with facilities for short-term occupancy by recreational vehicles and other camping equipment but not including mobile homes. 
    Capital Improvement Plan: See "Plan, Capital Improvement." 
    Capped System: A completed water supply and/or sewage system put in place for future use (contingent upon expansion), rather than to meet immediate development needs. 
    Cartway: The actual road surface area from curbline to curbline, which may include travel lanes, parking lanes, and deceleration and acceleration lanes. Where there are no curbs, the cartway is that portion between the edges of the paved, or hard surface, width. 
    Car Wash: Any permanent structure or facility used for the principal purpose of washing, cleaning, or polishing the exterior and/or interior of motor vehicles for a fee. 
    Central Sewerage System: The community sewer system including collection and treatment facilities owned and maintained by the City of Whiting. 
    Central Water System: The community water supply system including existing and new wells and/or surface water sources and intakes, treatment facilities, and distribution lines and includes such of the above facilities established by the developer to serve a new subdivision or commercial/industrial development. 
    Certificate of Occupancy: A certificate stating that the occupancy and use of a building or structure complies with the provisions of this Ordinance and the Whiting Building Code. 
    Channel: The bed and banks of a natural stream which convey the constant or intermittent flow of the stream. 
    Channelization: The straightening and deepening of channels and/or the surfacing thereof to permit water to move rapidly and/or directly. 
    City: The City of Whiting, Indiana. 
    Clinic: An establishment in which human patients are admitted for medical or dental study or treatment and in which the services of at least two (2) physicians or dentists are provided. 
    Club: A building or portion thereof or premises owned or operated by a person for a social, literacy, political, educational or recreational purpose primarily for the exclusive use of members and their guests, but not including any organization, group or association, the principal activity of which is to render a service usually and ordinarily carried on as a business. 
    Cluster Development: See "Planned Unit Development." 
    Collector Street: See "Street, Collector." 
    Commission: The City of Whiting Plan Commission. 
    Common Open Space: See "Open Space, Common." 
    Component Home: See "Manufactured Home." 
    Composting: A controlled process of degrading organic material by microorganisms. 
    Composting Facility: Any location, structure, or facility where composting takes place. 
    Comprehensive Plan: See "Plan, Comprehensive." 
    Conceptual Plan: See "Plan, Conceptual." 
    Conditional Use: Special provisions or requirements applicable to specific uses in certain zoning districts. If specified conditions are met as determined in this Ordinance or by the Administrator, no further approval is required. 
    Condominium: Real estate lawfully subject to IC § 32-1-6(1-31), (the Horizontal Property Law), by the recordation of condominium instruments, in which undivided interests in the common areas and facilities are vested in the condominium unit owners. 
    Conforming Manufactured Home: Pursuant to Public Law 312, Acts of 1981 (IC § 36-7-4-1106), a residence constructed after January 1, 1981, that exceeds nine hundred fifty (950) square feet of occupied space and which is installed as a permanent dwelling unit which may be placed or constructed providing it complies with setback, side and rear yard, parking space, and minimum square footage requirements for the district in which it is located, and the underfloor space requirements of the Whiting Unified Zoning and Subdivision Control Ordinance. 
    Construction Plan: See "Plan, Conceptual." 
    Contingent Use: A use contemplated by the ordinance, which is likely or liable but not certain to occur, and is compatible with the essential design of a particular district although the use is contrary to the restrictions imposed thereon. 
    Convenience Store: Any commercial location, facility, or structure where gasoline and groceries (including food, drink, and household items) are sold on the same premises. 
    Conventional Development: Development other than planned development. 
    Correctional Facility: A building or series of buildings used for the purpose of confining criminals. 
    Council: The Common Council of the City of Whiting, Indiana. 
    County: Lake County, Indiana. 
    Covenants: Private and legal restrictions of various kinds on the usage of lots within a subdivision which are proposed by the subdivider and, in the case of public health, safety and welfare, by the Plan Commission, that are recorded with the plat and deed. Covenants can also be placed on commercial and industrial developments. 
    Cul-de-sac: A short street having one (1) end open to traffic and being permanently terminated by a vehicular turn-around. 
    Culvert: A structure designed to convey a watercourse not incorporated in a closed drainage system under a road or pedestrian walk. 
    Curb: A vertical or sloping edge of a roadway. 
    Curb, Barrier: A steep-faced curb intended to prevent encroachments. 
    Curb, Mountable: A low curb with a flat slope designed to be crossed easily without discomfort. 
    Day Care Center: Any institution operated for the care of children, licensed pursuant to IC § 12-17.4, and as defined by IC § 12-7-2-29. 
    Dedication: The setting apart of land or interests in land for use by the public by ordinance, resolution, or entry in the official minutes as by the recording of a plat. 
    Density: The number of buildings, offices, or housing units on a particular area of land. 
    Density, High: Those residential districts in which the density is not in excess of ten (10) dwelling units per acre. 
    Density, Low: Those residential districts in which the density is equal to or less than four (4) dwelling units per acre. 
    Density, Medium: Those residential districts in which the density is less than or equal to eight (8) dwelling units per acre, but not less than five (5) dwelling units per acre. 
    Design Flood: See "Regulatory Flood." 
    Design Standards: Standards that set forth specific improvement requirements, including but not limited to Standards for Acceptance of Municipal Improvements. 
    Design Standards Variance: See "Variance, Design Standards/Development Regulations." 
    Detached Building: A building that has no structural connection with the principal building. 
    Detention Basin: A man-made or natural water collector facility designed to collect surface and subsurface water in order to impede its flow and to release the same, gradually, at a rate not greater than that prior to the development of the property, into natural or man-made outlets.
