Streets shall be named and renamed so that their names are easy to understand and to avoid duplication or conflict with other street names in the City of Whiting. 
Section 5. - Street Numbering and Numbering Notification. 
    In accordance with IC § 36-7-4-405(h), if the commission or the mayor of the City of Whiting names or renames streets or numbers or renumbers lots or structures under Section 4 of this Article, the commission or mayor shall notify: 
1.  The circuit court clerk or board of registration; 
2.  The administrator of the enhanced emergency telephone system established under IC § 36-8-16; 
3.  The United States Postal Service; and 
4.  Any person or body that the commission or mayor considers appropriate to receive notice. 
    Notification of its action shall be no later than the last day of the month following the month in which such action is taken by the commission. 
ARTICLE IX. - FINAL DISPOSITION OF RECOMMENDATIONS AND DECISIONS 

Section 1. - Final Disposition. 
    In accordance with IC § 36-7-4-405(a)(1), the final disposition of such recommendations by the commission shall be in the form of a written recommendation to the Whiting Common Council. The written recommendation shall set forth the findings and determinations of the commission, together with any modification, specification or limitation which the recommendation takes. 
Section 2. - Case Dismissal. 
    The commission may dismiss any petition or decision for lack of presentation or lack of jurisdiction. If a petitioner fails to appear at two (2) consecutive regular meetings of the commission in which the petitioner is on the agenda to present his or her case to the commission, the case may be dismissed by the commission for lack of presentation. 
Section 3. - Withdrawal of Petition By the Petitioner. 
    Following the publication of notice for any public hearing, until the conclusion of the hearing, a petitioner may not withdraw the matter to come before the public hearing without approval of the commission. 
Section 4. - Petition after Withdrawal. 
    A case which has been withdrawn by the petitioner shall not be again placed on the commission agenda for consideration for a period of twelve (12) months after the date of withdrawal by the petitioner, as established by the approval of the commission. 
Section 5. - Petition Resubmission. 
    A case which has been decided adversely to the petitioner shall not again be placed on the commission agenda for consideration until twelve (12) months after the date of the decision previously rendered by the commission. 
ARTICLE X. - APPROPRIATIONS, EXPENDITURES AND GRANTS 

Section 1. - Appropriations. 
    In accordance with IC § 36-7-4-308, after a legislative body has adopted an ordinance establishing a municipal plan commission (Ordinance No. 1062), the fiscal body of the municipality, in the commission's case the Whiting Common Council, may make appropriations to the commission to carry out the duties of the commission. 
Section 2. - Expenditures-Reversions. 
    In accordance with IC § 36-7-4-309, the commission may expend, in accord with applicable state, county and municipal fiscal procedures, all amounts appropriated to it for the purposes and activities authorized by IC § 36-7-4. Any unexpended or unencumbered part of the commission's appropriated funds shall revert to the city general fund at the end of each fiscal year. 
Section 3. - Professional Organizations or Conferences. 
    In accordance with IC § 36-7-4-222, if the commission determines that it is necessary or desirable for members or employees to join a professional organization or to attend a conference or interview dealing with planning or related problems, the commission may pay the applicable membership fees and all actual expenses of the members or employees, if that amount has been appropriated by the Whiting Common Council. 
Section 4. - Gifts, Donations and Grants. 
    In accordance with IC § 36-7-4-310, a municipality may accept gifts, donations, and grants from private or governmental sources for ADVISORY plan commission purposes or planning department purposes, as may be the case. 
    Any money so accepted shall be deposited with the municipality, as may be the case, in a special non-reverting plan commission fund to be available for expenditures by the commission for the purpose designed by the source. 
    The Whiting Clerk/Treasurer shall draw warrants against the special non-reverting fund only on vouchers signed by the president and the secretary of the commission. In accordance with IC § 36-7-4-409, a commission may, within its approved budget, negotiate for grants-in-aid and agree to terms and conditions attached to them. This section is specific authority to enter into grants-in-aid agreements under 40 U.S.C. section 461. Under the same limitations, the commission may enter into grants-in-aid agreements under act relating to planning and zoning. 
ARTICLE XI. - PUBLIC HEARING PETITION FILING PROCESS 

Section 1. - Public Hearing. 
    The commission shall hold hearings as are required by state statute and city ordinances. The commission may hold additional hearings at such times and places upon notice as the commission considers necessary. 
Section 2. - Petition Filing. 
    A petitioner who seeks to vacate a plat, amend the zoning ordinance, amend the subdivision control ordinance, amend the comprehensive plan or other matter under the jurisdiction of the commission shall file a petition with the commission. A minimum of ten (10) copies of the petition and application must be filed with the commission at least thirty (30) days prior to the next regularly scheduled commission meeting in order to be included on the meeting's agenda. 
Section 3. - Filing Fee Authority. 
    In accordance with IC § 36-7-4-411, the commission may establish a schedule of reasonable fees to defray the administrative costs connected with the following: 
1.  Processing and hearing administrative appeals and petitions for rezoning, special exemptions, special uses, contingent uses, and variances; 
2.  Issuing permits; and 
3.  Other official actions taken under IC § 36-7-4. 
Section 4. - Filing Fees. 
    All petitions not initiated by the commission itself may be accomplished by a non-refundable filing fee in an amount established by the commission. The commission shall set such filing fees as necessary to defray the administrative costs associated with any petition. In the event the commission establishes filing fees for petitions, the Fee Schedule shall be documented under this section. The filing fees shall be as follows: 
    For the Whiting Plan Commission 
1.  Comprehensive Plan Petition. 
1.  Text Amendment ..... $25.00 
2.  Map Amendment ..... $75.00 
2.  Zoning Petition. 
a.  Text Amendment ..... $25.00 
b.  Map Amendment ..... $75.00 
Section 5. - Additional Information. 
    The commission may require additional information, data, statistics, or plats beyond those established by statute or ordinance which are deemed necessary for intelligent determination by the commission. In the event of a public hearing, the burden shall be upon the petitioner to supply all information, including charts, diagrams, and other exhibits necessary for a clear understanding of the issue. 
Section 6. - Public Hearing Scheduling. 
    If the commission finds that a petition is in good order with sufficient information, it shall set a time for a public hearing on the matter and shall provide public notice in accordance with IC § 5-141.5. 
Section 7. - Public Notice Requirements. 
    Notice of a public hearing as required by state statute or city ordinance shall contain at a minimum the following information: 
1.  Docket number and the substance of the matter to be heard; 
2.  General location by address or other identifiable geographic characteristics of the property; 
3.  Name of the person, agency or entity initiating the matter to be heard; 
4.  Time and place of the he hearing; 
5.  Statement that the petition may be examined at the commission office; 
6.  Statement that any person may offer verbal comments at the hearing or may file written comments prior to or at the hearing; and 
7.  Any other information which may be required by law to be contained in such notice. 
Section 8. - Public Notice of a Hearing. 
    The petitioner shall prepare the legal advertisement of the public hearing for the approval of the commission. The petitioner shall bear the expense of the public notice's advertising costs. In addition, the commission shall at its discretion require the petitioner to notify by certified letter all persons deemed by state statute and the commission to be interested parties at least ten (10) days before the date of the public hearing. At the public hearing, the petitioner shall provide proof of publication that the petitioner has complied with this requirement. 
Section 9. - Interested Parties. 
    The commission shall by rule determine who effected property owners are as interested parties. The names of property owners to be notified by certified mail are to be ascertained from the real estate tax assessment list as they appear in the office of the North Township Assessor of Lake County located at 232 Russell Street in Hammond, Indiana 46320 (219-933-2810). In order for the Assessor's Office to prepare a list, the petitioner must provide the Assessor's Office with the legal description and address of the affected property. Allow adequate time (the North Township Assessor's Office suggests thirty (30) days) for the Assessor's Office to prepare the list. 
Section 10. - Proof of Public Notice to Affected Property Owners. 
    Certified mail receipts or signatures of all interested parties on a form provided by the commission shall be considered evidence that notice has been given. Personal appearance at the hearing also shall constitute evidence of notice. 
ARTICLE XII. - CONDUCT OF PUBLIC HEARINGS 

Section 1. - Introduction of a Public Hearing. 
    At the opening of any public hearing of the commission, the president of the commission shall state for the permanent record those reasons why the public hearing is being held. The president may read the petition to the commission into the permanent record as an introduction. 
Section 2. - Presentation of the Petitioner. 
    At a public hearing before the commission, the petitioner, property owner, or agent for the petitioner or property owner shall present the facts and arguments in support for the case. Comments and questions from the commission members may be interjected during the presentation for clarification of the subject matter. 
Section 3. - Public Discussion. 
    After a commission question period, the president shall begin the public discussion portion of the public hearing by reading all written comments on the petition received by the commission into the permanent record. The president shall then open the floor to any person wishing to comment on the petition. Individuals must address the president and be recognized before speaking. Each person must state his or her name and address for inclusion in the permanent record. The president may limit a speaker's time to assure an opportunity for all speakers to comment on the petition. 
Section 4. - Public Hearing Closing. 
    The president shall close the public hearing after the commission has adequately heard all interested persons and given the petitioner time to rebut any comments by the commission and interested parties. 
Section 5. - Public Hearing Decision. 
    Once the public hearing is closed by the president, the Commission shall consider the petition. The commission may either render a decision at the conclusion of the public hearing or may table the decision as "Under Advisement" for discussion at the next regularly scheduled meeting of the commission as "Old Business." 
Section 6. - Public Hearings Continuation. 
    The Commission, at its discretion, may continue or postpone the hearings of any case on an affirmative vote of a majority of the commission. The commission may continue the hearing when in its judgment the petitioner has not provided sufficient evidence on which to make a determination. 
Section 7. - Public Hearing Order. 
    Every person appearing before the commission shall abide by the order and directions of the president. Discourteous, disorderly or contemptuous conduct shall be regarded as a breach of the privileges of the commission and shall be dealt with as the commission directs. 
ARTICLE XIII. - COMMISSION COMMITTEES 

Section 1. - Committee Establishment. 
    The president with the approval of the commission may establish such committees as deemed to be necessary and desirable to administer the duties of the commission. The purpose, terms and number of members on the committee shall be specified at the time of their establishment. 
Section 2. - Executive Committee. 
    In accordance with IC § 36-7-4-408, the commission may establish an executive committee of not less than three (3) members nor more than nine (9) persons appointed by the commission from its membership. The establishment of the executive committee, the naming of its individual members, and the adoption of rules governing its operation requires a two-thirds (2/3) vote of the entire membership of the commission. A majority of the executive committee may act in the name of the commission; but, if there are any dissenting votes, a person voting in the minority may appeal the decision of the executive committee to the entire commission membership. 
Section 3. - Citizen Advisory Committee. 
    In accordance with IC § 36-7+407, the commission may establish ADVISORY committees of citizens interested in problems of planning and zoning. In its resolution establishing such a committee, the commission shall specify the terms of its members and its purposes. Each ADVISORY committee of citizens shall: 
1.  Study the subject and problems specified by the commission and recommend additional problems in need of study; 
2.  Advise the commission concerning how the subject and problems relate particularly to different areas and groups of the city; and, 
3.  If invited by the commission to do so, sit with and participate, without the right to vote, in the deliberations of the commission, when subjects of mutual concern are discussed. 
    The ADVISORY committee of citizens shall report only to the commission and shall make inquiries and reports only on the subject and problems specified by the commission resolution establishing the committee. 
Section 4. - Committee Appointing Authority. 
    The president of the commission shall be the appointing authority for all committees. All appointments shall be approved by a vote of the full commission. 
Section 5. - Plat Committee. 
    In accordance with IC § 36-7-4-701, the plan commission may appoint a plat committee to hold hearings on and approve plats and replats on behalf of the commission. The plat committee consists of three (3) persons, with at least one (1) of the members being a member of the commission. 
    Each appointment of a member of the plat committee is for a term of one (1) year, but the commission may remove a member from the committee. The commission must mail notice of the removal, to the member at their residence address. A member who is removed may not appeal the removal to a court or otherwise. 
    The plat committee may take action only by a majority vote. 
    The plat committee may grant primary approval to minor subdivision plats that subdivide four (4) or lots without public notice or hearing, and subject to appeal to the plan commission. The plat committee may also grant secondary approval to minor subdivision plats or other secondary plats that are submitted to the Zoning Administrator. 
    Within ten (10) days after primary approval, the Zoning Administrator shall provide for due notice to interested parties to their right to appeal to the plan commission. The notice shall be given in the manner set forth in IC § 36-7-4-706(2) and 706(3). 
ARTICLE XIV. - PLAT AND PLAN REQUIREMENTS 

Section 1. - Primary Plat or Preliminary Plan. 
1.  The plat shall be drawn at a scale of one hundred (100) feet to one (1) inch. Sheets shall not exceed twenty-four (24) inches by thirty-six (36) inches in size. Other scales and/or sheet sizes are permitted if prior approval is granted by the Commission. 
2.  The plat shall include a vicinity map showing the following: 
3.  Location of proposed subdivision. 
4.  Existing subdivisions and parcels of land adjacent to the proposed subdivision, including the names of the property owners. 
5.  Existing schools, parks, playgrounds, or other similar public facilities that will serve the proposed subdivision. 
6.  All public thoroughfares/rights-of-way adjacent to the site. 
7.  Location and size of all utilities adjacent to the subdivision site, including sanitary and storm sewers, gas lines, electric lines, telephone lines, water mains, fire hydrants, cable television lines, etc. 
8.  Existing zoning of the tract and all contiguous tracts surrounding the proposed subdivision. 
9.  All section and municipal corporate boundaries lying within or contiguous to the tract. 
10.  The location of any streets and alleys in the proposed subdivision, showing the relationship of said streets to any existing or proposed streets in contiguous subdivisions or undeveloped property to produce the most advantageous development of the entire neighborhood. 
11.  The vicinity map may be prepared by indicating the data by notation on available maps of an appropriate scale. 
12.  Two copies of a primary subdivision plat shall be submitted showing the following: 
13.  The proposed name of the subdivision. 
14.  Names and addresses of the owner, subdivider, consulting engineer, land surveyor, or planning firm who prepared the plat. 
15.  Legend and notes, including a graphic scale, north point, and date. 
16.  Tract boundary lines showing dimensions, bearings, angles, and references to section, township, range lines or corners, and existing bench marks. 
17.  Topographic contours at typical intervals of two (2) feet if the general slope of the tract is less than ten (10) percent, or intervals of five (5) feet if the slope is in excess of ten (10) percent. Said contours shall be referenced to mean sea level elevations and to U.S. Geological Survey datum plane. 
18.  Layout of lots, showing dimensions and numbers. 
19.  Building lines showing setback dimensions throughout the subdivision. 
20.  Parcels of land proposed to be dedicated or reserved for schools, parks, playgrounds, or other public, semi-public, or community purposes. 
21.  Existing and proposed streets and rights-of-way on and adjoining the site of the proposed subdivision, showing the proposed names, roadway widths, types and widths of pavements, curbs, sidewalks, bikeways, jogging paths, and other recreational ways. This may be deferred to the secondary plat approval stage if permitted by the Zoning Administrator. 
22.  Existing and proposed easements, including the location, width, and purpose of each easement. 
23.  Location and size of utilities existing and proposed on the site, including storm and sanitary sewers; water mains; electrical, telephone, and cable television lines; street lights; fire hydrants, and such other utilities as may be appropriate. NOTE: All proposed utility services must be underground; and all sump-pumps (excluding sanitary pumps for basements) must be connected to the storm sewer system or as permitted by the Commission. This may be deferred to the secondary plat approval stage if permitted by the Zoning Administrator. 
24.  Location of natural streams, regulated surface drains, legal ditches, flood plains, drain tiles, etc. 
25.  A preliminary drainage plan showing the proposed storm water drainage system to an improved outlet. Data shall be included showing that said outlet is adequate to accommodate the drainage requirements of the finished development. The plan shall include surface drainage system, storm sewer systems, subsurface drainage systems, and stormwater detention facilities. Arrows designating the general drainage of all streets and lots shall be included. 
26.  Location of water courses, marshes, wetlands, wooded areas, isolated trees to be preserved, houses, barns, and other structures and significant features. 
27.  Proposed sidewalks. 
28.  Proposed decorative lighting. 
29.  Type of drainage system(s) proposed to handle surface, underground, and runoff waters. The coefficient to be used for this determination shall be approved by the City Engineer. 
30.  The existing excess capacity available from the Hammond Sanitary District, the nearest location to the building site of a trunk or connecting sewer line, and the expected demand of the development or building (numbers to be acquired from the City). 
31.  Preliminary architectural drawings in sufficient detail to show building size, height, materials, types of units, and location of all buildings (existing and proposed) on the development site. This requirement may be waived by the Zoning Administrator until Secondary Plat approval. In housing and large commercial developments, this information may not be available. 
32.  Proposed preliminary landscaping, signage, entrance to the development, screening, and attempts at preserving natural terrain and open space. The Plan Commission may request a landscaping/screening plan. This requirement may be waived by the Zoning Administrator until secondary plat approval. 
33.  Estimated traffic count increase on adjacent streets resulting from the proposed development; description of type and condition of roads to serve such development; total number of motor vehicles expected to use or be stationed in such development; and on-and off-site parking to be supplied. A formal engineering study need not be conducted unless the Commission requests such extensive information. 
34.  Photographs may be requested by the Zoning Administrator for specific areas or elements on or surrounding the site. 
35.  If the primary plat is to be divided into sections or phases of development, the boundaries and numbers of such sections shall be shown, and a conceptual plan for the entire subdivision shall be submitted as a "phasing schedule." Due to a fluctuating economy, the Commission shall give some flexibility to revisions to the phasing schedule throughout the process and development. 
36.  Soil map of the site from the Soil Conservation Service. 
37.  Proposed development schedule. 
Section 2. - Secondary Plat or Secondary Plan. 
1.  Accurate boundary lines with dimensions and angles that provide a legal survey per state statute. 
2.  Accurate distances and directions to the nearest official monuments. Reference corners shall be accurately described on the plat. 
3.  Accurate locations of all existing and recorded streets intersecting the boundaries of the tract. 
4.  Accurate metes and bounds description of the tract boundary. 
5.  Source of title of applicant to the land as shown by the last entry in the books of the County Auditor. 
6.  Name of subdivision followed by the words "Secondary Plat." 
7.  Name and address of the owner and subdivider. 
8.  North point, graphic scale, and date. 
9.  Proposed street names. 
10.  Complete curve table for all curves included in the plat. 
11.  Street lines with accurate dimensions in feet and hundredths of feet with angles to street, alley, and lot lines. Radii, points of curvatures, tangent bearings, and lengths of all arcs of street lines shall be provided. 
12.  Lot numbers and dimensions, including the square footage of each lot. 
13.  Accurate locations of easements, descriptions of their use, and any limitations on such semi-public or community use. 
14.  Accurate dimensions for any property to be dedicated or reserved for public, semi-public, or community use, including sidewalks, bikeways, and other recreational ways. 
15.  Building lines and setback dimensions throughout the subdivision. 
16.  Location, types, material, and size of all monuments and markers. 
17.  Construction plans and specifications for all improvements required by this ordinance or the Commission. 
18.  Restrictions of all types which will run with the land and become covenants in the deeds for lots. 
19.  Certification by a registered land surveyor. 
20.  Certification by the owner(s) and lien holder(s) (if any) of dedication of streets and other public property, and an agreement executed by the owner(s) and subdivider(s) to make and install all improvements in accordance with the plans and specifications approved by the Commission and accompanying the secondary plat. 
21.  Certificate of approval by the Whiting Plan Commission, if approved. 
22.  Certificate of approval by the Whiting City Council, if approved. 
23.  A final landscape/screening plan shall be incorporated in the secondary plat design plans and a phasing schedule of landscaping/screening improvements. 
24.  Any other information or data requested by the Commission during primary plat approval or otherwise necessary to clarify conditions and terms of plat approval. 
Section 3. - Construction Plans. 
1.  General construction plans shall be prepared for all required improvements. Plans shall be drawn on standard twenty-four (24) inch by thirty-six (36) inch sheets at a scale of no less than one (1) inch equaling fifty (50) feet, and map sheets shall be the same size as the secondary plat. 
2.  Topographic contours at intervals of one (1) foot if the general slope of the tract is less than five (5) percent or intervals of two (2) feet if the slope exceeds five (5) percent. Contours shall be referenced to USGS datum plane. 
3.  Profiles showing existing and proposed elevations along centerlines of all streets. Where a proposed street intersects an existing street or streets, the elevation along the centerline of the existing street or streets within one hundred (100) feet of the intersection. Radii of all curves, lengths of tangents, and central angles on all streets shall be shown. 
4.  The Plan Commission may require, where steep slopes exist, the cross-sections of all proposed streets. 
5.  Plans and profiles showing the location and typical cross-section of streets including curbs, gutters, sidewalks, rights-of-way, drainage facilities, manholes, and catch basins. Plans shall show the location, size, and invert elevations of existing and proposed sanitary sewers, stormwater drains, water lines, gas, and fire hydrants, showing connection to any existing or proposed utility systems. 
6.  Location, size, elevation, and other appropriate descriptions of any other existing physical and natural features or facilities including wetlands, trees, the points of connection to proposed facilities and utilities, and the approximate high-and low-water elevations of all ponds, lakes, and streams. All elevations shall be referenced to the USGS datum plane. 
7.  Upon completion of the construction, the applicant's engineer or land surveyor shall provide the Plan Commission with a set of "as built" construction plans showing the location, dimensions, and materials used to construct all improvements within the subdivision. 
ARTICLE XIV. - OFFICIAL SEAL 

Section 1. - Official Seal. 
    The commission shall adopt a seal with the caption: "The Seal of the Whiting Plan Commission" The secretary shall employ the seal to certify to all official acts of the commission. 
ARTICLE XV. - AMENDMENTS 

Section 1. - Amendments. 
    Administrative Rules and Procedures amendments may be proposed by any member of the commission. The commission may amend these Administrative Rules and Procedures by a majority vote of the membership at a regular or special meeting of the commission. 
Section 2. - Refinement. 
    Amendments to these Administrative Rules and Procedures are to be typed and distributed to all commission members prior to a vote at a regular or special meeting of the commission. A proposed amendment may be refined at the meeting only by deletion and minor refinement. 
Section 3. - Enactment. 
    These Administrative Rules and Procedure shall be in full force and effect from and after its passage and approval by the commission. 
Section 4. - Administrative Rules and Procedures Review. 
    The commission shall review the Administrative Rules and Procedures prior to January 31 of each new calendar year or at the first meeting of each calendar year. All new sections, major rewording of sections, or similar potentially significant changes to the Administrative Rules and Procedures may only be approved after a complete review of the commission's Administrative Rules and Procedures at that time. Upon a comprehensive review of the Administrative Rules and Procedures, the commission shall vote upon and adopt any and all subsequent changes to the Administrative Rules and Procedures. Newly adopted Administrative Rules and Procedures shall be dated and filed in the Whiting Clerk/Treasurer's Office and made part of the public record. 
ARTICLE XVI. - REPEAL 

Section 1. - Repeal of Previous Rules. 
    All previous Administrative Rules and Procedures heretofore adopted by the Whiting Plan Commission are hereby expressly repealed, as of the effective date of these Administrative Rules and Procedures. 
ARTICLE XVII. - ADOPTION 

Section 1. - Adoption. 
    The Administrative Rules and Procedures of the Whiting Plan Commission of the City of Whiting, Lake County, Indiana were approved by the vote of: 
Yea: 
Nay: 
Abstentions 
Members Present: 
at the regular meeting of the Commission held on the day of.

Chapter 2. - BOARD OF ZONING APPEALS RULES AND PROCEDURES 
[INTRODUCTION] 
    Like many planning and zoning commissions, a board of zoning appeals can improve with the establishment of and through the utilization of a good set of administrative rules. Thorough and well-thought administrative rules set forth the organizational aspects of the Board and establish a definite procedure for conducting Board business. The administrative rules should include sections on officers and employees, meetings, order of business, committees, and public hearings. In addition to being required by the planning statutes of the state, administrative rules are essential because each board member should be aware, without question, of how the Board conducts business and operates. Furthermore, land developers, community officials and the general public should be able to determine, at any time, how the Board conducts its business and operates. 
    As a final note, if a set of rules and procedures are adopted, the Board must follow them. If the Board disregards the adopted rules and procedures, the Board may be opening itself to serious legal problems if a petitioner appeals its decision. However, if the Board opts not to establish or adopt a set of rules and procedures, certain minimum standards of administrative procedure will be implied. 
    The following Administrative Rules and Procedures for the Whiting Board of Zoning Appeals are documented in article form with the individual articles further divided into sections. Upon adoption by the Whiting Board of Zoning Appeals, these Administrative Rules and Procedures will become the official set of rules and procedures governing the Board's operation and business and all Whiting Board of Zoning Appeals meetings, hearings, and official actions. 
    All references to the State local planning legislation of the Indiana Code are coded with an "IC", and all references to the Whiting Municipal Code are coded with "WMC". 
ARTICLE I. - LEGISLATION OF ESTABLISHMENT 

Section 1. - Establishment. 
A.  The Whiting Board of Zoning Appeals (hereinafter known as "the BZA" or "the Board") is established by IC § 36-7-4-901(a) which states as part of the zoning ordinance, the legislative body shall establish a board of zoning appeals. 
B.  According to the Whiting Municipal Code section 17.64.010, the Whiting BZA is established with membership and appointments provided in accordance with Sections 66 to 69 inclusive of Chapter 174 of the Acts of the Indiana General Assembly of 1947 and all acts now or hereafter amendatory thereto (known as IC §§ 36-7-4-900 through 924 inclusive). 
C.  The board of zoning appeals is composed of one (1) division, unless the zoning ordinance is amended under IC § 36-7-4-901(b). Whenever it is considered desirable, the zoning ordinance, in accordance with 36-7-4-90Hb), may be amended to establish an additional one (1), two (2), or three (3) divisions of the board of zoning appeals. 
D.  After January 1, 1984, whenever any divisions of the board of zoning appeals are established or re-established by the zoning ordinance, the ordinance must provide for each division to consist of five (5) members appointed in accordance with section 902 (IC § 36-7-4-902) of the 900 SERIES BOARD OF ZONING APPEALS. 
E.  The zoning ordinance may provide that any additional division of the board of zoning appeals, having been established under IC § 36-7-4-901(b), is to have only limited territorial jurisdiction. The zoning ordinance must describe the limits of that division's territorial jurisdiction and specify whether that division has exclusive or concurrent jurisdiction within that territory. 
F.  According to IC § 36-7-4-901(d), the Board shall be known as an ADVISORY board of zoning appeals (under the ADVISORY PLANNING LAW). 
G.  According to IC § 36-7-4-901(h), any board of zoning appeals that was established under IC § 18-7-3-11 [repealed] continues as the board of zoning appeals for that jurisdiction, until otherwise provided by the zoning ordinance. 
H.  According to IC § 36-7-4-917, the fiscal body of the municipality (the Whiting Common Council) may appropriate under Section 308 (IC § 36-7-4-308) such amounts as are necessary to carry out the duties of the Board. 
ARTICLE II. - BOARD AUTHORITY AND DUTIES 

Section 1. - Authority. 
A.  In accordance with IC § 36-7-4-916, the Board shall adopt rules, which may not conflict with the zoning ordinance, concerning: 
1.  The filing of appeals; 
2.  The application for variances, special exceptions, special uses, contingent uses, and conditional uses; 
3.  The giving of notice; the conduct of hearings; and 
4.  The determination of whether a variance application, is for a variance of use or for a variance from development standards (such as height, bulk, or area): 
B.  The Board may also adopt rules providing for: 
1.  The allocation of cases filed among the divisions (if any) of the Board; and 
2.  The fixing of dates for hearing by the divisions; 
C.  Rules adopted by the Board shall be printed and be made available to all applicants and other interested parties. In addition, according to WMC 17.64.010 subsection (c), the board of zoning appeals shall adopt rules and regulations as it may deem necessary to effectuate the provisions of the WMC Title of Board of Zoning Appeals and the Ie 900 SERIES BOARD OF ZONING APPEALS. 
Section 2. - Powers and Duties. 
    The BZA shall have all the powers and duties as documented in the 900 SERIES BOARD OF ZONING APPEALS of the Indiana Code. In addition, according to the Whiting Municipal Code section 17.64.030 titled "Powers and Duties", the BZA shall have the powers and perform the duties as provided in sections 17.64.040 through 17.64.060 of the Whiting Municipal Code. These sections include for an administrative review (section 17.64.040), the granting of special exceptions (section 17.64.050), and the granting of variances (section 17.64.060). 
ARTICLE III. - BOARD MEMBERSHIP 

Section 1. - Membership. 
    In accordance with IC § 36-7-4-902(a), each ADVISORY board of zoning appeals shall consist of five (5) members. The Whiting BZA membership shall be appointed as follows: (1) Three (3) citizen members shall be appointed by the executive of the municipality (the Mayor of Whiting), of whom one (1) must be a member of the Whiting Plan Commission and two (2) must not be members of the Whiting Plan Commission; (2) One (1) citizen member shall be appointed by the fiscal body of the municipality (the Mayor of Whiting and the Whiting Common Council), who must not be a member of the Whiting Plan Commission; and (3) One (1) citizen member appointed by the ADVISORY plan commission (the Whiting Plan Commission), who must be a member of the Whiting Plan Commission other than the member appointed by the executive of the municipality (the Mayor of Whiting). 
Section 2. - Division Membership. 
    In accordance with IC § 36-7-4-902(g), whenever the zoning ordinance provides for a certain division of the board of zoning appeals to have limited territorial jurisdiction, it must also provide for that division to consist of member who are all residents of that limited territory. Those members shall be appointed in the same manner that is prescribed by IC § 36-7-4-902(a) for divisions of an ADVISORY board of zoning appeals, but if the Whiting Plan Commission is unable to make its appointment in that manner, the appointment shall be made instead by the legislative body (the Mayor of Whiting and the Whiting Common Council). 
Section 3. - Restriction on Holding Office. 
    In accordance with IC § 36-7-4-905, no members of the board of zoning appeals may hold other elective or appointed office, except as permitted by IC § 36-7-4-902 (Section 1 of this Article), in municipal, county or state government. In addition, a member must be resident of the jurisdictional area of the board of zoning appeals. 
Section 4. - Membership Terms. 
    In accordance with IC § 36-7-4-906, in an ADVISORY board of zoning appeals, when an initial term of office expires, each new appointment is for a term of four (4) years. 
A.  Upon the establishment of a Board of Zoning Appeals and or any divisions, the members shall initially be appointed as provided in the zoning ordinance for the following terms of office: 
1.  One (1) for a term of one (1) year; 
2.  One (1) for a term of two (2) years; 
3.  One (1) for a term of three (3) years; and 
4.  Two (2) for a term of four (4) years each. 
B.  In accordance with IC § 36-7-4-906(c), each member's appointed term expires on the first Monday of January of the first, second, third, or fourth year, respectively, after the year of the member's respective appointment. 
C.  In accordance with IC § 36-7-4-906(g), a member of the board of zoning appeals serves until his successor is appointed and qualified. A member is eligible for reappointment at the conclusion of his or her Board term. 
Section 5. - Removal of a Member. 
    In accordance with IC § 36-7-4-906(0), the appointing authority may remove a member from the Board for due cause. The appointing authority must mail notice of the removal, along with the written reason(s) for the removal to the member at the member's current residential address. A member who is removed may, within thirty (30) days after receiving notice of the removal, appeal the removal to the circuit or superior court of the county. 
Section 6. - Vacancy. 
    In accordance with IC § 36-7-4-907(a), if a vacancy occurs among the members of the board of zoning appeals, the 'appointing authority' shall appoint a member for the unexpired term of the vacating member. In addition, the appointing authority may appoint an alternate member to participate with the Board in any hearing or decision in which the regular member it has appointed has a disqualification (conflict of interest) under IC § 36-7-4-909. 
ARTICLE IV. - BOARD MEMBERS 

Section 1. - Election. 
    In accordance with IC § 36-7-4-912 and WMC Section 17.64.010 at the first meeting of each calendar year, the Board shall elect a chairperson and a vice-chairperson from its membership. The vice-chairperson may act as chairperson during the absence or disability of the chairperson. 
Section 2. - Duties of the Chairperson. 
    The chairperson of the Board shall preside over meetings, decide the order, subject to appeal by board members, and preserve decorum in the meeting room. The chairperson shall pronounce the decisions of the Board for purposes of recording in the minutes. 
Section 3. - Resignation or Replacement of Officers. 
    Upon resignation or replacement of the chairperson or vice-chairperson as a member of the board of zoning appeals, the Board shall elect a successor at its next scheduled meeting. 
Section 4. - Board Appointments and Employees. 
    In accordance with IC § 36-7-4-913 and WMC Section 17.64.010, the board of zoning appeals may appoint and fix the compensation of a secretary and such employees as are necessary for the discharge of its duties. All in conformity to and compliance with salaries and compensations thereto fixed by the Whiting Common Council. 
Section 5. - Duties of the Secretary. 
    The secretary shall keep the minutes of all the board of zoning appeals' meetings. The secretary shall record the minutes each meeting's and hearing's proceedings and record each member's vote. In addition, the secretary shall conduct all of the Board's correspondence as necessary. 
Section 6. - Representative to the Common Council. 
    One member of the Board shall be designated as the Board's representative to the Whiting Common Council. The Board's representative shall speak for the Board at all Whiting Common Council meetings and answer any and all questions in regard to the Whiting BZA. 
ARTICLE V. - BOARD EMPLOYEES 

Section 1. - Employees. 
    In accordance with IC § 36-7-4-913, the board of zoning appeals may appoint, prescribe the duties, and fix the compensation of such employees as are necessary to the discharge of the duties of the Board. In addition, such salaries must be in conformity to and compliance with salaries and compensations thereto fixed by the Whiting Common Council. 
Section 2. - Special or Temporary' Services. 
    The Board may within its budget allotment contract for special or temporary services and for legal council. 
ARTICLE VI. - MEETINGS AND HEARINGS 

Section 1. - Facilities. 
    In accordance with IC 136-7-4-914, the Whiting Plan Commission shall provide for suitable facilities for the holding of Board meetings and hearings. In addition, the Whiting Plan Commission shall provide the Board with suitable facilities for preserving the Board's records, documents, and accounts. 
Section 2. - Meeting or Hearing Place. 
    The board of zoning appeals meeting or hearings will take place at Whiting City Hall located at 1443-119th Street. The meetings or hearings will be held in the Whiting Conference Room located on the second floor of Whiting City Hall unless otherwise posted on the doors of City Hall in accordance with IC 15-14-1.5-5. 
Section 3. - Meetings and Hearings. 
A.  Meeting and hearings of the board of zoning appeals shall be fixed and scheduled by the Board itself. The Board shall fix the time and date of a meeting or hearing upon request by the Whiting Plan Commission to hear administrative appeals, exceptions, uses, and variance petitions from a land or property owner. 
B.  In accordance with WMC 17.64.010 subsection (e), all meetings and hearings of the Board shall be open to the public. The Board shall keep minutes of its proceedings, keep records of its examinations and other official actions and shall record the vote on all actions taken. All minutes and records shall be titled in the office of the Board (Whiting Clerk) Treasurers Office) and shall be made part of the public record. 
Section 4. - Notice of Meetings. 
A.  Public notice in accordance with IC 15-3-1-2(b) states that if the event is a public hearing or meeting, notice shall be published one (1) time, at least ten (10) days before the date of the hearing or meeting. 
B.  IC § 5-14-1.5-5 states that public notice of the date, time and place of any meetings, executive sessions, or of any rescheduled or reconvened meeting, shall be given at least forty-eight (48) hours before the meeting. Public notice shall be given by the governing body of a public agency by: 
1.  Posting a copy of the notice at the principal office of the public agency holding the meeting or, if no such office exists, at the building where the meeting is to be held; and 
2.  Depositing in the United States mail with postage prepaid or by delivering notice to all news media which file by January 1 an annual written request for such notices with the City of Whiting. 
C.  This requirement does not apply to reconvened meetings where announcement of the date, time and place of the reconvened meetings is made at the original meeting and recorded in a memoranda and minutes thereof, and there is no change in the agenda. 
Section 5. - Emergency Meetings. 
    IC § 5-14-1.5-5 also states that if a meeting is called to deal with an emergency involving actual or threatening injury to person or property, or actual or threatening disruption of the governmental activity under the jurisdiction of the Commission by any event, then the time requirements of notice under IC § 5-14-1.5-5 shall not apply, but: 
1.  News media which have requested notice of meetings must be given the same notice as is given to the members of the Commission; 
2.  The public must be notified by posting a copy of the notice according to IC § 5-14-1.5-5. 
Section 6. - Notice of Hearings. 
    In accordance with IC § 36-7-4-920, the board of zoning appeals shall fix a reasonable time for the hearing of administrative appeals, exceptions, uses, and variances. 
A.  Public notice in accordance with IC § 5-3-1-2(b) states that if the event is a public hearing or meeting, notice shall be published one (1) time, at least ten (10) days before the date of the hearing or meeting. In addition, WMC Section 17.64.050 subsection (2) states notice of such hearing shall be posted on, in or at the following locations: 
1.  The property for which special exception is sought; 
2.  Whiting City Hall; and 
3.  A newspaper of general circulation in the locality ten (10) days prior to the public hearing. 
B.  In accordance with IC § 5-3-1-2(h), in case any officer charged with the duty of publishing any notice required by law is unable to procure advertisement at the price fixed by law, or the newspaper refuses to publish the advertisement, it is sufficient for the officer to post printed notices in three (3) prominent places in the political subdivision, in lieu of such advertisement in newspapers. 
C.  In accordance with IC § 5-3-1-4 and due notice to interested parties, notice shall be given at least ten (10) days before the date set for the hearing. 
D.  In accordance with WMC 17.64.050 subsection (2), the owner of the property for which special exemption is sought or his agent shall be notified by mail of the date and time of such hearing. 
E.  The party making an appeal, or applying for the exception, use, or variance may be required to assume the cost of public notice and due notice to interested parties. At the hearing, each party may appear in person, by agent, or attorney. 
F.  The Board shall by rule determine who the interested parties are, how notice is to be given to them, and who is required to give that notice. 
G.  Section 17.64.050 subsection (2) states the cost of advertising the notices of public hearing shall be borne by the petitioner. 
Section 7. - Hearing Appearances. 
A.  In accordance with WMC 17.64.050 subsection (3), if a public hearing is held, any party may appear in person, or by agent or attorney. 
B.  In accordance with IC § 36-7-4-920(e), the staff (as defined in the zoning ordinance), if any, may appear before the Board at the hearing and present evidence in support of or in opposition to the granting of a variance or the determination of any other matter. 
C.  In accordance with IC § 36-7-4-920(1), other persons may appear and present relevant evidence. 
D.  In accordance with IC § 36-7-4-920(g), a person may not communicate with any member of the board of zoning appeals before the hearing with the intent to influence the member's action on a matter pending before the Board. Not less than five (5) days before the hearing, however, the staff (as defined in the zoning ordinance), if any, may file with the Board a written statement setting forth any facts or opinions relating to the matter. 
E.  In accordance with IC § 36-7-4-920(h), the Board may require any party adverse to any pending petition to enter a written appearance specifying the party's name and address. If the written appearance is entered more than four (4) days before the hearing, the Board may also require the petitioner to furnish each adverse party with a copy of the petition and a plot plan of the property involved. 
F.  No one who is not a member of the Board shall be permitted to address the Board during a hearing except by request and consent of the chairperson or of the vice-chairperson acting as the chairperson in his or her absence. 
ARTICLE VII. - MINUTES AND RECORDS 

Section 1. - Meeting Minutes. 
    In accordance with IC § 36-7-4-915 and WMC 17.64.010(e), the Board of Zoning Appeals shall keep minutes of its proceedings and record the vote on all actions taken. The Board shall, in all cases heard, make written findings of fact of its decision. All minutes and records shall be filed in the Office of the Board (the Whiting Clerk/Treasurer's Office) and are to be made part of the public records. 
Section 2. - Minutes. 
    The Secretary of the Board of Zoning Appeals shall prepare and maintain the minutes and proceedings of all board meetings and hearings. The minutes shall include the vote of each board member on each question, decision, appeal or variance presented to the Board in order to document that the board member is absent, abstaining with permission, or not voting because of a disqualification. 
Section 3. - Minute Approval. 
    The minutes of each meeting or hearing shall be presented to the Board for approval at a special meeting set to approve such minutes. When approved, the minutes of the Board's meeting or hearing shall be signed by the chairperson or the chairperson acting as the chairperson and attested by the secretary. 
Section 4. - Minute Filing. 
    Upon the Board's approval of a meeting or hearing minutes, the secretary shall file the approved minutes and all other records in the Office of the Board as public record. If no such office exists, the minutes shall be filed with the Whiting Clerk/Treasurers Office and made a part of the public record. 
Section 5. - Minute Inspection. 
    In accordance with IC § 5-14-3-3, any person may inspect and copy the minutes and/or any-public records of the Board during regular business hours of the Whiting Clerk/Treasurer's Office, except as provided in IC § 15-14-3-4. 
ARTICLE VIII. - OFFICIAL ACTION OF THE BOARD 

Section 1. - Official Action. 
    In accordance with IC § 36-7-4-911, action of the Board is not official, unless it is authorized by a majority of the entire membership of the board. 
Section 2. - Quorum. 
    In accordance with IC § 36-7-4-910 and WMC 17.64.010 subsection (d), a quorum consists of a majority of the entire membership of the Board. 
Section 3. - Conflict of Interest. 
    In accordance with IC § 36-7-4-909, a Board member may not participate in a hearing or decision concerning a zoning matter in which such Board member has a direct or indirect financial interest. The Board shall enter into its record: 
1.  The fact that a regular member has such a disqualification; and 
2.  The name of the alternate member, if any, who participates in the hearing or decision in place of the regular member. 
Section 4. - Roll Call Vote. 
    All decisions of the Board shall be decided by a roll call vote of the Board, Voting of the Board shall be by roll call vote of each Board member. All members present shall vote on every decision made by the Board unless they are permitted to abstain by the presiding officer, or, in the case of a zoning matter, have disqualified themselves because of a conflict of interest as defined under Section 3 of this Article. 
Section 5. - Tabling Decisions. 
    In the event a majority vote of the Board cannot be achieved due to absences, permitted abstentions, or disqualification's, the matter before the Board meeting or hearing shall be rescheduled or reconvened within a reasonable time period meeting at the request of any Board member, a petitioner or a remonstrator. 
Section 6. - Decision Appeal by a Member. 
    Any member of the Board who voted with the majority may call for a reconsideration of any vote at the same meeting of the Board at which an official decision was passed, and, if sustained by a majority of the Board members, the reconsideration shall be ordered. 
Section 7. - Order of Business for a Board Meeting. 
    The order of business at Board meetings shall be: 
1.  Call to Order; 
2.  Roll Call; 
3.  Determination of Quorum; 
4.  Consideration of minutes of previous meeting; 
5.  Communications, Bills, and Expenditures; 
6.  Report of the Chairperson; 
7.  Old Business; 
8.  New Business; 
9.  Public Discussion; and 
10.  Adjournment. 
Section 8. - Order of Business for a Board Hearing. 
    The order of business for a Board hearing shall be: 
1.  Call to Order; 
2.  Roll Call; 
3.  Determination of Quorum; 
4.  Introduction of Case to Board Members; 
5.  Petitioner's Case; 
6.  Question Period by Board; 
7.  Comments from Organized. Groups, Committees, or Individuals; 
8.  Petitioner's Rebuttal; 
9.  Close Hearing; 
10.  Board Discussion; 
11.  Final Decision and Finding by Board; 
12.  Board Member's Appeal; 
13.  If moved, return to "Board Discussion" of the hearing agenda; and 
14.  Adjournment. 
ARTICLE IX. - BOARD APPEALS 

Section 1. - Jurisdiction. 
    In accordance with IC § 36-7-4-918.1 and WMC 17.64.040, the Board shall hear and determine appeals from and review: 
1.  Any order, requirement, decision, or determination made by an administrative official, hearing officer, or staff member under the zoning ordinance; 
2.  Any order, requirement, decision, or determination made by an administrative board or other body except the Plan Commission in relation to the enforcement of the zoning ordinance; or 
3.  Any order, requirement, decision, or determination made by an administrative board or other body except the Plan Commission in relation to the enforcement of an ordinance adopted under the 900 SERIES BOARD OF ZONING APPEALS requiring the procurement of an improvement location or occupancy permit. 
Section 2. - Procedure. 
A.  In accordance with 36-7-4-919 subsection (a), an appeal to the Board must specify the grounds of the appeal and must be filed within such time and in such form as may be prescribed by the Board by rule. 
B.  In accordance with WMC 17.64.020 subsection (a), any decision of an administrative official in the enforcement of the title may be appealed to the Board by any person claiming to be adversely affected by such decision. And, in accordance with IC § 36-7-4-919(a) and WMC 17.64.020 subsection (a), the administrative official, hearing officer administrative board, or other body shall, on request of the Board, transmit to it all documents plans, and papers constituting the record of the action form which an appeal was taken. In addition, according to IC § 36-7-4-919(c), certified copies of the documents, plans, and papers constituting the record may be transmitted for the purposes of IC § 36-7-4-919(b). 
C.  In accordance with WMC 17.64.020 subsection (b), the Board shall fix a reasonable time for the hearing of an appeal, give due notice thereof to the parties of interest, and decide the same within a reasonable time, in any case within sixty (60) days. 
D.  In accordance with IC § 36-7-4-919(d) and WMC 17.64.070 subsection (a), upon appeal, the Board may reverse, affirm wholly, or modify the order, requirement, decision, or determination appealed from and may make such order, requirement, decision, or determination as ought to be made. For this purpose, the Board has all the powers of the official, officer, board, or body from which the appeal was taken. 
ARTICLE X. - VARIANCES 

Section 1. - Variances from Use. 
    In accordance with IC § 36-7-4-918.4 and WMC 17.64.060, the Board shall approve or deny variances of use from the terms of the zoning ordinance. The Board may impose reasonable conditions as part of its approval. A variance may impose reasonable conditions as part of its approval. A variance may be approved under this section only upon a determination in writing that: 
1.  The approval will not be injurious to the public health, safety, morals, and general welfare of the community; 
2.  The use and value of the area adjacent to the property included in the variance will not be affected in a substantially adverse manner; 
3.  The need for the variance arises from some condition peculiar to the property involved, specifically the land, structure, or building involved and which are not applicable to other lands, structures, or buildings in the same district; 
4.  The strict application of the terms of the zoning ordinance if applied to the property for which the variance is sought will constitute an unnecessary hardship and will deprive the applicant of rights commonly enjoyed by other properties in the same district: 
5.  That the special conditions and circumstances do not result from the actions of the applicant; 
6.  That granting the variance requested will not confer on the applicant any special privilege that is denied by this title to other lands, structures, or buildings in the same district; and 
7.  The approval does not interfere substantially with the official Comprehensive Plan for the City of Whiting adopted under the 500 SERIES COMPREHENSIVE PLAN of the Indiana Code. 
Section 2. - Variances from Development Standards. 
    In accordance with IC § 36-7-4-918.5 and WMC 17.64.060, the Board shall approve or deny variances from the development standards (such as height, bulk, or area) of the zoning ordinance. A variance may be approved under this section only upon a determination in writing that: 
1.  The approval will not be injurious to the public health, safety, morals, and general welfare of the community; 
2.  The use and value of the area adjacent to the property included in the variance will not be affected in a substantially adverse manner; 
3.  The need for the variance arises from some condition peculiar to the property involved, specifically the land, structure, or building involved and which are not applicable to other lands, structures, or buildings in the same district; 
4.  The strict application of the terms of the zoning ordinance will result in practical difficulties in the use of the property. However, the zoning ordinance may establish a stricter standard than the practical difficulties' standard prescribed by this subdivision. 
5.  That the special conditions and circumstances do not result from the actions of the applicant; 
6.  That granting the variance requested will not confer on the applicant any special privilege that is denied by this title to other lands, structures, or buildings in the same district; and 
7.  The approval does not interfere substantially with the official Comprehensive Plan for the City of Whiting adopted under the 500 SERIES COMPREHENSIVE PLAN of the Indiana Code. 
Section 3. - Granting Variances. 
A.  In accordance with WMC 17.64.060, the Board shall authorize upon appeal in specific cases such variance from the terms of the WMC title as will not be contrary to the public interest, where, owing to special conditions a literal enforcement of the provisions of the title would result in unnecessary hardship, and so that the spirit of the title shall be observed and substantial justice done. No such variances shall be granted by the Board unless and until: 
1.  A written application for a variance is submitted indicating the section or sections of the zoning ordinance and title or titles under which the variance is sought and stating the grounds in which the variance is requested; 
2.  Notice of such hearing shall be given in accordance with Article VI. Section 6, titled Notice of Hearings of these Administrative Rules and Procedures; 
3.  A public hearing shall be held at which any party may appear in person, by agent, or by attorney; 
4.  The Board shall make a finding or findings that the requirements of sections 1 and 2 of this Article have been met. 
5.  The Board shall further make finding that: 
a.  Granting the variance is necessary for the reasonable use of the land or building, and that the variance as granted by the Board is the minimum variance that will accomplish the relief sought by the applicant; and 
b.  Granting the variance will be in harmony with the general purpose and intent of this title, and will not be injurious to the neighborhood, or otherwise detrimental to the public welfare. 
B.  No nonconforming use of neighboring lands, structures, or buildings in the same district, and no permitted use of lands, structures, or buildings in other districts shall be considered grounds for the issuance of a variance. 
C.  Under no circumstances shall the Board grant a variance to allow a use not permissible under the terms of this title in the district involved, or any use expressly or by implication prohibited by the terms of this title in said district. 
D.  In granting any variance, the Board may prescribe appropriate conditions and safeguards in conformity with this title. Violations of such conditions and safeguards, when made a part of the terms under which the variance is granted, shall deem a violation of this title. 
ARTICLE XI. - SPECIAL EXCEPTIONS AND USES 

Section 1. - Exceptions and Uses. 
    In accordance with IC § 36-7-4-918.2, a Board shall approve or deny all: 
1.  Special exceptions, as defined; 
2.  Special uses, as defined; 
3.  Contingent uses, as defined; and 
4.  Conditional uses, as defined; 
from the terms of the zoning ordinance, but only in the classes of cases or in the particular situations specified in the zoning ordinance. The Board may impose reasonable conditions as a part or its approval. 
Section 2. - Granting Special Exceptions and Uses. 
A.  In accordance with WMC 17.64.050 subsection (a), the Board shall hear and decide special exceptions to the terms of this title, upon which the Board is required to act under this title, permit and authorize exceptions to the district regulations only in the classes of cases or in particular situations as specified in the title. A special exception shall not be granted by the Board unless and until: 
(1)  A written application for a special exception is submitted indicating the section of the zoning ordinance and title under which the special exception is sought and stating the grounds in which it is requested; 
(2)  Notice of such hearing shall be given in accordance with Article VI. Section 6. Titled Notice of Hearings of these Administrative Rules and Procedures; 
(3)  A public hearing shall be held at which any party may appear in person, by agent or by attorney. 
(4)  The Board shall make a finding that it is empowered under this title to grant the special exception, and that the granting will not adversely affect the public interest. 
B.  In accordance with WMC 17.64.050 subsection (b), In granting any special exception, the Board may prescribe appropriate conditions and safeguards in conformity with the zoning ordinance. Violation of such conditions and safeguards, when made part of the terms under which the special exception is granted, shall be deemed a violation of the zoning ordinance. The Board shall prescribe a time limit within the action for which the special exception is required shall be begun, completed, or both. Failure to begin or complete of both such actions within the time limit set shall void the special exception. 
ARTICLE XII. - EXCEPTION, USE, OR VARIANCE COMMITMENT BY OWNER 

Section 1. - Commitment by Owner. 
A.  In accordance with IC § 36-7-4-921, in case of a petition for a special exception, Special use, contingent use, conditional use, or variance form the terms of the zoning ordinance, the Board may permit or require the owner of a parcel of property to make a written commitment concerning the use or development of that parcel. 
B.  The Board may: 
1.  Adopt rules governing the creation, form, recording, modification, enforcement, and termination of commitments; and 
2.  Adopt rules designating which specially affected persons and classes of specially affected persons are entitled to enforce commitments. 
C.  Commitments shall be recorded in the office of the county recorder and take effect upon the granting of the exception, use, or variance. Unless modified or terminated by the Board, a commitment is binding on the owner of the parcel, each subsequent owner, and each other person acquiring an interest in the parcel. A commitment is binding on the owner of the parcel even if it is unrecorded; however, an unrecorded commitment is binding on subsequent owner or other persons acquiring an interest in the parcel only if that subsequent owner or other person has actual notice of the commitment. A commitment may be modified or terminated only by a decision of the Board made at a public hearing after notice as provided by rule. 
D.  By permitting or requiring commitments, a Board does not obligate itself to approve or deny any request. 
E.  Conditions imposed on the granting of an exception, use, or variance are not subject to the rules applicable to commitments. 
F.  This section does not affect the validity of any covenant, easement, equitable servitude, or other land use restriction created in accordance with law. 
ARTICLE XIII. - ALTERNATE PROCEDURE (RESERVED) 
    This Article is reserved for the establishment of an alternate procedure by the Plan Commission, if the Board deems necessary, under which there can be a more expedient disposition of matters under a hearing officer. IC § 36-7-4-923 documents the law for alternate procedure and IC § 36-7-4-924 documents the alternate procedures rules regarding such proceedings. 
ARTICLE XIV. - FINAL APPROVAL OR DENIAL 

Section 1. - Final Decision. 
    In accordance with IC § 36-7-4-919(e), the Board shall make a decision on any matter that it is required to hear under the 900 SERIES BOARD OF ZONING APPEALS either at the meeting at which the matter is first presented or at the conclusion of the hearing on that matter, if it is continued. 
Section 2. - Writ Decision. 
    In accordance with WMC 17.64.070 subsection (b), every variation granted or denied by the Board shall be accompanied by a written finding of fact, based on testimony and evidence and shall specify the reason for granting or denying the variation. In addition, in accordance with IC § 36-7-4-919(0, within five (5) days after making a decision under the 900 SERIES BOARD OF ZONINGAPPEALS, the Board shall file in the Office of the Board (Clerk/Treasurer's Office) a copy of its decision. 
ARTICLE XV. - REVIEW BY CERTIORARI 

Section 1. - Review Criteria. 
    In accordance with IC § 36-7-4-1003 and WMC 17.64.080, each and every decision of the Board shall be subject to review by certiorari (a writ from a higher court to a lower court requesting a transcript of the proceedings of the case for review). Each person aggrieved by a decision of the Board may present to the circuit court or superior court of the county in which the premises affected are located, a verified petition setting forth that the decision is illegal in whole or in part and specify the grounds of the illegality. No change of venue from the county in which the premises affected are located may be had in any cause arising under this section. 
Section 2. - Petition Period. 
    In accordance with [IC §] 36-7-4-1003 subsection (a), the person shall present the petition to the court within thirty (30) days after the entry of that decision of the Board. 
ARTICLE XVI. - AMENDMENTS 

Section 1. - Creation. 
    Administrative Rules and Procedure amendments may be proposed by members of the Board. 
Section 2. - Notification and Adoption. 
    The Board may amend these Administrative Rules and Procedures by a majority of the quorum of the membership. 
Section 3. - Refinement. 
    Amendments to these Administrative Rules and Procedures are to be typed and distributed to all Board members prior to being voted upon at a Board meeting. The proposed amendment may be refined at the meeting only by deletion and minor refinement. 
Section 4. - Enactment. 
    The Board shall enact all amendments to these Administrative Rules and Procedure as quickly as reasonably possible. 
Section 5. - Administrative Rules and Procedures Review. 
    The Board shall review these Administrative Rules and Procedures prior to January 31 of each new calendar year or at the first meeting of each calendar year. All new sections, major rewording of sections, or similar potentially significant changes to these Administrative Rules and Procedures may only be approved after a complete review of the Board's Administrative Rules and Procedures at that time. After a comprehensive review of these Administrative Rules and Procedures, the Board shall vote upon and adopt any and all changes into the Administrative Rules and Procedures. At that time, the new Administrative Rules and Procedures shall be dated and filed in the Whiting Clerk/Treasurer's Office and made part of the public record.
